An act providing for the organization of new counties and the location of county seats therein temporarily treats of but one general subject. Board of Comm'rs v. Woods, 18 Wyo. 316, 106 P. 923, 1910 Wyo. LEXIS 7 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 18 Wyo. 316, 107 P. 753, 1910 Wyo. LEXIS 8 (Wyo. 1910).

Act held to embrace 2 objects. —

Aside from the fact that ch. 194, Laws 1963, as passed, contains provisions beyond the subject expressed in its title, it also appears that both the title and the body of the act itself embrace two distinct objects, in contravention of this section, namely: (1) that of providing for a liquor purchase identification card; and (2) that of amending W.S. 1957, § 12-5. Smith v. Hansen, 386 P.2d 98, 1963 Wyo. LEXIS 115 (Wyo. 1963).

Sufficiency of title. —

“An act to define the judicial districts of the state and prescribing the time for holding the terms of the district court in the several counties of each judicial district” sufficiently expressed the subject matter of the act. In re Board of Comm'rs, 4 Wyo. 133, 32 P. 850 (Wyo. 1893).

An act designated as an act to amend and reenact a specified section of a code “in such manner as to repeal all limitations arising under contract not in writing, either expressed or implied, shall be brought within 8 years after the cause of action accrues” was not invalid under this section. Board of Comm'rs v. Stone, 7 Wyo. 280, 51 P. 605, 1898 Wyo. LEXIS 3 (Wyo. 1898).

Subject of amendatory statute relating to dipping of sheep was embraced within title. State v. Hall, 27 Wyo. 224, 194 P. 476, 1920 Wyo. LEXIS 34 (Wyo. 1920).

Where title recited that certain sections were to be amended and others repealed relating to gambling games, the provisions of this section were not violated. State v. Tobin, 31 Wyo. 355, 226 P. 681, 1924 Wyo. LEXIS 32 (Wyo. 1924).

Statutory provision for abatement of liquor nuisance and for injunction was not invalid as containing subject not expressed in the title to the act. Tucker v. State, 35 Wyo. 430, 251 P. 460, 1926 Wyo. LEXIS 27 (Wyo. 1926).

Act amending statutory provisions requiring publication of legal notices in newspaper established for a year is not void because of defective or restrictive title, including amended section. In re Gillette Daily Journal, 44 Wyo. 226, 11 P.2d 265, 1932 Wyo. LEXIS 20 (Wyo. 1932).

Provision for preference contained in “An act to expedite and simplify the collection and payment by banks of checks and other instruments for the payment of money” was sufficiently embraced in title, as giving such preference is at least one of the means to further and accomplish the main purpose or one of the main purposes of the act. In re Riverton State Bank, 48 Wyo. 372, 49 P.2d 637, 1935 Wyo. LEXIS 44 (Wyo. 1935).

No one who read the title to ch. 93, Laws 1955, and was thus aware of the passage of the law could reasonably claim to have been misled since the statement by fair implication advised all citizens that inclusive rules and regulations for fire protection would be adopted. Brinegar v. Clark, 371 P.2d 62, 1962 Wyo. LEXIS 82 (Wyo. 1962).

The fact that the title of ch. 204, Laws 1957, did not mention the right of a representative of a deceased spouse to elect to take against a will would not invalidate it under this section since the subject matter of the amended section is germane to the election rights of surviving spouses contained in the original section. Morrow v. Diefenderfer, 384 P.2d 601, 1963 Wyo. LEXIS 103 (Wyo. 1963).

The title to ch. 91, Laws 1965, “An act concerning the refunding of public securities” embraces the subject of the advance escrow-type refunding provisions of said act in all particulars and expresses said subject with sufficient clarity so as to comply with this section. Rodin v. State, 417 P.2d 180, 1966 Wyo. LEXIS 155 (Wyo. 1966).

The one general subject involved in ch. 66, Laws 1963, is the abatement of public nuisances, and the title to the act so states. Weiss v. State, 455 P.2d 904, 1969 Wyo. LEXIS 145 (Wyo. 1969), cert. denied, 398 U.S. 927, 90 S. Ct. 1815, 26 L. Ed. 2d 89, 1970 U.S. LEXIS 1748 (U.S. 1970).

Where the purpose of the initiative was to discourage abortions, which was reflected in the short title of the bill, the “Wyoming Human Life Protection Act” and where the language of the initiative, criminalizing abortion in most instances and withholding state funding for abortions under certain circumstances, fit within the single-subject rule, the title of the initiative adequately expressed the substantive provisions included within the body of the initiative. Wyoming Nat'l Abortion Rights Action League v. Karpan, 881 P.2d 281, 1994 Wyo. LEXIS 100 (Wyo. 1994).

Section 7-13-301 (placing guilty, unconvicted, person on probation) was constitutionally enacted in compliance with Wyo. Const., art. 3, §§ 20 and 24. Billis v. State, 800 P.2d 401, 1990 Wyo. LEXIS 119 (Wyo. 1990), reh'g denied, 1990 Wyo. LEXIS 133 (Wyo. Nov. 9, 1990); Mollman v. State, 800 P.2d 466, 1990 Wyo. LEXIS 113 (Wyo. 1990); Hudson v. State, 800 P.2d 471, 1990 Wyo. LEXIS 172 (Wyo. 1990); Heggen v. State, 800 P.2d 475, 1990 Wyo. LEXIS 111 (Wyo. 1990); Cambio v. State, 800 P.2d 482, 1990 Wyo. LEXIS 114 (Wyo. 1990).

Section 14-2-203 is constitutional. Mahaney v. Hunter Enters., 426 P.2d 442, 1967 Wyo. LEXIS 152 (Wyo. 1967).

Industrial Development Projects Act is constitutional. Uhls v. State, 429 P.2d 74, 1967 Wyo. LEXIS 161 (Wyo. 1967); Powers v. Cheyenne, 435 P.2d 448, 1967 Wyo. LEXIS 191 (Wyo. 1967), reh'g denied, 436 P.2d 961, 1968 Wyo. LEXIS 155 (Wyo. 1968).

Sections 27-10-101 to 27-10-109, pertaining to collective bargaining for fire fighters, do not violate this section. State ex rel. Fire Fighters Local 946 v. Laramie, 437 P.2d 295, 1968 Wyo. LEXIS 157 (Wyo. 1968).

§ 25. Vote required to pass bill.

No bill shall become a law except by a vote of a majority of all the members elected to each house, nor unless on its final passage the vote taken by ayes and noes, and the names of those voting be entered on the journal.

Cross references. —

As to approval or veto of legislation by governor and as to passage over veto, see art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const.

Court may examine journals to determine whether act was constitutionally passed. —

It is duty of the court, where an act is questioned, to examine the legislative journals to determine whether or not such act was passed by a majority of the members elected to each house, that being a matter which the constitution requires to be shown by the journals. State ex rel. Cheyenne v. Swan, 7 Wyo. 166, 51 P. 209, 1897 Wyo. LEXIS 22 (Wyo. 1897).

The enrolled bill as signed by the officers of the legislature and the governor is not conclusive on the courts, and the legislative journals may be consulted to determine whether the act has been passed in conformity with the constitutional requirements. State ex rel. Bd. of Comm'rs v. Wright, 62 Wyo. 112, 163 P.2d 190, 1945 Wyo. LEXIS 31 (Wyo. 1945).

Effect of erroneous journal entry. —

Though a journal entry on passage of an act is insufficient, the court is not limited by recital of a single journal entry when upon construing all entries together it is manifest such single entry is erroneous. Arbuckle v. Pflaeging, 20 Wyo. 351, 123 P. 918, 1912 Wyo. LEXIS 40 (Wyo. 1912).

Law reviews. —

For article, “How to Draft a Bill,” see 6 Wyo. L.J. 285.

§ 26. How laws revised, amended or extended.

No law shall be revised or amended, or the provisions thereof extended by reference to its title only, but so much thereof as is revised, amended, or extended, shall be re-enacted and published at length.

Cross references. —

For provision that tax must be authorized by law and law must state object to which it shall be applied, see art. 15, § 13, Wyo. Const.

Purpose of section. —

The purpose of this section was to prevent ill-advised and fraudulent legislation. State v. Pitet, 69 Wyo. 478, 243 P.2d 177, 1952 Wyo. LEXIS 14 (Wyo. 1952); Frank v. Cody, 572 P.2d 1106, 1977 Wyo. LEXIS 304 (Wyo. 1977).

The constitutional restriction in this section was aimed at the mischief of embracing in the same bill before a legislative body incongruous matters having no relation to each other or to the subject specified in the title, by which laws were often adopted without attracting attention. State v. Pitet, 69 Wyo. 478, 243 P.2d 177, 1952 Wyo. LEXIS 14 (Wyo. 1952); Frank v. Cody, 572 P.2d 1106, 1977 Wyo. LEXIS 304 (Wyo. 1977).

Section requires reasonable interpretation. —

This section must be given an interpretation that is reasonable having in mind always the evils that are to be suppressed and with a view of sustaining the legislative action. State v. Pitet, 69 Wyo. 478, 243 P.2d 177, 1952 Wyo. LEXIS 14 (Wyo. 1952).

This section does not prohibit additions to or extensions of existing statutes. English v. Smith, 71 Wyo. 1, 253 P.2d 857, 1953 Wyo. LEXIS 1 (Wyo. 1953).

Reference statutes. —

This section does not apply to statutes which refer to existing laws merely for the purpose of pointing out procedure in executing powers which the statute itself, original in form by its own language, grants, and enforcing rights or discharging duties created or imposed by such statutes. Board of County Comm'rs v. White, 79 Wyo. 420, 335 P.2d 433, 1959 Wyo. LEXIS 14 (Wyo. 1959); Frank v. Cody, 572 P.2d 1106, 1977 Wyo. LEXIS 304 (Wyo. 1977).

Reference to existing laws for the determination of positive and substantial rights thereby conferred or taken away is prohibited. Board of County Comm'rs v. White, 79 Wyo. 420, 335 P.2d 433, 1959 Wyo. LEXIS 14 (Wyo. 1959).

Use of the reference technique in the last sentence of former § 9-1-134(a)(iii) which provided, “These securities shall meet the procedural requirements and provisions of W. S. 35-136.2 through 35-136.5 [§§ 35-2-425 through 35-2-428] as provided for the issuance of bonds by hospital districts,” is not constitutionally objectionable but makes good sense. Frank v. Cody, 572 P.2d 1106, 1977 Wyo. LEXIS 304 (Wyo. 1977). See § 16-1-107(a)(iii).

Applied in

Long v. State, 745 P.2d 547, 1987 Wyo. LEXIS 542 (Wyo. 1987).

Quoted in

In re Trent, 68 Wyo. 146, 231 P.2d 180, 1951 Wyo. LEXIS 21 (1951).

Cited in

Littleton v. Burgess, 13 Wyo. 261, 79 P. 922, 1905 Wyo. LEXIS 7 (1905); Alberts v. State, 745 P.2d 898, 1987 Wyo. LEXIS 539 (Wyo. 1987).

§ 27. Special and local laws prohibited.

The legislature shall not pass local or special laws in any of the following enumerated cases, that is to say: For granting divorces; laying out, opening, altering or working roads or highways; vacating roads, town plats, streets, alleys or public grounds; locating or changing county seats; regulating county or township affairs; incorporation of cities, towns or villages; or changing or amending the charters of any cities, towns or villages; regulating the practice in courts of justice; regulating the jurisdiction and duties of justices of the peace, police magistrates or constables; changing the rules of evidence in any trial or inquiry; providing for changes of venue in civil or criminal cases; declaring any person of age; for limitation of civil actions; giving effect to any informal or invalid deeds; summoning or impaneling grand or petit juries; providing for the management of common schools; regulating the rate of interest on money; the opening or conducting of any election or designating the place of voting; the sale or mortgage of real estate belonging to minors or others under disability; chartering or licensing ferries or bridges or toll roads; chartering banks, insurance companies and loan and trust companies; remitting fines, penalties or forfeitures; creating[,] increasing, or decreasing fees, percentages or allowances of public officers; changing the law of descent; granting to any corporation, association or individual, the right to lay down railroad tracks, or any special or exclusive privilege, immunity or franchise whatever, or amending existing charter for such purpose; for punishment of crimes; changing the names of persons or places; for the assessment or collection of taxes; affecting estates of deceased persons, minors or others under legal disabilities; extending the time for the collection of taxes; refunding money paid into the state treasury, relinquishing or extinguishing, in whole or part, the indebtedness, liabilities or obligation of any corporation or person to this state or to any municipal corporation therein; exempting property from taxation; restoring to citizenship persons convicted of infamous crimes; authorizing the creation, extension or impairing of liens; creating offices or prescribing the powers or duties of officers in counties, cities, townships or school districts; or authorizing the adoption or legitimation of children. In all other cases where a general law can be made applicable no special law shall be enacted.

  • I. General Consideration.
  • II. Illustrative Cases.
I.General Consideration.

Cross references. —

As to special and local legislation, see art. 1, § 34, Wyo. Const. and art. 13, § 1, Wyo. Const.

Statute must operate alike upon all persons in same circumstances. Meyer v. Kendig, 641 P.2d 1235, 1982 Wyo. LEXIS 310 (Wyo. 1982).

This section does not prevent reasonable classification of objects of legislation. State ex rel. Wyckoff v. Ross, 31 Wyo. 500, 228 P. 636, 1924 Wyo. LEXIS 39 (Wyo. 1924).

This section does not prohibit a classification of persons and things for the purpose of legislation which is reasonable in view of the object sought to be accomplished. Ludwig v. Harston, 65 Wyo. 134, 197 P.2d 252, 1948 Wyo. LEXIS 21 (Wyo. 1948).

But classification cannot be made without reason therefor and there must be substantial distinction between places embraced in legislation and places excluded. May v. Laramie, 58 Wyo. 240, 131 P.2d 300, 1942 Wyo. LEXIS 21 (Wyo. 1942).

Classifications in statutes must be reasonable. —

The prohibition against special legislation does not mean that a statute must affect everyone in the same way; it only means that the classification contained in the statute must be reasonable, and that the statute must operate alike upon all persons or property in like or the same circumstances and conditions. Mountain Fuel Supply Co. v. Emerson, 578 P.2d 1351, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 292 (Wyo. 1978).

It is not what a law includes that makes it special, but what it excludes. May v. Laramie, 58 Wyo. 240, 131 P.2d 300, 1942 Wyo. LEXIS 21 (Wyo. 1942).

Legislation is special if it applies to all within a class without reason appearing why it is not made to apply generally to all. May v. Laramie, 58 Wyo. 240, 131 P.2d 300, 1942 Wyo. LEXIS 21 (Wyo. 1942).

Distinguishing peculiarity must exist giving rise to necessity for classification. —

To constitute general law, as opposed to special law, distinguishing peculiarity must exist giving rise to necessity for the law as to designated class. May v. Laramie, 58 Wyo. 240, 131 P.2d 300, 1942 Wyo. LEXIS 21 (Wyo. 1942).

Effect of legislative determination of necessity. —

The courts will not interfere with the legislative determination that a special law was necessary, at least until it is clear that a general law could have been adopted. State ex rel. McPherren v. Carter, 30 Wyo. 22, 215 P. 477, 1923 Wyo. LEXIS 28 (Wyo. 1923).

Burden on assailant to show classification is arbitrary. —

One who assails the classification in a law must carry the burden of showing that it does not rest upon any reasonable basis, but is essentially arbitrary. Bell v. Gray, 377 P.2d 924, 1963 Wyo. LEXIS 69 (Wyo. 1963); Mountain Fuel Supply Co. v. Emerson, 578 P.2d 1351, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 292 (Wyo. 1978).

And mere assertion of discrimination is insufficient. —

A person contesting the constitutionality of a statute must do more than make bold assertions of what he thinks is discriminatory. Bell v. Gray, 377 P.2d 924, 1963 Wyo. LEXIS 69 (Wyo. 1963).

Applied in

State ex rel. Fawcett v. Board of County Comm'rs, 73 Wyo. 69, 273 P.2d 188, 1954 Wyo. LEXIS 13 (1954); Tennant v. Sinclair Oil & Gas Co., 355 P.2d 887, 1960 Wyo. LEXIS 73 (Wyo. 1960); Hoem v. State, 756 P.2d 780, 1988 Wyo. LEXIS 88 (Wyo. 1988).

Quoted in

Walgreen Co. v. State Bd. of Equalization, 70 Wyo. 193, 246 P.2d 767, 1952 Wyo. LEXIS 23 (1952); Miller v. Board of County Comm'rs, 79 Wyo. 502, 337 P.2d 262, 1959 Wyo. LEXIS 18 (1959); Simons v. Laramie County Sch. Dist., 741 P.2d 1116, 1987 Wyo. LEXIS 496 (Wyo. 1987); White v. State, 784 P.2d 1313, 1989 Wyo. LEXIS 246 (Wyo. 1989); Campbell County Sch. Dist. v. State, 907 P.2d 1238, 1995 Wyo. LEXIS 203 (Wyo. 1995).

Stated in

Day v. Armstrong, 362 P.2d 137, 1961 Wyo. LEXIS 97 (Wyo. 1961).

Cited in

State ex rel. Wyoming Agric. College v. Irvine, 14 Wyo. 318, 84 P. 90, 1906 Wyo. LEXIS 18 (1906); Stutsman v. City of Cheyenne, 18 Wyo. 499, 113 P. 322, 1911 Wyo. LEXIS 32 (1911); Dillman v. State ex rel. Merrill, 20 Wyo. 404, 125 P. 367, 1912 Wyo. LEXIS 46 (1912); Town of Green River v. Bunger, 50 Wyo. 52, 58 P.2d 456, 1936 Wyo. LEXIS 14 (1936); In re West Hwy. San. & Imp. Dist., 77 Wyo. 384, 317 P.2d 495, 1957 Wyo. LEXIS 29 (1957); State ex rel. Fire Fighters Local v. Kingham, 420 P.2d 254, 1966 Wyo. LEXIS 179 (Wyo. 1966); Board of County Comm'rs v. Justice Court No. Two, 529 P.2d 977, 1974 Wyo. LEXIS 253 (Wyo. 1974); Cranston v. Thomson, 530 P.2d 726, 1975 Wyo. LEXIS 124 (Wyo. 1975); Neu v. Grant, 548 F.2d 281, 1977 U.S. App. LEXIS 10584 (10th Cir. 1977); In Interest of DG, 825 P.2d 369, 1992 Wyo. LEXIS 11 (Wyo. 1992); Greenwalt v. Ram Rest. Corp., 2003 WY 77, 71 P.3d 717, 2003 Wyo. LEXIS 96 (Wyo. 2003).

Law reviews. —

For note, “Constitutionality of Special Bills for Private Relief,” see 6 Wyo. L.J. 261.

For article, “Governmental Immunity from Damage Actions in Wyoming — Part II,” see VII Land & Water L. Rev. 617 (1972).

For case note, “Worker's Compensation — Constitutionality of Wyoming's Co-employee Immunity Statute under Article 10, Section 4, of the Wyoming Constitution.Meyer v. Kendig, 641 P.2d 1235, 1982 Wyo. LEXIS 310 (Wyo. 1982),” see XVIII Land & Water L. Rev. 355 (1983).

For article, “An Essay on Wyoming Constitutional Interpretation,” see XXI Land & Water L. Rev. 527 (1986).

For case note, “Worker's Compensation — The Dilemma of Co-Employee Immunity and the Confusion in the Aftermath of Mills II. Mills v. Reynolds, 837 P.2d 48, 1992 Wyo. LEXIS 92 (Wyo. 1992),” see XXVIII Land & Water L. Rev. 271 (1993).

II.Illustrative Cases.

Relinquishing indebtedness. —

Exemption from future taxes is not special law relinquishing indebtedness. Harkin v. Board of Comm'rs, 30 Wyo. 455, 222 P. 35, 1924 Wyo. LEXIS 71 (Wyo. 1924).

An act exempting from taxation property of war veterans in the future does not relinquish any indebtedness, liability or obligation in violation of this section. State ex rel. Bd. of Comm'rs v. Snyder, 29 Wyo. 199, 212 P. 771, 1923 Wyo. LEXIS 9 (Wyo. 1923).

Chapter 70, Laws 1937, did not violate this section prohibiting passage of “local laws” or “special laws” relinquishing or extinguishing indebtedness to this state or to any municipal corporation. Carter v. Thompson Realty Co., 58 Wyo. 279, 131 P.2d 297, 1942 Wyo. LEXIS 20 (Wyo. 1942).

Statute providing that only taxpayers may vote at bond elections is unconstitutional. Simpkin v. Rock Springs, 33 Wyo. 166, 237 P. 245, 1925 Wyo. LEXIS 32 (Wyo. 1925).

Voting for judge in consolidated judicial district. —

Statute abolishing two judicial districts and attaching the counties to other districts, permitting the electors of those counties, before the law becomes effective, to vote for judge in the intended consolidated district, contains no provisions in violation of this constitutional provision. Brown v. Clark, 47 Wyo. 216, 34 P.2d 17, 1934 Wyo. LEXIS 21 (Wyo. 1934).

Act forming Teton county. —

See Budge v. Board of Comm'rs, 29 Wyo. 35, 208 P. 874, 1922 Wyo. LEXIS 6 (Wyo. 1922).

Legalizing defective organization of county. —

Curative statute legalizing defective organization of county was not invalid as special act organizing county or regulating its affairs or interfering with uniform operation of general laws. State ex rel. Budge v. Snyder, 30 Wyo. 287, 219 P. 735, 1923 Wyo. LEXIS 45 (Wyo. 1923).

Funding for county courts. —

Statute that allows legislature to deny full funding for county courts in counties having a population of less than 30,000 did not, on its face, violate the state constitution as special legislation. Board of County Comm'rs v. Geringer, 941 P.2d 742, 1997 Wyo. LEXIS 95 (Wyo. 1997).

Establishing irrigation districts. —

In view of constitutional provision, irrigation districts must be established by general rather than special laws. Sullivan v. Blakesley, 35 Wyo. 73, 246 P. 918, 1926 Wyo. LEXIS 9 (Wyo. 1926).

Necessity for classification of cities. —

Mere classification of cities for purpose of legislation without regard to necessity is special legislation and condemned by constitution. May v. Laramie, 58 Wyo. 240, 131 P.2d 300, 1942 Wyo. LEXIS 21 (Wyo. 1942).

Law operating uniformly on cities is constitutional. —

A law operating uniformly on all cities of one class or all of several recognized classes was not unconstitutional. State ex rel. Diers v. Sheldon, 29 Wyo. 233, 213 P. 92, 1923 Wyo. LEXIS 11 (Wyo. 1923).

Statute applicable to only 1 city. —

Mere fact that statute applies for time being only to one city does not necessarily render it unconstitutional as special legislation, although this fact may be considered in determining its constitutionality. May v. Laramie, 58 Wyo. 240, 131 P.2d 300, 1942 Wyo. LEXIS 21 (Wyo. 1942).

Court may consider purpose of enactment creating second class cities. —

Purpose for which enactment creating cities of second class was passed may be considered in determining whether it is special or general legislation. May v. Laramie, 58 Wyo. 240, 131 P.2d 300, 1942 Wyo. LEXIS 21 (Wyo. 1942).

And contemporaneous legislation applicable to cities of another class. —

In considering constitutionality of statute creating second class city and in determining what is reasonable or arbitrary classification, court may consider nearly contemporaneous enactment relating to cities of first class. May v. Laramie, 58 Wyo. 240, 131 P.2d 300, 1942 Wyo. LEXIS 21 (Wyo. 1942).

Section applies to cities acting under special charter. May v. Laramie, 58 Wyo. 240, 131 P.2d 300, 1942 Wyo. LEXIS 21 (Wyo. 1942).

Grant to municipal corporation regarding public utility board. —

Legislature may constitutionally grant to municipal corporation right to elect or appoint board of public utilities. Stewart v. Cheyenne, 60 Wyo. 497, 154 P.2d 355, 1944 Wyo. LEXIS 20 (Wyo. 1944).

Special improvements and assessments. —

An act authorizing special chartered cities having less than 10,000 inhabitants, to make special improvements and assessments in a specified manner, is not in violation hereof. McGarvey v. Swan, 17 Wyo. 120, 96 P. 697, 1908 Wyo. LEXIS 11 (Wyo. 1908).

Statute authorizing removal of officers for refusal to perform duties under liquor statute is not special legislation. State ex rel. Wyckoff v. Ross, 31 Wyo. 500, 228 P. 636, 1924 Wyo. LEXIS 39 (Wyo. 1924).

Private School Licensing Act. —

No classification had been created by the Private School Licensing Act, Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 21-2-401 through 21-2-407, and it was unnecessary to do any further analysis under the test where those institutions that were already accredited obviously did not have to apply to become accredited, and those institutions that were not accredited had to become accredited within the time frame provided; therefore, no equal protection violation occurred because different classifications were not created under the act or the rules adopted by the Wyoming Department of Education. Newport Int'l Univ., Inc. v. State, 2008 WY 72, 186 P.3d 382, 2008 Wyo. LEXIS 74 (Wyo. 2008).

School funding. —

A $250,000 cap imposed on transitional hold harmless payments applicable to wealthy school districts subject to revenue recapture bore a rational relationship to a legitimate state interest in making the transition to a cost-based school funding system and thus did not violate the equal protection provisions of the Wyoming Constitution. Lincoln County Sch. Dist. No. One v. State, 985 P.2d 964, 1999 Wyo. LEXIS 125 (Wyo. 1999).

Schools' accreditation process. —

Wyoming had authority to impose reasonable regulations in state educational institutions, and requirement of accreditation of private degree-granting educational institutions was a reasonable restriction, adopted to ensure that quality education was being provided by a private entity licensed in Wyoming; to the extent the accreditation process required a contract between the university and the accrediting entity, need of the state to protect citizens outweighed contract rights of the university. Newport Int'l Univ., Inc. v. State, 2008 WY 72, 186 P.3d 382, 2008 Wyo. LEXIS 74 (Wyo. 2008).

Fixing qualification of newspapers entitled to publish legal notices. —

Statute requiring publication of legal notices in newspapers which had been in existence for one year was not unconstitutional as a special law granting special or exclusive privileges. In re Gillette Daily Journal, 44 Wyo. 226, 11 P.2d 265, 1932 Wyo. LEXIS 20 (Wyo. 1932).

Act limiting hours of labor for females in hotels and restaurants, except those operated by railroads, is unconstitutional. State v. Le Barron, 24 Wyo. 519, 162 P. 265, 1917 Wyo. LEXIS 1 (Wyo. 1917).

Rational basis exists for treating the employer differently from his employees with respect to the extent of immunity under § 27-14-104(a), relating to immunity from suit under the Workers' Compensation Act. Mauch v. Stanley Structures, 641 P.2d 1247, 1982 Wyo. LEXIS 309 (Wyo. 1982).

Negligence immunity of co-employees unconstitutional. —

The statute which, under the Wyoming worker's compensation scheme, granted immunity from suits by co-employees to employees who were acting within the scope of their employment, § 27-14-104, is unconstitutional because it violates the Wyoming Constitution's guarantee of equal protection. Mills v. Reynolds, 837 P.2d 48, 1992 Wyo. LEXIS 92 (Wyo. 1992).

Unemployment Compensation Act embraces group of objects or class of subjects and is accordingly not a special but a general law, unless exemption of certain employers makes classification unreasonable. Unemployment Compensation Comm'n v. Renner, 59 Wyo. 437, 143 P.2d 181, 1943 Wyo. LEXIS 25 (Wyo. 1943).

Liquor licenses. —

Chapter 7, Laws 1909, prohibiting the granting or extending of any liquor license outside of incorporated cities or towns, though impliedly authorizing those holding unexpired licenses to continue in the business until their licenses expire, does not create a privileged class because one whose license expires before the licenses of others may not obtain a license, and it is not in conflict with this section, prohibiting the granting by special laws of any exclusive privilege. State ex rel. Jones v. Board of Comm'rs, 18 Wyo. 153, 105 P. 295, 1909 Wyo. LEXIS 28 (Wyo. 1909).

Suspension of license unconstitutional. —

Section 31-7-126 (former) and § 31-7-128(f), which provide for the drivers license suspension of individuals under 19 years of age convicted of possession or consumption of alcohol, represent constitutionally prohibited special legislation that lacks rational differentiation from persons aged 19 and 20 who are also denied the right to use alcoholic beverages, constituting a similar class and, for that matter those of any age whose excessive use makes their use illegal. Johnson v. State Hearing Examiner's Office, 838 P.2d 158, 1992 Wyo. LEXIS 117 (Wyo. 1992).

Section 1-3-111 violates section. —

Section 1-3-111, which, prior to its 1981 amendment provided, that no action shall be brought more than 10 years after substantial completion of improvement to real property against any person performing or furnishing design, planning, supervision, construction or supervision of construction of the improvement, violated this section and art. 1, §§ 8 and 34, Wyo. Const.Phillips v. ABC Builders, 611 P.2d 821, 1980 Wyo. LEXIS 273 (Wyo. 1980).

Constitutionality of § 14-6-203. —

The statutory scheme of § 14-6-203 is constitutional; there is no demonstrable prejudice arising out of the failure to assign the burden of proof prior to any hearing; and there was no abuse of discretion on the part of the trial judge in refusing to transfer case to juvenile court or on the part of the trial judge in transferring another case to the county court from juvenile court for a preliminary examination with the view that the case would be prosecuted in the district court. Hansen v. State, 904 P.2d 811, 1995 Wyo. LEXIS 194 (Wyo. 1995).

Statute of limitations constitutional. —

Section 1-3-111, which sets forth a statute of limitations for actions involving improvements to real property, is constitutional and does not violate the open courts, uniform operation of general law, and special and local laws provisions of the Wyoming constitution. Worden v. Village Homes, 821 P.2d 1291, 1991 Wyo. LEXIS 183 (Wyo. 1991).

Mental Health Professions Practice Act violates equal protection. —

Under the Mental Health Professions Practice Act, private counselors rights to equal protection have been transgressed; none of the evidence demonstrates that supervision by public, licensed counselors results in the qualification of counselors who are more competent or more ethical and, thus, more likely to protect the health, safety, and welfare of the public. The differentiation of the public employer or the charitable employer from the private, for-profit employer cannot be justified as a proper classification and, thus, is not a legitimate exercise in police power. This classification is not founded on a reasonable basis, is arbitrary, and constitutes unwarranted discrimination. It is a violation of equal protection and must be set aside. Allhusen v. State, 898 P.2d 878, 1995 Wyo. LEXIS 106 (Wyo. 1995), (decided prior to 2001 amendments to the Mental Health Professions Practice Act).

The mandatory licensure provisions under § 33-38-110, the prerequisites to licensure found in § 33-38-106, and the licensure exemptions set forth in § 33-38-103 violate guarantees of equal protection under art. 1, §§ 2 and 34, Wyo. Const. and art. 3, § 27, Wyo. Const.; these provisions must be stricken as contrary to guarantees of equal protection, the guarantee of uniform operation of laws, and as special legislation. The unconstitutional provisions are of no effect, and the law in the form it existed prior to the 1993 amendments is controlling. Allhusen v. State, 898 P.2d 878, 1995 Wyo. LEXIS 106 (Wyo. 1995), (decided prior to 2001 amendments to the Mental Health Professions Practice Act).

For discussion of Wyoming Sex Offenders Registration Act as constitutional, see Snyder v. State, 912 P.2d 1127, 1996 Wyo. LEXIS 37 (Wyo. 1996).

Cited in

Huff v. Shumate, 2004 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 27781, 360 F. Supp. 2d 1197 (2004).

§ 28. Signing of bills.

The presiding officer of each house shall, in the presence of the house over which he presides, sign all bills and joint resolutions passed by the legislature immediately after their titles have been publicly read, and the fact of signing shall be at once entered upon the journal.

Substantial compliance is sufficient. —

House journal entry of signing by the speaker is sufficient if it substantially complies with the constitutional requirement. Younger v. Hehn, 12 Wyo. 289, 75 P. 443, 1904 Wyo. LEXIS 3 (Wyo. 1904).

Enrolled act may be looked to in determining sufficiency of journal entry. —

In determining whether an entry in a legislative journal is a sufficient compliance with this section, the enrolled act exhibiting the proper signature is to be looked to, and the favorable presumption arising therefrom is not to be overthrown unless it clearly appears that it is insufficient. State ex rel. Hynds v. Cahill, 12 Wyo. 225, 75 P. 433, 1904 Wyo. LEXIS 2 (Wyo. 1904); State ex rel. Smith v. Gillespie, 12 Wyo. 284, 75 P. 1135, 1904 Wyo. LEXIS 9 (Wyo. 1904).

Failure of journal entry to show that complete title of bill was read. —

Although the entry did not show that the complete title of the bill was read, yet it would be presumed that the speaker had not done his official duty and had not affixed his signature in the absence of such reading, and so the entry was sufficient to show a compliance with the constitutional requirement. Arbuckle v. Pflaeging, 20 Wyo. 351, 123 P. 918, 1912 Wyo. LEXIS 40 (Wyo. 1912).

Effect of error in designating bill. —

There may be a compliance with this section, notwithstanding an error in the senate journal in designating a bill. George Bolln Co. v. North Platte Valley Irrigation Co., 19 Wyo. 542, 121 P. 22, 1912 Wyo. LEXIS 9 (Wyo. 1912).

Statute not violative of section. —

Chapter 73, Laws 1897, as amended by ch. 85, Laws 1931, concerning newspapers eligible to publish legal notices, did not violate this section. In re Gillette Daily Journal, 44 Wyo. 226, 11 P.2d 265, 1932 Wyo. LEXIS 20 (Wyo. 1932).

Quoted in

Geringer v. Bebout, 10 P.3d 514, 2000 Wyo. LEXIS 181 (Wyo. 2000).

Cited in

Hansen v. Smith, 395 P.2d 944, 1964 Wyo. LEXIS 124 (Wyo. 1964).

§ 29. Legislative employees.

The legislature shall prescribe by law the number, duties and compensation of the officers and employes [employees] of each house, and no payment shall be made from the state treasury, or be in any way authorized to any such person except to an acting officer or employe [employee] elected or appointed in pursuance of law.

Cross references. —

For authority of legislature to hire additional employees when necessary, see § 28-1-103.

As to senate employees generally, see § 28-3-103.

As to employees of house of representatives generally, see § 28-4-103.

§ 30. Extra compensation to public officers prohibited.

No bill shall be passed giving any extra compensation to any public officer, servant or employe, agent or contractor, after services are rendered or contract made.

Cross references. —

As to salaries of public employees generally, see art. 14, §§ 1 to 6, Wyo. Const. For additional provisions concerning extra compensation, see §§ 9-3-102 through 9-3-104.

§ 31. Supplies for legislature and departments.

All stationery, printing, paper, fuel and lights used in the legislature and other departments of government shall be furnished, and the printing and binding of the laws, journals and department reports and other printing and binding, and the repairing and furnishing the halls and rooms used for the meeting of the legislature and its committees shall be performed under contract, to be given to the lowest responsible bidder, below such maximum price and under such regulations as may be prescribed by law. No member or officer of any department of the government shall be in any way interested in any such contract; and all such contracts shall be subject to the approval of the governor and state treasurer.

Violation of this section. — Wyo. Const. art. 2, § 1 prohibits any person or collection of persons charged with exercising the powers belonging to one of the three branches of government from exercising powers properly belonging to another branch, except as the Constitution expressly directs or permits. Wyo. Const. art. 3, § 31 expressly requires the state treasurer's approval of contracts for repairing and furnishing areas used by the legislature. Wyoming's capitol restoration legislation assigns all aspects of the project to the governor and other officials and groups created by the legislature. It, therefore, usurps the treasurer's authority under Wyo. Const. art. 3, § 31 and violates the separation of powers provision of the Wyoming Constitution. Gordon v. State, 2018 WY 32, 413 P.3d 1093, 2018 Wyo. LEXIS 34 (Wyo. 2018).

§ 32. Changing terms and salaries of public officers.

Except as otherwise provided in this constitution, no law shall extend the term of any public officer or increase or diminish his salary or emolument after his election or appointment; but this shall not be construed to forbid the legislature from fixing salaries or emoluments of those officers first elected or appointed under this constitution, if such salaries or emoluments are not fixed by its provisions.

Cross references. —

As to salaries of public officers generally, see art. 14, §§ 1 to 6, Wyo. Const.

As to salaries of county officers, see §§ 18-3-107 et seq.

Intent of section. —

This section was intended to secure official independence, and to prevent the legislature from being assailed by the demands of importunate officials, to the detriment of public business. State ex rel. Henderson v. Burdick, 4 Wyo. 272, 33 P. 125, 1893 Wyo. LEXIS 11 (Wyo. 1893).

Prohibition applies to officer, not to office. —

The prohibition of this section refers to any public officer, his salary and his election or appointment. The prohibition does not apply to an office. Ballangee v. Board of County Comm'rs, 66 Wyo. 390, 212 P.2d 71, 1949 Wyo. LEXIS 18 (Wyo. 1949).

Section inapplicable to county judge. —

It is only public officers in elective public office and public officers appointed to fill vacancies in elective public offices that are prohibited by this section from receiving an increase or decrease in salary during their terms. Since a county judge is not an elected public official, nor is he appointed to an elective public office, he is not prevented from receiving the salary increase granted by the enactment of § 5-5-119 (now § 5-9-116).County Court Judges Ass'n v. Sidi, 752 P.2d 960, 1988 Wyo. LEXIS 193 (Wyo. 1988).

Mid-term salary increases. —

Cost of living adjustment raises granted by board of county commissioners violated prohibition in Wyoming Constitution against mid-term salary increases for elected officials. Board of County Comm'rs v. State ex rel. Yeadon, 971 P.2d 129, 1998 Wyo. LEXIS 187 (Wyo. 1998).

Officer appointed to fill a vacancy was entitled to an increased salary, provided by the legislature, before his appointment but after the election of his predecessor. Ballangee v. Board of County Comm'rs, 66 Wyo. 390, 212 P.2d 71, 1949 Wyo. LEXIS 18 (Wyo. 1949).

Privilege of appointing deputies is not an emolument within the meaning of the constitutional inhibition of this section. Reals v. Smith, 8 Wyo. 159, 56 P. 690, 1899 Wyo. LEXIS 6 (Wyo. 1899).

Compensation for use of automobile while traveling on official business. —

Statutory compensation to be paid an officer for the use of his automobile while traveling on official business is not a part of his salary nor an emolument, and may be increased or diminished during the term for which he was elected without violating this section. Taxpayers' League of Carbon County v. McPherson, 49 Wyo. 251, 54 P.2d 897, 1936 Wyo. LEXIS 48 (Wyo. 1936).

Cessation of housing allowance violates section. —

Where a sheriff, from the beginning of his term, was paid a housing allowance, and thereafter the board of county commissioners ceased payment of the housing allowance, the board's action in terminating the monthly payments violated this section. Park County Bd. of County Comm'rs v. Hodge, 792 P.2d 1390, 1990 Wyo. LEXIS 67 (Wyo. 1990).

Effect of change in classification of county or precinct. —

The salary of an officer cannot be changed after his election, though at the time of the change in classification of county he had not yet taken office. Nickerson v. Winslow, 22 Wyo. 259, 138 P. 184, 1914 Wyo. LEXIS 7 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 22 Wyo. 259, 138 P. 184, 1914 Wyo. LEXIS 8 (Wyo. 1914).

Where the population of the precinct was 1,500 at the time of the election of a justice, though the fact was not determined until thereafter, it was held that he was entitled to a salary which was more than the fees of the office. Davis v. Board of Comm'rs, 4 Wyo. 477, 35 P. 467, 1894 Wyo. LEXIS 3 (Wyo. 1894).

Effect of change in assessed valuation of county's property. —

This section prevents a change in the salary of a county treasurer during the term of his office by reason of a change in the assessed valuation of the property in the county. Board of Comm'rs v. Burns, 3 Wyo. 691, 29 P. 894, 1892 Wyo. LEXIS 12 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 3 Wyo. 691, 29 P. 894, 1892 Wyo. LEXIS 13 (Wyo. 1892).

No change can be made in the salary of a county clerk during his term, notwithstanding a change in the assessed valuation of the county, which would place it in a higher or lower class. Guthrie v. Board of Comm'rs, 7 Wyo. 95, 50 P. 229, 1897 Wyo. LEXIS 16 (Wyo. 1897).

Act providing for the appointment of a county assessor was not repugnant to this section. Reals v. Smith, 8 Wyo. 159, 56 P. 690, 1899 Wyo. LEXIS 6 (Wyo. 1899).

Appropriation to widow of peace officer killed in line of duty. —

This section did not prohibit an appropriation for the benefit of the widow of a peace officer killed in the line of duty. In giving his life, the officer performed a service beyond what it was his legal duty to render, and compensation therefor should not be considered as part of his salary, the increase of which is forbidden by this section. State ex rel. McPherren v. Carter, 30 Wyo. 22, 215 P. 477, 1923 Wyo. LEXIS 28 (Wyo. 1923).

Quoted in

Marion v. City of Lander, 394 P.2d 910, 1964 Wyo. LEXIS 117 (Wyo. 1964).

Cited in

State ex rel. Murane v. Jack, 52 Wyo. 173, 70 P.2d 888, 1937 Wyo. LEXIS 43, 112 A.L.R. 161 (1937); In re Johnson, 568 P.2d 855, 1977 Wyo. LEXIS 313 (Wyo. 1977).

Law reviews. —

For case note, “Local Government Law—Platte County's Cost of Living Adjustment: Is It an Unconstitutional In-Term Adjustment of an Elected Officer's Salary?,” see XXXV Land & Water L. Rev. 549 (2000).

§ 33. Origin of revenue bills.

All bills for raising revenue shall originate in the house of representatives; but the senate may propose amendments, as in case of other bills.

Cross references. —

As to taxation and revenue generally, see art. 15, §§ 1 to 20, Wyo. Const., and title 39.

Cited in

Hansen v. Smith, 395 P.2d 944, 1964 Wyo. LEXIS 124 (Wyo. 1964); Rocky Mountain Oil & Gas Ass'n v. State Bd. of Equalization, Dep't of Revenue & Taxation, 749 P.2d 221, 1987 Wyo. LEXIS 572 (Wyo. 1987).

§ 34. General appropriation bills; other appropriations.

The general appropriation bills shall embrace nothing but appropriations for the ordinary expenses of the legislative, executive and judicial departments of the state, interest on the public debt, and for public schools. All other appropriations shall be made by separate bills, each embracing but one subject.

Cross references. —

For prohibition of appropriation for sectarian or religious societies or institutions, see art. 1, § 19, Wyo. Const.

As to taxation and revenue generally, see art. 15, §§ 1 to 19, Wyo. Const., and title 39.

Statute fixing salaries of officers and enlisted men of the national guard during encampments was not continuing appropriation. State ex rel. Davis v. Carter, 31 Wyo. 401, 226 P. 690, 1924 Wyo. LEXIS 34 (Wyo. 1924).

Appropriation of funds for administration of state instrumentality. —

Section 10, ch. 202, Laws 1975, which appropriated funds for the administration of the Wyoming community development authority, did not violate this section on the ground that said section was not related to ordinary expenses of the legislative, executive and judicial departments of the state and should be enacted by separate bill embracing one subject, since there is no constitutional limitation on the creation of a separate body corporate, as a state instrumentality, to perform governmental functions having a public purpose. With that right goes the implied authority to lend financial support for purely administrative purposes. Witzenburger v. State, 575 P.2d 1100, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 266 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 577 P.2d 1386, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 289 (Wyo. 1978).

Cited in

State ex rel. Jamison v. Forsyth, 21 Wyo. 359, 133 P. 521, 1913 Wyo. LEXIS 26 (1913); Geringer v. Bebout, 10 P.3d 514, 2000 Wyo. LEXIS 181 (Wyo. 2000).

§ 35. Money expended only on appropriation.

Except for interest on public debt, money shall be paid out of the treasury only on appropriations made by the legislature, and in no case otherwise than upon warrant drawn by the proper officer in pursuance of law.

Cross references. —

As to receipt and disbursement of public funds generally, see §§ 9-4-101 to 9-4-107.

Later enactment controls manner of spending appropriation. —

Later enactment governing expenditure of state funds controls manner of spending legislative appropriations, and approval of attorney's employment in sales tax division under older act could not require auditor to order payment of such attorney's salary unless authorized in appropriation act or by inclusion in budget. State ex rel. Watts v. Jack, 58 Wyo. 108, 125 P.2d 165, 1942 Wyo. LEXIS 15 (Wyo. 1942).

Contingent fee contract invalid. —

Contract whereby land commissioners hired auditors to investigate debts due state under mineral leases on contingent basis on amount recovered was invalid in its entirety because constitution requires money collected under contract to be paid into state treasury and precludes it from being paid out except pursuant to legislative appropriation and duly issued warrant. MacDougall v. Board of Land Comm'rs, 48 Wyo. 493, 49 P.2d 663, 1935 Wyo. LEXIS 47 (Wyo. 1935).

Past due, statutorily mandated, salaries payable. —

This section does not make ineffective a peremptory writ of mandamus directing payment of the amount of past due salaries to county court judges on the ground that the legislature failed to appropriate funds for payment of these salaries, as constitutionally required. Section 5-5-119 is effective to appropriate funds for payment. County Court Judges Ass'n v. Sidi, 752 P.2d 960, 1988 Wyo. LEXIS 193 (Wyo. 1988).

Statutes providing for salaries. —

An act providing for the salary and contingent fund for examiner operates as an appropriation act, and did not require any other legislation to keep it alive. State ex rel. Henderson v. Burdick, 4 Wyo. 272, 33 P. 125, 1893 Wyo. LEXIS 11 (Wyo. 1893).

Statute fixing salaries of officers and enlisted men of the national guard during encampments was not continuing appropriation. State ex rel. Davis v. Carter, 31 Wyo. 401, 226 P. 690, 1924 Wyo. LEXIS 34 (Wyo. 1924).

Provisions of Unemployment Compensation Act constitute continuing appropriation for specific purpose and are not in violation of this section. Unemployment Compensation Comm'n v. Renner, 59 Wyo. 437, 143 P.2d 181, 1943 Wyo. LEXIS 25 (Wyo. 1943).

In holding that the Department of Family Services must employ an accurate standard of need in administering the Aid to Families with Dependent Children program, the Wyoming Supreme Court did not invade the provinces of either the executive or legislative branches; the court did not order the state to participate in the federal program, order the department to set its standard of need at a particular level, or order the department to employ a particular methodology in determining the accurate standard of need, nor did the court order the state to maintain a particular benefit level and therefore did not order an increase in appropriations. Davidson v. Sherman, 848 P.2d 1341, 1993 Wyo. LEXIS 58 (Wyo. 1993).

Applied in

Wyoming State Tax Comm'n v. BHP Petro. Co., 856 P.2d 428, 1993 Wyo. LEXIS 109 (Wyo. 1993).

Quoted in

Mekss v. Wyoming Girls' Sch., 813 P.2d 185, 1991 Wyo. LEXIS 103 (Wyo. 1991).

Cited in

State ex rel. Jamison v. Forsyth, 21 Wyo. 359, 133 P. 521, 1913 Wyo. LEXIS 26 (1913); State v. Underwood, 54 Wyo. 1, 86 P.2d 707, 1939 Wyo. LEXIS 1 (1939); Witzenburger v. State ex rel. Wyo. Community Dev. Auth., 575 P.2d 1100, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 266 (Wyo. 1978); Wyodak Res. Dev. Corp. v. Wyo. Dep't of Revenue, 2002 WY 181, 60 P.3d 129, 2002 Wyo. LEXIS 217 (Wyo. 2002).

Law reviews. —

For article, “Governmental Immunity from Damage Actions in Wyoming — Part II,” see VII Land & Water L. Rev. 617 (1972).

§ 36. Prohibited appropriations.

No appropriation shall be made for charitable, industrial, educational or benevolent purposes to any person, corporation or community not under the absolute control of the state, nor to any denominational or sectarian institution or association.

Cross references. —

For an equivalent provision, see art. 1, § 19, Wyo. Const.

Appropriation to state penitentiary not prohibited. —

An appropriation to the state penitentiary, though it is a charitable institution, is not prohibited by this section. State v. Board of Comm'rs, 8 Wyo. 104, 55 P. 451, 1898 Wyo. LEXIS 26 (Wyo. 1898).

Counties are under absolute control of the state within constitutional provision restricting appropriations to other corporations. State ex rel. Bd. of Comm'rs v. Snyder, 29 Wyo. 199, 212 P. 771, 1923 Wyo. LEXIS 9 (Wyo. 1923).

Counties, whether regarded as corporations or as mere political subdivisions, are under the absolute control of the state, within this section. Harkin v. Board of Comm'rs, 30 Wyo. 455, 222 P. 35, 1924 Wyo. LEXIS 71 (Wyo. 1924).

This section had no application with regard to constitutionality of Wyoming Community Development Authority Act, § 9-18-101 et seq. (now § 9-7-101 et seq.), since the supreme court had held that no appropriated tax funds pledged beyond the current year's taxes of the state could go into a special fund to pay off the bonds of the Wyoming community development authority. Witzenburger v. State, 575 P.2d 1100, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 266 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 577 P.2d 1386, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 289 (Wyo. 1978).

Poverty of recipient. —

The prohibition against donations by the state cannot be nullified by claim recipient was poor. State ex rel. McPherren v. Carter, 30 Wyo. 22, 215 P. 477, 1923 Wyo. LEXIS 28 (Wyo. 1923).

Appropriation to widow of peace officer killed in line of duty. —

This section is not violated by an appropriation for the benefit of the widow of a peace officer who was killed in the line of duty, since such an appropriation is in recognition of a moral obligation of the state. State ex rel. McPherren v. Carter, 30 Wyo. 22, 215 P. 477, 1923 Wyo. LEXIS 28 (Wyo. 1923).

Quoted in

Miller v. Board of County Comm'rs, 79 Wyo. 502, 337 P.2d 262, 1959 Wyo. LEXIS 18 (1959).

Cited in

State ex rel. Wyoming Agric. College v. Irvine, 14 Wyo. 318, 84 P. 90, 1906 Wyo. LEXIS 18 (1906).

Law reviews. —

For article, “Through the Front Door,” see 19 Wyo. L.J. 164 (1965).

§ 37. Delegation of power to perform municipal functions prohibited.

The legislature shall not delegate to any special commissioner, private corporation or association, any power to make, supervise or interfere with any municipal improvements, moneys, property or effects, whether held in trust or otherwise, to levy taxes, or to perform any municipal functions whatever.

Intent of section. —

The constitutional prohibition against delegation of power is intended to protect against the exercise of the taxing power and other purely municipal functions by officials not subject to the people's control. Uhls v. State, 429 P.2d 74, 1967 Wyo. LEXIS 161 (Wyo. 1967); State ex rel. Fire Fighters Local 946 v. Laramie, 437 P.2d 295, 1968 Wyo. LEXIS 157 (Wyo. 1968); Frank v. Cody, 572 P.2d 1106, 1977 Wyo. LEXIS 304 (Wyo. 1977).

The purpose of this section was to prevent the legislature, either directly or indirectly, from taking away municipal powers from municipal authorities and conferring them on some commission in no way connected with the regularly constituted municipal authority, subject to the will of the municipal inhabitants. Frank v. Cody, 572 P.2d 1106, 1977 Wyo. LEXIS 304 (Wyo. 1977).

Control of municipal functions by elective municipal officers. —

Where performance of municipal functions is controlled by elective municipal officers, this section is not violated. Stewart v. Cheyenne, 60 Wyo. 497, 154 P.2d 355, 1944 Wyo. LEXIS 20 (Wyo. 1944).

No tax can be levied by officers who are appointed and not elected by the people. Lund v. Schrader, 492 P.2d 202, 1971 Wyo. LEXIS 277 (Wyo. 1971).

City manager is not “special commissioner.” —

A city manager, under act creating commission manager form of government, is not a “special commissioner” to whom prohibited powers are granted. State ex rel. Diers v. Sheldon, 29 Wyo. 233, 213 P. 92, 1923 Wyo. LEXIS 11 (Wyo. 1923).

State board of equalization is neither a special commissioner nor a private corporation nor an association within the meaning of this section. Town of Pine Bluffs v. State Bd. of Equalization, 79 Wyo. 262, 333 P.2d 700, 1958 Wyo. LEXIS 45 (Wyo. 1958), limited, State Bd. of Equalization v. City of Lander, 882 P.2d 844, 1994 Wyo. LEXIS 113 (Wyo. 1994).

County committee, whose function is to prepare and submit a plan of organization for a unified school district or unified school districts within the county, is not a “special commissioner” or a “private corporation” or an “association.” Lund v. Schrader, 492 P.2d 202, 1971 Wyo. LEXIS 277 (Wyo. 1971).

Status of board of public utilities. —

Under this constitutional provision a board of public utilities is under the general control of the town or city council and it has no other powers except those which are administrative. Town of Worland v. Odell & Johnson, 79 Wyo. 1, 329 P.2d 797, 1958 Wyo. LEXIS 29 (Wyo. 1958).

Meaning of governmental functions. —

Governmental functions are those conferred or imposed on a municipality as a local agency of limited and prescribed jurisdiction, to be employed in administering the affairs of the state and promoting the public welfare generally. Carter v. Board of County Comm'rs, 518 P.2d 142, 1974 Wyo. LEXIS 181 (Wyo. 1974).

Legislative power of a purely local nature may be delegated to political subdivisions created for the purpose of local self-government. Carter v. Board of County Comm'rs, 518 P.2d 142, 1974 Wyo. LEXIS 181 (Wyo. 1974).

Administrative powers may be delegated. —

Administrative powers, and these only, may be delegated under this section. Stewart v. Cheyenne, 60 Wyo. 497, 154 P.2d 355, 1944 Wyo. LEXIS 20 (Wyo. 1944).

Matters which are administrative only may be delegated without violating the constitutional prohibition against the legislature delegating to a special commissioner power to supervise or interfere with any municipal function. Uhls v. State ex rel. Fire Fighters Local 946 v. State ex rel. Fire Fighters Local 946 v. Laramie, 437 P.2d 295, 1968 Wyo. LEXIS 157 (Wyo. 1968). See also, Uhls v. State, 429 P.2d 74, 1967 Wyo. LEXIS 161 (Wyo. 1967); Frank v. Cody, 572 P.2d 1106, 1977 Wyo. LEXIS 304 (Wyo. 1977).

Statute requiring city to enact ordinances invalid. —

Mandatory provisions requiring governing board of city to enact ordinances deemed necessary by board of public utilities violates constitution and cannot stand under general principle that legislative power cannot be delegated. Stewart v. Cheyenne, 60 Wyo. 497, 154 P.2d 355, 1944 Wyo. LEXIS 20 (Wyo. 1944).

Municipal taxing power improperly vested. —

Since taxing power is vested only in mayor and city commission, leaving to their discretion determination in first instance whether affairs of city justify issuance of bonds, provisions of statute vesting such power in another board violate this section. Stewart v. Cheyenne, 60 Wyo. 497, 154 P.2d 355, 1944 Wyo. LEXIS 20 (Wyo. 1944).

Irrigation district law was not unconstitutional as delegating to special commissioner, private corporation or association power to perform municipal functions or levy taxes. Sullivan v. Blakesley, 35 Wyo. 73, 246 P. 918, 1926 Wyo. LEXIS 9 (Wyo. 1926).

Powers and duties of escrow bank with respect to escrowed municipal funds. —

The provisions of § 16-5-110, prescribing the powers and duties of the escrow bank with respect to escrowed municipal funds, do not constitute a delegation of power to a private corporation to supervise public moneys, properties, or effects, or otherwise perform municipal functions in contravention of this section. Rodin v. State, 417 P.2d 180, 1966 Wyo. LEXIS 155 (Wyo. 1966).

Industrial Development Projects Act is constitutional. Reed v. Cheyenne, 429 P.2d 69, 1967 Wyo. LEXIS 160 (Wyo. 1967); Uhls v. State, 429 P.2d 74, 1967 Wyo. LEXIS 161 (Wyo. 1967); Powers v. Cheyenne, 435 P.2d 448, 1967 Wyo. LEXIS 191 (Wyo. 1967), reh'g denied, 436 P.2d 961, 1968 Wyo. LEXIS 155 (Wyo. 1968).

Agency organized by municipalities under Joint Powers Act. —

Agency organized by several municipalities under the Wyoming Joint Powers Act, §§ 16-1-102 through 16-1-109, to provide electrical power and energy to their inhabitants, did not unconstitutionally delegate its power to the electrical transmission system of which it was an owner, as a tenant in common, where under the agreement among the participants in the system, including a private corporation, the private corporation was the project manager during construction of the generation station and transmission lines and after construction would be operating agent of the station and related distribution facilities. Frank v. Cody, 572 P.2d 1106, 1977 Wyo. LEXIS 304 (Wyo. 1977).

Because the operation of an electric utility is a proprietary and not a governmental function of a city, this section was not applicable and there was no unconstitutional delegation of a municipal function to an agency which was organized by eight municipalities by authority of the Wyoming Joint Powers Act, §§ 16-1-102 through 16-1-109, to provide electrical power and energy to their inhabitants. Frank v. Cody, 572 P.2d 1106, 1977 Wyo. LEXIS 304 (Wyo. 1977).

As long as the municipality and its representatives retain their powers of judgment, discretion and management, there is no objection to an alliance with private enterprise, with the latter performing ministerial and executive functions requiring special skills. Frank v. Cody, 572 P.2d 1106, 1977 Wyo. LEXIS 304 (Wyo. 1977).

Provisions of Wyoming Community Development Authority Act do not violate section. —

Section 9-18-105 (now § 9-7-105) and former §§ 9-18-109, 9-18-110 (now repealed) did not violate this section on the ground that they delegated to the Wyoming community development authority the power to interfere with municipal moneys. Witzenburger v. State, 575 P.2d 1100, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 266 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 577 P.2d 1386, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 289 (Wyo. 1978).

The Wyoming community development authority is a statewide governmental instrumentality, not a political subdivision. It is designed, though having some unconstitutional features, to meet the economic impact upon the entire state and its people. It is patterned to perform a function not within the capabilities of a municipality. It does not interfere with that which is within the powers of a municipality. Such a plan is not within the prohibition of this section. Witzenburger v. State, 575 P.2d 1100, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 266 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 577 P.2d 1386, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 289 (Wyo. 1978).

The Wyoming community development authority has no power to tax. There is nothing in the act permitting the authority to move into a community and perform any function against the will of the people there residing. Witzenburger v. State, 575 P.2d 1100, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 266 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 577 P.2d 1386, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 289 (Wyo. 1978).

Sections 27-10-101 to 27-10-109, pertaining to collective bargaining for fire fighters, do not violate this section. State ex rel. Fire Fighters Local 946 v. Laramie, 437 P.2d 295, 1968 Wyo. LEXIS 157 (Wyo. 1968).

Joint enterprise of county, federal government, constitutional. —

The joint enterprise of a county and the U.S. forest service to condemn a private road to provide access to a national forest for recreation, the harvesting of timber, and the development and operation of oil and gas leases, did not violate either the Wyoming statutes or the Wyoming constitution. L.U. Sheep Co. v. Board of County Comm'rs, 790 P.2d 663, 1990 Wyo. LEXIS 39 (Wyo. 1990).

Applied in

Fristam v. City of Sheridan, 66 Wyo. 143, 206 P.2d 741, 1949 Wyo. LEXIS 8 (1949).

Quoted in

Police Protective Ass'n v. City of Rock Springs, 631 P.2d 433, 1981 Wyo. LEXIS 329 (Wyo. 1981).

Stated in

Board of County Comm'rs v. White, 79 Wyo. 420, 335 P.2d 433, 1959 Wyo. LEXIS 14 (1959).

Cited in

White v. Board of County Comm'rs, 77 Wyo. 246, 313 P.2d 484, 1957 Wyo. LEXIS 22 (1957); State ex rel. Fire Fighters Local v. Kingham, 420 P.2d 254, 1966 Wyo. LEXIS 179 (Wyo. 1966).

Law reviews. —

For article, “The Constitutionality of Wyoming's Oil and Gas Compulsory Pooling Provision,” see 6 Wyo. L.J. 300.

For comment, “The Right of Wyoming State and Municipal Employees to Organize, Receive Exclusive Recognition, and Bargain Collectively,” see V Land & Water L. Rev. 605 (1970).

§ 38. Investment of trust funds.

The legislature may authorize the investment of trust funds by executors, administrators, guardians or trustees, in the bonds or stocks of private corporations, and in such other securities as it may by law provide. (As amended by Laws 1965, Senate Joint Resolution No. 5, p. 519.)

Construction of section. —

This section relates to financial matters running into indefinite future and is strictly construed. In re Durrin's Estate, 61 Wyo. 1, 154 P.2d 348, 1944 Wyo. LEXIS 21 (Wyo. 1944).

Law reviews. —

For article, “Legal Investment for a Wyoming Trustee,” see 12 Wyo. L.J. 130 (1958).

For note, “Common Trust and Mutual Fund as Legal Investments for a Wyoming Trustee,” see 17 Wyo. L.J. 187 (1963).

For article, “Wyoming's Law of Decedents' Estates, Guardianship and Trusts: A Comparison with the Uniform Probate Code — Part I,” see VII Land & Water L. Rev. 169 (1972).

§ 39. Aid to railroads prohibited.

The legislature shall have no power to pass any law authorizing the state or any county in the state to contract any debt or obligation in the construction of any railroad, or give or loan its credit to or in aid of the construction of the same.

Cross references. —

For other provisions concerning railroads, see art. 10, §§ 11 to 19, Wyo. Const., and §§ 37-9-101 to 37-9-1002.

§ 40. Debts to state or municipal corporation cannot be released unless otherwise prescribed by legislature.

No obligation or liability of any person, association or corporation held or owned by the state or any municipal corporation therein shall ever be exchanged, transferred, remitted, released, postponed or in any way diminished except as may be prescribed by the legislature. The liability or obligation shall not be extinguished except by payment into the proper treasury or as may otherwise be prescribed by the legislature in cases where the obligation or liability is not collectible. (As amended by Laws 1983, Senate Joint Resolution No. 1, p. 961.)

Cross references. —

As to public indebtedness generally, see art. 16, §§ 1 to 13, Wyo. Const.

Purpose of this section is to prevent discrimination by the favoring of one class of taxpayer or debtor of a governmental unit as against another and to further prevent waste or dissipation of the assets of such governmental units. Gonzales v. Personal Collection Serv., 494 P.2d 201, 1972 Wyo. LEXIS 229 (Wyo. 1972).

Compromise and settlement of judgment in favor of state for inheritance taxes. —

A judgment in favor of the state for inheritance taxes is not definite and certain to the extent that a compromise and settlement may not be entered into therefor. State ex rel. Wilson v. Young, 44 Wyo. 6, 7 P.2d 216, 1932 Wyo. LEXIS 2 (Wyo. 1932).

Provision that taxes not collected or enforced for 10 years shall be cancelled does not violate constitutional prohibition against remitting, releasing or diminishing obligations or liabilities owned by state or municipality. Board of County Comm'rs v. Bench Canal Drainage Dist., 56 Wyo. 260, 108 P.2d 590, 1940 Wyo. LEXIS 40 (Wyo. 1940).

Statute of limitation did not apply where self-reporting process was tainted. —

Wyoming Department of Revenue's ruling, which changed the allocation of the company's oil production from a production unit for 1980 through 1988 between one county and intervenor county was not reversible based on Wyo. Const. art. Art. III, § 40 because Wyoming's ad valorem tax system was a self-reporting system, and where the self-reporting process was tainted, statutes of limitations could not be called into play. BP Am. Prod. Co. v. Dep't of Revenue, 2006 WY 27, 130 P.3d 438, 2006 Wyo. LEXIS 29 (Wyo. 2006).

Sale by drainage district of lands acquired by tax sale. —

This section does not prevent sale by drainage district of lands acquired by tax sale, for a sum less than the amount necessary to pay in full the amount due the state under its lien as holder of the district bonds, when the district court finds that the sale price is a fair value of the land, and sufficient to pay the principal and interest on bonded debt, but not the accrued statutory interest. Big Bend Drainage Dist. v. State, 50 Wyo. 242, 60 P.2d 815, 1936 Wyo. LEXIS 18 (Wyo. 1936).

Effect of payment of dividend from insolvent estate. —

Payment of a dividend to the state or to a county from an insolvent estate cannot release the unpaid portion of the debt. State v. Foster, 5 Wyo. 199, 38 P. 926, 1895 Wyo. LEXIS 14 (Wyo. 1895).

Priority as between liens. —

This section has no controlling effect in determining whether lien of state by reason of investment of permanent school funds in bonds issued by drainage district is inferior to lien of general taxes. Alamo Drainage Dist. v. Board of County Comm'rs, 60 Wyo. 177, 148 P.2d 229, 1944 Wyo. LEXIS 7 (Wyo. 1944).

There is no constitutional ban forbidding contingent fee arrangement contracts as such if the statutory authorization of the legislature is sufficient. Gonzales v. Personal Collection Serv., 494 P.2d 201, 1972 Wyo. LEXIS 229 (Wyo. 1972).

Contingent fee arrangement for collection of accounts due. —

If a memorial hospital does not have sufficient means for collection of accounts due, it may rely upon a contingent fee arrangement and assign the accounts for collection by a collection service without constitutional violation. Gonzales v. Personal Collection Serv., 494 P.2d 201, 1972 Wyo. LEXIS 229 (Wyo. 1972).

Contingent fee contract held invalid. —

Contract whereby land commissioners hired auditors to investigate debts due state under mineral leases on contingent basis on amount recovered was invalid in its entirety because constitution requires moneys collected under contract to be paid into state treasury and precludes it from being paid out except pursuant to legislative appropriation and duly issued warrant. MacDougall v. Board of Land Comm'rs, 48 Wyo. 493, 49 P.2d 663, 1935 Wyo. LEXIS 47 (Wyo. 1935).

Claim for case by state of insane person. —

Summary judgment dismissing state's claim against estate of insane decedent, rendered in compliance with the nonclaim statute, now § 2-7-703(a), failed to violate this section, because no debt due the state had yet been ascertained. State ex rel. Bd. of Charities & Reform v. Bower, 362 P.2d 814, 1961 Wyo. LEXIS 100 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 363 P.2d 791, 1961 Wyo. LEXIS 104 (Wyo. 1961).

§ 41. Resolutions; approval or veto.

Every order, resolution or vote, in which the concurrence of both houses may be necessary, except on the question of adjournment, or relating solely to the transaction of the business of the two houses, shall be presented to the governor, and before it shall take effect be approved by him, or, being disapproved, be repassed by two-thirds of both houses as prescribed in the case of a bill.

Editor's notes. —

Laws 2001, Senate Enrolled Joint Resolution No. 2, § 1, authorized the submission of a proposed amendment to the electors of the state of Wyoming at the next general election for approval or rejection to become valid as a part of the constitution if ratified by a majority of the electors.

The proposed amendment provided that amendments to the Wyoming Constitution proposed by the legislature would be submitted to the electors of the state of Wyoming without prior approval by the governor. The amendment was not ratified by a majority of electors at the November 5, 2002 general election.

Legislative measures must be presented to governor. —

When art. 3, § 41, Wyo. Const. and art. 20, § 1, Wyo. Const., are read together, it is plainly declared that legislative measures, however denominated, which propose an amendment to the constitution, must be presented to the governor for approval or disapproval; thus, a measure proposing an amendment to the constitution must be presented to the governor for approval or disapproval. Geringer v. Bebout, 10 P.3d 514, 2000 Wyo. LEXIS 181 (Wyo. 2000).

Law reviews. —

For comment, “Wyoming's Administrative Regulation Review Act,” see XIV Land & Water L. Rev. 189 (1979).

See article, “Administrative Regulation Review — Act II,” XV Land & Water L. Rev. 207 (1980).

§ 42. Bribery of legislators and solicitation of bribery defined; expulsion of legislator for bribery or solicitation.

If any person elected to either house of the legislature shall offer or promise to give his vote or influence in favor of or against any measure or proposition, pending or to be introduced into the legislature, in consideration or upon condition that any other person elected to the same legislature will give, or promise or assent to give his vote or influence in favor of or against any other measure or proposition pending or proposed to be introduced into such legislature, the person making such offer or promise shall be deemed guilty of solicitation of bribery. If any member of the legislature shall give his vote or influence for or against any measure or proposition pending or to be introduced in such legislature, or offer, promise or assent thereto, upon condition that any other member will give or will promise or assent to give his vote or influence in favor of or against any other measure or proposition pending or to be introduced in such legislature, or in consideration that any other member has given his vote or influence for or against any other measure or proposition in such legislature, he shall be deemed guilty of bribery, and any member of the legislature, or person elected thereto, who shall be guilty of either of such offenses, shall be expelled and shall not thereafter be eligible to the legislature, and on conviction thereof in the civil courts shall be liable to such further penalty as may be prescribed by law.

Cross references. —

As to bribery of or by governor, see art. 4, § 10, Wyo. Const.

As to crime of bribery generally, see §§ 6-5-101, 6-5-102.

Law reviews. —

For article, “Goodbye 3-Card Monte: The Wyoming Criminal Code of 1982” (part two), see XIX Land & Water L. Rev. 509 (1984).

§ 43. Offers to bribe.

Any person who shall directly or indirectly offer, give or promise any money or thing of value, testimonial, privilege or personal advantage, to any executive or judicial officer or member of the legislature, to influence him in the performance of any of his official duties shall be deemed guilty of bribery, and be punished in such manner as shall be provided by law.

Cross references. —

As to bribery of or by governor, see art. 4, § 10, Wyo. Const.

As to crime of bribery generally, see §§ 6-5-101, 6-5-102.

Law reviews. —

For article, “Goodbye 3-Card Monte: The Wyoming Criminal Code of 1982” (part two), see XIX Land & Water L. Rev. 509 (1984).

§ 44. Witnesses in bribery charges.

Any person may be compelled to testify in any lawful investigation or judicial proceeding against any person who may be charged with having committed the offense of bribery or corrupt solicitation, or practices of solicitation, and shall not be permitted to withhold his testimony upon the ground that it may criminate [incriminate] himself, or subject him to public infamy; but such testimony shall not afterwards be used against him in any judicial proceeding, except for perjury in giving such testimony, and any person convicted of either of the offenses aforesaid shall, as part of the punishment therefor, be disqualified from holding any office or position of honor, trust or profit in this state.

Law reviews. —

For comment, “Immunity and the Grand Jury,” see VIII Land & Water L. Rev. 629 (1973).

For article, “Goodbye 3-Card Monte: The Wyoming Criminal Code of 1982” (part two), see XIX Land & Water L. Rev. 509 (1984).

§ 45. Legislature shall define corrupt solicitation.

The offense of corrupt solicitation of members of the legislature or of public officers of the state, or of any municipal division thereof, and the occupation or practice of solicitation of such members or officers to influence their official actions shall be defined by law and shall be punishable by fine and imprisonment.

Cross references. —

As to bribery of public officer, see § 6-5-102.

Law reviews. —

For article, “Goodbye 3-Card Monte: The Wyoming Criminal Code of 1982” (part two), see XIX Land & Water L. Rev. 509 (1984).

§ 46. Interested member shall not vote.

  • § 47. Congressional representation.
  • § 48. State census.
  • § 49. District representation.
  • § 50. Apportionment for first legislature.
  • § 51. Filling of vacancies.
  • § 52. Initiative and referendum.
  • § 53. Creation of criminal penalties not subject to governor's power to commute.

A member who has a personal or private interest in any measure or bill proposed or pending before the legislature shall disclose the fact to the house of which he is a member, and shall not vote thereon. Apportionment

§ 47. Congressional representation.

One representative in the congress of the United States shall be elected from the state at large, the Tuesday next after the first Monday in November, 1890, and thereafter at such times and places, and in such manner as may be prescribed by law. When a new apportionment shall be made by congress, the legislature shall divide the state into congressional districts accordingly.

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Application of constitutional “compactness requirement” to redistricting, 114 ALR5th 311.

State court jurisdiction over congressional redistricting disputes, 114 ALR5th 387.

§ 48. State census.

At the first budget session of the legislature following the federal census, the legislature shall reapportion its membership based upon that census. Notwithstanding any other provision of this article, any bill to apportion the legislature may be introduced in a budget session in the same manner as in a general session. (As amended by Laws 1965, House Joint Resolution No. 2. p. 520; as amended by Laws 1997, House Joint Resolution No. 1, § 1.)

This section must be read in the light of and construed with § 3 of this article. State ex rel. Whitehead v. Gage, 377 P.2d 299, 1963 Wyo. LEXIS 66 (Wyo. 1963).

Apportionment among counties required. —

Both § 3 of this article, and this section require the legislature to be “apportioned” among the counties. State ex rel. Whitehead v. Gage, 377 P.2d 299, 1963 Wyo. LEXIS 66 (Wyo. 1963).

And apportionment provisions are mandatory. —

The provisions of the constitution are quite clear, explicit and mandatory. They leave no room for confusion or doubt as to what the legislature is to do about reapportionment and when it is to do it. State ex rel. Whitehead v. Gage, 377 P.2d 299, 1963 Wyo. LEXIS 66 (Wyo. 1963).

Quoted in

Schaefer v. Thomson, 240 F. Supp. 247, 1964 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 7892 (D. Wyo. 1964).

Cited in

State ex rel. Sullivan v. Schnitger, 16 Wyo. 479, 95 P. 698, 1908 Wyo. LEXIS 35 (1908); Gorin v. Karpan, 775 F. Supp. 1430, 1991 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 14885 (D. Wyo. 1991).

Law reviews. —

For article, “Possible Action to Force the Wyoming Legislature to Reapportion,” see 11 Wyo. L.J. 136.

For note, “Wyoming Legislative Reapportionment in the Light (?) of Baker v. Carr,” see 18 Wyo. L.J. 23 (1963).

§ 49. District representation.

Congressional districts may be altered from time to time as public convenience may require. When a congressional district shall be composed of two or more counties they shall be contiguous, and the districts as compact as may be. No county shall be divided in the formation of congressional districts. (As amended by Laws 1965, House Joint Resolution No. 4, p. 521.)

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Application of constitutional “compactness requirement” to redistricting, 114 ALR5th 311.

State court jurisdiction over congressional redistricting disputes, 114 ALR5th 387.

§ 50. Apportionment for first legislature.

Until an apportionment of senators and representatives as otherwise provided by law, they shall be divided among the several counties of the state in the following manner:

Albany County, two senators and five representatives.

Carbon County, two senators and five representatives.

Converse County, one senator and three representatives.

Crook County, one senator and two representatives.

Fremont County, one senator and two representatives.

Laramie County, three senators and six representatives.

Johnson County, one senator and two representatives.

Sheridan County, one senator and two representatives.

Sweetwater County, two senators and three representatives.

Uinta County, two senators and three representatives.

Cross references. —

As to current apportionment, see §§ 28-2-116 to 28-2-119.

Cited in

State ex rel. Sullivan v. Schnitger, 16 Wyo. 479, 95 P. 698, 1908 Wyo. LEXIS 35 (1908); Schaefer v. Thomson, 240 F. Supp. 247, 1964 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 7892 (D. Wyo. 1964).

§ 51. Filling of vacancies.

When vacancies shall occur in the membership of either house of the legislature of the State of Wyoming through death, resignation or other cause, such vacancies shall be filled in such manner as may be prescribed by law, notwithstanding the provisions of section 4 of article III of the constitution which is by this section repealed. (As added by Laws 1947, House Joint Resolution No. 5, p. 249.)

Cross references. —

As to when governor may fill vacancies in office, see art. 4, § 7, Wyo. Const.

As to vacancies in elective state offices, see § 22-18-111.

Section added. —

This section was added by a constitutional amendment proposed by Laws 1947, House Joint Resolution No. 5, p. 249, adopted by a vote of the people at the general election held November 2, 1948, and proclaimed in effect December 1, 1948. Initiative and Referendum

§ 52. Initiative and referendum.

  1. The people may propose and enact laws by the initiative, and approve or reject acts of the legislature by the referendum.
  2. An initiative or referendum is proposed by an application containing the bill to be initiated or the act to be referred. The application shall be signed by not less than one hundred (100) qualified voters as sponsors, and shall be filed with the secretary of state. If he finds it in proper form he shall so certify. Denial of certification shall be subject to judicial review.
  3. After certification of the application, a petition containing a summary of the subject matter shall be prepared by the secretary of state for circulation by the sponsors. The petition may be filed with the secretary of state if it meets both of the following requirements:
    1. It is signed by qualified voters, equal in number to fifteen per cent (15%) of those who voted in the preceding general election; and
    2. It is signed by qualified voters equal in number to fifteen percent (15%) of those resident in at least two-thirds (2/3) of the counties of the state, as determined by those who voted in the preceding general election in that county.
