  4. An initiative petition may be filed at any time except that one may not be filed for a measure substantially the same as that defeated by an initiative election within the preceding (5) years. The secretary of state shall prepare a ballot title and proposition summarizing the proposed law, and shall place them on the ballot for the first statewide election held more than one hundred twenty (120) days after adjournment of the legislative session following the filing. If, before the election, substantially the same measure has been enacted, the petition is void.
  5. A referendum petition may be filed only within ninety (90) days after adjournment of the legislative session at which the act was passed, except that a referendum petition respecting any act previously passed by the legislature may be filed within six months after the power of referendum is adopted. The secretary of state shall prepare a ballot title and proposition summarizing the act and shall place them on the ballot for the first statewide election held more than one hundred eighty (180) days after adjournment of that session.
  6. If votes in an amount in excess of fifty percent (50%) of those voting in the general election are cast in favor of adoption of an initiated measure, the measure is enacted. If votes in an amount in excess of fifty percent (50%) of those voted in the general election are cast in favor of rejection of an act referred, it is rejected. The secretary of state shall certify the election returns. An initiated law becomes effective ninety (90) days after certification, is not subject to veto, and may not be repealed by the legislature within two (2) years of its effective date. It may be amended at any time. An act rejected by referendum is void thirty (30) days after certification. Additional procedures for the initiative and referendum may be prescribed by law.
  7. The initiative shall not be used to dedicate revenues, make or repeal appropriations, create courts, define the jurisdiction of courts or prescribe their rules, enact local or special legislation, or enact that prohibited by the constitution for enactment by the legislature. The referendum shall not be applied to dedications of revenue, to appropriations, to local or special legislation, or to laws necessary for the immediate preservation of the public peace, health, or safety. (As added by Laws 1967, Senate Joint Resolution No. 3, p. 729; as amended by Laws 1985, House Joint Resolution No. 3, p. 550; as amended by Laws 1997, Senate Joint Resolution No. 1, § 1.)

Cross references. —

See also §§ 22-24-101 to 22-24-125.

Editor's notes. —

Joint Resolution 1, 2008 Budget Session, proposed to amend the Wyoming Constitution to modify the signature requirement for a petition for an initiative or referendum, under Wy. Const. Art. 3, § 52(c)(ii). The passage of this amendment would have changed the requirement for petition signatures for an initiative or referendum from at least fifteen percent (15%) of the qualified voters in at least two thirds (2/3) of the counties, as determined by those who voted in the last general election, to at least fifteen percent (15%) of the qualified voters in at least two-thirds (2/3) of the senate districts, as determined by those who voted in the last general election .At the election of November 4, 2008, the proposed amendment did not meet the requirement of approval from a majority of the total ballots cast.

“Qualified voter” and “qualified registered voter” synonymous. —

The term “qualified voter,” required by subsection (c) to sign an initiative petition, is synonymous with the term “qualified registered voter,” required, pursuant to § 22-24-116(a)(i), to be counted as a valid signature on an initiative petition by the secretary of state. Thomson v. Wyoming In-Stream Flow Comm., 651 P.2d 778, 1982 Wyo. LEXIS 387 (Wyo. 1982).

Standard for foreclosing initiative from vote of people. —

An initiative, attacked as facially unconstitutional, must be unconstitutional in toto before foreclosing its inclusion in the ballot for a vote of the people. Wyoming Nat'l Abortion Rights Action League v. Karpan, 881 P.2d 281, 1994 Wyo. LEXIS 100 (Wyo. 1994).

Secretary of state not to adopt rules implementing initiative and referendum. —

Since the constitutional provisions for initiative and referendum, coupled with applicable statutes, are considered self-executing, and, thereby, require no act of implementation, neither this section nor title 22, ch. 24 authorizes the secretary of state to adopt rules to implement procedures relative to initiative and referendum. Thomson v. Wyoming In-Stream Flow Comm., 651 P.2d 778, 1982 Wyo. LEXIS 387 (Wyo. 1982).

Term limit statute unconstitutional. —

Term limit law, Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 22-5-103, as it applies to candidates for the state legislature, whether adopted by initiative or legislative action, is unconstitutional and unenforceable because it violates art. 1, § 3 and art. 3, §§ 2 and 52(g), Wyo. Const. No law, whether enacted by the legislature through the legislative process or by the people through the initiative process, may condition political rights and privileges upon a circumstance or condition such as incumbency. Cathcart v. Meyer, 2004 WY 49, 88 P.3d 1050, 2004 Wyo. LEXIS 62 (Wyo. 2004).

Law reviews. —

For article, “Corporate Expression in Wyoming Ballot Issues, Referenda and Initiatives: A Political and Legal Dilemma,” see XIV Land & Water L. Rev. 449 (1979).

For case note, “Administrative Law — Initiative and Referendum. Initiative Petitions in Wyoming — The Presumption of Validity and the Secretary of State's Review. Thomson v. Wyoming In-Stream Flow Comm., 651 P.2d 778, 1982 Wyo. LEXIS 387 (Wyo. 1982),” see XVIII Land & Water L. Rev. 857 (1983).

For comment, “Wyoming's New Instream Flow Act: An Administrative Quagmire,” see XXI Land & Water L. Rev. 455 (1986).

For article, “An Essay on Wyoming Constitutional Interpretation,” see XXI Land & Water L. Rev. 527 (1986).

§ 53. Creation of criminal penalties not subject to governor's power to commute.

Notwithstanding Article 4, Section 5 of this Constitution, the legislature may by law create a penalty of life imprisonment without parole for specified crimes which sentence shall not be subject to commutation by the governor. The legislature may in addition limit commutation of a death sentence to a sentence of life imprisonment without parole which sentence shall not be subject to further commutation. In no event shall the inherent power of the governor to grant a pardon be limited or curtailed. (Added by 1993 Senate JR 4, ratified in 1994.)

Cross references. —

As to commutation of a death sentence once it has been commuted to a sentence of life imprisonment without parole, see § 7-13-807.

Quoted in

Booth v. State, 2008 WY 3, 174 P.3d 171, 2008 Wyo. LEXIS 3 (Jan. 10, 2008).

Editor's notes. —

In the original constitution the sections under the heading “Apportionment” were numbered 1, 2, 3 and 4, but to avoid confusion in making references, these sections have been renumbered 47, 48, 49 and 50 so as to make the section numbers of this article run consecutively.

Article 4. Executive Department

  • § 1. Executive power vested in governor; term of governor.
  • § 2. Qualifications of governor.
  • § 3. Election of governor.
  • § 4. Powers and duties of governor generally.
  • § 5. Pardoning power of governor.
  • § 6. Acting governor.
  • § 7. When governor may fill vacancies in office.
  • § 8. Approval or veto of legislation by governor; passage over veto.
  • § 9. Veto of items of appropriations.
  • § 10. Bribery or coercion of or by governor.
  • § 11. State officers; election; qualifications; terms.
  • § 12. State officers; powers and duties.
  • § 13. Salaries of governor and other elective state officers.
  • § 14. Examination of accounts.
  • § 15. Great seal of state.

§ 1. Executive power vested in governor; term of governor.

The executive power shall be vested in a governor, who shall hold his office for the term of four (4) years and until his successor is elected and duly qualified.

Cross references. —

For provision that legislature shall meet in special session when convened by the governor, see art. 3, § 7, Wyo. Const.

As to administration of government generally, see title 9.

As to term of office of governor, see § 22-2-105.

Effect of neglect to send appointee's name to senate. —

The fact that the governor neglected to send the name of an appointee to the senate did not deprive him thereafter of the power to appoint. People ex rel. Emerson v. Shawver, 30 Wyo. 366, 222 P. 11, 1924 Wyo. LEXIS 69 (Wyo. 1924).

Applied in

Billis v. State, 800 P.2d 401, 1990 Wyo. LEXIS 119 (Wyo. 1990).

Quoted in

State ex rel. Chatterton v. Grant, 12 Wyo. 1, 73 P. 470, 1903 Wyo. LEXIS 23 (1903).

Cited in

State ex rel. Miller v. Barber, 4 Wyo. 409, 34 P. 1028, 1893 Wyo. LEXIS 22, 27 L.R.A. 45 (1893); State ex rel. Murane v. Jack, 52 Wyo. 173, 70 P.2d 888, 1937 Wyo. LEXIS 43, 112 A.L.R. 161 (1937); Brinegar v. Clark, 371 P.2d 62, 1962 Wyo. LEXIS 82 (Wyo. 1962).

Law reviews. —

For article, “The Wyoming Constitution: A Centennial Assessment,” see XXVI Land & Water L. Rev. 13 (1991).

§ 2. Qualifications of governor.

No person shall be eligible to the office of governor unless he be a citizen of the United States and a qualified elector of the state, who has attained the age of thirty years, and who has resided 5 years next preceding the election within the state or territory, nor shall he be eligible to any other office during the term for which he was elected.

Cross references. —

For definition of “qualified elector,” see § 22-1-102(a)(xxvi).

As to qualifications of electors, see § 22-3-102.

Eligibility of governor to office of United States senator. —

The provision of this section that the governor should not be eligible to any other office during the term for which he was elected would not bar his candidacy for, and election to, the office of United States senator during his term as governor. The eligibility qualifications for the office of senator are set out in the United States constitution which controls as the supreme law of the land and such qualifications cannot be altered by the provisions of a state constitution. State ex rel. Johnson v. Crane, 65 Wyo. 189, 197 P.2d 864, 1948 Wyo. LEXIS 23 (Wyo. 1948).

Cited in

State ex rel. Irvine v. Brooks, 14 Wyo. 393, 84 P. 488, 1906 Wyo. LEXIS 19, 6 L.R.A. (n.s.) 750 (1906); Cathcart v. Meyer, 2004 WY 49, 88 P.3d 1050, 2004 Wyo. LEXIS 62 (2004).

Law reviews. —

For article, “A Loyalty Oath for Candidates,” see 5 Wyo. L.J. 146.

§ 3. Election of governor.

The governor shall be elected by the qualified electors of the state at the time and place of choosing members of the legislature. The person having the highest number of votes for governor shall be declared elected, but if two or more shall have an equal and highest number of votes for governor, the two houses of the legislature at its next regular session shall forthwith, by joint ballot, choose one of such persons for said office. The returns of the election for governor shall be made in such manner as shall be prescribed by law.

Cross references. —

For Election Code, see title 22.

§ 4. Powers and duties of governor generally.

The governor shall be commander-in-chief of the military forces of the state, except when they are called into the service of the United States, and may call out the same to execute the laws, suppress insurrection and repel invasion. He shall have power to convene the legislature on extraordinary occasions. He shall at the commencement of each session communicate to the legislature by message, information of the condition of the state, and recommend such measures as he shall deem expedient. He shall transact all necessary business with the officers of the government, civil and military. He shall expedite all such measures as may be resolved upon by the legislature and shall take care that the laws be faithfully executed.

Cross references. —

As to powers and duties of governor as commander-in-chief of the military forces of the state, see art. 17, § 5, Wyo. Const.

For other provisions concerning powers of the governor, see §§ 9-1-201 to 9-1-219.

Applied in

Hilderbrand v. Padget, 678 P.2d 870, 1984 Wyo. LEXIS 271 (Wyo. 1984).

Cited in

State ex rel. Chatterton v. Grant, 12 Wyo. 1, 73 P. 470, 1903 Wyo. LEXIS 23 (1903).

§ 5. Pardoning power of governor.

The governor shall have power to remit fines and forfeitures, to grant reprieves, commutations and pardons after conviction, for all offenses except treason and cases of impeachment; but the legislature may by law regulate the manner in which the remission of fines, pardons, commutations and reprieves may be applied for. Upon conviction for treason he shall have power to suspend the execution of sentence until the case is reported to the legislature at its next regular session, when the legislature shall either pardon, or commute the sentence, direct the execution of the sentence or grant further reprieve. He shall communicate to the legislature at each regular session each case of remission of fine, reprieve, commutation or pardon granted by him, stating the name of the convict, the crime for which he was convicted, the sentence and its date, and the date of the remission, commutation, pardon or reprieve with his reasons for granting the same.

Cross references. —

As to treason, see art. 1, § 26, Wyo. Const.

As to pardons and reprieves generally, see §§ 7-13-801 to 7-13-806.

Commutation deemed prerogative of executive. —

Possibilities of commutation are matters within the constitutional prerogative of the executive department and do not concern the court. Kennedy v. State, 595 P.2d 577, 1979 Wyo. LEXIS 413 (Wyo. 1979).

Court without jurisdiction to expunge criminal record for purpose of restoring civil rights. —

An expungement of a criminal record by a court, under its inherent powers, of one not pardoned, whose conviction was without error, and only for the purpose of restoring civil rights, would have been an encroachment on the power of the executive branch, i.e., the pardoning power of the governor, and the district court properly refused to take such action as being beyond its jurisdiction. Stanton v. State, 686 P.2d 587, 1984 Wyo. LEXIS 328 (Wyo. 1984).

Statutes regulating applications for pardon. —

Sections 7-13-803 to 7-13-806, regulating applications for pardon and requiring the giving and publication of notice thereof, are directory only to applicants for pardon, and those moving in their behalf, prescribing a method by which they can procure a hearing before the governor. They do not limit or impose any restrictions upon the authority of the governor to grant pardons, nor is their effect enlarged by this section of the constitution. In re Moore, 4 Wyo. 98, 31 P. 980, 1893 Wyo. LEXIS 3 (Wyo. 1893).

Officials not liable for withholding commutation order. —

A parole board official and the penitentiary warden were entitled to the defense of qualified immunity in a prisoner's civil rights action against them for withholding a commutation order while they sought to obtain a clarification of its ambiguity. Deckert v. Lang, 774 P.2d 1285, 1989 Wyo. LEXIS 130 (Wyo. 1989).

Applied in

Billis v. State, 800 P.2d 401, 1990 Wyo. LEXIS 119 (Wyo. 1990); Weldon v. State, 800 P.2d 513, 1990 Wyo. LEXIS 132 (Wyo. 1990).

Cited in

State ex rel. Chatterton v. Grant, 12 Wyo. 1, 73 P. 470, 1903 Wyo. LEXIS 23 (1903).

Law reviews. —

For article, “The Changing Structure of Criminal Sentencing,” see XVIII Land & Water L. Rev. 591 (1983).

For article, “The Wyoming Criminal Code Revisited: Reflections after Fifteen Years,” see XXXIII Land and Water L. Rev. 523 (1998).

§ 6. Acting governor.

If the governor be impeached, displaced, resign or die, or from mental or physical disease or otherwise become incapable of performing the duties of his office or be absent from the state, the secretary of state shall act as governor until the vacancy is filled or the disability removed.

Cross references. —

For another provision authorizing secretary of state to perform duties of governor in case of impeachment, see § 9-1-211.

Salary. —

Where the secretary of state became acting governor and performed the duties of both offices, he was entitled to receive the salary of both governor and secretary of state. State ex rel. Chatterton v. Grant, 12 Wyo. 1, 73 P. 470, 1903 Wyo. LEXIS 23 (Wyo. 1903).

Pardoning power. —

A pardon granted by a secretary of state who was acting governor was valid. In re Moore, 4 Wyo. 98, 31 P. 980, 1893 Wyo. LEXIS 3 (Wyo. 1893).

§ 7. When governor may fill vacancies in office.

When any office from any cause becomes vacant, and no mode is provided by the constitution or law for filling such vacancy, the governor shall have the power to fill the same by appointment.

Cross references. —

As to filling of vacancies in legislature, see art. 3, § 51, Wyo. Const.

As to power of governor to fill vacancies in case of impeachment, see § 9-1-203.

As to power of governor to fill vacancy in the office of justice of the supreme court or judge of district court, see § 22-18-110.

As to vacancies in other elected offices, see § 22-18-111.

When office deemed vacant. —

An office cannot be said to be vacant while any person is authorized to act in it and does so act. State ex rel. Richardson v. Henderson, 4 Wyo. 535, 35 P. 517, 1894 Wyo. LEXIS 8 (Wyo. 1894).

Under statute providing term of office shall be 6 years and “until successors are appointed and qualified,” no vacancy in office exists enabling governor to appoint successor without consent of senate while qualified person is in possession of office. People ex rel. Warren v. Christian, 58 Wyo. 39, 123 P.2d 368, 1942 Wyo. LEXIS 12 (Wyo. 1942).

Change in judicial districts does not create vacancy. —

An act decreasing and changing boundaries of judicial districts of the state does not create any vacancy in office within the meaning of this section. Brown v. Clark, 47 Wyo. 216, 34 P.2d 17, 1934 Wyo. LEXIS 21 (Wyo. 1934).

Effect of military service. —

A district judge who during term of office entered the service of the United States as a major in advocate general's department, upon returning to and resuming the office of district judge, was a de jure and not a de facto judge, where he had not resigned and his office had not been declared vacant and no successor had qualified. State ex rel. Raymond v. Jefferis, 26 Wyo. 115, 178 P. 909, 1919 Wyo. LEXIS 4 (Wyo. 1919).

Acquiescence of hold-over officer in appointment of successor. —

Where governor's appointment to public office was invalid because there was no vacancy, there being an incumbent holding over after expiration of his term, but the old officer acquiesced in governor's appointee occupying his office, the former abandoned and vacated office and new appointee stood in his shoes as hold-over incumbent. People ex rel. Warren v. Christian, 58 Wyo. 39, 123 P.2d 368, 1942 Wyo. LEXIS 12 (Wyo. 1942).

Death of hold-over officer. —

Where governor's appointment of new member to board was invalid because not confirmed by senate, death of hold-over member created vacancy which governor could fill by appointment, with new appointee standing in shoes of deceased. People ex rel. Warren v. Christian, 58 Wyo. 39, 123 P.2d 368, 1942 Wyo. LEXIS 12 (Wyo. 1942).

Governor's appointment after incumbent's term expired became valid on incumbent's death to extent incumbent had right to office until successor qualified. However, since senate did not confirm appointment, and since appointment for regular term could not be made without consent of senate, appointee's name or that of someone to succeed him should go to senate at next session, and such person when confirmed would serve for balance of term which commenced when term of deceased incumbent expired. People ex rel. Warren v. Christian, 58 Wyo. 39, 123 P.2d 368, 1942 Wyo. LEXIS 12 (Wyo. 1942).

Vacancy in the office of district judge may be filled by appointment by the governor. In re Board of Comm'rs, 4 Wyo. 133, 32 P. 850 (Wyo. 1893).

Power of appointment without advice and consent of senate. —

Governor's power of appointment without advice and consent of senate is confined to cases when vacancy exists and no other mode for filling it has been provided. People ex rel. Warren v. Christian, 58 Wyo. 39, 123 P.2d 368, 1942 Wyo. LEXIS 12 (Wyo. 1942).

Effect of neglect to send appointee's name to senate. —

Governor's neglect to send name of appointee to senate did not deprive him of the power thereafter to appoint. People ex rel. Emerson v. Shawver, 30 Wyo. 366, 222 P. 11, 1924 Wyo. LEXIS 69 (Wyo. 1924).

Term of appointee. —

A state engineer appointed to fill vacancy is entitled to hold office until the appointment and qualification of a successor. People ex rel. Emerson v. Shawver, 30 Wyo. 366, 222 P. 11, 1924 Wyo. LEXIS 69 (Wyo. 1924).

Where a person appointed to fill a vacancy in the office of state treasurer is afterward elected to the office at a general election held before the term of his predecessor would have expired, he is not entitled to hold the office for 4 years after such election, but only for the remainder of his predecessor's term. State ex rel. Irvine v. Brooks, 14 Wyo. 393, 84 P. 488, 1906 Wyo. LEXIS 19 (Wyo. 1906).

Cited in

State ex rel. Chatterton v. Grant, 12 Wyo. 1, 73 P. 470, 1903 Wyo. LEXIS 23 (1903).

§ 8. Approval or veto of legislation by governor; passage over veto.

Every bill which has passed the legislature shall, before it becomes a law, be presented to the governor. If he approve, he shall sign it; but if not, he shall return it with his objections to the house in which it originated, which shall enter the objections at large upon the journal and proceed to reconsider it. If, after such reconsideration, two-thirds of the members elected agree to pass the bill, it shall be sent, together with the objections, to the other house, by which it shall likewise be reconsidered, and if it be approved by two-thirds of the members elected, it shall become a law; but in all such cases the vote of both houses shall be determined by the yeas and nays, and the names of the members voting for and against the bill shall be entered upon the journal of each house respectively. If any bill is not returned by the governor within three days (Sundays excepted) after its presentation to him, the same shall be a law, unless the legislature by its adjournment, prevent its return, in which case it shall be a law, unless he shall file the same with his objections in the office of the secretary of state within fifteen days after such adjournment.

This section applies to appropriation bills as well as other statutes. State ex rel. Jamison v. Forsyth, 21 Wyo. 359, 133 P. 521, 1913 Wyo. LEXIS 26 (Wyo. 1913).

Approval of erroneously enrolled bill. —

Where a bill as adopted by both houses provided for the disbursement of 23 percent of gasoline license taxes to counties but because of error in enrolling, the bill, as approved, provided for a disbursement of 25 percent of the revenue and the governor approved the bill with knowledge of the error but called attention thereto, such error should be corrected by the courts and the bill amended to read as adopted by the legislature. State ex rel. Bd. of Comm'rs v. Wright, 62 Wyo. 112, 163 P.2d 190, 1945 Wyo. LEXIS 31 (Wyo. 1945).

Unauthorized disapproval of a bill by the governor does not defeat its enactment. State ex rel. Jamison v. Forsyth, 21 Wyo. 359, 133 P. 521, 1913 Wyo. LEXIS 26 (Wyo. 1913).

Applied in

Billis v. State, 800 P.2d 401, 1990 Wyo. LEXIS 119 (Wyo. 1990).

Quoted in

Geringer v. Bebout, 10 P.3d 514, 2000 Wyo. LEXIS 181 (Wyo. 2000).

Cited in

State ex rel. Chatterton v. Grant, 12 Wyo. 1, 73 P. 470, 1903 Wyo. LEXIS 23 (1903); Arbuckle v. Pflaeging, 20 Wyo. 351, 123 P. 918, 1912 Wyo. LEXIS 40 (1918); Amoco Prod. Co. v. Hakala, 644 P.2d 785, 1982 Wyo. LEXIS 338 (Wyo. 1982).

Law reviews. —

For article, “How to Draft a Bill,” see 6 Wyo. L.J. 285.

For comment, “Wyoming's Administrative Regulation Review Act,” see XIV Land & Water L. Rev. 189 (1979).

See article, “Administrative Regulation Review — Act II,” XV Land & Water L. Rev. 207 (1980).

§ 9. Veto of items of appropriations.

The governor shall have power to disapprove of any item or items or part or parts of any bill making appropriations of money or property embracing distinct items, and the part or parts of the bill approved shall be the law, and the item or items and part or parts disapproved shall be void unless enacted in the following manner: If the legislature be in session he shall transmit to the house in which the bill originated a copy of the item or items or part or parts thereof disapproved, together with his objections thereto, and the items or parts objected to shall be separately reconsidered, and each item or part shall then take the same course as is prescribed for the passage of bills over the executive veto.

Editor's notes. —

Laws 2001, Senate Enrolled Joint Resolution No. 1, § 1, authorized the submission of a proposed amendment to the electors of the state of Wyoming at the next general election for approval or rejection to become valid as a part of the constitution if ratified by a majority of the electors.

The proposed amendment would have changed this section by limiting the governor's partial veto authority to apply only to general appropriations bills.

The amendment was not ratified by a majority of the electors at the November 5, 2002 general election.

Doctrine of great public interest. —

The court recognized the “doctrine of great public interest or importance” in connection with the existence of a justiciable controversy to support the invocation of their authority to make a declaratory judgment. Management Council of the Wyo. Legislature v. Geringer, 953 P.2d 839, 1998 Wyo. LEXIS 13 (Wyo. 1998).

Purpose of section. —

This section provides for striking out such items of an appropriation as are improper, in order to overcome evil of forcing the executive to approve many unwise and improper appropriations. State ex rel. Jamison v. Forsyth, 21 Wyo. 359, 133 P. 521, 1913 Wyo. LEXIS 26 (Wyo. 1913).

Approval of appropriation in part. —

The approval of $10,000 of an appropriation of $15,000, and disapproval of $5,000 was not a disapproval of the entire appropriation. State ex rel. Jamison v. Forsyth, 21 Wyo. 359, 133 P. 521, 1913 Wyo. LEXIS 26 (Wyo. 1913).

Veto power of Governor. —

The Governor has authority to veto substantive provisions of any bill making appropriations, even though the vetoed substantive provision does not appropriate money. Management Council of the Wyo. Legislature v. Geringer, 953 P.2d 839, 1998 Wyo. LEXIS 13 (Wyo. 1998).

Quoted in

Geringer v. Bebout, 10 P.3d 514, 2000 Wyo. LEXIS 181 (Wyo. 2000).

Cited in

State ex rel. Chatterton v. Grant, 12 Wyo. 1, 73 P. 470, 1903 Wyo. LEXIS 23 (1903).

Law reviews. —

For case note, “Constitutional Law—Wyoming's Line Item Veto: Allowing the Governor to Legislate? Management Council of the Wyoming Legislature v. Geringer, 953 P.2d 839, 1998 Wyo. LEXIS 13 (Wyo. 1999),” see XXXIV Land & Water L. Rev. 451 (1999).

§ 10. Bribery or coercion of or by governor.

Any governor of this state who asks, receives or agrees to receive any bribe upon any understanding that his official opinion, judgment or action shall be influenced thereby, or who gives or offers, or promises his official influence in consideration that any member of the legislature shall give his official vote or influence on any particular side of any question or matter upon which he is required to act in his official capacity, or who menaces any member by the threatened use of his veto power, or who offers or promises any member that he, the governor, will appoint any particular person or persons to any office created or thereafter to be created, in consideration that any member shall give his official vote or influence on any matter pending or thereafter to be introduced into either house of said legislature; or who threatens any member that he, the governor, will remove any person or persons from office or position with intent in any manner to influence the action of said members, shall be punished in the manner now or that may hereafter be provided by law, and upon conviction thereof shall forfeit all right to hold or exercise any office of trust or honor in this state.

Cross references. —

As to crime of bribery, see § 6-5-102.

§ 11. State officers; election; qualifications; terms.

There shall be chosen by the qualified electors of the state at the times and places of choosing members of the legislature, a secretary of state, auditor, treasurer, and superintendent of public instruction, who shall have attained the age of twenty-five (25) years respectively, shall be citizens of the United States, and shall have the qualifications of state electors. They shall severally hold their offices at the seat of government, for the term of four (4) years and until their successors are elected and duly qualified. The legislature may provide for such other state officers as are deemed necessary. (As amended by Laws 1981, House Joint Resolution No. 1, p. 330.)

Cross references. —

For definition of “qualified elector,” see § 22-1-102(a)(xxvi).

As to date of general election, see § 22-2-104.

As to terms of office and offices voted on at general elections, see § 22-2-105.

As to qualifications of electors, see § 22-3-102.

Appointment by governor. —

The legislature may provide for such other state officers not enumerated in the constitution as are deemed necessary, and it seems that in the creation of such officers the governor may be vested by law with the sole power of appointing them, dispensing with the consent of the senate. Such, however, has not been the habit of the state or territorial legislatures in creating new offices, as such officials are generally required by the statutes to be appointed by the governor by and with the advice and consent of the senate, except only in case of vacancies. State ex rel. Richardson v. Henderson, 4 Wyo. 535, 35 P. 517, 1894 Wyo. LEXIS 8 (Wyo. 1894).

Removal by governor. —

Since the governor is vested with power to appoint many subordinate officers for whose conduct he is in a measure responsible, the legislature may vest him with the further power to summarily remove such appointees for misconduct in office. State ex rel. Hamilton v. Grant, 14 Wyo. 41, 81 P. 795, 1905 Wyo. LEXIS 29 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 14 Wyo. 41, 81 P. 795, 1905 Wyo. LEXIS 30 (Wyo. 1905).

Term limit statute unconstitutional as to Secretary of State. —

Wyo. Const. art. 1, § 3 prohibited the passage of any law conditioning political rights and privileges upon a circumstance or condition other than those enumerated. Because Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 22-5-103 conditioned the right to hold the office of Secretary of State on incumbency, not an enumerated condition, it was unconstitutional. Maxfield v. State, 2013 WY 14, 294 P.3d 895, 2013 Wyo. LEXIS 17 (Wyo. 2013).

District judge elected at a general election to fill a vacancy is entitled to hold office for the full term of six years. State ex rel. Burdick v. Schnitger, 17 Wyo. 65, 96 P. 238, 1908 Wyo. LEXIS 7 (Wyo. 1908).

Applied in

State ex rel. Irvine v. Brooks, 14 Wyo. 393, 84 P. 488, 1906 Wyo. LEXIS 19, 6 L.R.A. (n.s.) 750 (1906).

Quoted in

Powers v. State, 2014 WY 15, 2014 Wyo. LEXIS 16 (Jan 28, 2014) and Powers v. State, No. 180-673 (1st Jud. Dist. Ct. Apr. 18, 2014).

Cited in

People ex rel. Emerson v. Shawver, 30 Wyo. 366, 222 P. 11, 1924 Wyo. LEXIS 69 (1924); Natrona County Sch. Dist. v. Ryan, 764 P.2d 1019, 1988 Wyo. LEXIS 153 (Wyo. 1988); Cathcart v. Meyer, 2004 WY 49, 88 P.3d 1050, 2004 Wyo. LEXIS 62 (2004).

Law reviews. —

For article, “A Loyalty Oath for Candidates,” see 5 Wyo. L.J. 146.

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Validity of age requirement for state public office, 90 ALR3d 900.

§ 12. State officers; powers and duties.

The powers and duties of the secretary of state, of state auditor, treasurer and superintendent of public instruction shall be as prescribed by law.

Cross references. —

As to secretary of state, see §§ 9-1-301 to 9-1-307.

As to state auditor and state treasurer, see §§ 9-1-401 to 9-1-417.

As to superintendent of public instruction, see §§ 21-2-201, 21-2-202, and 21-13-301.

Secretary of state must sign and affix the state seal to an appointment of the governor, as it is no concern of the secretary whether he approves or disapproves the appointment. State ex rel. Miller v. Barber, 4 Wyo. 409, 34 P. 1028, 1893 Wyo. LEXIS 22 (Wyo. 1893).

Quoted in

Powers v. State, 2014 WY 15, 2014 Wyo. LEXIS 16 (Jan 28, 2014) and Powers v. State, No. 180-673 (1st Jud. Dist. Ct. Apr. 18, 2014).

§ 13. Salaries of governor and other elective state officers.

Until otherwise provided by law, the governor shall receive an annual salary of two thousand and five hundred dollars, the secretary of state, state auditor, state treasurer and superintendent of public instruction shall each receive an annual salary of two thousand dollars, and the salaries of any of the said officers shall not be increased or diminished during the period for which they were elected, and all fees and profits arising from any of the said offices shall be covered into the state treasury.

Cross references. —

For prohibition against increasing or diminishing salaries of public officers during term, see art. 3, § 32, Wyo. Const.

For amount of annual salaries, see § 9-3-101.

§ 14. Examination of accounts.

The legislature shall provide by law for examination of the accounts of state treasurer, supreme court clerks, district court clerks, and all county treasurers, and treasurers of such other public institutions as the legislature may prescribe. (As amended by Laws 1989, Senate Joint Resolution No. 5, p. 771.)

Cross references. —

For other provisions concerning director of state department of audit, see §§ 9-1-504 through 9-1-513.

Act fixing the salary of the examiner operates as an appropriation and does not require any additional appropriation to keep it alive. State ex rel. Henderson v. Burdick, 4 Wyo. 272, 33 P. 125, 1893 Wyo. LEXIS 11 (Wyo. 1893).

Vacancy in office of examiner. —

Where a statute provided that a vacancy in the office of state examiner should be filled by appointment by the governor until the next meeting of the legislature, and upon the resignation of the state examiner the governor appointed a person to fill the vacancy, but did not send the name of the appointee or of any other person to the next session of the legislature for confirmation, the person so appointed held over under art. 6, § 16, Wyo. Const., and no vacancy thereafter existed which could be filled by appointment under § 7 of this article. State ex rel. Richardson v. Henderson, 4 Wyo. 535, 35 P. 517, 1894 Wyo. LEXIS 8 (Wyo. 1894).

Cited in

Board of Comm'rs v. Burns, 3 Wyo. 691, 29 P. 894, 1892 Wyo. LEXIS 12 (1892); People ex rel. Emerson v. Shawver, 30 Wyo. 366, 222 P. 11, 1924 Wyo. LEXIS 69 (1924).

§ 15. Great seal of state.

There shall be a seal of state which shall be called the “Great Seal of the State of Wyoming”; it shall be kept by the secretary of state and used by him officially as directed by law.

The seal of the Territory of Wyoming as now used shall be the seal of the state until otherwise provided by law.

Cross references. —

See also § 8-3-101.

Article 5. Judicial Department

  • § 1. How judicial power vested.
  • § 2. Supreme court generally; appellate jurisdiction.
  • § 3. Supreme court generally; original jurisdiction.
  • § 4. Supreme court generally; number; election of chief justice; quorum; vacancies in supreme court or district court; judicial nominating commission; terms; standing for retention in office.
  • § 5. Voluntary retirement and compensation of justices and judges.
  • § 6. Commission on judicial conduct and ethics.
  • § 7. Supreme court generally; terms of court.
  • § 8. Supreme court generally; qualifications of justices.
  • § 9. Supreme court generally; clerk.
  • § 10. District courts generally; jurisdiction.
  • § 11. District courts generally; judges to hold court for each other.
  • § 12. District courts generally; qualifications of judges.
  • § 13. District courts generally; clerks.
  • § 14. District courts generally; commissioners.
  • § 15. Style of process.
  • § 16. Supreme court judges limited to judicial duties.
  • § 17. Salaries of judges of supreme and district courts.
  • § 18. Appeals from district courts to supreme court.
  • § 19. State divided into districts; election and terms of district judges.
  • § 20. Districts defined.
  • § 21. Increase in number of districts and judges.
  • § 22. Jurisdiction of justices of the peace. [Repealed.]
  • § 23. Appeals from justices' courts. [Repealed.]
  • § 24. Terms of district courts; attaching unorganized territory to organized counties.
  • § 25. Judges of supreme and district courts shall not practice.
  • § 26. Power to fix terms of court.
  • § 27. Judges of supreme and district courts shall not hold other office.
  • § 28. Appeals from boards of arbitration.
  • § 29. Juvenile delinquency and domestic relations courts.

§ 1. How judicial power vested.

The judicial power of the state shall be vested in the senate, sitting as a court of impeachment, in a supreme court, district courts, and such subordinate courts as the legislature may, by general law, establish and ordain from time to time. (As amended by Laws 1965, Senate Joint Resolution No. 1, p. 518.)

Cross references. —

For provision that the constitution of the United States shall be the supreme law of the land, see art. 1, § 37, Wyo. Const.

As to probate courts, see §§ 2-2-101 to 2-2-404.

As to courts generally, see title 5.

As to juvenile courts, see §§ 14-6-201 through 14-6-252.

Term “district court” is used in a broad or inclusive sense as if there were one district court in a given judicial district for several counties, and as if there were one district court in a given county for the several jurisdictions such as civil, criminal and probate. Gaunt v. Kansas Univ. Endowment Ass'n, 379 P.2d 825, 1963 Wyo. LEXIS 79 (Wyo. 1963).

Effect of 1967 amendment to this article on art. 3, §§ 18 and 19, Wyo. Const. —

The provisions of art. 3, §§ 18 and 19, Wyo. Const., as they relate to justices of the peace were repealed by implication when the 1965 constitutional amendment to this article became effective in 1967. In re Johnson, 568 P.2d 855, 1977 Wyo. LEXIS 313 (Wyo. 1977).

The provisions of art. 3, §§ 18 and 19, Wyo. Const., as they relate to impeachment of justices of the peace, are irreconcilable with the 1965 constitutional amendment to this article, which eliminated justice of the peace courts from the constitution. In re Johnson, 568 P.2d 855, 1977 Wyo. LEXIS 313 (Wyo. 1977).

Office of justice of the peace is legislative, not constitutional, office. —

See In re Johnson, 568 P.2d 855, 1977 Wyo. LEXIS 313 (Wyo. 1977).

Powers conferred on board of control do not violate section. —

The powers conferred upon the board of control in regard to water appropriations was not in violation of this section. Farm Inv. Co. v. Carpenter, 9 Wyo. 110, 61 P. 258, 1900 Wyo. LEXIS 8 (Wyo. 1900).

But jurisdiction of board of control is not exclusive. —

The state board of control is not vested with exclusive jurisdiction of actions to determine priority of water rights, and such actions may be brought in courts. Simmons v. Ramsbottom, 51 Wyo. 419, 68 P.2d 153, 1937 Wyo. LEXIS 29 (Wyo. 1937).

Statute requiring dipping of sheep not invalid delegation of power. —

Former statute, providing for compulsory dipping of all sheep kept or herded within the state, whether diseased or not, done under supervision of an inspector, was not invalid as reposing judicial powers in an administrative officer contrary to this section. State v. Hall, 27 Wyo. 224, 194 P. 476, 1920 Wyo. LEXIS 34 (Wyo. 1920).

Statute empowering board of charities and reform to transfer prisoner in industrial institute to penitentiary if it should appear that he had been previously convicted of crime was not unconstitutional as a delegation of judicial functions to an executive board. Uram v. Roach, 47 Wyo. 335, 37 P.2d 793, 1934 Wyo. LEXIS 27 (Wyo. 1934).

Condemnation procedure authorized by act authorizing city to condemn land for waterworks was not violative of this or of any other provision of the constitution. Edwards v. Cheyenne, 19 Wyo. 110, 114 P. 677, 1911 Wyo. LEXIS 9 (Wyo. 1911), reh'g denied, 19 Wyo. 110, 122 P. 900, 1912 Wyo. LEXIS 1 (Wyo. 1912).

Jurisdiction of district court on appeal from board of land commissioners. —

District court is without jurisdiction on appeal from board of land commissioners unless appeal comes within provision of statute. State ex rel. Walls v. District Court, 38 Wyo. 427, 267 P. 1060, 1928 Wyo. LEXIS 62 (Wyo. 1928).

Authority of judge at chambers to punish for contempt. —

A judge at chambers has no authority without express authority of law to punish for a contempt not committed in his presence. Mau v. Stoner, 12 Wyo. 478, 76 P. 584, 1904 Wyo. LEXIS 14 (Wyo. 1904).

Territorial judge refusing to deliver records. —

A territorial probate judge who refused to deliver his records to the district judge under statehood may be punished for contempt. Ex parte Bergman, 3 Wyo. 396, 26 P. 914, 1890 Wyo. LEXIS 13 (Wyo. 1890).

Jurisdiction over same-sex divorce action. —

District court had subject-matter jurisdiction pursuant to Wyo. Const. art. 5, § 10, this section, and Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 20-2-104 over a divorce action involving a same-sex couple legally married in Canada. Recognizing the marriage under Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 20-1-111 for this limited purpose was not inconsistent with the definition of marriage in Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 20-1-101. Christiansen v. Christiansen, 2011 WY 90, 253 P.3d 153, 2011 Wyo. LEXIS 93 (Wyo. 2011).

Applied in

Brinegar v. Clark, 371 P.2d 62, 1962 Wyo. LEXIS 82 (Wyo. 1962); Nollsch v. City of Rock Springs, 724 P.2d 447, 1986 Wyo. LEXIS 603 (Wyo. 1986); Billis v. State, 800 P.2d 401, 1990 Wyo. LEXIS 119 (Wyo. 1990); Best v. Best, 2015 WY 133, 2015 Wyo. LEXIS 150 (Sept. 30, 2015).

Quoted in

Lapp v. City of Worland, 612 P.2d 868, 1980 Wyo. LEXIS 283 (Wyo. 1980); Bi-Rite Package, Inc. v. District Court, 735 P.2d 709, 1987 Wyo. LEXIS 423 (Wyo. 1987); Foster v. Foster, 768 P.2d 1038, 1989 Wyo. LEXIS 39 (Wyo. 1989).

Cited in

Dawson v. City of Casper, 731 P.2d 1186, 1987 Wyo. LEXIS 389 (Wyo. 1987); Katona v. City of Cheyenne, 686 F. Supp. 287, 1988 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 4215 (D. Wyo. 1988); Cathcart v. Meyer, 2004 WY 49, 88 P.3d 1050, 2004 Wyo. LEXIS 62 (2004); Granite Springs Retreat Ass'n v. Manning, 2006 WY 60, 133 P.3d 1005, 2006 Wyo. LEXIS 59 (Wyo. May 12, 2006); Harmon v. Star Valley Med. Ctr., 2014 WY 90, 2014 Wyo. LEXIS 99 (Jul 16, 2014).

Law reviews. —

For note, “Constitutional Law — Due Process — Replevin — Right to Notice and Hearing Prior to Deprivation of Property. Fuentes v. Shevin, 407 U.S. 67, 32 L. Ed. 2d 556, 92 S. Ct. 1983, 1972 U.S. LEXIS 42 (1972),” see VIII Land & Water L. Rev. 315 (1973).

For comment, “The Institutional Transfer Statute: Three Challenges to the Imprisonment of Juvenile Offenders,” see XVII Land & Water L. Rev. 643 (1982).

For article, “The Wyoming Constitution: A Centennial Assessment,” see XXVI Land & Water L. Rev. 13 (1991).

For article, “Journey for the Pole: The Life and Times of Fred H. Blume, Justice of the Wyoming Supreme Court,” see XXVIII Land & Water L. Rev. 511 (1993).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Applicability of judicial immunity to acts of clerk of court under state law, 34 ALR4th 1186.

§ 2. Supreme court generally; appellate jurisdiction.

The supreme court shall have general appellate jurisdiction, co-extensive with the state, in both civil and criminal causes, and shall have a general superintending control over all inferior courts, under such rules and regulations as may be prescribed by law.

Cross references. —

As to appeals from district courts to supreme court, see art. 5, § 18, Wyo. Const., and Rules 1.01 to 29 W.R.A.P.

As to reservation of difficult constitutional questions to the supreme court by the district court, see § 1-13-101.

As to supreme court generally, see §§ 5-2-101 to 5-2-502.

As to rules of the supreme court, see Rules 1 to 9, Sup. Ct.

Scope of court's authority. —

Supreme court is clothed with appellate jurisdiction in criminal as well as civil causes. In re Boulter, 5 Wyo. 263, 39 P. 875, 1895 Wyo. LEXIS 18 (Wyo. 1895).

Prescribe by law. —

Power of the legislature to “prescribe by law” is not unrestricted; laws may be enacted that do not interfere with the constitutional or inherent authority of the courts, but statutes that interfere with that authority are unconstitutional, and this concept is applicable to constitutionally created executive branch offices. Powers v. State, 2014 WY 15, 318 P.3d 300, 2014 Wyo. LEXIS 16 (Wyo. 2014) and Powers v. State, No. 180-673 (1st Jud. Dist. Ct. Apr. 18, 2014).

Duty of court. —

Because the supreme court has general superintending control over all the courts of the state and the Wyoming judicial system in general, it is the court's duty to protect its integrity and prohibit dealing lightly with its proceedings. Allen v. Allen, 550 P.2d 1137, 1976 Wyo. LEXIS 200 (Wyo. 1976).

Superintending control sparingly used. —

It is the policy of this court that the general superintending control given by this section be sparingly used. Mott v. England, 604 P.2d 560, 1979 Wyo. LEXIS 506 (Wyo. 1979).

Courts' right to prescribe rules. —

The courts have inherent rights to prescribe rules, limited only by their reasonableness and conformity to constitutional and legislative enactments that deal with the substantive rights of persons or the jurisdiction of a court. Petersen v. State, 594 P.2d 978, 1979 Wyo. LEXIS 411 (Wyo. 1979).

Superintending control encompasses rulemaking. —

The general superintending control over all inferior courts granted to the supreme court encompasses the authority to prescribe rules of practice and procedure in those courts. White v. Fisher, 689 P.2d 102, 1984 Wyo. LEXIS 341 (Wyo. 1984); Squillace v. Kelley, 990 P.2d 497, 1999 Wyo. LEXIS 173 (Wyo. 1999).

In accord with bound volume. Squillace v. Kelley, 990 P.2d 497, 1999 Wyo. LEXIS 173 (Wyo. 1999).

Supreme court has plenary power to control course of litigation in trial courts. State ex rel. Jones v. District Court, 37 Wyo. 516, 263 P. 700, 1928 Wyo. LEXIS 14 (Wyo. 1928).

Legislative regulation of entry on pleadings. —

The legislature is constitutionally prohibited from enacting statutes specifying the content of or foreclosing material from pleadings, as these are procedural matters. White v. Fisher, 689 P.2d 102, 1984 Wyo. LEXIS 341 (Wyo. 1984).

District employees without property right in employment. —

Because each district court judge has authority over the personnel rules of his or her court, there being no evidence that the Wyoming judicial conference ever adopted the supreme court's personnel rules as a whole to apply to district court employees, retired district court judge's former secretary had no property in her continued employment on the basis of the supreme court rules. Munroe v. Kautz, 833 F. Supp. 854, 1993 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 13660 (D. Wyo. 1993), aff'd, 33 F.3d 62, 1994 U.S. App. LEXIS 30842 (10th Cir. Wyo. 1994).

Right of appeal to supreme court is not guaranteed in all cases. Mau v. Stoner, 14 Wyo. 183, 83 P. 218, 1905 Wyo. LEXIS 41 (Wyo. 1905).

And its jurisdiction is limited. —

The supreme court is essentially a court of review with reference to cases where original jurisdiction is lodged exclusively in a lower court and in that sense its jurisdiction is limited. State v. Kelley, 17 Wyo. 335, 98 P. 886, 1909 Wyo. LEXIS 4 (Wyo. 1909).

Restrictions on right of appeal not permitted. —

The supreme court would be remiss in its duty if it permitted district courts to include provisions in their judgments which might restrict a party's right of appeal or in any manner penalize a party for exercising his right of appeal. Beckle v. Beckle, 452 P.2d 205, 1969 Wyo. LEXIS 125 (Wyo. 1969).

Review of action of district court on appeal from police court. —

Supreme court may issue a writ of certiorari to review the action of the district court in reviewing a conviction for violation of a city ordinance, which was appealed from police court. Sheridan v. Cadle, 24 Wyo. 293, 157 P. 892, 1916 Wyo. LEXIS 33 (Wyo. 1916).

Appeal from judgment entered by district court in vacation. —

An appeal may be taken from a judgment entered by the district court in vacation. Anderson v. Matthews, 8 Wyo. 307, 57 P. 156, 1899 Wyo. LEXIS 13 (Wyo. 1899).

Injunction issued by district court in pending cause. —

The supreme court has no jurisdiction to vacate or modify an injunction issued by the district court in a cause pending before it. Smith v. Healy, 12 Wyo. 218, 75 P. 430, 1904 Wyo. LEXIS 1 (Wyo. 1904).

Test of court's jurisdiction through writ of prohibition inappropriate. —

Since a lower court does have authority to close pretrial hearings under certain circumstances, a test of the court's jurisdiction to do so through an application for writ of prohibition is inappropriate, as the issuance of such a writ is closely guarded so as not to disrupt, unless absolutely necessary, the usual course of judicial proceedings. Williams v. Stafford, 589 P.2d 322, 1979 Wyo. LEXIS 342 (Wyo. 1979), overruled, Vaughn v. State, 962 P.2d 149, 1998 Wyo. LEXIS 97 (Wyo. 1998).

Supreme court cannot supersede statutory jury-trial right through exercise of its rule-making power. Goodman v. State, 644 P.2d 1240, 1982 Wyo. LEXIS 339 (Wyo. 1982).

When constitutionality of statute passed on. —

The constitutionality of a statute will not be passed on unless the decision is necessary to the determination of the pending controversy. State v. Kelley, 17 Wyo. 335, 98 P. 886, 1909 Wyo. LEXIS 4 (Wyo. 1909).

Supreme court is at liberty to decide a case upon any point which the ends of justice require, particularly on a point so fundamental that it must take cognizance of it. Allen v. Allen, 550 P.2d 1137, 1976 Wyo. LEXIS 200 (Wyo. 1976).

Judgment vacated for gross miscarriage of justice. —

An erroneous judgment was vacated, with an order directing the reassignment of the case to another judge, where the supreme court's conclusion as to the privileged nature of documents sought to be produced in discovery was diametrically opposite to that apparently reached by the district court, and the judgment was a gross miscarriage of justice. Continental Ins. Co. v. First Wyo. Bank, N.A. - Jackson Hole, 771 P.2d 374, 1989 Wyo. LEXIS 95 (Wyo. 1989).

Moot case. —

Although a case had become moot in character through lapse of time, under the mandate of this section, the supreme court would consider and dispose of it, where matters of general public interest likely to arise again were concerned, for the guidance of administrative agencies and in order to produce uniformity in the decisions of the special district courts thereafter. Morad v. Wyoming Highway Dep't, 66 Wyo. 12, 203 P.2d 954, 1949 Wyo. LEXIS 1 (Wyo. 1949).

Questions as to bail certified from district court. —

The supreme court has jurisdiction of questions certified from the district court as to whether a person indicted for murder should be admitted to bail. State v. Crocker, 5 Wyo. 385, 40 P. 681, 1895 Wyo. LEXIS 32 (Wyo. 1895).

Modification of verdict in criminal case. —

Modification by appellate court of verdict of murder in second degree to one of manslaughter was authorized and not infringement of due process or right to jury trial. State v. Sorrentino, 36 Wyo. 111, 253 P. 14, 1927 Wyo. LEXIS 14 (Wyo. 1927).

New trial where party deprived of opportunity for review without his fault. —

Where, after instituting proceedings in error in criminal case, defendant was prevented, without fault on his part, from obtaining bill of exceptions through the accidental loss of the testimony by the official stenographer, and a bill of exceptions was necessary to a review of the errors assigned in the motion for a new trial, the supreme court had jurisdiction to vacate the judgment and grant new trial. Richardson v. State, 15 Wyo. 465, 89 P. 1027, 1907 Wyo. LEXIS 29 (Wyo. 1907).

Divorce cases. —

In proceeding in error to review trial court's refusal to grant a divorce, supreme court had jurisdiction to consider a motion for an allowance for the support of wife and child pending the proceedings and for reasonable allowance for expenses. Duxstad v. Duxstad, 16 Wyo. 396, 94 P. 463, 1908 Wyo. LEXIS 30 (Wyo. 1908).

The supreme court may compel a husband, who is prosecuting a proceeding in error to judgment for separate maintenance, to pay his wife reasonable sum for attorney's fees in the appellate court. Brown v. Brown, 22 Wyo. 92, 135 P. 801, 1913 Wyo. LEXIS 38 (Wyo. 1913).

Grounds for dismissal of proceeding before supreme court. —

Failure to file petition in error within the statutory period, after denial of motion for a new trial, is ground for dismissal of proceedings. In re Bosick, 48 Wyo. 46, 41 P.2d 533, 1935 Wyo. LEXIS 21 (Wyo. 1935).

Applied in

Thomas v. Justice Court, 538 P.2d 42, 1975 Wyo. LEXIS 151 (Wyo. 1975); Nicholaus v. Nicholaus, 756 P.2d 1338, 1988 Wyo. LEXIS 95 (Wyo. 1988); Gillis v. F & A Enters., 813 P.2d 1304, 1991 Wyo. LEXIS 111 (Wyo. 1991); Terex Corp. v. Hough, 2002 WY 112, 50 P.3d 317, 2002 Wyo. LEXIS 118 (Wyo. 2002).

Quoted in

Application of Stone, 74 Wyo. 389, 288 P.2d 767, 1955 Wyo. LEXIS 42 (1955); Bi-Rite Package, Inc. v. District Court, 735 P.2d 709, 1987 Wyo. LEXIS 423 (Wyo. 1987); Reynolds v. Bonar, 2013 WY 144, 313 P.3d 501, 2013 Wyo. LEXIS 150, 2013 WL 6122405 (Nov 21, 2013).

Stated in

Hoem v. State, 756 P.2d 780, 1988 Wyo. LEXIS 88 (Wyo. 1988).

Cited in

Murdock v. State, 351 P.2d 674, 1960 Wyo. LEXIS 59 (Wyo. 1960); Katona v. City of Cheyenne, 686 F. Supp. 287, 1988 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 4215 (D. Wyo. 1988); Osborn v. Emporium Videos, 848 P.2d 237, 1993 Wyo. LEXIS 47 (Wyo. 1993); Lowseth v. State, 875 P.2d 725, 1994 Wyo. LEXIS 73 (Wyo. 1994); Kittles v. Rocky Mt. Recovery, Inc., 1 P.3d 1220, 2000 Wyo. LEXIS 77 (Wyo. 2000); Cathcart v. Meyer, 2004 WY 49, 88 P.3d 1050, 2004 Wyo. LEXIS 62 (2004).

Law reviews. —

For article, “Supreme Court Jurisdiction and the Wyoming Constitution: Justice v. Judicial Restraint,” see XX Land & Water L. Rev. 159 (1985).

For comment, “Reforming Criminal Sentencing in Wyoming,” see XX Land & Water L. Rev. 575 (1985).

For case note, “Criminal Procedure — The State's Right to Appeal in Criminal Cases, State v. Heiner, 683 P.2d 629, 1984 Wyo. LEXIS 284 (Wyo. 1984),” see XX Land & Water L. Rev. 723 (1985).

For article, “An Essay on Wyoming Constitutional Interpretation,” see XXI Land & Water L. Rev. 527 (1986).

For case note, “Appeal and Error—The Omnipotent Wyoming Supreme Court: New Allegations and Evidence Will Be Heard for the First Time on Appeal. Boller v. Western Law Associates, 828 P.2d 1184, 1992 Wyo. LEXIS 38 (Wyo. 1992),” see XXVIII Land & Water L. Rev. 677 (1993).

§ 3. Supreme court generally; original jurisdiction.

The supreme court shall have original jurisdiction in quo warranto and mandamus as to all state officers, and in habeas corpus. The supreme court shall also have power to issue writs of mandamus, review, prohibition, habeas corpus, certiorari, and other writs necessary and proper to the complete exercise of its appellate and revisory jurisdiction. Each of the judges shall have power to issue writs of habeas corpus to any part of the state upon petition by or on behalf of a person held in actual custody, and may make such writs returnable before himself or before the supreme court, or before any district court of the state or any judge thereof.

  • I. General Consideration.
  • II. Quo Warranto.
  • III. Mandamus.
  • IV. Habeas Corpus.
  • V. Writ Of Review.
  • VI. Prohibition.
  • VII. Certiorari.
I.General Consideration.

Cross references. —

As to habeas corpus and prerogative writs, see Rule 3, Sup. Ct.

As to writs of prohibition, see Rule 4, Sup. Ct.

Plenary power. —

The supreme court has plenary power to control course of litigation in trial courts. State ex rel. Jones v. District Court, 37 Wyo. 516, 263 P. 700, 1928 Wyo. LEXIS 14 (Wyo. 1928).

Bail pending trial. —

Supreme court has jurisdiction, on question reserved thereto by district court, to determine if an accused should be admitted to bail pending trial. State v. Crocker, 5 Wyo. 385, 40 P. 681, 1895 Wyo. LEXIS 32 (Wyo. 1895).

Order for supersedeas. —

If on motion for supersedeas a district court should refuse to act, or if an appellant should be otherwise prevented from obtaining a timely or effectual order from that court, or bond given should prove unavailing for some reason beyond appellant's control, or without his fault, an order by the supreme court after acquiring jurisdiction might become proper. Farmers' State Bank v. Haun, 29 Wyo. 322, 213 P. 361, 1923 Wyo. LEXIS 13 (Wyo. 1923).

Injunctions. —

On review of an order denying a motion for injunction pendente lite, the supreme court has power to issue restraining order pending the proceeding in error. Weaver v. Richardson, 21 Wyo. 343, 132 P. 1148, 1913 Wyo. LEXIS 20 (Wyo. 1913).

Supreme court has no jurisdiction to vacate or modify a temporary injunction issued by the district court, while cause is pending in such district court. Smith v. Healy, 12 Wyo. 218, 75 P. 430, 1904 Wyo. LEXIS 1 (Wyo. 1904).

Vacating judgment and granting new trial. —

Where, after the institution of proceedings in error in criminal case, defendant was prevented, without fault on his part, from obtaining bill of exceptions through the accidental loss of the testimony by the official stenographer, and a bill of exceptions was necessary to a review of the errors assigned in the motion for a new trial, the supreme court had jurisdiction to vacate judgment and grant new trial. Richardson v. State, 15 Wyo. 465, 89 P. 1027, 1907 Wyo. LEXIS 29 (Wyo. 1907).

Divorce cases. —

The supreme court on review may consider motion for the allowance of support of wife and child and reasonable expenses in a divorce action. Duxstad v. Duxstad, 16 Wyo. 396, 94 P. 463, 1908 Wyo. LEXIS 30 (Wyo. 1908).

The supreme court may compel a husband, on his prosecuting a proceeding in error to a judgment for separate maintenance, to pay his wife reasonable sum for attorneys' fees in the appellate court. Brown v. Brown, 22 Wyo. 92, 135 P. 801, 1913 Wyo. LEXIS 38 (Wyo. 1913).

Limitation on “other writs.” —

The words “necessary and proper to the complete exercise of its appellate and revisory jurisdiction,” in the second sentence, pertain to that which they modify, i.e. to “other writs,” and not to the writs specified in this section (including certiorari). Wright v. State, 670 P.2d 1090, 1983 Wyo. LEXIS 373 (Wyo. 1983), reh'g denied, 707 P.2d 153, 1985 Wyo. LEXIS 575 (Wyo. 1985).

Remedy for failure to set hearing. —

The proper remedy for a failure to set an adjudicatory hearing within the time constraints of §§ 14-6-209 and 14-6-226 is a motion to the juvenile court for a prompt hearing brought by the minor through the guardian ad litem, or brought by the parents, guardians or custodian named in the petition as parties to the proceeding; if such a motion is not acted upon in a timely fashion, then a petition for a writ of habeas corpus may be filed in the supreme court seeking release of the minor. In In Interest of MFB, 860 P.2d 1140, 1993 Wyo. LEXIS 157 (Wyo. 1993).

Applied in

Thomas v. Justice Court, 538 P.2d 42, 1975 Wyo. LEXIS 151 (Wyo. 1975); Wyoming Bancorporation v. Bonham, 563 P.2d 1382, 1977 Wyo. LEXIS 254 (Wyo. 1977); Stogner v. State, 792 P.2d 1358, 1990 Wyo. LEXIS 58 (Wyo. 1990); Barker Bros. v. Barker-Taylor, 823 P.2d 1204, 1992 Wyo. LEXIS 7 (Wyo. 1992); Saunders v. Hornecker, 2015 WY 34, 2015 Wyo. LEXIS 39 (Mar. 5, 2015).

Quoted in

Hamill v. Ferguson, 937 F. Supp. 1517, 1996 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 17115 (D. Wyo. 1996).

Stated in

Whiteley v. Meacham, 416 F.2d 36, 1969 U.S. App. LEXIS 10625 (10th Cir. 1969); State ex rel. Hopkinson v. District Court, 696 P.2d 54, 1985 Wyo. LEXIS 455 (Wyo. 1985).

Cited in

State ex rel. R.R. Crow & Co. v. Copenhaver, 64 Wyo. 1, 184 P.2d 594, 1947 Wyo. LEXIS 24 (1947); State ex rel. Pearson v. Hansen, 401 P.2d 954, 1965 Wyo. LEXIS 140 (Wyo. 1965); State ex rel. Wyo. Ass'n of Consulting Eng'rs & Land Surveyors v. Sullivan, 798 P.2d 826, 1990 Wyo. LEXIS 116 (Wyo. 1990).

Law reviews. —

For article, “Supreme Court Jurisdiction and the Wyoming Constitution: Justice v. Judicial Restraint,” see XX Land & Water L. Rev. 159 (1985).

For article, “Basic Appellate Practice: A Guide to Perfecting an Appeal in Wyoming,” see XX Land & Water L. Rev. 537 (1985).

For case note, “Criminal Procedure — The State's Right to Appeal in Criminal Cases, State v. Heiner, 683 P.2d 629, 1984 Wyo. LEXIS 284 (Wyo. 1984),” see XX Land & Water L. Rev. 723 (1985).

For article, “An Essay on Wyoming Constitutional Interpretation,” see XXI Land & Water L. Rev. 527 (1986).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Availability of writ of prohibition or similar remedy against acts of public prosecutor, 16 ALR4th 112.

Civil actions removable from state court to federal court under 28 U.S.C. § 1443, 159 ALR Fed 377.

II.Quo Warranto.

Quo warranto is limited to state officers, when issued by the supreme court. In re Board of Comm'rs, 4 Wyo. 133, 32 P. 850 (Wyo. 1893).

Contesting election of district judge. —

Original jurisdiction of supreme court in quo warranto for the purpose of contesting the election of district judge is not exclusive and should be exercised only in those cases where it is shown that it is necessary or proper that the writ should issue originally from supreme court. State ex rel. Walton v. Christmas, 48 Wyo. 239, 44 P.2d 905, 1935 Wyo. LEXIS 30 (Wyo. 1935).

If quo warranto to contest the election of district judge should be filed in the district court, the judge, being disqualified, would be obliged to call in another judge and his refusal to do so would be ground for appropriate proceeding in supreme court to require him to do so. State ex rel. Walton v. Christmas, 48 Wyo. 239, 44 P.2d 905, 1935 Wyo. LEXIS 30 (Wyo. 1935).

Legal right to office must affirmatively appear. —

In quo warranto to determine right and title to office, legal right of the relator to the office must affirmatively appear, without any presumption in favor of respondent who has forcibly obtained possession. People ex rel. Emerson v. Shawver, 30 Wyo. 366, 222 P. 11, 1924 Wyo. LEXIS 69 (Wyo. 1924).

III.Mandamus.

Supreme court has original jurisdiction in mandamus. State ex rel. Wyoming Agric. College v. Irvine, 14 Wyo. 318, 84 P. 90, 1906 Wyo. LEXIS 18 (Wyo. 1906), aff'd, 206 U.S. 278, 27 S. Ct. 613, 51 L. Ed. 1063, 1907 U.S. LEXIS 1163 (U.S. 1907).

Statute authorizing single judge to issue writ is valid. —

Statute allowing a single judge, in the first instance, to issue a writ of mandamus, was not repugnant to the constitution. State ex rel. Bennett v. Barber, 4 Wyo. 56, 32 P. 14, 1892 Wyo. LEXIS 27 (Wyo. 1892).

Mandamus lies against all state officers. —

The power of the courts to compel “all state officers” to perform their duties is recognized in this section and § 10 of this article, which confer jurisdiction upon the courts in mandamus as to such officers. State ex rel. Whitehead v. Gage, 377 P.2d 299, 1963 Wyo. LEXIS 66 (Wyo. 1963).

When court has power to issue writ not directed to state officer. —

Supreme court has power to issue writs of mandamus, except as to state officers, only in cases where such writs are necessary to complete exercise of appellate and revisory jurisdiction, since general words, followed by words of specific meaning, are limited in their application to matters of the same nature, included in the meaning of the specific words, and since any other construction would render the first clause of the section redundant, and of no effect. State ex rel. School Dist. v. Clay, 3 Wyo. 393, 31 P. 409, 1890 Wyo. LEXIS 14 (Wyo. 1890).

Compelling governor to perform ministerial duty. —

Supreme court has jurisdiction to issue mandamus to compel the governor to perform a ministerial duty. State ex rel. Irvine v. Brooks, 14 Wyo. 393, 84 P. 488, 1906 Wyo. LEXIS 19 (Wyo. 1906).

State auditor is subject to mandamus under this section, and under sections of the statute relating to mandamus, where there is no adequate remedy at law. State ex rel. Jeffrey v. Burdick, 3 Wyo. 588, 28 P. 146, 1891 Wyo. LEXIS 16 (Wyo. 1891).

As is the secretary of state. —

Mandamus will lie to compel the secretary of state to countersign and affix the seal of the state to an appointment made to state office by the governor. State ex rel. Miller v. Barber, 4 Wyo. 409, 34 P. 1028, 1893 Wyo. LEXIS 22 (Wyo. 1893).

IV.Habeas Corpus.

Supreme court has been invested with original jurisdiction in habeas corpus by the constitution. Ex parte Bergman, 3 Wyo. 396, 26 P. 914, 1890 Wyo. LEXIS 13 (Wyo. 1890).

A writ of habeas corpus in all restraint cases, including child-custody cases, may be filed in the supreme court of Wyoming although the issuance of a similar writ may have been refused by a district court. State ex rel. Klopotek v. District Court, 621 P.2d 223, 1980 Wyo. LEXIS 325 (Wyo. 1980).

Showing required. —

While the supreme court has original jurisdiction to entertain applications for writs of habeas corpus pursuant to this section, it does not do so unless a showing is made of circumstances which render it necessary or proper that the writ if granted should issue originally from the supreme court. Ostwald v. State, 538 P.2d 1298, 1975 Wyo. LEXIS 156 (Wyo. 1975).

Exhausting state remedies for federal habeas corpus purposes. —

A petitioner does not effect a fair presentation of a claim of ineffective assistance of appellate counsel, for federal habeas exhaustion purposes, by raising that issue for the first time in a petition for a writ of certiorari to the state supreme court to reinstate his direct appeal. Parkhurst v. Shillinger, 128 F.3d 1366, 1997 U.S. App. LEXIS 29095 (10th Cir. Wyo. 1997).

Probable cause must be shown. —

The court is not bound, in the first instance, to issue the writ of habeas corpus as of course. Probable cause must first be shown to obtain it. Ex parte Bergman, 3 Wyo. 396, 26 P. 914, 1890 Wyo. LEXIS 13 (Wyo. 1890).

Inquiry into jurisdictional matters. —

One of the provisos of habeas corpus proceedings is to inquire into jurisdictional matters. State ex rel. Klopotek v. District Court, 621 P.2d 223, 1980 Wyo. LEXIS 325 (Wyo. 1980).

Unless a court has exceeded its jurisdiction, its decision is not subject to attack by means of a writ of habeas corpus, no matter how erroneous it may appear. Miskimins v. Shaver, 8 Wyo. 392, 58 P. 411, 1899 Wyo. LEXIS 18 (Wyo. 1899).

Custody of infants. —

District court has unqualified jurisdiction to issue habeas corpus writs for the custody of infants. Tytler v. Tytler, 15 Wyo. 319, 89 P. 1, 1907 Wyo. LEXIS 13 (Wyo. 1907).

Appeal available in child-custody cases. —

An appeal is available from action taken in a habeas corpus proceeding in child-custody cases. State ex rel. Klopotek v. District Court, 621 P.2d 223, 1980 Wyo. LEXIS 325 (Wyo. 1980).

But denial of petition is nonappealable determination. —

Normally, a person may petition for a writ of habeas corpus again and again to the same or other courts, each denial thereof being a nonappealable determination. State ex rel. Klopotek v. District Court, 621 P.2d 223, 1980 Wyo. LEXIS 325 (Wyo. 1980).

Person illegally confined in insane asylum. —

Statute, providing a proceeding in the original court of commitment whereby one who has been adjudged insane, and who is alleged to have been restored to his right mind may have his restoration to capacity adjudged, does not divest the courts of jurisdiction to issue writs of habeas corpus in behalf of those illegally confined in an insane asylum. Byers v. Solier, 16 Wyo. 232, 93 P. 59, 1907 Wyo. LEXIS 48 (Wyo. 1907).

V.Writ Of Review.

Jurisdiction remains inactive until statutory method of procedure prescribed. —

The jurisdiction of a writ of review, authorized by this section, for the purpose of a reexamination of issues of law and fact, remains inactive until a statutory method of procedure has been prescribed. Kelsey v. District Court, 22 Wyo. 297, 139 P. 433, 1914 Wyo. LEXIS 12 (Wyo. 1914).

Writ proper. —

In defendant's aggravated assault case, where the district court concluded that the prosecution's conduct provided grounds for a mistrial, granted the defense motion, and dismissed the case with prejudice on the basis of speedy trial concerns, the State's writ of review was appropriate. The State had no other adequate remedy, the issues presented were of constitutional magnitude and public importance, and it was not established that allowing the writ would place defendant in jeopardy for a second time. State v. Newman, 2004 WY 41, 88 P.3d 445, 2004 Wyo. LEXIS 48 (Wyo. 2004).

VI.Prohibition.

Nature of power. —

Power granted the supreme court to issue writs of prohibition has reference to the writ as known at common law, and is confined to cases where act sought to be prohibited is of a judicial nature. Dobson v. Westheimer, 5 Wyo. 34, 36 P. 626, 1894 Wyo. LEXIS 13 (Wyo. 1894).

Object of a writ of prohibition is to restrain the action of inferior courts in excess of their jurisdiction. State ex rel. Pearson v. Hansen, 409 P.2d 769, 1966 Wyo. LEXIS 126 (Wyo. 1966).

Writ of prohibition is most appropriately granted when the inferior court lacks subject-matter jurisdiction. State ex rel. Peterson v. District Court, 617 P.2d 1056, 1980 Wyo. LEXIS 302 (Wyo. 1980).

A writ of prohibition is appropriate to prevent a district court from exercising subject-matter jurisdiction forbidden to it by federal law. State ex rel. Peterson v. District Court, 617 P.2d 1056, 1980 Wyo. LEXIS 302 (Wyo. 1980).

Writ of prohibition is a discretionary writ and not one of right. State ex rel. Pearson v. Hansen, 409 P.2d 769, 1966 Wyo. LEXIS 126 (Wyo. 1966); State ex rel. Weber v. Municipal Court of Jackson, 567 P.2d 698, 1977 Wyo. LEXIS 311 (Wyo. 1977).

Which is not favored. —

A writ of prohibition is not favored and is issued with caution. State ex rel. Pearson v. Hansen, 409 P.2d 769, 1966 Wyo. LEXIS 126 (Wyo. 1966); State ex rel. Weber v. Municipal Court of Jackson, 567 P.2d 698, 1977 Wyo. LEXIS 311 (Wyo. 1977).

And it should not be issued if there is other adequate means of redress. State ex rel. Pearson v. Hansen, 409 P.2d 769, 1966 Wyo. LEXIS 126 (Wyo. 1966).

A writ of prohibition is ordinarily granted only where there is no adequate remedy at law. State ex rel. Peterson v. District Court, 617 P.2d 1056, 1980 Wyo. LEXIS 302 (Wyo. 1980).

A writ of prohibition is not granted if the petitioner has available some other plain, speedy and adequate remedy, which normally encompasses review on appeal after trial. State ex rel. Weber v. Municipal Court of Jackson, 567 P.2d 698, 1977 Wyo. LEXIS 311 (Wyo. 1977).

Since it is disruptive. —

A writ of prohibition results in a disruption of the usual course of legal proceedings. State ex rel. Weber v. Municipal Court of Jackson, 567 P.2d 698, 1977 Wyo. LEXIS 311 (Wyo. 1977).

Supreme court has jurisdiction to restrain by prohibition the action of inferior courts in excess of their jurisdiction. State ex rel. Mau v. Ausherman, 11 Wyo. 410, 72 P. 200, 1903 Wyo. LEXIS 15 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 11 Wyo. 410, 73 P. 548, 1903 Wyo. LEXIS 16 (Wyo. 1903).

When supreme court to issue writ of prohibition. —

The supreme court will only exercise its power to issue a writ of prohibition in those circumstances where the trial court seeks to act without subject-matter jurisdiction, or where the trial court attempts to exceed the scope of its jurisdiction although having jurisdiction over the subject matter, and only in circumstances where the petitioner has no other plain, speedy and adequate remedy. Osborne v. District Court of Ninth Judicial Dist., 654 P.2d 124, 1982 Wyo. LEXIS 404 (Wyo. 1982).

Writ of prohibition tests jurisdiction of lower court, and is available only if no jurisdiction of the subject matter has been afforded to that court, or if having that subject-matter jurisdiction it in some manner exceeds the scope thereof. State ex rel. Weber v. Municipal Court of Jackson, 567 P.2d 698, 1977 Wyo. LEXIS 311 (Wyo. 1977).

Exceptional or extraordinary circumstances may justify issuance of writ of prohibition. State ex rel. Weber v. Municipal Court of Jackson, 567 P.2d 698, 1977 Wyo. LEXIS 311 (Wyo. 1977).

Court has no jurisdiction to issue writ against state engineer. —

Supreme court has no original jurisdiction to issue writ of prohibition against state engineer to restrain him from holding a threatened hearing seeking to cancel a permit to construct a reservoir, the state engineer not being an “inferior court” within the constitution. State ex rel. Leazenby v. True, 26 Wyo. 314, 184 P. 229, 1919 Wyo. LEXIS 22 (Wyo. 1919).

Adequate remedy by application to court in course of appeal. —

Prohibition will not lie to prevent court requiring party garnishing judgment debtors to give judgment creditors bond, application to court in course of appeal being adequate remedy. State ex rel. Jones v. District Court, 37 Wyo. 516, 263 P. 700, 1928 Wyo. LEXIS 14 (Wyo. 1928).

Right of appeal from final orders and judgments is usually adequate remedy, especially if there is no showing of harassment or that undue hardship would result, or that no apparent cause of action has been asserted. State ex rel. Weber v. Municipal Court of Jackson, 567 P.2d 698, 1977 Wyo. LEXIS 311 (Wyo. 1977).

Mistake not justifying resort to prohibition. —

A mistaken exercise of jurisdiction or of its acknowledged powers by an inferior court will not justify resort to the extraordinary remedy of prohibition. State ex rel. Weber v. Municipal Court of Jackson, 567 P.2d 698, 1977 Wyo. LEXIS 311 (Wyo. 1977).

An error or mistake in practice affords no foundation for the writ of prohibition unless it involves the doing of something which is contrary to the laws of the land. State ex rel. Weber v. Municipal Court of Jackson, 567 P.2d 698, 1977 Wyo. LEXIS 311 (Wyo. 1977).

VII.Certiorari.

Common-law writ. —

The writ of certiorari is a common-law writ, and under the power conferred by the constitution, the supreme court has authority to issue it, at least in cases not coming within the operation of the statute abolishing it, subject to the conditions and limitations controlling the writ at common law. Sheridan v. Cadle, 24 Wyo. 293, 157 P. 892, 1916 Wyo. LEXIS 33 (Wyo. 1916).

Writ of certiorari is not one of right, and its issuance is discretionary with the court, though such discretion should not be exercised arbitrarily or capriciously. Sheridan v. Cadle, 24 Wyo. 293, 157 P. 892, 1916 Wyo. LEXIS 33 (Wyo. 1916).

Considering notice of appeal as petition for writ of certiorari. —

There is no inhibition in the court rules, the state constitution or any legislative mandate that precludes the supreme court from, on its own motion, considering a notice of appeal as a petition for writ of certiorari and proceeding with review on that basis. Whenever the court determines that review by certiorari is in the best interest of the state, or its citizens, it may be invoked. In re General Adjudication of All Rights to Use Water, 803 P.2d 61, 1990 Wyo. LEXIS 140 (Wyo. 1990).

Although a district court's order annulling a municipal candidate's election was not appealable because it granted only partial summary judgment and was not certified as immediately appealable by the district court, the supreme court converted the notice of appeal into a writ of review because the issues raised presented questions of significant state importance. Smith v. Brito, 2007 WY 191, 173 P.3d 351, 2007 Wyo. LEXIS 203 (Wyo. 2007).

Important state question or issue of public significance. —

The supreme court's power of certiorari is invoked when a case from a lower court involves an important state question or is of sufficient public significance to justify a determination by the supreme court. In re General Adjudication of All Rights to Use Water, 803 P.2d 61, 1990 Wyo. LEXIS 140 (Wyo. 1990).

Certiorari should be granted without hesitation when the timely resolution of matters coming to the supreme court's attention is of extreme and lasting importance to the citizens of the state and may contribute to judicial efficiency. In re General Adjudication of All Rights to Use Water, 803 P.2d 61, 1990 Wyo. LEXIS 140 (Wyo. 1990).

Rule 13.02 (now see Rule 13.01), W.R.A.P, should be followed by litigants who seek a writ of certiorari, but it is not binding on the supreme court when it elects to grant the writ on its own motion. In re General Adjudication of All Rights to Use Water, 803 P.2d 61, 1990 Wyo. LEXIS 140 (Wyo. 1990).

Existence of another adequate remedy. —

Writ of certiorari is not ordinarily granted if there is another plain, speedy and adequate remedy and if there is no question of jurisdiction or excess thereof. Call v. Afton, 73 Wyo. 271, 278 P.2d 270, 1954 Wyo. LEXIS 21 (Wyo. 1954).

The writ will not as a rule be granted where other adequate remedies are open to the petitioner. Sheridan v. Cadle, 24 Wyo. 293, 157 P. 892, 1916 Wyo. LEXIS 33 (Wyo. 1916).

Review pursuant to certiorari is never granted lightly, especially if an adequate alternative remedy is available. In re General Adjudication of All Rights to Use Water, 803 P.2d 61, 1990 Wyo. LEXIS 140 (Wyo. 1990).

The grant of a writ of certiorari not sought by petition is rare, and it will not serve as a substitute for a proper appeal if that is the appropriate remedy. In re General Adjudication of All Rights to Use Water, 803 P.2d 61, 1990 Wyo. LEXIS 140 (Wyo. 1990).

Where no appeal provided. —

A writ of certiorari would seem ordinarily not to be improper in cases in which no appeal has been provided from proceedings before a judicial or quasi judicial tribunal, at least in cases in which such tribunal had no jurisdiction or acted in excess of jurisdiction. Call v. Afton, 73 Wyo. 271, 278 P.2d 270, 1954 Wyo. LEXIS 21 (Wyo. 1954).

Where right of appeal has been lost. —

Where petitioners had entered an appeal from a judgment of the district court denying them the right to water service from a town, and had withdrawn their appeal in reliance on the oral promise of the town officers that their property would be annexed to the town, which promise was not kept, certiorari would not issue to review the judgment of the district court, since no question of jurisdiction was involved, the remedy by appeal from the judgment of the district court was plain, speedy and adequate, and the loss of such remedy by failure to perfect the appeal was due in part at least to petitioners' own fault. Call v. Afton, 73 Wyo. 271, 278 P.2d 270, 1954 Wyo. LEXIS 21 (Wyo. 1954).

Review action of district court on appeal from conviction in municipal court. —

The supreme court had authority to issue a writ of certiorari to review the action of the district court in reviewing a conviction in a municipal court for violation of a city ordinance, where the contention was that the district court had no jurisdiction of the appeal.
