No person qualified to be an elector of the State of Wyoming, shall be allowed to vote at any general or special election hereafter to be holden in the state, until he or she shall have registered as a voter according to law, unless the failure to register is caused by sickness or absence, for which provisions shall be made by law. The legislature of the state shall enact such laws as will carry into effect the provisions of this section, which enactment shall be subject to amendment, but shall never be repealed; but this section shall not apply to the first election held under this constitution.

Cross references. —

For other provisions concerning voter registration, see ch. 3 of title 22.

Section not violated. —

The failure of the legislature to provide in ch. 17, Laws 1950, for a special registration for a special election on issuance of bonds by an improvement district did not contravene this section. In re West Highway Sanitary & Improvement Dist., 77 Wyo. 384, 317 P.2d 495, 1957 Wyo. LEXIS 29 (Wyo. 1957).

Quoted in

State ex rel. Keefe v. McInerney, 63 Wyo. 280, 182 P.2d 28, 1947 Wyo. LEXIS 15 (1947); Thomson v. Wyoming In-Stream Flow Comm., 651 P.2d 778, 1982 Wyo. LEXIS 387 (Wyo. 1982).

Cited in

School Dist. v. Cook, 424 P.2d 751, 1967 Wyo. LEXIS 144 (Wyo. 1967).

Law reviews. —

For case note, “Administrative Law — Initiative and Referendum. Initiative Petitions in Wyoming — The Presumption of Validity and the Secretary of State's Review. Thomson v. Wyoming In-Stream Flow Comm., 651 P.2d 778, 1982 Wyo. LEXIS 387 (Wyo. 1982),” see XVIII Land & Water L. Rev. 857 (1983). Elections

§ 13. Purity of elections to be provided for.

The legislature shall pass laws to secure the purity of elections, and guard against abuses of the elective franchise.

Cross references. —

For regulation of campaign practices, see chapter 25 of title 22.

For other offenses and penalties, see ch. 26 of title 22.

Quoted in

Thomson v. Wyoming In-Stream Flow Comm., 651 P.2d 778, 1982 Wyo. LEXIS 387 (Wyo. 1982).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Actionability, under 42 USC § 1983, of claim arising out of maladministration of election, 66 ALR Fed 750.

§ 14. Election contests.

The legislature shall, by general law, designate the courts by which the several classes of election contests not otherwise provided for, shall be tried, and regulate the manner of trial and all matters incident thereto; but no such law shall apply to any contest arising out of an election held before its passage.

Cross references. —

For other provisions concerning election contests, see chapter 17 of title 22.

Amendment of petition. —

New and separate causes of contest set forth in an amended petition are barred where the amendment was not filed within the time required by statute for instituting election contests. Turner v. Hamilton, 13 Wyo. 408, 80 P. 664, 1905 Wyo. LEXIS 15 (Wyo. 1905).

§ 15. Qualifications for office.

No person except a qualified elector shall be elected or appointed to any civil or military office in the state. “Military office” shall be limited to the offices of adjutant general, assistant adjutant general for the army national guard and assistant adjutant general for the air national guard. (As amended by Laws 1999, Senate Joint Resolution No. 3, § 1.)

Cross references. —

As to qualified electors, see §§ 22-1-102(a)(xxvi) and 22-3-102.

Amendments. —

Laws 1999, Senate Joint Resolution No. 3, § 1, authorized the submission of a proposed amendment of this section, which was approved by vote of the people at the general election held November 7, 2000, and declared in effect November 15, 2000.

The 1999 amendment added the second sentence.

Laws 2000, House Enrolled Joint Resolution No. 1, § 1, repealed Laws 1999, Senate Enrolled Joint Resolution No. 2, which proposed an identical amendment to the amendment proposed to this section by Laws 1999, Senate Enrolled Joint Resolution No. 3.

Assistant adjutant generals. —

State of Wyoming's newly enacted residency requirement for the position of assistant adjutant general (AAG) of the Wyoming national guard violates the Privileges and Immunities Clause, and consequently, removal of two officers from their positions as AAGs violated the United States Constitution, for which the proper remedy was reinstatement. Nelson v. Geringer, 295 F.3d 1082, 2002 U.S. App. LEXIS 13267 (10th Cir. Wyo. 2002).

City manager. —

Since the position of city manager is an “office” within meaning of this section, a provision that he need not be a qualified elector “of the municipality or of this state” is invalid. State ex rel. Diers v. Sheldon, 29 Wyo. 233, 213 P. 92, 1923 Wyo. LEXIS 11 (Wyo. 1923).

Applied in

Cathcart v. Meyer, 2004 WY 49, 88 P.3d 1050, 2004 Wyo. LEXIS 62 (2004).

Quoted in

Crawford v. City of Sheridan, 392 P.2d 519, 1964 Wyo. LEXIS 102 (Wyo. 1964).

§ 16. When officers to hold over; suspension of officers.

Every person holding any civil office under the state or any municipality therein shall, unless removed according to law, exercise the duties of such office until his successor is duly qualified, but this shall not apply to members of the legislature, nor to members of any board or assembly, two or more of whom are elected at the same time. The legislature may by law provide for suspending any officer in his functions, pending impeachment or prosecution for misconduct in office.

Cross references. —

As to authority of governor to suspend officer pending impeachment, see § 9-1-203.

As to suspension of governor pending impeachment, see § 9-1-214.

Words “civil office under the state” import an office in which is reposed some portion of the sovereign power of the state, and, of necessity, having some connection with the legislative, judicial or executive department of the government. Wyoming. Geraud v. Schrader, 531 P.2d 872, 1975 Wyo. LEXIS 128 (Wyo.), cert. denied, 423 U.S. 904, 96 S. Ct. 205, 46 L. Ed. 2d 134, 1975 U.S. LEXIS 3003 (U.S. 1975).

Justices of the peace are civil officers under the state within the meaning of this section, and are entitled to hold office until their successors qualify. Ballantyne v. Bower, 17 Wyo. 356, 99 P. 869, 1909 Wyo. LEXIS 6 (Wyo. 1909).

Members of livestock and sanitary board hold civil office under state and hold their offices for 6 years and until their successors are appointed and have qualified. People ex rel. Warren v. Christian, 58 Wyo. 39, 123 P.2d 368, 1942 Wyo. LEXIS 12 (Wyo. 1942).

State engineer appointed to fill vacancy is entitled to hold office until the appointment and qualification of a successor. People ex rel. Emerson v. Shawver, 30 Wyo. 366, 222 P. 11, 1924 Wyo. LEXIS 69 (Wyo. 1924).

When vacancy exists. —

Under this provision there is no vacancy in office, so as to enable governor to appoint successor without consent of senate, so long as a qualified person is in possession of the office. People ex rel. Warren v. Christian, 58 Wyo. 39, 123 P.2d 368, 1942 Wyo. LEXIS 12 (Wyo. 1942).

Under statute providing term of office shall be 6 years and “until successors are appointed and qualified,” no vacancy in office exists enabling governor to appoint successor without consent of senate while qualified person is in possession of office. People ex rel. Warren v. Christian, 58 Wyo. 39, 123 P.2d 368, 1942 Wyo. LEXIS 12 (Wyo. 1942).

Right to hold over. —

Where appointment to public office by governor is not confirmed by senate as required by statute, appointment is ineffective and invalid, and incumbent may hold over until his successor is properly appointed and confirmed. People ex rel. Warren v. Christian, 58 Wyo. 39, 123 P.2d 368, 1942 Wyo. LEXIS 12 (Wyo. 1942).

“Successor” defined. —

“Successor” held to mean one legally chosen. Ballantyne v. Bower, 17 Wyo. 356, 99 P. 869, 1909 Wyo. LEXIS 6 (Wyo. 1909).

Death of hold-over member. —

Where governor's appointment of new member to livestock and sanitary board was invalid because not confirmed by senate, death of hold-over member created vacancy which governor could fill by appointment, with new appointee standing in shoes of deceased. People ex rel. Warren v. Christian, 58 Wyo. 39, 123 P.2d 368, 1942 Wyo. LEXIS 12 (Wyo. 1942).

Abandonment. —

Failure of incumbents to bring quo warranto until eight months after invalid appointments of new board members and after annual meeting did not show loss of offices by “abandonment.” People ex rel. Warren v. Christian, 58 Wyo. 39, 123 P.2d 368, 1942 Wyo. LEXIS 12 (Wyo. 1942).

Where governor's appointment to public office was invalid because there was no vacancy, but the old officer acquiesced in governor's appointee occupying his office, the former abandoned and vacated office and new appointee stood in his shoes as hold-over incumbent. People ex rel. Warren v. Christian, 58 Wyo. 39, 123 P.2d 368, 1942 Wyo. LEXIS 12 (Wyo. 1942).

Acquiescence. —

Where former member of livestock and sanitary board acquiesced in appointment of successor for more than two and 1/2 years, he lost all rights to office which he might otherwise have had as hold-over incumbent. People ex rel. Warren v. Christian, 58 Wyo. 39, 123 P.2d 368, 1942 Wyo. LEXIS 12 (Wyo. 1942).

Prospective appointments. —

Mere fact term of office of livestock and sanitary board member did not expire until after adjournment of legislature did not prevent prospective appointment followed by concurrence by senate. People ex rel. Warren v. Christian, 58 Wyo. 39, 123 P.2d 368, 1942 Wyo. LEXIS 12 (Wyo. 1942).

Effect of governor's failure to send name of appointee to legislature. —

Where a statute provided that a vacancy in the office of state examiner should be filled by appointment by the governor until the next meeting of the legislature, and upon the resignation of the state examiner the governor appointed a person to fill the vacancy, but did not send the name of the appointee or of any other person to the next session of the legislature for confirmation, the person so appointed held over under this section, and no vacancy thereafter existed which could be filled by appointment. State ex rel. Richardson v. Henderson, 4 Wyo. 535, 35 P. 517, 1894 Wyo. LEXIS 8 (Wyo. 1894).

Governor's neglect to send name of appointee to senate did not deprive him of the power thereafter to appoint. People ex rel. Emerson v. Shawver, 30 Wyo. 366, 222 P. 11, 1924 Wyo. LEXIS 69 (Wyo. 1924).

§ 17. Time of holding general and special elections; when elected officers to enter upon duties.

All general elections for state and county officers, for members of the house of representatives and the senate of the State of Wyoming, and representatives to the congress of the United States, shall be held on the Tuesday next following the first Monday in November of each even year. Special elections may be held as now, or may hereafter be provided by law. All state and county officers elected at a general election shall enter upon their respective duties on the first Monday in January next following the date of their election, or as soon thereafter as may be possible.

Cross references. —

For another provision establishing the date of general elections, see § 22-2-104.

For another provision concerning when elected county and state officers assume their duties, see § 22-2-107.

Eligibility to office is a continuing requirement, and an officer who is qualified at the time of the election but who is not qualified at the time of the commencement of his term cannot hold the office. State ex rel. Willis v. Larson, 539 P.2d 352, 1975 Wyo. LEXIS 157 (Wyo. 1975).

Person elected to office entitled to full term. —

Where term of elective office is fixed by constitution or statute without time being established for its beginning or ending, a person elected to office is entitled to hold for the period established as full term, whether elected upon happening of a casual vacancy or at expiration of a complete term. State ex rel. Irvine v. Brooks, 14 Wyo. 393, 84 P. 488, 1906 Wyo. LEXIS 19 (Wyo. 1906).

Term of state treasurer where elected after appointment to fill vacancy. —

Where a person appointed to fill a vacancy in the office of state treasurer is afterward elected to the office at a general election held before the term of his predecessor would have expired, he is not entitled to hold the office for 4 years after such election, but only for the remainder of his predecessor's term. State ex rel. Irvine v. Brooks, 14 Wyo. 393, 84 P. 488, 1906 Wyo. LEXIS 19 (Wyo. 1906).

Person elected to fill a vacancy in the office of governor on Tuesday next after the first Monday of November, 1892, was elected at a general election. In re Moore, 4 Wyo. 98, 31 P. 980, 1893 Wyo. LEXIS 3 (Wyo. 1893).

District judges may be elected at any general election where a vacancy will exist before the next general election. State ex rel. Burdick v. Schnitger, 17 Wyo. 65, 96 P. 238, 1908 Wyo. LEXIS 7 (Wyo. 1908).

Justices of the peace are county officers and their terms of office, when elected at a general election, commence on the first Monday of the following January. Ballantyne v. Bower, 17 Wyo. 356, 99 P. 869, 1909 Wyo. LEXIS 6 (Wyo. 1909).

§ 18. Method of selecting officers whose election is not provided for.

All officers, whose election is not provided for in this constitution, shall be elected or appointed as may be directed by law.

State engineer appointed to fill a vacancy is entitled to hold office until a new appointment is made and has been confirmed. People ex rel. Emerson v. Shawver, 30 Wyo. 366, 222 P. 11, 1924 Wyo. LEXIS 69 (Wyo. 1924).

Judges of the district court elected at general elections are entitled to hold office for the full term of six years. State ex rel. Burdick v. Schnitger, 17 Wyo. 65, 96 P. 238, 1908 Wyo. LEXIS 7 (Wyo. 1908).

Effect of military service. —

A district judge who during term of office, entered the service of the United States as a major in advocate general's department, upon returning to and resuming the office of district judge, was a de jure and not a de facto judge, where he had not resigned and his office had not been declared vacant and no successor had qualified. State ex rel. Raymond v. Jefferis, 26 Wyo. 115, 178 P. 909, 1919 Wyo. LEXIS 4 (Wyo. 1919).

§ 19. Dual office holding.

No member of congress from this state, nor any person holding or exercising any office or appointment of trust or profit under the United States, shall at the same time hold or exercise any office in this state to which a salary, fees or perquisites shall be attached. The legislature may by law declare what offices are incompatible.

Special prosecutor. —

In a defendant's murder case, there was nothing in the record to suggest that the presence of an Assistant United States Attorney, who had been appointed as a special prosecutor, affected the trial proceedings in any manner so as to impede the defendant's right to a fair trial, where the defendant offered only unsupported allegations. Belden v. State, 2003 WY 89, 73 P.3d 1041, 2003 Wyo. LEXIS 110 (Wyo. 2003), reh'g denied, 2003 Wyo. LEXIS 126 (Wyo. Aug. 26, 2003), cert. denied, 540 U.S. 1165, 124 S. Ct. 1179, 157 L. Ed. 2d 1212, 2004 U.S. LEXIS 898 (U.S. 2004).

Cited in

Cathcart v. Meyer, 2004 WY 49, 88 P.3d 1050, 2004 Wyo. LEXIS 62 (2004).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Validity, construction and effect of state statutes restricting political activities of public officers or employees, 51 ALR4th 702.

§ 20. Oath of office; form.

Senators and representatives and all judicial, state and county officers shall, before entering on the duties of their respective offices, take and subscribe the following oath or affirmation: “I do solemnly swear (or affirm) that I will support, obey and defend the constitution of the United States, and the constitution of the state of Wyoming; that I have not knowingly violated any law related to my election or appointment, or caused it to be done by others; and that I will discharge the duties of my office with fidelity.”

Editor's notes. —

Laws 2007, Senate Joint Resolution No. 3, approved March 1, 2007, authorized the submission of a proposed amendment of this section, which was approved by vote of the people at the general election held November 4, 2008, and certified November 12, 2008.

The 2008 amendment clarified and modernized the oath of office taken by all elected and appointed officials of whom the oath is required.

Cited in

Scott v. Ward, 49 Wyo. 243, 54 P.2d 805, 1936 Wyo. LEXIS 41 (1936).

Law reviews. —

For article, “A Loyalty Oath for Candidates,” see 5 Wyo. L.J. 146.

For article, “No Home On the Range for Home Rule,” see XXXI Land & Water L. Rev. 791 (1996).

§ 21. Oath of office; how administered.

The foregoing oath shall be administered by some person authorized to administer oaths, and in the case of state officers and judges of the supreme court shall be filed in the office of the secretary of state, and in the case of other judicial and county officers in the office of the clerk of the county in which the same is taken; any person refusing to take said oath or affirmation shall forfeit his office, and any person who shall be convicted of having sworn or affirmed falsely, or of having violated said oath or affirmation, shall be guilty of perjury, and be forever disqualified from holding any office of trust or profit within this state. The oath to members of the senate and house of representatives shall be administered by one of the judges of the supreme court or a justice of the peace, in the hall of the house to which the members shall be elected.

Cross references. —

As to officers authorized to administer oaths, see § 1-2-102 and notes thereunder.

Nature of duties imposed by law. —

When duties are imposed upon a public officer, such as a county clerk, by law rather than by some appointing power, such duties are usually governmental and not ministerial. Denver Buick v. Pearson, 465 P.2d 512, 1970 Wyo. LEXIS 157 (Wyo. 1970).

Cited in

Scott v. Ward, 49 Wyo. 243, 54 P.2d 805, 1936 Wyo. LEXIS 41 (1936).

§ 22. Absent voter ballots, voting and registration.

The provisions of section 11 of article 6 of this constitution, which provides that the ballots therein mentioned shall be delivered on election day to the voters within the polling place by sworn public officials, and that only such ballots so delivered shall be received and counted, shall not be applicable to, affect or invalidate absent voter ballots and voting thereof and registration therefor, as provided by article 14, of chapter 36, Wyoming Revised Statutes, 1931, and other acts of the legislature of the State of Wyoming, amendatory thereof or related thereto, whether heretofore or hereafter enacted. (As added by Laws 1944, Sp. Sess., ch. 3.)

Cross references. —

For other provisions concerning absentee voting, see chapter 9 of title 22.

Editor's notes. —

This article as adopted was in 2 subdivisions. The first was headed “Suffrage” and consisted of 12 sections numbered from 1 to 12. The second subdivision was headed “Elections” and consisted of 9 sections numbered from 1 to 9. In printing the constitution the sections in the second subdivision were renumbered consecutively with those sections in the first subdivision.

Article 7. Education; State Institutions; Promotion of Health and Morals; Public BuildingsPublic Schools and School Funds

  • § 1. Legislature to provide for public schools.
  • § 2. School revenues.
  • § 3. Other sources of school revenues.
  • § 4. Restriction in use of revenues.
  • § 5. Fines and penalties to belong to public school fund.
  • § 6. State to keep school funds; investment.
  • § 7. Application of school funds.
  • § 8. Distribution of school funds.
  • § 9. Taxation for schools.
  • § 10. No discrimination between pupils.
  • § 11. Textbooks.
  • § 12. Sectarianism prohibited.
  • § 13. Land commissioners. [Superseded.]
  • § 14. Supervision of schools entrusted to state superintendent of public instruction.
  • § 15. Establishment of university confirmed.
  • § 16. Tuition free.
  • § 17. Government of university.
  • § 18. Establishment of institutions.
  • § 19. Territorial institutions pass to state.
  • § 20. Duty of legislature to protect and promote health and morality of people.
  • § 21. Buildings and property of territory pass to state.
  • § 22. Construction and supervision.
  • § 23. Permanent location.

§ 1. Legislature to provide for public schools.

The legislature shall provide for the establishment and maintenance of a complete and uniform system of public instruction, embracing free elementary schools of every needed kind and grade, a university with such technical and professional departments as the public good may require and the means of the state allow, and such other institutions as may be necessary.

Cross references. —

For other provisions concerning education, see art. 1, § 23, and art. 21, § 28, Wyo. Const., and title 21.

Tax equalization provision unconstitutional. —

Section 21-13-310(c), which prior to its 1985 amendment, mandated the withholding of earned funds under the state school finance system if a county elected official, the county assessor, and the state appointed officials, the state board of equalization, failed to achieve a constitutionally and statutorily mandated tax equalization, was unconstitutional. The right to an education cannot constitutionally be conditioned on wealth, in that such a measure does not afford equal protection. Simons v. Laramie County Sch. Dist., 741 P.2d 1116, 1987 Wyo. LEXIS 496 (Wyo. 1987).

Legislature has complete control of state's school system in every respect, including division of the state into school districts and providing for their financing. Washakie County Sch. Dist. v. Herschler, 606 P.2d 310, 1980 Wyo. LEXIS 227 (Wyo.), cert. denied, 449 U.S. 824, 101 S. Ct. 86, 66 L. Ed. 2d 28, 1980 U.S. LEXIS 2692 (U.S. 1980).

Delegation of legislative function held valid. —

While establishment of school districts and changes therein is a legislative function under this section, legislative delegation of such duty to district boundary boards in each county has been held valid. Chicago, B. & Q. R.R. v. Byron Sch. Dist., 37 Wyo. 259, 260 P. 537, 1927 Wyo. LEXIS 82 (Wyo. 1927).

“Such other institutions as may be necessary” includes community colleges. —

In giving consideration to the various categories of schools referred to in this section, it is entirely clear that community colleges can only come under the category of “such other institutions as may be necessary.” Goshen County Community College Dist. v. School Dist., 399 P.2d 64, 1965 Wyo. LEXIS 122 (Wyo. 1965).

Agricultural college. —

The legislature could repeal an act establishing the agricultural college, which was located by a vote of the people. State ex rel. Wyoming Agric. College v. Irvine, 14 Wyo. 318, 84 P. 90, 1906 Wyo. LEXIS 18 (Wyo. 1906), aff'd, 206 U.S. 278, 27 S. Ct. 613, 51 L. Ed. 1063, 1907 U.S. LEXIS 1163 (U.S. 1907).

A high school is a component part of a school district. Erickson v. School Dist., 67 Wyo. 216, 217 P.2d 887, 1950 Wyo. LEXIS 12 (Wyo. 1950).

School bond elections. —

Statute requiring payment of realty tax as a qualification to vote at a school bond election was invalid. West v. School Dist., 37 Wyo. 36, 258 P. 583, 1927 Wyo. LEXIS 63 (Wyo. 1927).

School district not entitled to eleventh amendment immunity. —

Although a school district obtains more than one-fourth of its funds from the state of Wyoming, the school district on balance is not entitled to an eleventh amendment immunity as an arm of the state of Stoddard v. School Dist., 429 F. Supp. 890, 1977 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 16623 (D. Wyo. 1977), aff'd in part and rev'd in part, 590 F.2d 829, 1979 U.S. App. LEXIS 17844 (10th Cir. Wyo. 1979).

Since school board is more like county than arm of state. —

The characteristics of Wyoming school districts demonstrate that in Wyoming on balance a local school board is more like a county or city than it is like an arm of the state. Stoddard v. School Dist., 429 F. Supp. 890, 1977 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 16623 (D. Wyo. 1977), aff'd in part and rev'd in part, 590 F.2d 829, 1979 U.S. App. LEXIS 17844 (10th Cir. Wyo. 1979).

School district is not authorized to adopt four-day school week, resulting in a 144-day school year. Johnston v. Board of Trustees, 661 P.2d 1045, 1983 Wyo. LEXIS 313 (Wyo. 1983).

Quoted in

Natrona County Sch. Dist. v. Ryan, 764 P.2d 1019, 1988 Wyo. LEXIS 153 (Wyo. 1988); Powers v. State, 2014 WY 15, 2014 Wyo. LEXIS 16 (Jan 28, 2014).

Cited in

Gale v. School Dist., 49 Wyo. 384, 54 P.2d 811, 1936 Wyo. LEXIS 43 (1936); Laramie County Sch. Dist. Number One v. Muir, 808 P.2d 797, 1991 Wyo. LEXIS 51 (Wyo. 1991); RM v. Washakie County Sch. Dist. No. One, 2004 WY 162, 102 P.3d 868, 2004 Wyo. LEXIS 208 (2004).

Law reviews. —

For comment, “Equal Protection and the Financing of Public Education in Wyoming,” see VIII Land & Water L. Rev. 273 (1973).

For article, “School Finance Reform in Wyoming,” see XIX Land & Water L. Rev. 135 (1984).

For comment, “Education for Handicapped Children in Wyoming: What Constitutes a Free Appropriate Public Education and Other Administrative Hurdles,” see XIX Land & Water L. Rev. 225 (1984).

For case note, “EDUCATIONAL LAW — Wyoming Refuses to Recognize Compensatory Education as a Remedy Under the Education for All Handicapped Children Act of 1975. Natrona County School Dist. No. 1 v. McKnight, 764 P.2d 1039, 1988 Wyo. LEXIS 152 (Wyo. 1988),” see XXIV Land & Water L. Rev. 529 (1989).

For article, “The Wyoming Constitution: A Centennial Assessment,” see XXVI Land & Water L. Rev. 13 (1991).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

AIDS infection as affecting right to attend public schools, 60 ALR4th 15.

§ 2. School revenues.

The following are declared to be perpetual funds for school purposes, of which the annual income only can be appropriated, to wit: Such per centum as has been or may hereafter be granted by congress on the sale of lands in this state; all moneys arising from the sale or lease of sections number sixteen and thirty-six in each township in the state, and the lands selected or that may be selected in lieu thereof; the proceeds of all lands that have been or may hereafter be granted to this state, where by the terms and conditions of the grant, the same are not to be otherwise appropriated; the net proceeds of lands and other property and effects that may come to the state by escheat or forfeiture, or from unclaimed dividends or distributive shares of the estates of deceased persons; all moneys, stocks, bonds, lands and other property now belonging to the common school funds. Provided, that the rents for the ordinary use of said lands shall be applied to the support of public schools and, when authorized by general law, not to exceed thirty-three and one-third (33 1/3) per centum of oil, gas, coal, or other mineral royalties arising from the lease of any said school lands may be so applied. (As amended by Laws 1923, Senate Joint Resolution No. 7, p. 225.)

Cross references. —

As to state tax to support schools, see art. 15, § 15, Wyo. Const.

For provision that unexpended income or interest shall be added to and become part of perpetual school fund, see art. 18, § 6, Wyo. Const.

School district not entitled to eleventh amendment immunity. —

Although a school district obtains more than one-fourth of its funds from the state of Wyoming, the school district on balance is not entitled to an eleventh amendment immunity as an arm of the state of Stoddard v. School Dist., 429 F. Supp. 890, 1977 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 16623 (D. Wyo. 1977), aff'd in part and rev'd in part, 590 F.2d 829, 1979 U.S. App. LEXIS 17844 (10th Cir. Wyo. 1979).

Since school board is more like county than arm of state. —

The characteristics of Wyoming school districts demonstrate that in Wyoming on balance a local school board is more like a county or city than it is like an arm of the state. Stoddard v. School Dist., 429 F. Supp. 890, 1977 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 16623 (D. Wyo. 1977), aff'd in part and rev'd in part, 590 F.2d 829, 1979 U.S. App. LEXIS 17844 (10th Cir. Wyo. 1979).

Bequests to state. —

Where property is bequeathed to the state with an annual income payable to a legatee out of income, the property cannot be considered “not otherwise appropriated” and must be added to the common school fund. Bond v. State, 45 Wyo. 133, 16 P.2d 53, 1932 Wyo. LEXIS 56 (Wyo. 1932).

Contract with an expert to investigate leases of state lands and ascertain if correct accounting was being made, and if not, to assist in recovering amount due state, on contingent basis, is not violative of constitution as depleting school funds, as moneys so recovered are a new fund brought into existence through the investigation. Bourne v. Cole, 53 Wyo. 31, 77 P.2d 617, 1938 Wyo. LEXIS 1 (Wyo. 1938).

Supreme court's duty. —

It is bounden duty of supreme court, insofar as possible, to carry provisions that permanent school funds shall remain forever inviolate and undiminished into force and effect. Alamo Drainage Dist. v. Board of County Comm'rs, 60 Wyo. 177, 148 P.2d 229, 1944 Wyo. LEXIS 7 (Wyo. 1944).

Quoted in

Oregon Basin Oil & Gas Co. v. Ohio Oil Co., 70 Wyo. 263, 248 P.2d 198, 1952 Wyo. LEXIS 31 (1952); Riedel v. Anderson, 2003 WY 70, 70 P.3d 223, 2003 Wyo. LEXIS 88 (Wyo. 2003).

Cited in

Witzenburger v. State ex rel. Wyo. Community Dev. Auth., 575 P.2d 1100, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 266 (Wyo. 1978).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Procedural issues concerning public school funding cases, 115 ALR5th 563.

§ 3. Other sources of school revenues.

To the sources of revenue above mentioned shall be added all other grants, gifts and devises that have been or may hereafter be made to this state and not otherwise appropriated by the terms of the grant, gift or devise.

Bequests to state. —

Where property is bequeathed to the state with an annual income payable to a legatee out of income, the property cannot be considered “not otherwise appropriated” and must be added to the common school fund. Bond v. State, 45 Wyo. 133, 16 P.2d 53, 1932 Wyo. LEXIS 56 (Wyo. 1932).

Stated in

Washakie County Sch. Dist. v. Herschler, 606 P.2d 310, 1980 Wyo. LEXIS 227 (Wyo. 1980).

Cited in

In re Board of Comm'rs, 4 Wyo. 133, 32 P. 850 (1893).

§ 4. Restriction in use of revenues.

All money, stocks, bonds, lands and other property belonging to a county school fund, except such moneys and property as may be provided by law for current use in aid of public schools, shall belong to and be invested by the several counties as a county public school fund, in such manner as the legislature shall by law provide, the income of which shall be appropriated exclusively to the use and support of free public schools in the several counties of the state. (As amended by Laws 1969, Senate Joint Resolution No. 3, p. 494.)

Taxing district responsibility. —

It is competent for the state to make taxing district responsible as principal debtor for its quota of state tax assessed within it. State v. Board of Comm'rs, 8 Wyo. 104, 55 P. 451, 1898 Wyo. LEXIS 26 (Wyo. 1898).

§ 5. Fines and penalties to belong to public school fund.

All fines and penalties under general laws of the state shall belong to the public school fund of the respective counties and be paid over to the custodians of such funds for the current support of the public schools therein.

Quoted in

Washakie County Sch. Dist. v. Herschler, 606 P.2d 310, 1980 Wyo. LEXIS 227 (Wyo. 1980).

Stated in

Wyoming Disct. Corp. v. Lamar, 444 P.2d 620, 1968 Wyo. LEXIS 195 (Wyo. 1968).

Cited in

State v. Board of County Comm'rs, 8 Wyo. 104, 55 P. 451, 1898 Wyo. LEXIS 26 (1898).

Law reviews. —

For article, “School Finance Reform in Wyoming,” see XIX Land & Water L. Rev. 135 (1984).

§ 6. State to keep school funds; investment.

All funds belonging to the state for public school purposes, the interest and income of which only are to be used, shall be deemed trust funds in the care of the state, which shall keep them for the exclusive benefit of the public schools. The legislature shall provide by law for the investment of such trust funds. (As amended by Laws 1915, House Joint Resolution No. 2, p. 264; Laws 1969, Senate Joint Resolution No. 4, p. 492.)

School district not entitled to eleventh amendment immunity. —

Although a school district obtains more than 1/4 of its funds from the state of Wyoming, the school district on balance is not entitled to an eleventh amendment immunity as an arm of the state of Wyoming. Stoddard v. School Dist., 429 F. Supp. 890, 1977 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 16623 (D. Wyo. 1977), aff'd in part and rev'd in part, 590 F.2d 829, 1979 U.S. App. LEXIS 17844 (10th Cir. Wyo. 1979).

Since school board is more like county than arm of state. —

The characteristics of Wyoming school districts demonstrate that in Wyoming on balance a local school board is more like a county or city than it is like an arm of the state. Stoddard v. School Dist., 429 F. Supp. 890, 1977 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 16623 (D. Wyo. 1977), aff'd in part and rev'd in part, 590 F.2d 829, 1979 U.S. App. LEXIS 17844 (10th Cir. Wyo. 1979).

A high school is a component part of a school district. Erickson v. School Dist., 67 Wyo. 216, 217 P.2d 887, 1950 Wyo. LEXIS 12 (Wyo. 1950).

Contract with an expert to investigate leases of state lands and ascertain if correct accounting was being made, and if not, to assist in recovering amount due state, on contingent basis, is not violative of constitution as depleting school funds, as moneys so recovered are a new fund brought into existence through the investigation. Bourne v. Cole, 53 Wyo. 31, 77 P.2d 617, 1938 Wyo. LEXIS 1 (Wyo. 1938).

Unauthorized contract. —

Contract whereby land commissioners authorized auditing company to investigate debts due state under mineral leases was void as delegating discretionary power. MacDougall v. Board of Land Comm'rs, 48 Wyo. 493, 49 P.2d 663, 1935 Wyo. LEXIS 47 (Wyo. 1935).

Supreme court's duty. —

It is bounden duty of supreme court, insofar as possible, to carry provisions that permanent school funds shall remain forever inviolate and undiminished into force and effect. Alamo Drainage Dist. v. Board of County Comm'rs, 60 Wyo. 177, 148 P.2d 229, 1944 Wyo. LEXIS 7 (Wyo. 1944).

Quoted in

Riedel v. Anderson, 2003 WY 70, 70 P.3d 223, 2003 Wyo. LEXIS 88 (Wyo. 2003).

Cited in

Oregon Basin Oil & Gas Co. v. Ohio Oil Co., 70 Wyo. 263, 248 P.2d 198, 1952 Wyo. LEXIS 31 (1952).

§ 7. Application of school funds.

The income arising from the funds mentioned in the preceding section, together with all the rents of the unsold school lands and such other means as the legislature may provide, shall be exclusively applied to the support of free schools in every county in the state.

School district not entitled to eleventh amendment immunity. —

Although a school district obtains more than 1/4 of its funds from the state of Wyoming, the school district on balance is not entitled to an eleventh amendment immunity as an arm of the state of Wyoming. Stoddard v. School Dist., 429 F. Supp. 890, 1977 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 16623 (D. Wyo. 1977), aff'd in part and rev'd in part, 590 F.2d 829, 1979 U.S. App. LEXIS 17844 (10th Cir. Wyo. 1979).

Since school board is more like county than arm of state. —

The characteristics of Wyoming school districts demonstrate that in Wyoming on balance a local school board is more like a county or city than it is like an arm of the state. Stoddard v. School Dist., 429 F. Supp. 890, 1977 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 16623 (D. Wyo. 1977), aff'd in part and rev'd in part, 590 F.2d 829, 1979 U.S. App. LEXIS 17844 (10th Cir. Wyo. 1979).

Bequests to state. —

Where property is bequeathed to the state with an annual income payable to a legatee out of income, the property cannot be considered “not otherwise appropriated” and must be added to the common school fund. Bond v. State, 45 Wyo. 133, 16 P.2d 53, 1932 Wyo. LEXIS 56 (Wyo. 1932).

Quoted in

Riedel v. Anderson, 2003 WY 70, 70 P.3d 223, 2003 Wyo. LEXIS 88 (Wyo. 2003).

Cited in

State v. Board of County Comm'rs, 8 Wyo. 104, 55 P. 451, 1898 Wyo. LEXIS 26 (1898); Oregon Basin Oil & Gas Co. v. Ohio Oil Co., 70 Wyo. 263, 248 P.2d 198, 1952 Wyo. LEXIS 31 (1952).

§ 8. Distribution of school funds.

Provision shall be made by general law for the equitable allocation of such income among all school districts in the state. But no appropriation shall be made from said fund to any district for the year in which a school has not been maintained for at least three (3) months; nor shall any portion of any public school fund ever be used to support or assist any private school, or any school, academy, seminary, college or other institution of learning controlled by any church or sectarian organization or religious denomination whatsoever. (As amended by Laws 1978, House Joint Resolution No. 2, p. 429.)

Cross references. —

As to distribution to school districts, see § 21-13-301.

As to distribution of funds from foundation program account, see § 21-13-313.

School bond elections. —

An act requiring payment of tax as a qualification to vote on the question of a school bond issue is unconstitutional. West v. School Dist., 37 Wyo. 36, 258 P. 583, 1927 Wyo. LEXIS 63 (Wyo. 1927).

Quoted in

Washakie County Sch. Dist. v. Herschler, 606 P.2d 310, 1980 Wyo. LEXIS 227 (Wyo. 1980); Simons v. Laramie County Sch. Dist., 741 P.2d 1116, 1987 Wyo. LEXIS 496 (Wyo. 1987).

Law reviews. —

For article, “Through the Front Door,” see 19 Wyo. L.J. 164 (1965).

For article, “School Finance Reform in Wyoming,” see XIX Land & Water L. Rev. 135 (1984).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Constitutionality of regulation or policy governing prayer, meditation, or “moment of silence” in public schools, 110 ALR Fed 211.

Bible distribution or use in public schools — modern cases, 111 ALR Fed 121.

§ 9. Taxation for schools.

The legislature shall make such further provision by taxation or otherwise, as with the income arising from the general school fund will create and maintain a thorough and efficient system of public schools, adequate to the proper instruction of all youth of the state, between the ages of six and twenty-one years, free of charge; and in view of such provision so made, the legislature shall require that every child of sufficient physical and mental ability shall attend a public school during the period between six and eighteen years for a time equivalent to three years, unless educated by other means.

Cross references. —

As to state tax to support schools, see also art. 15, § 15, Wyo. Const.

As to maximum rate of school district tax, see § 21-13-102.

As to levy, collection and distribution of school tax, see § 21-13-201.

As to levy of state tax for support of public elementary and secondary schools, see § 21-13-303.

As to tax for support of community college, see § 21-18-205.

Education for children of state is matter of fundamental interest. Washakie County Sch. Dist. v. Herschler, 606 P.2d 310, 1980 Wyo. LEXIS 227 (Wyo.), cert. denied, 449 U.S. 824, 101 S. Ct. 86, 66 L. Ed. 2d 28, 1980 U.S. LEXIS 2692 (U.S. 1980).

Pre-school funding not required. —

State is required to provide a thorough and effective system of public schools for all youths between the ages of six and 21, but the constitution does not require the state to provide the necessary funds for each school district to offer voluntary pre-school education. Campbell County Sch. Dist. v. State, 2008 WY 2, 181 P.3d 43, 2008 Wyo. LEXIS 2 (Wyo. 2008).

No educational services past age 21. —

A county school district is neither entitled nor obligated to provide educational services for individuals within the district after a recipient reaches his or her twenty-first birthday. Natrona County Sch. Dist. v. Ryan, 764 P.2d 1019, 1988 Wyo. LEXIS 153 (Wyo. 1988).

Right to education cannot constitutionally be conditioned on wealth. —

Although the quality of a child's education in the state, measured in terms of dollars available for that purpose, is dependent upon the property tax resources of his school district, the right to an education cannot constitutionally be conditioned on wealth in that such a measure does not afford equal protection. Washakie County Sch. Dist. v. Herschler, 606 P.2d 310, 1980 Wyo. LEXIS 227 (Wyo.), cert. denied, 449 U.S. 824, 101 S. Ct. 86, 66 L. Ed. 2d 28, 1980 U.S. LEXIS 2692 (U.S. 1980).

Right can be conditioned on conduct. —

Where two students were expelled for one year for selling marijuana, the state constitution did not require that the school district had to provide them with an alternate education because they had been lawfully expelled, the district's actions were the least onerous means of accomplishing its compelling interest in providing for the safety and welfare of its students, and the students had not been denied all educational opportunity as they could have chosen to return to school after their suspensions. RM v. Washakie County Sch. Dist. No. One, 2004 WY 162, 102 P.3d 868, 2004 Wyo. LEXIS 208 (Wyo. 2004).

Distribution of public school funds based upon wealth is suspect classification. —

Funding a public school system where money is distributed upon the basis of wealth or lack thereof is in a suspect classification, requiring the court's strict scrutiny test to determine if it is achieving a compelling state interest. Washakie County Sch. Dist. v. Herschler, 606 P.2d 310, 1980 Wyo. LEXIS 227 (Wyo.), cert. denied, 449 U.S. 824, 101 S. Ct. 86, 66 L. Ed. 2d 28, 1980 U.S. LEXIS 2692 (U.S. 1980).

Although no requirement of absolute equality in funding. —

Each school district need not receive exactly the same number of dollars per pupil as every other school district because exact or absolute equality is not required. Washakie County Sch. Dist. v. Herschler, 606 P.2d 310, 1980 Wyo. LEXIS 227 (Wyo.), cert. denied, 449 U.S. 824, 101 S. Ct. 86, 66 L. Ed. 2d 28, 1980 U.S. LEXIS 2692 (U.S. 1980).

Tax equalization provision unconstitutional. —

Section 21-13-310(c), which prior to its 1985 amendment, mandated the withholding of earned funds under the state school finance system if a county elected official, the county assessor, and the state appointed officials, the state board of equalization, failed to achieve a constitutionally and statutorily mandated tax equalization, was unconstitutional. The right to an education cannot constitutionally be conditioned on wealth, in that such a measure does not afford equal protection. Simons v. Laramie County Sch. Dist., 741 P.2d 1116, 1987 Wyo. LEXIS 496 (Wyo. 1987).

A high school is a component part of a school district. Erickson v. School Dist., 67 Wyo. 216, 217 P.2d 887, 1950 Wyo. LEXIS 12 (Wyo. 1950).

Quoted in

State ex rel. R.R. Crow & Co. v. Copenhaver, 64 Wyo. 1, 184 P.2d 594, 1947 Wyo. LEXIS 24 (1947).

§ 10. No discrimination between pupils.

In none of the public schools so established and maintained shall distinction or discrimination be made on account of sex, race or color.

Cross references. —

For equivalent statutory provision, see § 21-4-303.

Nature of section. —

This is a special state constitutional provision pertaining to schools and does not fall under any general constitutional provision, such as the fourteenth amendment to the constitution of the United States, which is directed toward the equal protection of the laws, and under which the many school segregation cases are laid. Wyoming. Geraud v. Schrader, 531 P.2d 872, 1975 Wyo. LEXIS 128 (Wyo.), cert. denied, 423 U.S. 904, 96 S. Ct. 205, 46 L. Ed. 2d 134, 1975 U.S. LEXIS 3003 (U.S. 1975).

“Distinction” contained in this section must be given its ordinary meaning: “seeming to distinguish,” “setting apart from others,” “individualizing,” “characteristic,” “peculiar,” “special.” Wyoming. Geraud v. Schrader, 531 P.2d 872, 1975 Wyo. LEXIS 128 (Wyo.), cert. denied, 423 U.S. 904, 96 S. Ct. 205, 46 L. Ed. 2d 134, 1975 U.S. LEXIS 3003 (U.S. 1975).

No distinctive school may be established for Indians by an agency of the state of Wyoming. Geraud v. Schrader, 531 P.2d 872, 1975 Wyo. LEXIS 128 (Wyo.), cert. denied, 423 U.S. 904, 96 S. Ct. 205, 46 L. Ed. 2d 134, 1975 U.S. LEXIS 3003 (U.S. 1975).

Stated in

Washakie County Sch. Dist. v. Herschler, 606 P.2d 310, 1980 Wyo. LEXIS 227 (Wyo. 1980).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

AIDS infection as affecting right to attend public schools, 60 ALR4th 15.

What constitutes impairment of proposed intervenor's interest to support intervention as matter of right under Rule 24(a)(2) of Federal Rules of Civil Procedure in actions relating to school desegregation, 75 ALR Fed 231.

Validity and construction of public school regulation of student distribution of religious documents at school, 136 ALR Fed 551.

What constitutes reverse or majority race or national origin discrimination violative of federal constitution or statutes — nonemployment cases 152 ALR Fed 1.

Sex discrimination in public education under Title IX — Supreme Court cases, 158 ALR Fed 563.

§ 11. Textbooks.

Neither the legislature nor the superintendent of public instruction shall have power to prescribe text books to be used in the public schools.

Cross references. —

For provision that schools shall adhere to minimum standards promulgated by state board of education, see § 21-9-101.

As to free textbooks and supplies, see §§ 21-9-201 to 21-9-203.

Stated in

Washakie County Sch. Dist. v. Herschler, 606 P.2d 310, 1980 Wyo. LEXIS 227 (Wyo. 1980).

§ 12. Sectarianism prohibited.

No sectarian instruction, qualifications or tests shall be imparted, exacted, applied or in any manner tolerated in the schools of any grade or character controlled by the state, nor shall attendance be required at any religious service therein, nor shall any sectarian tenets or doctrines be taught or favored in any public school or institution that may be established under this constitution.

Cross references. —

As to religious liberty, see art. 1, § 18, and art. 21, § 25, Wyo. Const.

For provision prohibiting use of school funds to assist educational institution controlled by church or sectarian organization, see art. 7, § 8, Wyo. Const.

Applied in

Williams v. Eaton, 310 F. Supp. 1342, 1970 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 12370 (D. Wyo. 1970).

Stated in

Washakie County Sch. Dist. v. Herschler, 606 P.2d 310, 1980 Wyo. LEXIS 227 (Wyo. 1980).

Cited in

Williams v. Eaton, 333 F. Supp. 107, 1971 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 11210 (D. Wyo. 1971).

Law reviews. —

For article, “Through the Front Door,” see 19 Wyo. L.J. 164 (1965).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Validity and construction of public school regulation of student distribution of religious documents at school, 136 ALR Fed 551.

§ 13. Land commissioners. [Superseded.]

Section superseded. —

This section has been superseded by art. 18, § 3, Wyo. Const., as amended in 1922.

§ 14. Supervision of schools entrusted to state superintendent of public instruction.

The general supervision of the public schools shall be entrusted to the state superintendent of public instruction, whose powers and duties shall be prescribed by law.

Cross references. —

As to duties of superintendent of public instruction, see §§ 21-2-201 and 21-2-202.

Legislature has complete control of state's school system in every respect, including division of the state into school districts and providing for their financing. Washakie County Sch. Dist. v. Herschler, 606 P.2d 310, 1980 Wyo. LEXIS 227 (Wyo.), cert. denied, 449 U.S. 824, 101 S. Ct. 86, 66 L. Ed. 2d 28, 1980 U.S. LEXIS 2692 (U.S. 1980).

Power of general supervision. —

Phrase “shall be prescribed by law,” as set forth in this provision, does not provide the legislature with unrestricted power to eliminate or transfer powers and duties of the office of State Superintendent of Public Instruction. While the legislature can prescribe powers and duties of the Superintendent, it cannot eliminate or transfer powers and duties to such an extent that the Superintendent no longer maintains the power of general supervision of the public schools. Powers v. State, 2014 WY 15, 318 P.3d 300, 2014 Wyo. LEXIS 16 (Wyo. 2014) and Powers v. State, No. 180-673 (1st Jud. Dist. Ct. Apr. 18, 2014).

There is no need to ascertain the “characteristic common law duties” of the office of the State Superintendent of Public Instruction because Wyoming's constitutional framers expressly entrusted the power of “general supervision of the public schools” to the Superintendent. Powers v. State, 2014 WY 15, 318 P.3d 300, 2014 Wyo. LEXIS 16 (Wyo. 2014) and Powers v. State, No. 180-673 (1st Jud. Dist. Ct. Apr. 18, 2014).

Legislature may not delegate powers and duties to other entities to such an extent that the power of general supervision of the public schools no longer resides with the State Superintendent of Public Instruction. Powers v. State, 2014 WY 15, 318 P.3d 300, 2014 Wyo. LEXIS 16 (Wyo. 2014) and Powers v. State, No. 180-673 (1st Jud. Dist. Ct. Apr. 18, 2014).

Laws 2013, Chapter 1 unconstitutional. —

Senate Enrolled Act 1 (Laws 2013, Chapter 1) is unconstitutional, as it deprives the State Superintendent of Public Instruction the power of “general supervision of the public schools” that is entrusted to the Superintendent. Powers v. State, 2014 WY 15, 318 P.3d 300, 2014 Wyo. LEXIS 16 (Wyo. 2014) and Powers v. State, No. 180-673 (1st Jud. Dist. Ct. Apr. 18, 2014).

Although Senate Enrolled Act 1 (Laws 2013, Chapter 1) does not “eliminate” the office of State Superintendent of Public Instruction, it has effectively marginalized the office and has left it an empty shell. The legislature has attempted to accomplish through legislation what it may only do through the constitutional amendment process; therefore, the act is unconstitutional. Powers v. State, 2014 WY 15, 318 P.3d 300, 2014 Wyo. LEXIS 16 (Wyo. 2014) and Powers v. State, No. 180-673 (1st Jud. Dist. Ct. Apr. 18, 2014).

School district not entitled to eleventh amendment immunity. —

Although a school district obtains more than one-fourth of its funds from the state of Wyoming, the school district on balance is not entitled to an eleventh amendment immunity as an arm of the state of Stoddard v. School Dist., 429 F. Supp. 890, 1977 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 16623 (D. Wyo. 1977), aff'd in part and rev'd in part, 590 F.2d 829, 1979 U.S. App. LEXIS 17844 (10th Cir. Wyo. 1979).

Since school board is more like county than arm of state. —

The characteristics of Wyoming school districts demonstrate that in Wyoming on balance a local school board is more like a county or city than it is like an arm of the state. Stoddard v. School Dist., 429 F. Supp. 890, 1977 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 16623 (D. Wyo. 1977), aff'd in part and rev'd in part, 590 F.2d 829, 1979 U.S. App. LEXIS 17844 (10th Cir. Wyo. 1979).

Quoted in

Natrona County Sch. Dist. v. Ryan, 764 P.2d 1019, 1988 Wyo. LEXIS 153 (Wyo. 1988).The University

§ 15. Establishment of university confirmed.

The establishment of the University of Wyoming is hereby confirmed, and said institution, with its several departments, is hereby declared to be the University of the State of Wyoming. All lands which have been heretofore granted or which may be granted hereafter by congress unto the university as such, or in aid of the instruction to be given in any of its departments, with all other grants, donations, or devises for said university, or for any of its departments, shall vest in said university, and be exclusively used for the purposes for which they were granted, donated or devised. The said lands may be leased on terms approved by the land commissioners, but may not be sold on terms not approved by congress.

Cross references. —

For other provisions concerning the university of Wyoming, see §§ 21-17-101 to 21-17-450.

Agricultural college. —

The legislature can repeal an act establishing an agricultural college, which was located by a vote of the people. State ex rel. Wyoming Agric. College v. Irvine, 14 Wyo. 318, 84 P. 90, 1906 Wyo. LEXIS 18 (Wyo. 1906), aff'd, 206 U.S. 278, 27 S. Ct. 613, 51 L. Ed. 1063, 1907 U.S. LEXIS 1163 (U.S. 1907).

Control and disposition of lands granted to the state university lies in state board of land commissioners. Ross v. Trustees of Univ., 31 Wyo. 464, 228 P. 642, 1924 Wyo. LEXIS 40 (Wyo. 1924).

Rights-of-way. —

The legislature is not prohibited from authorizing board of land commissioners to grant right-of-way across university lands. Ross v. Trustees of Univ. of Wyo., 30 Wyo. 433, 222 P. 3, 1924 Wyo. LEXIS 67 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 31 Wyo. 464, 228 P. 642, 1924 Wyo. LEXIS 40 (Wyo. 1924).

Use of permanent land fund. —

University permanent land fund was not intended to be confined to use in paying current expenses, but may, if necessary and proper, be used for erection of buildings when authorized by the legislature. Arnold v. Bond, 47 Wyo. 236, 34 P.2d 28, 1934 Wyo. LEXIS 22 (Wyo. 1934).

Quoted in

Witzenburger v. State ex rel. Wyo. Community Dev. Auth., 575 P.2d 1100, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 266 (Wyo. 1978).

Cited in

Washakie County Sch. Dist. v. Herschler, 606 P.2d 310, 1980 Wyo. LEXIS 227 (Wyo. 1980).

§ 16. Tuition free.

The university shall be equally open to students of both sexes, irrespective of race or color; and, in order that the instruction furnished may be as nearly free as possible, any amount in addition to the income from its grants of lands and other sources above mentioned, necessary to its support and maintenance in a condition of full efficiency shall be raised by taxation or otherwise, under provisions of the legislature.

Cross references. —

For equivalent statutory provision, see § 21-17-105.

Quoted in

Biscar v. University of Wyo. Bd. of Trustees, 605 P.2d 374, 1980 Wyo. LEXIS 229 (Wyo. 1980).

Cited in

State v. Board of County Comm'rs, 8 Wyo. 104, 55 P. 451, 1898 Wyo. LEXIS 26 (1898); State ex rel. Wyoming Agric. College v. Irvine, 14 Wyo. 318, 84 P. 90, 1906 Wyo. LEXIS 18 (1906); Ross v. Trustees of Univ., 31 Wyo. 464, 228 P. 642, 1924 Wyo. LEXIS 40 (1924); Washakie County Sch. Dist. v. Herschler, 606 P.2d 310, 1980 Wyo. LEXIS 227 (Wyo. 1980).

§ 17. Government of university.

The legislature shall provide by law for the management of the university, its lands and other property by a board of trustees, consisting of not less than seven members, to be appointed by the governor by and with the advice and consent of the senate, and the president of the university, and the superintendent of public instruction, as members ex officio, as such having the right to speak, but not to vote. The duties and powers of the trustees shall be prescribed by law.

Cross references. —

As to board of trustees of university, see §§ 21-17-201 to 21-17-206.

Editor's Note. —

2013 Senate Enrolled Joint Resolution No.1, proposes to amend the Wyoming Constitution to remove the requirement that a person be a resident of the state of Wyoming to serve as a trustee of the University of Wyoming and limiting the number of nonresidents who may serve as trustees. Sections 1 and 2 state as follows: Section 1. The following proposal to amend Wyoming Constitution, Article 7, Section 17 is proposed for submission to the electors of the State of Wyoming at the next general election for approval or rejection to become valid as a part of the Constitution if ratified by a majority of the electors at the election: Article 7, Section 17. Government of university. The legislature shall provide by law for the management ofthe university, its lands and other property by a board of trustees, consisting of not less than seven members, to be appointed by the governor by and with the advice and consent of the senate, and the president of the university, and the superintendent of public instruction, as members ex officio, as such having the right to speak, but not to vote. The duties and powers of the trustees shall be prescribed by law. Not more than twenty percent (20%) of the appointed trustees may be nonresidents of the state, notwithstanding the provisions of Article 6, Section 15 of this Constitution. Section 2. That the Secretary of State shall endorse the following statement on the proposed amendment: The adoption of this amendment would allow the governor to appoint nonresidents of the state to serve as University of Wyoming trustees. Not more than twenty percent (20%) of the appointed trustees may be nonresidents of the state. The governor would not be required to appoint any nonresident as a trustee. All appointments to the board of trustees are with the advice and consent of the Wyoming Senate.

Powers of board of land commissioners. —

Control and disposition of lands granted to the state university lies in state board of land commissioners. Ross v. Trustees of Univ., 31 Wyo. 464, 228 P. 642, 1924 Wyo. LEXIS 40 (Wyo. 1924).

Legislature is not prohibited from authorizing board of land commissioners to grant right-of-way across university lands. Ross v. Trustees of Univ. of Wyo., 30 Wyo. 433, 222 P. 3, 1924 Wyo. LEXIS 67 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 31 Wyo. 464, 228 P. 642, 1924 Wyo. LEXIS 40 (Wyo. 1924).

Trustees have no power to dispose of university lands. Ross v. Trustees of Univ., 31 Wyo. 464, 228 P. 642, 1924 Wyo. LEXIS 40 (Wyo. 1924).

Suit against the trustees of the university is a suit against the state. Hjorth Royalty Co. v. University of Wyoming, 30 Wyo. 309, 222 P. 9, 1924 Wyo. LEXIS 68 (Wyo. 1924).

Quoted in

Witzenburger v. State ex rel. Wyo. Community Dev. Auth., 575 P.2d 1100, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 266 (Wyo. 1978).

Cited in

State ex rel. Wyoming Agric. College v. Irvine, 14 Wyo. 318, 84 P. 90, 1906 Wyo. LEXIS 18 (1906).Charitable and Penal Institutions

§ 18. Establishment of institutions.

Such charitable, reformatory and penal institutions as the claims of humanity and the public good may require, shall be established and supported by the state in such manner as the legislature may prescribe. They shall be supervised as prescribed by law. (As amended by Laws 1989, Senate Joint Resolution No. 4, p. 770.)

Cross references. —

As to conduct of jails, see art. 1, § 16, Wyo. Const.

As to the creation and duties of the department of corrections, see § 25-1-104.

As to state penal institutions generally, see §§ 25-2-101 to 25-4-103.

Editor's notes. —

The catchline for this section was changed to reflect the amendment by Laws 1989, Senate Joint Resolution No. 4, p. 770.

Wyoming state hospital is an agency of the state created by statute at the mandate of the state constitution. Carbon County Sch. Dist. v. Wyoming State Hosp., 680 P.2d 773, 1984 Wyo. LEXIS 283 (Wyo. 1984).

Appropriations for institutions mentioned herein are constitutional. State v. Board of Comm'rs, 8 Wyo. 104, 55 P. 451, 1898 Wyo. LEXIS 26 (Wyo. 1898).

Transfer of prisoner. —

Transfer of prisoner from industrial institute to state penitentiary is an “executive act,” though board of charities and reform may be required incidentally to determine questions of fact, while sentence of prisoner to the institute is a “judicial act.” Uram v. Roach, 47 Wyo. 335, 37 P.2d 793, 1934 Wyo. LEXIS 27 (Wyo. 1934).

Law reviews. —

For comment, “The Institutional Transfer Statute: Three Challenges to the Imprisonment of Juvenile Offenders,” see XVII Land & Water L. Rev. 643 (1982).

For casenote, “Constitutional Law — Freedom of Speech: Public Employee — Can We Talk? The Wyoming Supreme Court Grants Little Protection to Public-Employee Whistleblowers. Mekss v. Wyoming Girls' Sch., 813 P.2d 185, 1991 Wyo. LEXIS 103 (Wyo. 1991),” see XXVII Land & Water L. Rev. 625 (1992).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Civil liability of prison or jail authorities for self-inflicted injury or death of prisoner, 79 ALR3d 1210.

§ 19. Territorial institutions pass to state.

The property of all charitable and penal institutions belonging to the Territory of Wyoming shall, upon the adoption of this constitution, become the property of the State of Wyoming, and such of said institutions as are then in actual operation, shall thereafter have the supervision of the board of charities and reform as provided in the last preceding section of this article, under provisions of the legislature.

Appropriations for institutions mentioned herein are constitutional. State v. Board of Comm'rs, 8 Wyo. 104, 55 P. 451, 1898 Wyo. LEXIS 26 (Wyo. 1898).Public Health and Morals

§ 20. Duty of legislature to protect and promote health and morality of people.

As the health and morality of the people are essential to their well-being, and to the peace and permanence of the state, it shall be the duty of the legislature to protect and promote these vital interests by such measures for the encouragement of temperance and virtue, and such restrictions upon vice and immorality of every sort, as are deemed necessary to the public welfare.

Cross references. —

As to offenses against morality and decency generally, see §§ 6-4-101 through 6-4-502, 6-6-201 through 6-6-209.

As to public health and safety generally, see title 35.

Constitutionality of statutes. —

The constitutionality of a statute will not be passed on unless the decision is necessary to the determination of the pending controversy. State v. Kelley, 17 Wyo. 335, 98 P. 886, 1909 Wyo. LEXIS 4 (Wyo. 1909).

Law reviews. —

For note dealing with fluoridation of municipal water systems, see 10 Wyo. L.J. 153.

For comment, “The Constitutionality of Automobile Compensation Plans in Wyoming,” see V Land & Water L. Rev. 191 (1970).Public Buildings

§ 21. Buildings and property of territory pass to state.

All public buildings and other property, belonging to the territory shall, upon the adoption of this constitution, become the property of the State of Wyoming.

Cross references. —

As to public property and contracts generally, see §§ 9-5-101 through 9-5-205 and chapter 6 of title 16.

§ 22. Construction and supervision.

The construction, care and preservation of all public buildings of the state not under the control of the board or officers of public institutions by authority of law shall be entrusted to such officers or boards, and under such regulations as shall be prescribed by law.

§ 23. Permanent location.

The legislature shall have no power to change or to locate the seat of government, the state university, or state hospital, but may provide by law for submitting the question of the permanent locations thereof respectively, to the qualified electors of the state, at some general election, and a majority of all votes upon said question cast at said election, shall be necessary to determine the location thereof; but until the same are respectively and permanently located, as herein provided, the location of the seat of government and said institutions shall be as follows: The seat of government shall be located at the City of Cheyenne, in the County of Laramie. The state university shall be centered at the City of Laramie, in the County of Albany. The state hospital shall be located at or near the City of Evanston, in the County of Uinta. A penitentiary shall be located at or near the City of Rawlins, in the County of Carbon. The legislature may provide by law the location of other public institutions, including correctional facilities. (As amended by Laws 1978, Sp. Sess., House Joint Resolution No. 1A, p. 492.)

Cross references. —

As to University of Wyoming, see §§ 21-17-101 to 21-17-450.

As to state penitentiary generally, see §§ 25-2-101 to 25-2-103.

As to state hospital for the insane, see §§ 25-10-101 to 25-10-126.

Agricultural college. —

The legislature could repeal an act establishing the agricultural college, which was located by a vote of the people. State ex rel. Wyoming Agric. College v. Irvine, 14 Wyo. 318, 84 P. 90, 1906 Wyo. LEXIS 18 (Wyo. 1906), aff'd, 206 U.S. 278, 27 S. Ct. 613, 51 L. Ed. 1063, 1907 U.S. LEXIS 1163 (U.S. 1907).

Appropriation for the completion and repair of penitentiary buildings is proper under this section. State v. Board of Comm'rs, 8 Wyo. 104, 55 P. 451, 1898 Wyo. LEXIS 26 (Wyo. 1898).

Cited in

Simpkin v. Rock Springs, 33 Wyo. 166, 237 P. 245, 1925 Wyo. LEXIS 32 (1925).

Article 8. Irrigation and Water Rights

  • § 1. Water is state property.
  • § 2. Board of control.
  • § 3. Priority of appropriation.
  • § 4. Water divisions.
  • § 5. State engineer.

§ 1. Water is state property.

The water of all natural streams, springs, lakes or other collections of still water, within the boundaries of the state, are hereby declared to be the property of the state.

Cross references. —

As to control of water, see art. 1, § 31, Wyo. Const.

As to acquisition of water rights by municipalities, see art. 13, § 5, Wyo. Const.

As to water and water rights generally, see title 41.

Consent of United States. —

This section is not void on the ground that the United States is primarily possessed of title to the waters of the stream flowing across the public lands, since the act of congress admitting the state into the union accepted, ratified, and confirmed the constitution the people had formed, and thereby, and by the several desert-land acts, congress consented to such appropriation by the state. Farm Inv. Co. v. Carpenter, 9 Wyo. 110, 61 P. 258, 1900 Wyo. LEXIS 8 (Wyo. 1900).

Constitutionality of section. —

This section is not in conflict with the federal constitution, as divesting those who had appropriated parts of waters prior to the adoption of the constitution of their property, since they never acquired any title to the water in the natural channels before it was diverted into the private ditches or laterals, and only the running water in the natural channel was appropriated to the state. Farm Inv. Co. v. Carpenter, 9 Wyo. 110, 61 P. 258, 1900 Wyo. LEXIS 8 (Wyo. 1900).

Water reserved on Wind River Indian reservation. —

The admission of Wyoming to the Union did not evidence an intent by Congress not to reserve water for the Wind River Indian reservation. In re General Adjudication of All Rights to Use Water in Big Horn River Sys., 753 P.2d 76, 1988 Wyo. LEXIS 26 (Wyo. 1988), aff'd, 492 U.S. 406, 109 S. Ct. 2994, 106 L. Ed. 2d 342, 1989 U.S. LEXIS 3173 (U.S. 1989), cert. denied, 492 U.S. 926, 109 S. Ct. 3265, 106 L. Ed. 2d 610, 1989 U.S. LEXIS 3337 (U.S. 1989), in part, 488 U.S. 1040, 109 S. Ct. 863, 102 L. Ed. 2d 987, 1989 U.S. LEXIS 486 (U.S. 1989), overruled, Vaughn v. State, 962 P.2d 149, 1998 Wyo. LEXIS 97 (Wyo. 1998).

And state may monitor. —

The provisions in a stream adjudication decree, authorizing the state engineer to monitor Indian reserved water rights, were proper, as they contemplated neither the application of state law nor the authority to deprive the Tribes of water without the assistance of the courts in a suit for the administration of the decree. The role of the state engineer was not to apply state law, but to enforce the reserved rights against state appropriators, as decreed under principles of federal law. In re General Adjudication of All Rights to Use Water in Big Horn River Sys., 753 P.2d 76, 1988 Wyo. LEXIS 26 (Wyo. 1988), aff'd, 492 U.S. 406, 109 S. Ct. 2994, 106 L. Ed. 2d 342, 1989 U.S. LEXIS 3173 (U.S. 1989), cert. denied, 492 U.S. 926, 109 S. Ct. 3265, 106 L. Ed. 2d 610, 1989 U.S. LEXIS 3337 (U.S. 1989), in part, 488 U.S. 1040, 109 S. Ct. 863, 102 L. Ed. 2d 987, 1989 U.S. LEXIS 486 (U.S. 1989), overruled, Vaughn v. State, 962 P.2d 149, 1998 Wyo. LEXIS 97 (Wyo. 1998).

Supervision and control. —

The legislature has power to authorize by statute the supervision and control of the appropriation and distribution of the public waters of the state by administrative officers, pursuant to adjudicated priorities. Hamp v. State, 19 Wyo. 377, 118 P. 653, 1911 Wyo. LEXIS 26 (Wyo. 1911).

A district court may not assign the duties of administering state water within a reservation to a tribal water agency. In re General Adjudication of All Rights to Use Water in Big Horn River Sys., 835 P.2d 273, 1992 Wyo. LEXIS 71 (Wyo. 1992).

State ownership of water is subject to a trust. Willey v. Decker, 11 Wyo. 496, 73 P. 210, 1903 Wyo. LEXIS 22 (Wyo. 1903); Lake De Smet Reservoir Co. v. Kaufmann, 75 Wyo. 87, 292 P.2d 482, 1956 Wyo. LEXIS 2 (Wyo. 1956); Day v. Armstrong, 362 P.2d 137, 1961 Wyo. LEXIS 97 (Wyo. 1961).

Waters subject to appropriation and abandonment. —

Waters from sources within the constitutional classifications of this section are subject to appropriation and, likewise, abandonment. Bruegman v. Johnson Ranches, Inc., 520 P.2d 489, 1974 Wyo. LEXIS 193 (Wyo. 1974).

Water rights may not be acquired by adverse possession. —

The district court correctly dismissed a complaint seeking a determination of ownership in water rights by virtue of adverse possession, for the simple reason that water rights may not be acquired by adverse possession or prescription in this state. Lewis v. State Bd. of Control, 699 P.2d 822, 1985 Wyo. LEXIS 483 (Wyo. 1985).

What waters appropriable. —

Water which would naturally reach a stream if not intercepted is appropriable. Bower v. Big Horn Canal Ass'n, 77 Wyo. 80, 307 P.2d 593, 1957 Wyo. LEXIS 10 (Wyo. 1957).

In view of this section, only waters of natural streams, springs or lakes are subject to appropriation. Binning v. Miller, 55 Wyo. 451, 102 P.2d 54, 1940 Wyo. LEXIS 20 (Wyo. 1940).

Where during course of 30 years seepage water flowing down a draw finally made a regular, natural stream with definite channels and banks, waters thereof are subject to appropriation. Binning v. Miller, 55 Wyo. 451, 102 P.2d 54, 1940 Wyo. LEXIS 20 (Wyo. 1940).

Condition precedent to appropriation. —

Appropriation permit and application therefor to state engineer was condition precedent to lawful appropriation, notwithstanding that this article does not require such permit. Wyoming Hereford Ranch v. Hammond Packing Co., 33 Wyo. 14, 236 P. 764, 1925 Wyo. LEXIS 25 (Wyo. 1925).

Watercourse defined. —

A watercourse is a stream of water usually flowing in a particular direction, with well defined banks and channels, but the water need not flow throughout the year. State v. Hiber, 48 Wyo. 172, 44 P.2d 1005, 1935 Wyo. LEXIS 32 (Wyo. 1935).

Natural stream. —

Fact that, before irrigation of lands under a federal reclamation project commenced, a wash or channel within the lands covered by the project carried water only as the run-off from rain or melting snow and was generally dry during all the irrigating season showed that the wash was not a natural stream within this section. United States v. Ide, 277 F. 373, 1921 U.S. App. LEXIS 2017 (8th Cir. Wyo. 1921), aff'd, 263 U.S. 497, 44 S. Ct. 182, 68 L. Ed. 407, 1924 U.S. LEXIS 2813 (U.S. 1924).

Where draw was dry most of the time, was covered with grass, had no banks and evidence showed no natural outlet, evidence failed to sustain state's contention that draw was natural stream. State v. Hiber, 48 Wyo. 172, 44 P.2d 1005, 1935 Wyo. LEXIS 32 (Wyo. 1935).

Title to water in natural streams in Wyoming is in state, but water is subject to withdrawal or appropriation for irrigation or other beneficial use. Mitchell Irr. Dist. v. Sharp, 121 F.2d 964, 1941 U.S. App. LEXIS 3370 (10th Cir. Wyo.), cert. denied, 314 U.S. 667, 62 S. Ct. 129, 86 L. Ed. 534, 1941 U.S. LEXIS 241 (U.S. 1941).

Seepage water. —

In accordance with the constitutional provisions of this state, and, in line with previous holdings of the supreme court, seepage water arising on a farmer's land is subject to appropriation by him (subject to prescribed procedures) for lands other than those upon which the seepage arises. Bower v. Big Horn Canal Ass'n, 77 Wyo. 80, 307 P.2d 593, 1957 Wyo. LEXIS 10 (Wyo. 1957).

Percolating waters developed artificially by excavations and other artificial means belong to the owner of the land upon which they are developed, and are not waters of the state which may be appropriated. Hunt v. Laramie, 26 Wyo. 160, 181 P. 137, 1919 Wyo. LEXIS 5 (Wyo. 1919), limited, Bower v. Big Horn Canal Ass'n, 77 Wyo. 80, 307 P.2d 593, 1957 Wyo. LEXIS 10 (Wyo. 1957).

Private waters. —

An attempted appropriation of waste and seepage waters, being private waters, is void. Binning v. Miller, 55 Wyo. 451, 102 P.2d 54, 1940 Wyo. LEXIS 20 (Wyo. 1940).

Seepage and waste water is private water so long as it is on the lands from which it originates and such water cannot be appropriated by adjoining landowners. Binning v. Miller, 55 Wyo. 451, 102 P.2d 54, 1940 Wyo. LEXIS 20 (Wyo. 1940).

Reservoirs. —

Water may, in this state, be impounded in a reservoir by anyone who is neither the owner or in possession of any land. The owner of such reservoir may sell, lease, transfer, and use such water in such manner and upon such lands as the owner may desire. In other words, one man may divert and impound water, under an application to, and permit by, the state engineer, for the ultimate use of it by another. The only material difference between such case and diversion by direct flow from a stream seems to be that in the former case the water is not required to be attached to land, while in the latter case it is. Kearney Lake Land & Reservoir Co. v. Lake Desmet Reservoir Co., 475 P.2d 548, 1970 Wyo. LEXIS 198 (Wyo. 1970).

Reservoir rights are subject to abandonment. Kearney Lake Land & Reservoir Co. v. Lake Desmet Reservoir Co., 475 P.2d 548, 1970 Wyo. LEXIS 198 (Wyo. 1970).

Petition to intervene brought by irrigators to adjudicate water rights in a reservoir was properly dismissed by the district court, pursuant to Rule 12(b)(6), W.R.C.P., as the matter was barred by res judicata and the petition was untimely. The disputed reservoir certificates were previously adjudicated in 1963. In re Gen. Adjudication of All Rights, 2004 WY 21, 85 P.3d 981, 2004 Wyo. LEXIS 28 (2004).

Priority of right. —

A priority of right in water includes the quality as well as the quantity so that an oil producer has no right to deteriorate the quality of the water in a stream as against persons lower down on the stream having priority. Sussex Land & Live Stock Co. v. Midwest Refining Co., 294 F. 597, 1923 U.S. App. LEXIS 2531 (8th Cir. Wyo. 1923).

Public right to use waters for floating usable craft not to be interfered with. —

Irrespective of the ownership of the bed or channel of waters, and irrespective of their navigability, the public has the right to use public waters of Wyoming for floating usable craft and that use may not be interfered with or curtailed by any landowner. Day v. Armstrong, 362 P.2d 137, 1961 Wyo. LEXIS 97 (Wyo. 1961).

Extent of public easement in nonnavigable river. —

In a dispute over a river which is nonnavigable, the supreme court held that its riparian owners have title to the bed and channel of the river, but that this title is subject to an easement for a right-of-way of the river's waters in their natural channel through, over and across the owner's lands; that the waters of the river are the property of the state and are held by it in trust for the equal use and benefit of the public; and that the waters of the river may be used by the public for floating usable craft therein or thereon and for transporting in such usable craft persons or property. Day v. Armstrong, 362 P.2d 137, 1961 Wyo. LEXIS 97 (Wyo. 1961).

Abatement of dam as nuisance. —

A dam more than 10 feet high may be abated as nuisance though it is not in natural stream, but only to extent that it is above 10 feet high and without inflicting unnecessary injury. State v. Hiber, 48 Wyo. 172, 44 P.2d 1005, 1935 Wyo. LEXIS 32 (Wyo. 1935).

Suit against state. —

Nebraska irrigation district action to restrain Wyoming water officials from unlawfully permitting junior appropriators to take water and to compel distribution in proper order is not suit against state. Mitchell Irr. Dist. v. Sharp, 121 F.2d 964, 1941 U.S. App. LEXIS 3370 (10th Cir. Wyo.), cert. denied, 314 U.S. 667, 62 S. Ct. 129, 86 L. Ed. 534, 1941 U.S. LEXIS 241 (U.S. 1941).

Applied in

Thayer v. City of Rawlins, 594 P.2d 951, 1979 Wyo. LEXIS 407 (Wyo. 1979).

Quoted in

State ex rel. Christopulos v. Husky Oil Co., 575 P.2d 262, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 268 (Wyo. 1978); In re The General Adjudication of All Rights to Use Water in the Big Horn River System and All Other Sources, State of Wyoming, 835 P.2d 273, 1992 Wyo. LEXIS 71 (Wyo. 1992).

Cited in

State v. Kelley, 17 Wyo. 335, 98 P. 886, 1909 Wyo. LEXIS 4 (1909); State ex rel. Mitchell Irrigation Dist. v. Parshall, 22 Wyo. 318, 140 P. 830, 1914 Wyo. LEXIS 16 (1914).

Law reviews. —

For article, “Rights of Wyoming Appropriators in Underground Water,” see 1 Wyo. L.J. 111.

For article, “Constitutionality of the Wyoming Underground Water Statute,” see 3 Wyo. L.J. 140.

For article, “Record Title to Water and Ditch Rights,” see 6 Wyo. L.J. 200 (1957).

For article, “Water Rights of Various Levels of Government — States' Rights v. National Powers,” see 19 Wyo. L.J. 189 (1965).

For comment, “Water Appropriation for Recreation,” see I Land & Water L. Rev. 209 (1966).

For article, “Legal Aspects of Weather Modification Snowpack Augmentation in Wyoming,” see II Land & Water L. Rev. 273 (1967).

For article, “Transfer of Water Rights — Errata and Addenda — Sales for Recreational Purposes and to Districts,” see II Land & Water L. Rev. 321 (1967).

For article, “Public Rights in Navigable State Waters — Some Statutory Approaches,” see VI Land & Water L. Rev. 459 (1971).

For comment, “‘It's Our Water!’ — Can Wyoming Constitutionally Prohibit the Exportation of State Waters,” X Land & Water L. Rev. 119 (1975).

For comment, “Water Saved or Water Lost: The Consequences of Individual Conservation Measures in the Appropriation States,” see XI Land & Water L. Rev. 435 (1976).

See comment, “Marketing of Surplus Water from Federal Reservoirs,” XIII Land & Water L. Rev. 835 (1978).

See case note, “Importation Doctrine Applied to Water Transfers Within a River System: A Step Too Far,” XV Land & Water L. Rev. 99 (1980).

For comment, “Statutory Recognition of Instream Flow Preservation: A Proposed Solution for Wyoming,” see XVII Land & Water L. Rev. 139 (1982).

For case note, “Water Law — Statutory Forfeiture of Water Rights in Wyoming. Wheatland Irr. Dist. v. Laramie Rivers Co., 659 P.2d 561, 1983 Wyo. LEXIS 285 (Wyo. 1983),” see XIX Land & Water L. Rev. 93 (1984).

For comment, “Solar Access Rights in Wyoming,” see XIX Land & Water L. Rev. 419 (1984).

For case note, “Water Law — Standing Requirement Under the Wyoming Forfeiture Statute. Platte County Grazing Association v. State Board of Control, 675 P.2d 1279, 1984 Wyo. LEXIS 244 (Wyo. 1984),” see XIX Land & Water L. Rev. 485 (1984).

For comment, “Forfeiture Proceedings in Wyoming Water Law: The Legislature Revives Private Standing,” see XX Land & Water L. Rev. 459 (1985).

For article, “Wyoming's Groundwater Laws: Quantity and Quality Regulation,” see XXIV Land & Water L. Rev. 39 (1989).

For article, “A Critical Look at Wyoming Water Law,” see XXIV Land & Water L. Rev. 307 (1989).

For article, “The Wyoming Constitution: A Centennial Assessment,” see XXVI Land & Water L. Rev. 13 (1991).

For article, “Waist Deep in the Big Muddy: Property Rights, Public Values, and Instream Waters,” see XXVI Land & Water L. Rev. 535 (1991).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Public rights of recreational boating, fishing, wading, or the like, in inland stream the bed of which is privately owned, 6 ALR4th 1030.

§ 2. Board of control.

There shall be constituted a board of control, to be composed of the state engineer and superintendents of the water divisions; which shall, under such regulations as may be prescribed by law, have the supervision of the waters of the state and of their appropriation, distribution and diversion, and of the various officers connected therewith.
