§ 12. Discrimination by railroads and telegraph lines forbidden.

Railroad and telegraph lines heretofore constructed or that may hereafter be constructed in this state are hereby declared public highways and common carriers, and as such must be made by law to extend the same equality and impartiality to all who use them, excepting employees and their families and ministers of the gospel, whether individuals or corporations.

Cross references. —

For provision prohibiting monopolies, see art. 1, § 30, Wyo. Const.

For other provisions as to discrimination in rates, see §§ 40-4-101 to 40-4-123.

§ 13. Railroads to make annual reports to state auditor.

Every railroad corporation or association operating a line of railroad within this state shall annually make a report to the auditor of state of its business within this state, in such form as the legislature may prescribe.

§ 14. Eminent domain.

Exercise of the power and right of eminent domain shall never be so construed or abridged as to prevent the taking by the legislature of property and franchises of incorporated companies and subjecting them to public use the same as property of individuals.

Cross references. —

For identical provision, see § 9 of this article.

As to eminent domain in connection with railroads, see §§ 1-26-810, 1-26-811.

§ 15. Aid to railroads and telegraph lines prohibited.

Neither the state, nor any county, township, school district or municipality shall loan or give its credit or make donations to or in aid of any railroad or telegraph line; provided, that this section shall not apply to obligations of any county, city, township or school district, contracted prior to the adoption of this constitution.

Cross references. —

For another provision prohibiting aid to railroads, see art. 3, § 39, Wyo. Const.

§ 16. Acceptance of constitution by existing railroad, transportation and telegraph companies.

No railroad or other transportation company or telegraph company in existence upon the adoption of this constitution shall derive the benefit of any future legislation without first filing in the office of the secretary of state an acceptance of the provisions of this constitution.

Territorial corporations. —

Provision of statute permitting any corporation organized under any law of the state to prolong its existence in the manner therein stated is available to corporations organized while Wyoming was a territory. Drew v. Beckwith, Quinn & Co., 57 Wyo. 140, 114 P.2d 98, 1941 Wyo. LEXIS 25 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 57 Wyo. 140, 115 P.2d 651, 1941 Wyo. LEXIS 26 (Wyo. 1941).

§ 17. Rights of telegraph companies.

Any association, corporation or lessee of the franchises thereof organized for the purpose shall have the right to construct and maintain lines of telegraph within this state, and to connect the same with other lines.

Cross references. —

As to eminent domain in connection with utilities, see §§ 1-26-813 to 1-26-816.

§ 18. Foreign railroad or telegraph company must have agent for service of process.

No foreign railroad or telegraph line shall do any business within this state without having an agent or agents within each county through which such railroad or telegraph line shall be constructed upon whom process may be served.

Cross references. —

For provisions concerning service of process, see chapter 6 of title 1 and Rule 4, W.R.C.P.

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Service of process by mail in international civil action as permissible under Hague Convention, 112 ALR Fed 241.

§ 19. Location of depots.

No railroad company shall construct or operate a railroad within four (4) miles of any existing town or city without providing a suitable depot or stopping place at the nearest practicable point for the convenience of said town or city, and stopping all trains doing local business at said stopping place. No railroad company shall deviate from the most direct practicable line in constructing a railroad for the purpose of avoiding the provisions of this section.

Cross references. —

For other provisions concerning location of depots, see §§ 37-9-401 to 37-9-410.

Editor's notes. —

In the original constitution the sections under the heading “Railroads” were numbered 1 to 9, but to avoid confusion in making references these sections were renumbered 11 to 19 so as to make the section numbers of this article run consecutively.

Article 11. Boundaries

  • § 1. State boundaries.

§ 1. State boundaries.

The boundaries of the State of Wyoming shall be as follows: Commencing at the intersection of the twenty-seventh meridian of longitude west from Washington with the forty-fifth degree of north latitude, and running thence west to the thirty-fourth meridian of west longitude, thence south to the forty-first degree of north latitude, thence east to the twenty-seventh meridian of west longitude, and thence north to the place of beginning.

Cross references. —

As to boundaries of counties, see §§ 18-1-101, 18-1-102.

Law reviews. —

For article, “The Wyoming Constitution: A Centennial Assessment,” see XXVI Land & Water L. Rev. 13 (1991).

Article 12. County Organization

  • § 1. Existing counties remain such.
  • § 2. Organization of new counties.
  • § 3. Changing county seats.
  • § 4. Township organization.
  • § 5. County officers.

§ 1. Existing counties remain such.

The several counties in the Territory of Wyoming as they shall exist at the time of the admission of said territory as a state, are hereby declared to be counties of the State of Wyoming.

Cross references. —

As to counties generally, see title 18.

Judicial notice will be taken of the organization of the counties of the state. State ex rel. Sullivan v. Schnitger, 16 Wyo. 479, 95 P. 698, 1908 Wyo. LEXIS 35 (Wyo. 1908).

County must sue and be sued in the name of the board of commissioners of the county. Board Comm'rs Sweetwater County v. Young, 3 Wyo. 684, 29 P. 1002, 1892 Wyo. LEXIS 14 (Wyo. 1892).

Big Horn county was not organized before the adoption of the constitution and proceedings for its organization could not be taken until it had a population of 1,500. Board of Comm'rs v. Perkins, 5 Wyo. 166, 38 P. 915, 1895 Wyo. LEXIS 11 (Wyo. 1895).

Applied in

State ex rel. Fawcett v. Board of County Comm'rs, 73 Wyo. 69, 273 P.2d 188, 1954 Wyo. LEXIS 13 (1954).

Cited in

MTM v. LD, 2002 WY 26, 41 P.3d 522, 2002 Wyo. LEXIS 17 (Wyo. 2002).

Law reviews. —

For article, “The Wyoming Constitution: A Centennial Assessment,” see XXVI Land & Water L. Rev. 13 (1991).

§ 2. Organization of new counties.

The legislature shall provide by general law for organizing new counties, locating the county seats thereof temporarily and changing county lines. But no new county shall be formed unless it shall contain within the limits thereof property of the valuation of two million dollars, as shown by last preceding tax returns, and not then unless the remaining portion of the old county or counties shall each contain property of at least three million dollars of assessable valuation; and no new county shall be organized nor shall any organized county be so reduced as to contain a population of less than one thousand five hundred bona fide inhabitants, and in case any portion of an organized county or counties is stricken off to form a new county, the new county shall assume and be holden for an equitable proportion of the indebtedness of the county or counties so reduced. No county shall be divided unless a majority of the qualified electors of the territory proposed to be cut off voting on the proposition shall vote in favor of the division.

Cross references. —

As to organization of new counties, see §§ 18-1-301 to 18-1-320.

New county formed from territory of existing county. —

A new county may be formed out of the territory forming a part of an existing county. Board of Comm'rs v. Woods, 18 Wyo. 316, 106 P. 923, 1910 Wyo. LEXIS 7 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 18 Wyo. 316, 107 P. 753, 1910 Wyo. LEXIS 8 (Wyo. 1910).

Additional requirements permitted. —

This section was cited in connection with the proposition that a legislature may set requirements additional to those set up as the minimum by the constitution. State ex rel. Voiles v. Johnson County High Sch., 43 Wyo. 494, 5 P.2d 255, 1931 Wyo. LEXIS 31 (Wyo. 1931).

Sections 18-1-301 to 18-1-303 are a valid exercise of legislative power to provide by general law for the organization of new counties under this section. Budge v. Board of Comm'rs, 29 Wyo. 35, 208 P. 874, 1922 Wyo. LEXIS 7 (Wyo. 1922).

Curative statute legalizing defective organization of county was not invalid as special act organizing county or regulating its affairs or interfering with uniform operation of general laws. State ex rel. Budge v. Snyder, 30 Wyo. 287, 219 P. 735, 1923 Wyo. LEXIS 45 (Wyo. 1923).

Act creating Big Horn county is not in conflict with this section, as the constitutional provision acts prospectively only, and was adopted subsequent to said section. Board of Comm'rs v. Perkins, 5 Wyo. 166, 38 P. 915, 1895 Wyo. LEXIS 11 (Wyo. 1895).

Elections. —

Provision in an act creating Platte county, providing that it should be considered for election purposes as attached to Laramie county until the officers had qualified, was held to mean elections that would be held in the old county and not to the election on the organization of the new county. Dillman v. State, 20 Wyo. 404, 125 P. 367, 1912 Wyo. LEXIS 46 (Wyo. 1912).

Act providing that only taxpayers could vote at a bond election was unconstitutional. Simpkin v. Rock Springs, 33 Wyo. 166, 237 P. 245, 1925 Wyo. LEXIS 32 (Wyo. 1925).

Applied in

State ex rel. Fawcett v. Board of County Comm'rs, 73 Wyo. 69, 273 P.2d 188, 1954 Wyo. LEXIS 13 (1954).

Stated in

Lund v. Schrader, 492 P.2d 202, 1971 Wyo. LEXIS 277 (Wyo. 1971).

Cited in

In re Fremont County, 8 Wyo. 1, 54 P. 1073, 1898 Wyo. LEXIS 21 (1898); State ex rel. Sullivan v. Schnitger, 16 Wyo. 479, 95 P. 698, 1908 Wyo. LEXIS 35 (1908).

§ 3. Changing county seats.

The legislature shall provide by general law for changing county seats in organized counties, but it shall have no power to remove the county seat of any organized county.

Cross references. —

For enumeration of county seats, see § 18-1-201.

§ 4. Township organization.

The legislature shall provide by general law for a system of township organization and government, which may be adopted by any county whenever a majority of the citizens thereof voting at a general election shall so determine.

Bond election. —

A statute providing that only taxpayers can vote at a bond election was unconstitutional. Simpkin v. Rock Springs, 33 Wyo. 166, 237 P. 245, 1925 Wyo. LEXIS 32 (Wyo. 1925).

§ 5. County officers.

The legislature shall provide by law for the election of such county officers as may be necessary.

Cross references. —

As to county officers generally, see §§ 18-3-101 to 18-3-907.

As to Election Code, see title 22.

County assessors are not constitutional officers, so that the legislature may abolish any of the duties of the office or change the duties to be performed. Reals v. Smith, 8 Wyo. 159, 56 P. 690, 1899 Wyo. LEXIS 6 (Wyo. 1899).

Cited in

In re Johnson, 568 P.2d 855, 1977 Wyo. LEXIS 313 (Wyo. 1977).

Cited in

MTM v. LD, 2002 WY 26, 41 P.3d 522, 2002 Wyo. LEXIS 17 (Wyo. 2002).

Article 13. Municipal Corporations

  • § 1. Incorporation; alteration of boundaries; merger; consolidation; dissolution; determination of local affairs; classification; referendum; liberal construction.
  • § 2. Consent of electors necessary.
  • § 3. Restriction on powers to levy taxes and contract debts.
  • § 4. Franchises.
  • § 5. Acquisition of water rights.

§ 1. Incorporation; alteration of boundaries; merger; consolidation; dissolution; determination of local affairs; classification; referendum; liberal construction.

  1. The legislature shall provide by general law, applicable to all cities and towns,
    1. For the incorporation of cities,
    2. For the methods by which city and town boundaries may be altered, and
    3. For the procedures by which cities and towns may be merged, consolidated or dissolved; provided that existing laws on such subjects and laws pertaining to civil service, retirement, collective bargaining, the levying of taxes, excises, fees, or any other charges, whether or not applicable to all cities and towns on the effective date of this amendment, shall remain in effect until superseded by general law and such existing laws shall not be subject to charter ordinance.
  2. All cities and towns are hereby empowered to determine their local affairs and government as established by ordinance passed by the governing body, subject to referendum when prescribed by the legislature, and further subject only to statutes uniformly applicable to all cities and towns, and to statutes prescribing limits of indebtedness. The levying of taxes, excises, fees, or any other charges shall be prescribed by the legislature. The legislature may not establish more than four (4) classes of cities and towns. Each city and town shall be governed by all other statutes, except as it may exempt itself by charter ordinance as hereinafter provided.
  3. Each city or town may elect that the whole or any part of any statute, other than statutes uniformly applicable to all cities and towns and statutes prescribing limits of indebtedness, may not apply to such city or town. This exemption shall be by charter ordinance passed by a two-thirds (2/3) vote of all members elected to the governing body of the city or town. Each such charter ordinance shall be titled and may provide that the whole or any part of any statute, which would otherwise apply to such city or town as specifically designated in the ordinance shall not apply to such city or town. Such ordinance may provide other provisions on the same subject. Every charter ordinance shall be published once each week for two consecutive weeks in the official city or town newspaper, if any, otherwise in a newspaper of general circulation in the city or town. No charter ordinance shall take effect until the sixtieth (60th) day after its final publication. If prior thereto, a petition, signed by a number of qualified electors of the city or town, equaling at least ten per cent (10%) of the number of votes cast at the last general municipal election, shall be filed in the office of the clerk of such city or town, demanding that such ordinance be submitted to referendum, then the ordinance shall not take effect unless approved by a majority of the electors voting thereon. Such referendum election shall be called within thirty (30) days and held within ninety (90) days after the petition is filed. An ordinance establishing procedures, and fixing the date of such election shall be passed by the governing body and published once each week for three (3) consecutive weeks in the official city or town newspaper, if any, otherwise in a newspaper of general circulation in the city or town. The question on the ballot shall be: “Shall Charter Ordinance No. . . . . .  Entitled (stating the title of the ordinance) take effect?”. The governing body may submit, without a petition, any charter ordinance to referendum election under the procedures as previously set out. The charter ordinance shall take effect if approved by a majority of the electors voting thereon. An approved charter ordinance, after becoming effective, shall be recorded by the clerk in a book maintained for that purpose with a certificate of the procedures of adoption. A certified copy of the ordinance shall be filed with the secretary of state, who shall keep an index of such ordinances. Each charter ordinance enacted shall prevail over any prior act of the governing body of the city or town, and may be repealed or amended only by subsequent charter ordinance, or by enactments of the legislature applicable to all cities and towns.
  4. The powers and authority granted to cities and towns, pursuant to this section, shall be liberally construed for the purpose of giving the largest measure of self-government to cities and towns. (As amended by Laws 1971, Senate Joint Resolution No. 1, p. 715.)

Cross references. —

As to municipal corporations generally, see title 15.

This section is popularly known as the home-rule amendment. Police Protective Ass'n v. Rock Springs, 631 P.2d 433, 1981 Wyo. LEXIS 329 (Wyo. 1981).

City or town can only exercise those powers expressly or impliedly conferred by constitution or statute. Tri-County Elec. Ass'n v. Gillette, 584 P.2d 995, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 227 (Wyo. 1978).

Legislature has power to classify cities. May v. Laramie, 58 Wyo. 240, 131 P.2d 300, 1942 Wyo. LEXIS 21 (Wyo. 1942).

Classification based on population is sufficient basis in many cases, but sound and sufficient reason must appear, and arbitrary classification based on population cannot be sustained. May v. Laramie, 58 Wyo. 240, 131 P.2d 300, 1942 Wyo. LEXIS 21 (Wyo. 1942).

Commission manager form does not create classification. —

Provision for commission manager form of government does not create a classification of cities within the intent of this section. State ex rel. Diers v. Sheldon, 29 Wyo. 233, 213 P. 92, 1923 Wyo. LEXIS 11 (Wyo. 1923).

Cities adopting commission form of government are not a class not contemplated herein. State ex rel. Diers v. Sheldon, 29 Wyo. 233, 213 P. 92, 1923 Wyo. LEXIS 11 (Wyo. 1923).

In considering constitutionality of statute creating second class city and in determining what is reasonable or arbitrary classification, court may consider nearly contemporaneous enactment relating to cities of first class. May v. Laramie, 58 Wyo. 240, 131 P.2d 300, 1942 Wyo. LEXIS 21 (Wyo. 1942).

Class within a class. —

Chapter 28, Laws 1897, was in violation of this section, insofar as cities organized under general laws were concerned because statute created a class within a class. May v. Laramie, 58 Wyo. 240, 131 P.2d 300, 1942 Wyo. LEXIS 21 (Wyo. 1942).

Uniform operation of statutes. —

A law operating uniformly on all cities of one class or all of several recognized classes is not unconstitutional. State ex rel. Diers v. Sheldon, 29 Wyo. 233, 213 P. 92, 1923 Wyo. LEXIS 11 (Wyo. 1923).

Municipalities can join together under Joint Powers Act. —

There is no prohibition in the Wyoming constitution which would preclude the legislature from permitting political subdivisions of the state of Wyoming from joining together, as allowed by the Joint Powers Act, §§ 16-1-102 through 16-1-110.Frank v. Cody, 572 P.2d 1106, 1977 Wyo. LEXIS 304 (Wyo. 1977).

Limitations on power to incur indebtedness. —

Specific constitutional limitations on power of municipal corporation to incur indebtedness do not prevent legislature from imposing additional restrictions. Whipps v. Greybull, 56 Wyo. 355, 109 P.2d 805, 1941 Wyo. LEXIS 5 (Wyo. 1941).

Board of public utilities. —

Legislature may constitutionally grant to municipal corporation right to elect or appoint board of public utilities. Stewart v. Cheyenne, 60 Wyo. 497, 154 P.2d 355, 1944 Wyo. LEXIS 20 (Wyo. 1944).

Police force. —

An act relating to, and prescribing a procedure to be followed in dismissing or demoting members of the police force, was held unconstitutional, as creating an arbitrary class of cities. McFarland v. Cheyenne, 48 Wyo. 86, 42 P.2d 413, 1935 Wyo. LEXIS 24 (Wyo. 1935).

Section does not authorize city to establish nonprofit corporation to purchase and resell to city facilities for water supply. "Laramie Citizens for Good Government" v. Laramie, 617 P.2d 474, 1980 Wyo. LEXIS 307 (Wyo. 1980).

Fire and police civil service not “local affairs.” —

As the provisions of art. 1, ch. 5, title 15, relating to police and fire department civil service, are “statutes uniformly applicable to all cities and towns,” they must be complied with, despite subsection (b)'s authorization of cities and towns to “determine their local affairs and government.” Police Protective Ass'n v. Rock Springs, 631 P.2d 433, 1981 Wyo. LEXIS 329 (Wyo. 1981).

Driving under the influence.—

In a case involving two petitioners who were both convicted of driving under the influence, the Supreme Court concluded that Laramie, Wyo., Mun. Ordinance § 10.24.030(H) flouted the uniformly applicable statutes governing traffic regulations and was therefore void. The City of Laramie had created a minimum mandatory jail sentence for blood alcohol content (BAC) results of 0.15% or more, which exceeded the minimum punishment for the same BAC level under Wyoming law. Wofford v. City of Laramie, 2016 WY 59, 375 P.3d 740, 2016 Wyo. LEXIS 68 (Wyo. 2016).

Convictions in municipal courts for driving while intoxicated are for violations of ordinances and not of state statutes, even if the state statute is copied verbatim in the ordinance or if it is adopted as the ordinance by reference to it. State ex rel. Motor Vehicle Div. v. Holtz, 674 P.2d 732, 1983 Wyo. LEXIS 394 (Wyo. 1983).

Applied in

Coulter v. City of Rawlins, 662 P.2d 888, 1983 Wyo. LEXIS 311 (Wyo. 1983).

Quoted in

City of Rock Springs v. Police Protection Ass'n, 610 P.2d 975, 1980 Wyo. LEXIS 261 (Wyo. 1980); Cook v. Zoning Bd. of Adjustment, 776 P.2d 181, 1989 Wyo. LEXIS 148 (Wyo. 1989); City of Torrington v. Smith, 2016 WY 126, 386 P.3d 336, 2016 Wyo. LEXIS 140 (Wyo. 2016).

Stated in

Day v. Armstrong, 362 P.2d 137, 1961 Wyo. LEXIS 97 (Wyo. 1961).

Law reviews. —

For note on home rule as a solution for municipal problems, see 16 Wyo. L.J. 47 (1961).

For comment, “The Municipal Action Exemption to the Federal Antitrust Laws: Increased Antitrust Exposure for Wyoming Cities and Towns,” see XIX Land & Water L. Rev. 673 (1984).

For article, “The Wyoming Constitution: A Centennial Assessment,” see XXVI Land & Water L. Rev. 13 (1991).

For article, “No Home on the Range for Home Rule,” see XXXI Land & Water L. Rev. 791 (1996).

§ 2. Consent of electors necessary.

No municipal corporation shall be organized without the consent of the majority of the electors residing within the district proposed to be so incorporated, such consent to be ascertained in the manner and under such regulations as may be prescribed by law.

This section was not self-executing, and did not, without legislation to carry it into effect, by implication repeal the then existing law authorizing incorporation of towns or application of 30 electors. State ex rel. Vidal v. Lamoureux, 3 Wyo. 731, 30 P. 243, 1892 Wyo. LEXIS 15 (Wyo. 1892).

Prohibitions of this section do not relate to irrigation districts. Sullivan v. Blakesley, 35 Wyo. 73, 246 P. 918, 1926 Wyo. LEXIS 9 (Wyo. 1926).

Bond elections. —

A statute providing that only taxpayers may vote at bond elections is unconstitutional. Simpkin v. Rock Springs, 33 Wyo. 166, 237 P. 245, 1925 Wyo. LEXIS 32 (Wyo. 1925).

Cited in

Mestas v. Diamond Coal & Coke Co., 12 Wyo. 414, 76 P. 567, 1904 Wyo. LEXIS 10 (1904).

§ 3. Restriction on powers to levy taxes and contract debts.

The legislature shall restrict the powers of such corporations to levy taxes and assessments, to borrow money and contract debts so as to prevent the abuse of such power, and no tax or assessment shall be levied or collected or debts contracted by municipal corporations except in pursuance of law for public purposes specified by law.

Cross references. —

For another limitation on power of cities to levy taxes, see art. 15, § 6, Wyo. Const.

Municipalities, in their right to tax, are tightly hemmed in this section. Witzenburger v. State, 575 P.2d 1100, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 266 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 577 P.2d 1386, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 289 (Wyo. 1978).

And have only powers delegated by legislature. —

Such entities as counties and municipalities have no inherent powers but only those specially delegated to them by legislative action. Witzenburger v. State, 575 P.2d 1100, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 266 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 577 P.2d 1386, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 289 (Wyo. 1978).

Limitations on power to incur indebtedness. —

Specific constitutional limitations on power of municipal corporation to incur indebtedness do not prevent legislature from imposing additional restrictions. Whipps v. Greybull, 56 Wyo. 355, 109 P.2d 805, 1941 Wyo. LEXIS 5 (Wyo. 1941).

Authority to borrow money and issue bonds. —

Town council, without approval by vote of the people, does not have authority to borrow money to pay for municipal light and power plant and to issue bonds payable solely from revenues accruing from operation of plant. Whipps v. Greybull, 56 Wyo. 355, 109 P.2d 805, 1941 Wyo. LEXIS 5 (Wyo. 1941).

This section does not prohibit municipal corporation from borrowing within applicable limitations of art. Witzenburger v. State, 575 P.2d 1100, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 266 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 577 P.2d 1386, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 289 (Wyo. 1978).

Voting at bond elections. —

A statute providing that only taxpayers may vote at bond elections in unconstitutional. Simpkin v. Rock Springs, 33 Wyo. 166, 237 P. 245, 1925 Wyo. LEXIS 32 (Wyo. 1925).

Refunding authorized by General Obligation Public Securities Refunding Law is for a public purpose, as required by this section. Rodin v. State, 417 P.2d 180, 1966 Wyo. LEXIS 155 (Wyo. 1966).

Purchasing public utility plant. —

Power to purchase public utility plant accorded cities and towns by ch. 78, Laws 1933, does not imply a power also to finance that purchase in a manner which legislature has persistently refused to recognize. Jensen v. Afton, 59 Wyo. 500, 143 P.2d 190, 1943 Wyo. LEXIS 26 (Wyo. 1943).

Town did not have power to issue revenue bonds to purchase power company property, especially where such property had over half the assessed value of all taxable property and town already had bonded indebtedness of $53,000 and the school district, of $66,000. Jensen v. Afton, 59 Wyo. 500, 143 P.2d 190, 1943 Wyo. LEXIS 26 (Wyo. 1943).

Occupation tax. —

Where an occupation tax was authorized by § 15-1-103(a)(xiii), it must be said that it was enacted in pursuance of law within the meaning of this section. City of Rawlins v. Frontier Ref. Co., 396 P.2d 740, 1964 Wyo. LEXIS 128 (Wyo. 1964).

Permit fee for motor caravans. —

A city has the power to enact all ordinances, not inconsistent with the laws of the state, for the general welfare of such cities, including an ordinance for regulation and supervision of motor caravans, which involved the exaction of a permit fee. Kenosha Auto Transp. Corp. v. Cheyenne, 55 Wyo. 298, 100 P.2d 109, 1940 Wyo. LEXIS 11 (Wyo. 1940).

Industrial Development Projects Act held constitutional. —

See Reed v. Cheyenne, 429 P.2d 69, 1967 Wyo. LEXIS 160 (Wyo. 1967); Uhls v. State, 429 P.2d 74, 1967 Wyo. LEXIS 161 (Wyo. 1967); Powers v. Cheyenne, 435 P.2d 448, 1967 Wyo. LEXIS 191 (Wyo. 1967), reh'g denied, 436 P.2d 961, 1968 Wyo. LEXIS 155 (Wyo. 1968).

Quoted in

Mariano & Assocs. v. Board of County Comm'rs, 737 P.2d 323, 1987 Wyo. LEXIS 444 (Wyo. 1987); K N Energy, Inc. v. City of Casper, 755 P.2d 207, 1988 Wyo. LEXIS 78 (Wyo. 1988).

Cited in

State ex rel. Vidal v. Lamoureux, 3 Wyo. 731, 30 P. 243, 1892 Wyo. LEXIS 15 (1892).

§ 4. Franchises.

No street passenger railway, telegraph, telephone or electric light line shall be constructed within the limits of any municipal organization without the consent of its local authorities.

Legislature and this section give cities extensive control over electric utilities within their boundaries. Tri-County Elec. Ass'n v. Gillette, 584 P.2d 995, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 227 (Wyo. 1978).

City immune from antitrust liability for denying franchise. —

Under the “state action” doctrine as applied to the laws of the state, the city was immune from antitrust liability for denying plaintiff a franchise for electric service within the city while granting defendant a monopoly. Rural Electric Co. v. Cheyenne Light, Fuel & Power Co., 602 F. Supp. 105, 1983 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 18645 (D. Wyo. 1983), aff'd, 762 F.2d 847, 1985 U.S. App. LEXIS 31246 (10th Cir. Wyo. 1985).

An antitrust action by a power company against another power company and a municipality, following the issuance by the public service commission to the defendant-power company of a nonexclusive franchise to serve the municipality, alleging an anticompetitive conspiracy to keep the plaintiff-power company out of the municipality, was dismissed under the “state action” immunity doctrine. Rural Electric Co. v. Cheyenne Light, Fuel & Power Co., 762 F.2d 847, 1985 U.S. App. LEXIS 31246 (10th Cir. Wyo. 1985).

Jurisdiction to adjudicate rights between city and public utility in contract dispute. —

Courts, rather than the public service commission, have jurisdiction to adjudicate rights between city and public utility in contract dispute between them. Tri-County Elec. Ass'n v. Gillette, 525 P.2d 3, 1974 Wyo. LEXIS 226 (Wyo. 1974).

Law reviews. —

For article, “State Jurisdiction over the Regulation of Energy Distribution and Other Public Utility Services,” see XV Land & Water L. Rev. 535 (1980).

§ 5. Acquisition of water rights.

Municipal corporations shall have the same right as individuals to acquire rights by prior appropriation and otherwise to the use of water for domestic and municipal purposes, and the legislature shall provide by law for the exercise upon the part of incorporated cities, towns and villages of the right of eminent domain for the purpose of acquiring from prior appropriators upon the payment of just compensation, such water as may be necessary for the well being thereof and for domestic uses.

Cross references. —

As to irrigation and water rights generally, see art. 8, §§ 1 to 5, Wyo. Const. See also title 41.

Supreme court judgments established rule of property. —

Supreme court judgments establishing rights of municipality in waters of stream as prior appropriator established rule of property which would not be overruled where city had expended large sums of money in reliance thereon and could have condemned prior rights at reasonable amount before times of water scarcity. Van Tassel Real Estate & Livestock Co. v. Cheyenne, 49 Wyo. 333, 54 P.2d 906, 1936 Wyo. LEXIS 49 (Wyo.), cert. denied, 299 U.S. 574, 57 S. Ct. 38, 81 L. Ed. 423, 1936 U.S. LEXIS 282 (U.S. 1936); Application of Beaver Dam Ditch Co., 54 Wyo. 459, 93 P.2d 934, 1939 Wyo. LEXIS 28 (Wyo. 1939).

Deed conveying use of water held enforceable. —

A deed by which appropriators conveyed the use of all the water to which grantor was entitled on alternate weeks is enforceable as against a subsequent appropriator, where no more water was shown to have been used than they could use beneficially. Johnston v. Little Horse Creek Irrigating Co., 13 Wyo. 208, 79 P. 22, 1904 Wyo. LEXIS 39 (Wyo. 1904).

Applied in

Barber v. City of Douglas, 931 P.2d 948, 1997 Wyo. LEXIS 19 (Wyo. 1997).

Law reviews. —

For article, “A Critical Look at Wyoming Water Law,” see XXIV Land & Water L. Rev. 307 (1989).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Right of owner of land not originally taken or purchased as part of adjacent project to recover, on enlargement of project to include adjacent land, enhanced value of property by reason of proximity to original land, 95 ALR3d 752.

Article 14. Public Officers

  • § 1. Stated salaries to be paid.
  • § 2. Fees.
  • § 3. Legislature to designate county offices and fix salaries of county officers.
  • § 4. Deputies.
  • § 5. Who are county officers referred to by section 3.
  • § 6. Consolidation of offices.

§ 1. Stated salaries to be paid.

All state, city, county, town and school officers, (excepting justices of the peace and constables in precincts having less than fifteen hundred population, and excepting court commissioners, boards of arbitration and notaries public) shall be paid fixed and definite salaries. The legislature shall, from time to time, fix the amount of such salaries as are not already fixed by this constitution, which shall in all cases be in proportion to the value of the services rendered and the duty performed.

Cross references. —

As to compensation of legislators, see art. 3, § 6, Wyo. Const.

For provision that compensation of legislators shall not be increased during term, see art. 3, § 9, Wyo. Const.

As to prohibition of granting extra compensation to public officers, see art. 3, § 30, Wyo. Const.

As to prohibition of change in salary of public officer after elected, see art. 3, § 32, Wyo. Const.

As to salary of governor and other state officers, see art. 4, § 13, Wyo. Const.

As to amount of salary of state officers and employees, see § 9-3-101.

Powers of legislature. —

Legislature may fix minimum as well as maximum amount of salaries, or definite amount, but if legislature fixes maximum to be paid municipal officers, leaving to municipalities power to fix definite amounts to meet local conditions, that is sufficient. May v. Laramie, 58 Wyo. 240, 131 P.2d 300, 1942 Wyo. LEXIS 21 (Wyo. 1942).

Ordinarily, if legislature fixes rule under which compensation of officials in municipalities is to be fixed, that is sufficient. May v. Laramie, 58 Wyo. 240, 131 P.2d 300, 1942 Wyo. LEXIS 21 (Wyo. 1942).

Emoluments. —

The language of the several sections of this article make it apparent that the framers had in mind that there were officers who would not receive a salary but would receive “emoluments.” Taxpayers' League of Carbon County v. McPherson, 49 Wyo. 251, 54 P.2d 897, 1936 Wyo. LEXIS 48 (Wyo. 1936).

Secretary of state while acting governor was entitled to salary of both offices, where he performed the duty of both. State ex rel. Chatterton v. Grant, 12 Wyo. 1, 73 P. 470, 1903 Wyo. LEXIS 23 (Wyo. 1903).

Act fixing salary of state examiner was held to operate as an appropriation and not to require any special appropriation of each session of the legislature to keep it alive. State ex rel. Henderson v. Burdick, 4 Wyo. 272, 33 P. 125, 1893 Wyo. LEXIS 11 (Wyo. 1893).

Change in salaries of county officials. —

The slight variance in language between the second sentence of this section and § 3 of this article does not carry any idea or notion that in either section anything was intended regarding a change in the salaries of county officials during their term or after their election or appointment. Blackburn v. Board of County Comm'rs, 67 Wyo. 494, 226 P.2d 784, 1951 Wyo. LEXIS 37 (Wyo. 1951).

This section does not imply that the salaries of county officers can be increased or diminished after their election and appointment, and during their term of service. Board of Comm'rs v. Burns, 3 Wyo. 691, 29 P. 894, 1892 Wyo. LEXIS 12 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 3 Wyo. 691, 29 P. 894, 1892 Wyo. LEXIS 13 (Wyo. 1892).

No change in the salary of a county clerk can be made during his term of office. Guthrie v. Board of Comm'rs, 7 Wyo. 95, 50 P. 229, 1897 Wyo. LEXIS 16 (Wyo. 1897).

Commission manager form of government. —

Provision in act providing for commission manager form of government for fixing of salaries by the council is void. State ex rel. Diers v. Sheldon, 29 Wyo. 233, 213 P. 92, 1923 Wyo. LEXIS 11 (Wyo. 1923).

An act providing for commission form of government which did not fix the salary of police judge is not invalid therefor. State ex rel. Diers v. Sheldon, 29 Wyo. 233, 213 P. 92, 1923 Wyo. LEXIS 11 (Wyo. 1923).

Office manager who is under control of board of public utilities is an employee and not an officer and his salary need not be fixed by legislature. Stewart v. Cheyenne, 60 Wyo. 497, 154 P.2d 355, 1944 Wyo. LEXIS 20 (Wyo. 1944).

Fees. —

A sheriff was not entitled to retain fees received for the inspection of stock in addition to his salary, as he was in the case of services rendered in civil actions pending in courts. Messenger v. Board of Comm'rs, 19 Wyo. 309, 117 P. 126, 1911 Wyo. LEXIS 21 (Wyo. 1911).

County attorney was not entitled to additional fee for prosecuting action to abate liquor nuisance. State ex rel. Cone v. Bernweiser, 39 Wyo. 314, 271 P. 13, 1928 Wyo. LEXIS 98 (Wyo. 1928).

The state, in proceeding to abate liquor nuisance, was not entitled to tax reasonable attorney's fees, which statute allows successful complainant, as the compensation of the county attorney is covered by his salary. State ex rel. Cone v. Bernweiser, 39 Wyo. 314, 271 P. 13, 1928 Wyo. LEXIS 98 (Wyo. 1928).

Finding by county commissioners regarding population of county precinct. —

The finding by the board of county commissioners that a county precinct contained 1,500 population for the purpose of salary of a justice of the peace will not be disturbed in the absence of proof that it erred. Davis v. Board of Comm'rs, 4 Wyo. 477, 35 P. 467, 1894 Wyo. LEXIS 3 (Wyo. 1894).

Defenses in action for salary by clerk of district court. —

It is no defense to an action by the clerk of a district court for salary that he has failed or refused to account for fees received by him, since there is a separate proceeding provided for compelling such accounting, by enforcement of liability on his official bond. Board of Comm'rs v. Atkinson, 4 Wyo. 334, 33 P. 995, 1893 Wyo. LEXIS 16 (Wyo. 1893).

The fact that, after the qualification of the clerk of the district court, one of the sureties on his bond died, and he failed to furnish a new bond, though requested by the county board so to do, is no defense to an action for his salary, if there was no declaration by competent authority that the office was vacant, and no steps were taken to oust him from office. Board of Comm'rs v. Atkinson, 4 Wyo. 334, 33 P. 995, 1893 Wyo. LEXIS 16 (Wyo. 1893).

Cited in

Reals v. Smith, 8 Wyo. 159, 56 P. 690, 1899 Wyo. LEXIS 6 (1899).

Law reviews. —

For article, “The Wyoming Constitution: A Centennial Assessment,” see XXVI Land & Water L. Rev. 13 (1991).

For case note, “Local Government Law—Platte County's Cost of Living Adjustment: Is It an Unconstitutional In-Term Adjustment of an Elected Officer's Salary?,” see XXXV Land & Water L. Rev. 549 (2000).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Validity of statutory classifications based on population — governmental employee salary or pension statutes, 96 ALR3d 538.

§ 2. Fees.

The legislature shall provide by law the fees which may be demanded by justices of the peace and constables in precincts having less than fifteen hundred population, and of court commissioners, boards of arbitration and notaries public, which fees the said officers shall accept as their full compensation. But all other state, county, city, town and school officers shall be required by law to keep a true and correct account of all fees collected by them, and to pay the same into the proper treasury when collected, and the officer whose duty it is to collect such fees shall be held responsible, under his bond, for neglect to collect the same. (As amended by Laws 1989, Senate Joint Resolution No. 1, p. 770.)

Cross references. —

As to fees of court commissioners, see § 5-3-308.

For provisions abolishing office of constable, see § 5-4-401.

As to fees of sheriff for services rendered in civil cases, see § 18-3-608.

As to fees of notaries public, see § 32-1-112.

Emoluments. —

The language of the several sections of this article make it apparent that the framers had in mind that there were officers who would not receive a salary but would receive “emoluments.” Taxpayers' League of Carbon County v. McPherson, 49 Wyo. 251, 54 P.2d 897, 1936 Wyo. LEXIS 48 (Wyo. 1936).

Inspection of stock by sheriff. —

A sheriff was not entitled to retain fees received for inspection of stock in addition to his salary, as he was in case of services rendered in civil actions pending in courts. Messenger v. Board of Comm'rs, 19 Wyo. 309, 117 P. 126, 1911 Wyo. LEXIS 21 (Wyo. 1911).

Action by county attorney to abate liquor nuisance. —

County attorney was not entitled to additional fee for prosecuting action to abate liquor nuisance. State ex rel. Cone v. Bernweiser, 39 Wyo. 314, 271 P. 13, 1928 Wyo. LEXIS 98 (Wyo. 1928).

The state, in proceeding to abate liquor nuisance, was not entitled to tax reasonable attorney's fees which statute allows successful complainant, as the compensation of the county attorney is covered by his salary. State ex rel. Cone v. Bernweiser, 39 Wyo. 314, 271 P. 13, 1928 Wyo. LEXIS 98 (Wyo. 1928).

Defense in action for salary by clerk of district court. —

It is no defense to an action by a clerk of a district court for salary that he had failed or refused to account for fees received by him, since there is a separate proceeding provided for compelling such accounting, by enforcement of liability on his official bond. Board of Comm'rs v. Atkinson, 4 Wyo. 334, 33 P. 995, 1893 Wyo. LEXIS 16 (Wyo. 1893).

Cited in

Board of Comm'rs v. Burns, 3 Wyo. 691, 29 P. 894, 1892 Wyo. LEXIS 12 (1892); Davis v. Board of Comm'rs, 4 Wyo. 477, 35 P. 467, 1894 Wyo. LEXIS 3 (1894).

§ 3. Legislature to designate county offices and fix salaries of county officers.

The legislature shall by law designate county offices and shall, from time to time, fix the salaries of county officers, which shall in all cases be in proportion to the value of the services rendered and the duties performed. (As amended by Laws 1943, House Joint Resolution No. 1, p. 167.)

Cross references. —

As to county officers generally, see §§ 18-3-101 to 18-3-907.

As to salaries, fees and expenses generally, see §§ 18-3-107 to 18-3-110.

Nature of duties imposed by law. —

When duties are imposed upon a public officer, such as a county clerk, by law rather than by some appointing power, such duties are usually governmental and not ministerial. Denver Buick v. Pearson, 465 P.2d 512, 1970 Wyo. LEXIS 157 (Wyo. 1970).

County assessors are not constitutional officers, so that the legislature may abolish any of the duties of the office or change the duties to be performed. Reals v. Smith, 8 Wyo. 159, 56 P. 690, 1899 Wyo. LEXIS 6 (Wyo. 1899).

Emoluments. —

The language of the several sections of this article make it apparent that the framers had in mind that there were officers who would not receive a salary but would receive “emoluments.” Taxpayers' League of Carbon County v. McPherson, 49 Wyo. 251, 54 P.2d 897, 1936 Wyo. LEXIS 48 (Wyo. 1936).

Fees. —

A sheriff was not entitled to retain fees received for the inspection of stock in addition to his salary, as he was in the case of services rendered in civil actions pending in courts. Messenger v. Board of Comm'rs, 19 Wyo. 309, 117 P. 126, 1911 Wyo. LEXIS 21 (Wyo. 1911).

County attorney was not entitled to additional fee for prosecuting action to abate liquor nuisance. State ex rel. Cone v. Bernweiser, 39 Wyo. 314, 271 P. 13, 1928 Wyo. LEXIS 98 (Wyo. 1928).

The state, in proceeding to abate liquor nuisance, was not entitled to tax reasonable attorney's fees, which statute allows successful complainant, as the compensation of the county attorney is covered by his salary. State ex rel. Cone v. Bernweiser, 39 Wyo. 314, 271 P. 13, 1928 Wyo. LEXIS 98 (Wyo. 1928).

Changes in salary. —

Under this section and a statute prescribing the “annual” salary of treasurers of the counties, the salary must continue same throughout an official year, and cannot be made more or less for the last than the first part. Board of Comm'rs v. Burns, 3 Wyo. 691, 29 P. 894, 1892 Wyo. LEXIS 12 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 3 Wyo. 691, 29 P. 894, 1892 Wyo. LEXIS 13 (Wyo. 1892).

No change can be made in the salary of a county clerk during his term. Guthrie v. Board of Comm'rs, 7 Wyo. 95, 50 P. 229, 1897 Wyo. LEXIS 16 (Wyo. 1897).

Applied in

Pfister v. Niobrara County, 557 P.2d 735, 1976 Wyo. LEXIS 233 (Wyo. 1976).

Cited in

Grand Island & N.W.R.R. v. Baker, 6 Wyo. 369, 45 P. 494, 1896 Wyo. LEXIS 21, 34 L.R.A. 835 (1896); In re Johnson, 568 P.2d 855, 1977 Wyo. LEXIS 313 (Wyo. 1977).

Law reviews. —

For case note, “Local Government Law—Platte County's Cost of Living Adjustment: Is It an Unconstitutional In-Term Adjustment of an Elected Officer's Salary?,” see XXXV Land & Water L. Rev. 549 (2000).

§ 4. Deputies.

The legislature shall provide by general law for such deputies as the public necessities may require, and shall fix their compensation.

Cross references. —

As to deputies to state officers generally, see § 9-1-101.

As to deputies to county officers, see §§ 18-3-111, 18-3-112.

Deputy county clerk. —

Where board of county commissioners did not consent to appointment of deputy clerk under law providing county clerk in such county might appoint deputy with consent of board, but paid deputy's salary, payment may constitute ratification of the appointment, but board may withdraw its consent at any time. Griggs v. Board of Comm'rs, 5 Wyo. 274, 40 P. 304, 1895 Wyo. LEXIS 21 (Wyo. 1895).

Applied in

Pfister v. Niobrara County, 557 P.2d 735, 1976 Wyo. LEXIS 233 (Wyo. 1976).

Cited in

Board of Comm'rs v. Burns, 3 Wyo. 691, 29 P. 894, 1892 Wyo. LEXIS 12 (1892).

§ 5. Who are county officers referred to by section 3.

Any county officers performing the duties usually performed by the officers named in this article shall be considered as referred to by section 3 of this article, regardless of the title by which their offices may hereafter be designated.

County assessors are not constitutional officers, so that the legislature may abolish any of the duties of the office or change the duties to be performed. Reals v. Smith, 8 Wyo. 159, 56 P. 690, 1899 Wyo. LEXIS 6 (Wyo. 1899).

Applied in

Pfister v. Niobrara County, 557 P.2d 735, 1976 Wyo. LEXIS 233 (Wyo. 1976).

Cited in

In re Johnson, 568 P.2d 855, 1977 Wyo. LEXIS 313 (Wyo. 1977).

§ 6. Consolidation of offices.

Whenever practicable the legislature may, and whenever the same can be done without detriment to the public service, shall consolidate offices in state, county and municipalities respectively, and whenever so consolidated, the duties of such additional office shall be performed under an ex officio title.

Office of county assessor may be consolidated with that of county treasurer under the provisions hereof. Reals v. Smith, 8 Wyo. 159, 56 P. 690, 1899 Wyo. LEXIS 6 (Wyo. 1899).

Article 15. Taxation and Revenue

  • § 1. Assessment of lands and improvements thereon.
  • § 2. Assessment of coal lands.
  • § 3. Taxation of mines and mining claims.
  • § 4. State levy limited.
  • § 5. County levies limited.
  • § 6. City levies limited.
  • § 7. Depositories for public moneys.
  • § 8. Profit making from public funds prohibited.
  • § 9. Legislature to provide for state board of equalization.
  • § 10. Duties of state board of equalization.
  • § 11. Uniformity of assessment required.
  • § 12. Exemptions from taxation.
  • § 13. Tax must be authorized by law; law to state object.
  • § 14. Surrender of taxing power prohibited.
  • § 15. State tax for support of public schools.
  • § 16. Disposition of fees, excises and license taxes on vehicles and gasoline.
  • § 17. County levy for support and maintenance of public schools.
  • § 18. Full tax credit allowed against any liability arising from a tax on income.
  • § 19. Mineral excise tax; distribution.
  • § 20. Higher education trust funds; investments; earnings.

§ 1. Assessment of lands and improvements thereon.

All lands and improvements thereon shall be listed for assessment, valued for taxation and assessed separately.

Cross references. —

For provision that no tax shall be imposed without the consent of the people and that all taxation shall be equal and uniform, see art. 1, § 28, Wyo. Const.

As to origin of revenue bills, see art. 3, § 33, Wyo. Const.

As to homestead exemption, see art. 19, § 9, Wyo. Const.

As to taxation generally, see title 39.

Special assessments for municipal improvements. —

This section does not restrict the power to levy special assessments for municipal improvements. McGarvey v. Swan, 17 Wyo. 120, 96 P. 697, 1908 Wyo. LEXIS 11 (Wyo. 1908).

City council was held not authorized to pass ordinance taxing each lot certain amount for water for irrigation, regardless of value of the property. Town Council of Hudson v. Board of Comm'rs, 37 Wyo. 160, 259 P. 1051, 1927 Wyo. LEXIS 74 (Wyo. 1927).

Gross product tax. —

Tax on gross product of all mines and mining claims in Wyoming is a tax on “personalty.” Board of Comm'rs v. Bernardin, 74 F.2d 809, 1934 U.S. App. LEXIS 4015 (10th Cir. Wyo. 1934), cert. denied, 295 U.S. 731, 55 S. Ct. 645, 79 L. Ed. 1680, 1935 U.S. LEXIS 1129 (U.S. 1935).

Decision of state court, based on construction of constitution and statutes of Wyoming that gross product tax was not a severance tax, is binding on the federal courts. Board of Comm'rs v. Bernardin, 74 F.2d 809, 1934 U.S. App. LEXIS 4015 (10th Cir. Wyo. 1934), cert. denied, 295 U.S. 731, 55 S. Ct. 645, 79 L. Ed. 1680, 1935 U.S. LEXIS 1129 (U.S. 1935).

Taxes not allowable as administrative expense. —

Taxes against a corporation, for which a receiver was appointed, are not allowable as administrative expense. First Nat'l Bank v. Central Coal & Coke Co., 3 F. Supp. 433, 1933 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 1628 (D. Wyo. 1933), modified, 74 F.2d 809, 1934 U.S. App. LEXIS 4015 (10th Cir. Wyo. 1934).

Quoted in

Oregon Basin Oil & Gas Co. v. Ohio Oil Co., 70 Wyo. 263, 248 P.2d 198, 1952 Wyo. LEXIS 31 (1952).

Cited in

State ex rel. Greenwood v. Pearson, 46 Wyo. 307, 26 P.2d 641, 1933 Wyo. LEXIS 45 (1933).

Law reviews. —

For article, “Remedies for Defects in General Property Tax Assessments in Wyoming,” see 4 Wyo. L.J. 240.

For article, “Royalty Interest — Real or Personal,” see 7 Wyo. L.J. 145.

For article, “The Wyoming Constitution: A Centennial Assessment,” see XXVI Land & Water L. Rev. 13 (1991).

§ 2. Assessment of coal lands.

All coal lands in the state from which coal is not being mined shall be listed for assessment, valued for taxation and assessed according to value.

Gross product tax. —

Tax on gross product of all mines and mining claims in Wyoming is a tax on “personalty.” Board of Comm'rs v. Bernardin, 74 F.2d 809, 1934 U.S. App. LEXIS 4015 (10th Cir. Wyo. 1934), cert. denied, 295 U.S. 731, 55 S. Ct. 645, 79 L. Ed. 1680, 1935 U.S. LEXIS 1129 (U.S. 1935).

Decision of state court, based on construction of constitution and statutes of Wyoming that gross product tax was not a severance tax, is binding on the federal courts. Board of Comm'rs v. Bernardin, 74 F.2d 809, 1934 U.S. App. LEXIS 4015 (10th Cir. Wyo. 1934), cert. denied, 295 U.S. 731, 55 S. Ct. 645, 79 L. Ed. 1680, 1935 U.S. LEXIS 1129 (U.S. 1935).

Taxes not allowable as administrative expense. —

Taxes against a corporation, for which a receiver was appointed, are not allowable as administrative expense. First Nat'l Bank v. Central Coal & Coke Co., 3 F. Supp. 433, 1933 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 1628 (D. Wyo. 1933), modified, 74 F.2d 809, 1934 U.S. App. LEXIS 4015 (10th Cir. Wyo. 1934).

Applied in

State ex rel. Wilkerson v. State Bd. of Equalization, 490 P.2d 1258, 1971 Wyo. LEXIS 270 (Wyo. 1971).

Cited in

Oregon Basin Oil & Gas Co. v. Ohio Oil Co., 70 Wyo. 263, 248 P.2d 198, 1952 Wyo. LEXIS 31 (1952).

§ 3. Taxation of mines and mining claims.

All mines and mining claims from which gold, silver and other precious metals, soda, saline, coal, mineral oil or other valuable deposit, is or may be produced shall be taxed in addition to the surface improvements, and in lieu of taxes on the lands, on the gross product thereof, as may be prescribed by law; provided, that the product of all mines shall be taxed in proportion to the value thereof.

Tax deed voidable, not void. —

Assignee's contest of a mineral tax deed was time-barred because an error in the property's assessment rendered the deed voidable, not void, as a county had authority to tax minerals, so there was no clear jurisdictional error. Anadarko Land Corp. v. Family Tree Corp., 2017 WY 24, 389 P.3d 1218, 2017 Wyo. LEXIS 24 (Wyo. 2017).

Department of revenue and taxation was not required to continue invalid pricing system used in 1985 for determining the severance tax on uranium, where the system afforded no reasonable relationship to market value and was illegal and contrary to the constitutional mandates of equal and uniform taxation. Pathfinder Mines Corp. v. State Bd. of Equalization, 766 P.2d 531, 1988 Wyo. LEXIS 171 (Wyo. 1988).

Whether mineral deposit is subject to production tax should be determined by whether it can reasonably be said, considering all economic factors, that value of materials is, in the long run, reasonably able to bear production tax in addition to tax assessed against manufacturer. Certain-Teed Prods. Corp. v. Comly, 54 Wyo. 79, 87 P.2d 21, 1939 Wyo. LEXIS 4 (Wyo. 1939).

Gypsite, if of requisite quality, is subject to production tax, notwithstanding that it could be obtained by open workings and inexpensively, since “gypsite” may be considered a mineral or such substance which if of requisite quality would be subject to the tax. Certain-Teed Prods. Corp. v. Comly, 54 Wyo. 79, 87 P.2d 21, 1939 Wyo. LEXIS 4 (Wyo. 1939).

Tax on production is a personal tax. First Nat'l Bank v. Central Coal & Coke Co., 3 F. Supp. 433, 1933 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 1628 (D. Wyo. 1933), modified, 74 F.2d 809, 1934 U.S. App. LEXIS 4015 (10th Cir. Wyo. 1934).

And receiver operating property, with consent of mortgagee, is liable for the production tax. First Nat'l Bank v. Central Coal & Coke Co., 3 F. Supp. 433, 1933 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 1628 (D. Wyo. 1933), modified, 74 F.2d 809, 1934 U.S. App. LEXIS 4015 (10th Cir. Wyo. 1934).

Change in allocation between one county and another did not violate provision. —

Wyoming Department of Revenue's ruling that changed the allocation of the company's oil production from a production unit for 1980 through 1988 between one county and intervenor county did not violate Wyo. Const. art. XV, §§ 3 and 11 or Wyo. Const. art. I, § 34 because the company had the burden of showing unconstitutionality and it failed to meet the burden imposed on it in this regard. Moreover, the arguments were not supported by reference to pertinent authority or by cogent argument. BP Am. Prod. Co. v. Dep't of Revenue, 2006 WY 27, 130 P.3d 438, 2006 Wyo. LEXIS 29 (Wyo. 2006).

Gross product tax. —

Tax on gross product of all mines and mining claims in Wyoming is a tax on “personalty.” Board of Comm'rs v. Bernardin, 74 F.2d 809, 1934 U.S. App. LEXIS 4015 (10th Cir. Wyo. 1934), cert. denied, 295 U.S. 731, 55 S. Ct. 645, 79 L. Ed. 1680, 1935 U.S. LEXIS 1129 (U.S. 1935).

The gross product tax is one upon personal property. J. Ray McDermott & Co. v. Hudson, 370 P.2d 364, 1962 Wyo. LEXIS 77 (Wyo. 1962).

Tax on gross products of all mining claims was property tax, rather than license, privilege or occupation tax. Miller v. Buck Creek Oil Co., 38 Wyo. 505, 269 P. 43, 1928 Wyo. LEXIS 70 (Wyo. 1928).

Decision of state court, based on construction of constitution and statutes of Wyoming that gross product tax was not a severance tax, is binding on the federal courts. Board of Comm'rs v. Bernardin, 74 F.2d 809, 1934 U.S. App. LEXIS 4015 (10th Cir. Wyo. 1934), cert. denied, 295 U.S. 731, 55 S. Ct. 645, 79 L. Ed. 1680, 1935 U.S. LEXIS 1129 (U.S. 1935).

A lessee under an oil and gas lease which provided that the lessee was to pay “all taxes assessed and levied on said lands” was entitled to deduct from the royalties due the lessor for oil and gas produced the amount of the gross product tax, since the gross product tax is a tax on personal property, the severed product, and not a tax on real estate. Oregon Basin Oil & Gas Co. v. Ohio Oil Co., 70 Wyo. 263, 248 P.2d 198, 1952 Wyo. LEXIS 31 (Wyo. 1952).

Computation of tax. —

Tax on production of coal lands is based upon the production for the preceding year. First Nat'l Bank v. Central Coal & Coke Co., 3 F. Supp. 433, 1933 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 1628 (D. Wyo. 1933), modified, 74 F.2d 809, 1934 U.S. App. LEXIS 4015 (10th Cir. Wyo. 1934).

Method of valuation held proper. —

The application of a method of valuation which, as applied, had the effect of arriving at the value of the mineral at the mine by separating, as components of the total sales price, the value attributable to processing or transportation and the value of the mineral at the mine was proper and legally justified. Hillard v. Big Horn Coal Co., 549 P.2d 293, 1976 Wyo. LEXIS 185 (Wyo. 1976).

Black lung tax included in coal's value. —

The state board of equalization did not err, in determining the taxable value for ad valorem and severance tax purposes of coal produced by a coal company, by including all of the federal black lung excise tax paid to the company by its customers in the value of the coal at the mine mouth, rather than to exclude that portion of the amount paid on the value added to the coal by nontaxable transportation and processing activities. Amax Coal Co. v. Wyoming State Bd. of Equalization, 819 P.2d 825, 1991 Wyo. LEXIS 155 (Wyo. 1991).

Assessment held invalid. —

Where gypsite was assessed at $2.85 per ton one year and the next year at $28 per ton, assessment was invalid as arbitrary and as a constructive fraud and not a mere overvaluation. Certain-Teed Prods. Corp. v. Comly, 54 Wyo. 79, 87 P.2d 21, 1939 Wyo. LEXIS 4 (Wyo. 1939).

Sharing taxes. —

Under lease entitling lessor to take royalty from “net” returns of oil or in kind, lessee could deduct proportionate share of taxes from lessor's interest. Miller v. Buck Creek Oil Co., 38 Wyo. 505, 269 P. 43, 1928 Wyo. LEXIS 70 (Wyo. 1928).

Tax on products of mining claim covering both claim and royalty interest should be borne by lessor and lessee in proportion to interests. Miller v. Buck Creek Oil Co., 38 Wyo. 505, 269 P. 43, 1928 Wyo. LEXIS 70 (Wyo. 1928).

Section does not authorize exemption of all operational expenses. —

This section does not admit of an interpretation which would allow oil companies to claim all operational expenses, including depreciation, as an exemption. J. Ray McDermott & Co. v. Hudson, 370 P.2d 364, 1962 Wyo. LEXIS 77 (Wyo. 1962).

Reclamation costs deductible from coal's value. —

Reclamation costs should be allowed as part of transportation and processing costs deducted from the value of coal. Amax Coal Co. v. Wyoming State Bd. of Equalization, 819 P.2d 825, 1991 Wyo. LEXIS 155 (Wyo. 1991).

Taxes not allowable as administrative expense. —

Taxes against corporation, for which a receiver was appointed, are not allowable as administrative expense. First Nat'l Bank v. Central Coal & Coke Co., 3 F. Supp. 433, 1933 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 1628 (D. Wyo. 1933), modified, 74 F.2d 809, 1934 U.S. App. LEXIS 4015 (10th Cir. Wyo. 1934).

Applied in

Powder River Coal Co. v. Wyo. State Bd. of Equalization, 2002 WY 5, 38 P.3d 423, 2002 Wyo. LEXIS 5 (Wyo. 2002); Bd. of County Comm'rs v. Exxon Mobil Corp. 2002 WY 151, 55 P.3d 714, 2002 Wyo. LEXIS 172 (Wyo. 2002).

Cited in

Amoco Prod. Co. v. Wyoming State Bd. of Equalization, 797 P.2d 552, 1990 Wyo. LEXIS 97 (Wyo. 1990); Amoco Prod. Co. v. Wyoming State Bd. of Equalization, 7 P.3d 900, 2000 Wyo. LEXIS 160 (Wyo. 2000); Wyodak Res. Dev. Corp. v. Wyo. Dep't of Revenue, 2002 WY 181, 60 P.3d 129, 2002 Wyo. LEXIS 217 (Wyo. 2002).

Quoted in

Wyodak Res. Dev. Corp. v. Wyo. Dep't of Revenue, 2017 WY 6, 387 P.3d 725, 2017 Wyo. LEXIS 5 (Wyo. 2017).

Law reviews. —

For note dealing with tax on mineral production, see 4 Wyo. L.J. 250.

For article, “Tax Lien Priority,” see 4 Wyo. L.J. 255.

For comment dealing with nature of a royalty interest, see 7 Wyo. L.J. 145.

§ 4. State levy limited.

For state revenue, there shall be levied annually a tax not to exceed four mills on the dollar of the assessed valuation of the property in the state except for the support of state educational and charitable institutions, the payment of the state debt and the interest thereon.

Cross references. —

As to levy of property taxes generally, see § 39-13-101 et seq.

School construction. —

The Wyoming Constitution does not prohibit the state from imposing a statewide mill levy taxation level for capital construction of schools, and does not limit the number of mills that can be levied for such a fund. State v. Campbell County Sch. Dist., 2001 WY 19, 19 P.3d 518, 2001 Wyo. LEXIS 21 (Wyo. 2001).

Applied in

Witzenburger v. State ex rel. Wyo. Community Dev. Auth., 575 P.2d 1100, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 266 (Wyo. 1978).

Law reviews. —

For article, “Administration of the General Property Tax in Wyoming,” see 4 Wyo. L.J. 227.

For article, “Defeating Tax Levies to Recover Excess Taxes,” see 4 Wyo. L.J. 233.

§ 5. County levies limited.

For county revenue, there shall be levied annually a tax not to exceed twelve mills on the dollar for all purposes including general school tax, exclusive of state revenue, except for the payment of its public debt and the interest thereon. (As amended by Laws 1967, House Joint Resolution No. 1, p. 724.)

Cross references. —

As to levy and collection of county school tax, see § 21-13-201.

For authority of county to levy and collect license taxes and exceptions thereto, see §§ 33-1-107 and 33-1-108.

“County tax” does not include state taxes. State ex rel. Bd. of Comm'rs v. Snyder, 30 Wyo. 468, 222 P. 40, 1924 Wyo. LEXIS 73 (Wyo. 1924).

Special county levy. —

A requirement that a county shall levy a special tax to make up a deficiency in a prior annual levy of its quota of state taxes is unaffected by this section. State v. Board of Comm'rs, 8 Wyo. 104, 55 P. 451, 1898 Wyo. LEXIS 26 (Wyo. 1898).

School taxes. —

Special school district tax was not “county tax.” State ex rel. Bd. of Comm'rs v. Snyder, 30 Wyo. 468, 222 P. 40, 1924 Wyo. LEXIS 73 (Wyo. 1924).

Taxes levied for the support of common schools of the county are not taxes for “county purposes.” Powder River Cattle Co. v. Board of Comm'rs, 3 Wyo. 597, 29 P. 361, 31 P. 278, 1892 Wyo. LEXIS 8 (Wyo. 1892), overruled, Kelley v. Rhoads, 7 Wyo. 237, 51 P. 593, 1898 Wyo. LEXIS 2 (Wyo. 1898).

A levy for payment of interest and principal on school bonds of a district are not “tax for county revenue” within the provisions of this section. McCague Inv. Co. v. Mallin, 25 Wyo. 373, 170 P. 763, 1918 Wyo. LEXIS 3 (Wyo. 1918).

School district taxes are not levied for county revenue and they are not included in general school taxes as provided in this section. McCague Inv. Co. v. Mallin, 25 Wyo. 373, 170 P. 763, 1918 Wyo. LEXIS 3 (Wyo. 1918).

School district taxes are not to be considered in determining whether the county tax levy exceeds limitation prescribed by this section. McCague Inv. Co. v. Mallin, 25 Wyo. 373, 170 P. 763, 1918 Wyo. LEXIS 3 (Wyo. 1918).

General school tax levy by county was “county tax” within statute exempting property of war veterans from taxation. State ex rel. Bd. of Comm'rs v. Snyder, 30 Wyo. 468, 222 P. 40, 1924 Wyo. LEXIS 73 (Wyo. 1924).

Public debt. —

A judgment entered upon a claim or evidence of indebtedness incurred in excess of the ordinary revenue of the county, without a vote of the people, or in excess of the limitation, is not a public debt within the meaning of this section. Grand I. & N. W. R.R. v. Baker, 6 Wyo. 369, 45 P. 494, 1896 Wyo. LEXIS 21 (Wyo. 1896).

Action to enjoin tax. —

Where an action is brought to enjoin a tax because it exceeds the constitutional or statutory authority, only so much of the tax will be enjoined as exceeds the constitutional or statutory authority. Cottle v. Union P. R. Co., 201 F. 39, 1912 U.S. App. LEXIS 1990 (8th Cir. Wyo. 1912).

Stated in

Washakie County Sch. Dist. v. Herschler, 606 P.2d 310, 1980 Wyo. LEXIS 227 (Wyo. 1980).

Cited in

State v. Campbell County Sch. Dist., 2001 WY 19, 19 P.3d 518, 2001 Wyo. LEXIS 21 (Wyo. 2001).

Law reviews. —

For article, “Administration of the General Property Tax in Wyoming,” see 4 Wyo. L.J. 227.

For article, “Defeating Tax Levies to Recover Excess Taxes,” see 4 Wyo. L.J. 233.

For article, “School Finance Reform in Wyoming,” see XIX Land & Water L. Rev. 135 (1984).

§ 6. City levies limited.

No incorporated city or town shall levy a tax to exceed eight mills on the dollar in any one year, except for the payment of its public debt and the interest thereon.

Cross references. —

For another provision restricting power of municipal corporations to levy taxes, see art. 13, § 3, Wyo. Const.

Tax intended to suffice for expenses of essential governmental functions. —

It is quite apparent the framers of the constitution thought that a direct tax of eight mills against the property of the city or town (together with indirect taxes permitted) would and should suffice for the payment of expenses incurred in performing the governmental functions essential to the convenience, safety and happiness of the citizens of the municipality, rather than the welfare of the general public. It is hardly probable they contemplated that this limitation should be evaded either directly or indirectly and that a direct tax greater than eight mills could be imposed upon such property for the performance of these functions. War Memorial Hosp. of Dist. v. Board of County Comm'rs, 73 Wyo. 371, 279 P.2d 472, 1955 Wyo. LEXIS 4 (Wyo. 1955).

Section inapplicable to occupation taxes. —

Limit of levy herein refers to property taxes and does not apply to occupation taxes. City of Sheridan v. Litman, 32 Wyo. 14, 228 P. 628, 1924 Wyo. LEXIS 43 (Wyo. 1924).

Fire protection district. —

The county commissioners could not levy a tax for operation and maintenance of a fire protection district, which tax when combined with general levy of the town exceeded eight mills, since fire protection is a primary governmental function which every city and town must perform. War Memorial Hosp. of Dist. v. Board of County Comm'rs, 73 Wyo. 371, 279 P.2d 472, 1955 Wyo. LEXIS 4 (Wyo. 1955).

Hospital district. —

The county commissioners could levy a tax of not exceeding three mills for the operation and maintenance of a hospital district though tax when combined with town's general levy exceeded eight mills, since operation and maintenance of a hospital district is not an essential function of a town or city. War Memorial Hosp. of Dist. v. Board of County Comm'rs, 73 Wyo. 371, 279 P.2d 472, 1955 Wyo. LEXIS 4 (Wyo. 1955).

Cemetery district. —

The county commissioners could levy a tax of not exceeding three mills for the operation and maintenance of a cemetery district though tax when combined with town's general levy exceeded eight mills, since operation and maintenance of cemetery district is not an essential function of a town or city. War Memorial Hosp. of Dist. v. Board of County Comm'rs, 73 Wyo. 371, 279 P.2d 472, 1955 Wyo. LEXIS 4 (Wyo. 1955).

Law reviews. —

For article, “Administration of the General Property Tax in Wyoming,” see 4 Wyo. L.J. 227.

For article, “Defeating Tax Levies to Recover Excess Taxes,” see 4 Wyo. L.J. 233.

For article, “School Finance Reform in Wyoming,” see XIX Land & Water L. Rev. 135 (1984).

§ 7. Depositories for public moneys.

All money belonging to the state or to any county, city, town, village or other subdivision therein, except as herein otherwise provided, shall, whenever practicable, be deposited in a national bank or banks or in a bank or banks incorporated under the laws of this state; provided, that the bank or banks in which such money is deposited shall furnish security to be approved as provided by law; and provided further, that such bank or banks shall pay the same rate of interest on any money so deposited therein on time certificates of deposit by the legal custodian or custodians of any such public moneys as such bank or banks pay on time certificates of deposit of private depositors, and the custodian or custodians of any such public moneys shall be authorized to deposit same under time certificates of deposit as may be provided by law. Such interest shall accrue to the fund from which it is derived. (As amended by Laws 1937, Senate Joint Resolution No. 7, p. 319.)

Escrow not within purview of section. —

Escrow held not such a deposit of public moneys as comes within the purview of this section. Rodin v. State, 417 P.2d 180, 1966 Wyo. LEXIS 155 (Wyo. 1966).

County treasurer not insurer. —

This section does not make a county treasurer an insurer of the safety of public funds, so as to render him liable for the loss by reason of the failure of the bank in which he has deposited them, where he was without negligence. Roberts v. Board of Comm'rs, 8 Wyo. 177, 56 P. 915, 1899 Wyo. LEXIS 7 (Wyo. 1899).

State is not estopped from pursuing treasurer upon his bond by bringing suit to trace public funds deposited by him in a bank which afterwards became insolvent, and by accepting dividends from the estate of the banker. State v. Gramm, 7 Wyo. 329, 52 P. 533, 1898 Wyo. LEXIS 8 (Wyo. 1898).

No recovery on treasurer's bond. —

Where following a custom in vogue for 18 years, treasurer deposited state funds in a reputable and solvent private bank for safe-keeping, separate from his private account, and owing to a panic, the depository became insolvent, and the greater portion of the funds were lost, no recovery could be had on the official bond where the treasurer was not chargeable with negligence or fraud. State v. Gramm, 7 Wyo. 329, 52 P. 533, 1898 Wyo. LEXIS 8 (Wyo. 1898).

Surety succeeds to preference right of state upon payment of state's loss. National Sur. Co. v. Morris, 34 Wyo. 134, 241 P. 1063, 1925 Wyo. LEXIS 63 (Wyo. 1925).

Industrial Development Projects Act held constitutional. —

See Powers v. Cheyenne, 435 P.2d 448, 1967 Wyo. LEXIS 191 (Wyo. 1967), reh'g denied, 436 P.2d 961, 1968 Wyo. LEXIS 155 (Wyo. 1968).

§ 8. Profit making from public funds prohibited.

The making of profit, directly or indirectly, out of state, county, city, town or school district money or other public fund, or using the same for any purpose not authorized by law, by any public officer, shall be deemed a felony, and shall be punished as provided by law.

Cross references. —

As to profit making by public officers in connection with public funds and penalty therefor, see § 9-4-829.

§ 9. Legislature to provide for state board of equalization.

The legislature shall provide by law for a state board of equalization. (As amended by Laws 1909, Senate Joint Resolution No. 2, p. 248.)

Applied in

Simons v. Laramie County Sch. Dist., 741 P.2d 1116, 1987 Wyo. LEXIS 496 (Wyo. 1987).

Quoted in

Rocky Mountain Oil & Gas Ass'n v. State Bd. of Equalization, Dep't of Revenue & Taxation, 749 P.2d 221, 1987 Wyo. LEXIS 572 (Wyo. 1987); Amax Coal Co. v. Wyoming State Bd. of Equalization, 819 P.2d 825, 1991 Wyo. LEXIS 155 (Wyo. 1991).

Stated in

Scott Realty Co. v. State Bd. of Equalization, 395 P.2d 289, 1964 Wyo. LEXIS 120 (Wyo. 1964).

Cited in

Town of Pine Bluffs v. State Bd. of Equalization, 79 Wyo. 262, 333 P.2d 700, 1958 Wyo. LEXIS 45 (1958); J. Ray McDermott & Co., v. Hudson, 370 P.2d 364, 1962 Wyo. LEXIS 77 (Wyo. 1962); Hillard v. Big Horn Coal Co., 549 P.2d 293, 1976 Wyo. LEXIS 185 (Wyo. 1976); Amoco Prod. Co. v. Wyoming State Bd. of Equalization, 12 P.3d 668, 2000 Wyo. LEXIS 96 (Wyo. 2000).

§ 10. Duties of state board of equalization.

The duties of the state board shall be to equalize the valuation on all property in the several counties and such other duties as may be prescribed by law. (As amended by Laws 1985, Senate Joint Resolution No. 2, p. 551.)

Cross references. —

For another provision concerning duties of state board of equalization, see § 39-11-102.1.

“All” as used in this section must, if possible, be given some meaning. Chicago & N. W. R.R. v. Hall, 46 Wyo. 380, 26 P.2d 1071, 1933 Wyo. LEXIS 46 (Wyo. 1933).

Power to equalize valuations. —

Under this section, as to powers of state board of equalization, in connection with § 11 of this article, requiring uniform assessment, the legislature had power to authorize such board to equalize valuations for other purposes than the state tax. Baker v. Paxton, 29 Wyo. 500, 215 P. 257, 1923 Wyo. LEXIS 27 (Wyo. 1923).

The state board of equalization has authority to equalize the values where that is appropriate in order to meet the constitutional requirements and the burden is on the taxpayer to establish any overevaluation. Hillard v. Big Horn Coal Co., 549 P.2d 293, 1976 Wyo. LEXIS 185 (Wyo. 1976).

Lawful assessment required. —

To overcome prima facie case in replevin, made by mortgagee of cattle with immediate right to possession, a tax collector distraining cattle, under lien for taxes, must at least show that a lawful assessment was made against cattle of mortgagor in sufficient number to satisfy tax lien. Farm & Cattle Loan Co. v. Faulkner, 34 Wyo. 199, 242 P. 415, 1926 Wyo. LEXIS 34 (Wyo. 1926).

Requirements for method of valuation. —

In performing its constitutional and statutory functions, the state board of equalization may arrive at different valuations for different property, but the method or system used by the board must lead to a fair value, and the properties must be assessed at a uniform rate. Hillard v. Big Horn Coal Co., 549 P.2d 293, 1976 Wyo. LEXIS 185 (Wyo. 1976).

Board may not usurp valuation function assigned to department of revenue. —

Board of equalization erred where it departed from its adjudicatory role and assumed function of prescribing system of establishing fair market value of property, which was statutorily assigned to department of revenue. Amoco Prod. Co. v. Wyoming State Bd. of Equalization, 12 P.3d 668, 2000 Wyo. LEXIS 96 (Wyo. 2000).

Reassessment protested on first statutorily provided occasion. —

A reassessment amount may be protested by the taxpayer, before the county and state board, on the first statutorily provided occasion available after the reassessment has occurred, even if during the next year, after the protest period has passed. In re Appeal of Paradise Valley Country Club, 748 P.2d 298, 1988 Wyo. LEXIS 6 (Wyo. 1988).

Board of equalization not a proper party to appeal from its own order. —

Board of equalization functions in its adjudicatory capacity when it considers appeal from final decision of department of revenue, and when board acts in its adjudicatory capacity, it is not a proper party to an appeal from its own order. Antelope Valley Improvement & Serv. Dist. v. State Bd. of Equalization, 4 P.3d 876, 2000 Wyo. LEXIS 93 (Wyo. 2000).

Applied in

Baker v. Paxton, 29 Wyo. 500, 215 P. 257, 1923 Wyo. LEXIS 27 (1923); Chicago, N.W. Ry. v. Hall, 46 Wyo. 380, 26 P.2d 1071, 1933 Wyo. LEXIS 46 (1933); J. Ray McDermott & Co., v. Hudson, 370 P.2d 364, 1962 Wyo. LEXIS 77 (Wyo. 1962); Simons v. Laramie County Sch. Dist., 741 P.2d 1116, 1987 Wyo. LEXIS 496 (Wyo. 1987).

Quoted in

Scott Realty Co. v. State Bd. of Equalization, 395 P.2d 289, 1964 Wyo. LEXIS 120 (Wyo. 1964); Rocky Mountain Oil & Gas Ass'n v. State Bd. of Equalization, Dep't of Revenue & Taxation, 749 P.2d 221, 1987 Wyo. LEXIS 572 (Wyo. 1987); Amax Coal Co. v. Wyoming State Bd. of Equalization, 819 P.2d 825, 1991 Wyo. LEXIS 155 (Wyo. 1991).

Cited in

Powder River Cattle Co. v. Board of Comm'rs, 3 Wyo. 597, 29 P. 361, 31 P. 278, 1892 Wyo. LEXIS 8 (1892); Powder River Cattle Co. v. Board of Comm'rs, 3 Wyo. 597, 29 P. 361, 31 P. 278, 1892 Wyo. LEXIS 8 (1892); Kelley v. Rhoads, 7 Wyo. 237, 51 P. 593, 1898 Wyo. LEXIS 2, 39 L.R.A. 594 (1898); Pellish Bros. v. Cooper, 47 Wyo. 480, 38 P.2d 607, 1934 Wyo. LEXIS 33 (1934); In re Union Pac. Motor Freight Co., 72 Wyo. 298, 264 P.2d 771, 1953 Wyo. LEXIS 46 (1953); Town of Pine Bluffs v. State Bd. of Equalization, 79 Wyo. 262, 333 P.2d 700, 1958 Wyo. LEXIS 45 (1958); Chicago & N.W. Ry. v. Hillard, 502 P.2d 189, 1972 Wyo. LEXIS 276 (Wyo. 1972); Pathfinder Mines Corp. v. State Bd. of Equalization, 766 P.2d 531, 1988 Wyo. LEXIS 171 (Wyo. 1988); Basin Elec. Power Coop. v. Department of Revenue, 970 P.2d 841, 1998 Wyo. LEXIS 191 (Wyo. 1998); Exxon Corp. v. Board of County Comm'rs, 987 P.2d 158, 1999 Wyo. LEXIS 141 (Wyo. 1999).

§ 11. Uniformity of assessment required.

  1. All property, except as in this constitution otherwise provided, shall be uniformly valued at its full value as defined by the legislature, in three (3) classes as follows:
    1. Gross production of minerals and mine products in lieu of taxes on the land where produced;
    2. Property used for industrial purposes as defined by the legislature; and
    3. All other property, real and personal.
  2. The legislature shall prescribe the percentage of value which shall be assessed within each designated class. All taxable property shall be valued at its full value as defined by the legislature except agricultural and grazing lands which shall be valued according to the capability of the land to produce agricultural products under normal conditions. The percentage of value prescribed for industrial property shall not be more than forty percent (40%) higher nor more than four (4) percentage points more than the percentage prescribed for property other than minerals.
  3. The legislature shall not create new classes or subclasses or authorize any property to be assessed at a rate other than the rates set for authorized classes.
  4. All taxation shall be equal and uniform within each class of property. The legislature shall prescribe such regulations as shall secure a just valuation for taxation of all property, real and personal. (As amended by Laws 1988, Senate Joint Resolution No. 7, p. 283.)

Cross references. —

As to assessment and taxation of property, see §§ 39-11-101 et seq. and 39-13-101 et seq.

Construction with declaration of rights. —

Declaration of rights requiring uniform taxation must be construed with the revenue article. Harkin v. Board of Comm'rs, 30 Wyo. 455, 222 P. 35, 1924 Wyo. LEXIS 71 (Wyo. 1924) (decided prior to 1988 amendment).

Right to uniform assessment. —

Taxpayer has right to have all taxable property assessed uniformly, and departure from uniform rate, if made in illegal manner where his property is assessed at full value, is a discrimination, and not only a fraud against him, but violation of this section. Bunten v. Rock Springs Grazing Ass'n, 29 Wyo. 461, 215 P. 244, 1923 Wyo. LEXIS 25 (Wyo. 1923) (decided prior to 1988 amendment).

Not every discrimination should render an assessment or tax invalid either in whole or in part. Hillard v. Big Horn Coal Co., 549 P.2d 293, 1976 Wyo. LEXIS 185 (Wyo. 1976) (decided prior to 1988 amendment).

Uniformity of assessment requires only that method of appraisal be consistently applied. Appeal of Monolith Portland Midwest Co., 574 P.2d 757, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 265 (Wyo. 1978) (decided prior to 1988 amendment).

Change in allocation between one county and another did not violate provision. —

Wyoming Department of Revenue's ruling that changed the allocation of the company's oil production from a production unit for 1980 through 1988 between one county and intervenor county did not violate Wyo. Const. art. XV, §§ 3 and 11 or Wyo. Const. art. I, § 34 because the company had the burden of showing unconstitutionality and it failed to meet the burden imposed on it in this regard. Moreover, the arguments were not supported by reference to pertinent authority or by cogent argument. BP Am. Prod. Co. v. Dep't of Revenue, 2006 WY 27, 130 P.3d 438, 2006 Wyo. LEXIS 29 (Wyo. 2006).

County Board of Equalization and State Board of Equalization did not violate Wyo. Const. art. XV, § 11 because the fair market value of the taxpayer's personal property at its coal mines that were purchased in 1998 was determined using a rational method, equally applied, that resulted in essential fairness.
