The assessor's use of the purchase price as the starting place for the cost method of appraisal was consistent with the regulations, applicable law, and guidelines, which seemed to direct it; and the assessor correctly reasoned that the recentness of the purchase obviated the need to do an economic obsolescence calculation because the 1998 value was derived from an arms length transaction, was provided by the taxpayer, and fairly included economic obsolescence in 2001. Thunder Basin Coal Co. v. Campbell County, 2006 WY 44, 132 P.3d 801, 2006 Wyo. LEXIS 47 (Wyo. 2006).

Including reimbursements in assessment process applies retroactively. —

The decision in Enron Oil & Gas Co. v. Department of Revenue & Taxation, 820 P.2d 977, 1991 Wyo. LEXIS 174 (Wyo. 1991), which held that the department of revenue and taxation can include ad valorem tax reimbursements as a component in the assessment process for determining fair cash market value of minerals, including natural gas, should be applied retroactively. Under the Wyoming constitution, minerals are a class of property and, as such, they must be uniformly given full value. Limiting Enron to prospective application would have the effect of taxing mineral producers who reported reimbursements as part of value at a higher rate than those who failed to report. Wyoming State Tax Comm'n v. BHP Petroleum Co., 856 P.2d 428, 1993 Wyo. LEXIS 109 (Wyo. 1993).

Rule promulgated by state board of equalization violated uniformity provision. —

See Rocky Mountain Oil & Gas Ass'n v. State Bd. of Equalization, Dep't of Revenue & Taxation, 749 P.2d 221, 1987 Wyo. LEXIS 572 (Wyo. 1987), reh'g denied, 749 P.2d 221, 1988 Wyo. LEXIS 3 (Wyo. 1988).

All minerals of like kind need not be assigned same value. —

This section and art. 1, § 28, Wyo. Const., do not require that all minerals of the like kind be assigned the same value. Appeal of Monolith Portland Midwest Co., 574 P.2d 757, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 265 (Wyo. 1978) (decided prior to 1988 amendment).

The constitution of the state of Wyoming does not require the inclusion in a cost appraisal formula to establish the value of mine products of hypothetical costs not borne by a particular mining enterprise in order to tax that firm equally and uniformly with those firms which actually do have such costs. Appeal of Monolith Portland Midwest Co., 574 P.2d 757, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 265 (Wyo. 1978) (decided prior to 1988 amendment).

Department of revenue and taxation was not required to continue invalid pricing system used in 1985 for determining the severance tax on uranium, where the system afforded no reasonable relationship to market value and was illegal and contrary to the constitutional mandates of equal and uniform taxation. Pathfinder Mines Corp. v. State Bd. of Equalization, 766 P.2d 531, 1988 Wyo. LEXIS 171 (Wyo. 1988).

Different basis for assessing golf grounds illegal. —

A county assessor's reassessment use of a commercial square-footage appraisal for golf grounds, as compared to an agricultural land basis for the comparable properties of another country club, was illegal. In re Appeal of Paradise Valley Country Club, 748 P.2d 298, 1988 Wyo. LEXIS 6 (Wyo. 1988) (decided prior to 1988 amendment).

Omission to assess property either from mistake of law or fact, or accidentally, did not protect other taxpayers from the tax assessed against them. Hillard v. Big Horn Coal Co., 549 P.2d 293, 1976 Wyo. LEXIS 185 (Wyo. 1976) (decided prior to 1988 amendment).

Board authorized to equalize valuations. —

Under § 10 of this article, as to powers of state board of equalization, in connection with this section, requiring uniform assessment, the legislature had power to authorize such board to equalize valuations for other purposes than the state tax. Baker v. Paxton, 29 Wyo. 500, 215 P. 257, 1923 Wyo. LEXIS 27 (Wyo. 1923) (decided prior to 1988 amendment).

The state board of equalization has authority to equalize the values where that is appropriate in order to meet the constitutional requirements and the burden is on the taxpayer to establish any overevaluation. Hillard v. Big Horn Coal Co., 549 P.2d 293, 1976 Wyo. LEXIS 185 (Wyo. 1976) (decided prior to 1988 amendment).

Uniform assessment requires method of establishing fair value. —

Uniform assessment for taxation could scarcely be accomplished unless there existed some method of establishing fair value. Scott Realty Co. v. State Bd. of Equalization, 395 P.2d 289, 1964 Wyo. LEXIS 120 (Wyo. 1964) (decided prior to 1988 amendment).

In performing its constitutional and statutory functions the state board of equalization may arrive at different valuations for different property, but the method or system used by the board must lead to a fair value, and the properties must be assessed at a uniform rate. Hillard v. Big Horn Coal Co., 549 P.2d 293, 1976 Wyo. LEXIS 185 (Wyo. 1976) (decided prior to 1988 amendment).

Replacement-cost theory held proper. —

Even though the board of equalization may have in part used the replacement-cost theory of assessment, which gives a higher value, this in itself would not violate the plaintiff's constitutional rights as long as the method is uniformly used in all assessments. Scott Realty Co. v. State Bd. of Equalization, 395 P.2d 289, 1964 Wyo. LEXIS 120 (Wyo. 1964) (decided prior to 1988 amendment).

Reassessment protested on first statutorily provided opportunity. —

A reassessment amount may be protested by the taxpayer, before the county and state board, on the first statutorily provided occasion available after the reassessment has occurred, even if during the next year, after the protest period has passed. In re Appeal of Paradise Valley Country Club, 748 P.2d 298, 1988 Wyo. LEXIS 6 (Wyo. 1988).

Judicial review. —

Courts cannot correct judgment of board of equalization for error in ordering increase of assessments in a county. State ex rel. Greenwood v. Pearson, 46 Wyo. 307, 26 P.2d 641, 1933 Wyo. LEXIS 45 (Wyo. 1933) (decided prior to 1988 amendment).

Taxpayer was required to exhaust administrative remedies before bringing declaratory judgment action; constitutionally-established and statutorily-directed agency was proper forum for initial review of challenge to tax assessment. Union Pac. Resources Co. v. State, 839 P.2d 356, 1992 Wyo. LEXIS 135 (Wyo. 1992).

Valuation upheld. —

In an action to compel the county commissioners to increase assessments as ordered by the board of equalization, the evidence did not show an erroneous method in fixing values in Crook County. State ex rel. Greenwood v. Pearson, 46 Wyo. 307, 26 P.2d 641, 1933 Wyo. LEXIS 45 (Wyo. 1933) (decided prior to 1988 amendment).

Charge that board of equalization ordering increase of assessments on grazing and dry farm lands acted fraudulently, arbitrarily or intentionally discriminated against taxpayers in said county was not supported by the evidence. State ex rel. Greenwood v. Pearson, 46 Wyo. 307, 26 P.2d 641, 1933 Wyo. LEXIS 45 (Wyo. 1933) (decided prior to 1988 amendment).

The board of equalization found in relation between the value of the railway in Wyoming and the system value by considering the relative mileage in the railroad within and without the state, by comparing the cost of reproduction less depreciation of the Wyoming property with the agreed system value and by comparing the operating net revenues from Wyoming lines with the revenue of the system. It was held that the evidence was insufficient to support the finding that the valuation of the railway for state tax purposes was arbitrary or unreasonable or that the property was overvalued. Rowley v. Chicago & N. R. Co., 293 U.S. 102, 55 S. Ct. 55, 79 L. Ed. 222, 1934 U.S. LEXIS 8 (U.S.), reh'g denied, 293 U.S. 632, 55 S. Ct. 211, 79 L. Ed. 717, 1934 U.S. LEXIS 441 (U.S. 1934) (decided prior to 1988 amendment).

A method of valuation which, as applied, had the effect of arriving at the value of the mineral at the mine by separating, as components of the total sales price, the value attributable to processing or transportation and the value of the mineral at the mine was not arbitrary, capricious or abuse of discretion, and its application was proper and legally justified. Hillard v. Big Horn Coal Co., 549 P.2d 293, 1976 Wyo. LEXIS 185 (Wyo. 1976) (decided prior to 1988 amendment).

Where a valuation formula was applied only to three companies and comparative valuations were made of the product of other mines, lack of uniformity resulting in illegality of the assessment was not shown, since there were discrepancies in the sales prices of the coal involved similar and proportionate to the discrepancy in valuations, and the record demonstrated that the comparative valuations were made using as a base the valuations reached pursuant to the formula or through an approach which was equivalent to the formula. This resulted in uniformity of assessment, not lack of uniformity. Hillard v. Big Horn Coal Co., 549 P.2d 293, 1976 Wyo. LEXIS 185 (Wyo. 1976) (decided prior to 1988 amendment).

Substantial evidence existed to support the use of the cost and income method of appraisal to determine the fair market value of sugar factory; factory owner's argument that the market approach was a more rational method of appraisal was misguided where the record was replete with evidence which supported the cost and income approach. Holly Sugar Corp. v. State Bd. of Equalization, 839 P.2d 959, 1992 Wyo. LEXIS 145 (Wyo. 1992).

By refusing to allow first year depreciation and by establishing the 40% floor for depreciation of used equipment of gas company the county assessor did not create an unconstitutional subclass of property because other property within the industrial property class was not valued under the same methodology. Amoco Prod. Co. v. Wyoming State Bd. of Equalization, 899 P.2d 855, 1995 Wyo. LEXIS 119 (Wyo. 1995), reh'g denied, 1995 Wyo. LEXIS 143 (Wyo. Aug. 15, 1995).

Adopting for the plaintiff the adjustment it sought, that is, applying a Wyoming market to book ratio, rather than a system market to book ratio, in the valuation of its tax exempt property, would have resulted in an improper deviation from the uniformity requirement. Pacificorp, Inc. v. Department of Revenue, 13 P.3d 256, 2000 Wyo. LEXIS 220 (Wyo. 2000), reh'g denied, 2001 Wyo. LEXIS 99 (Wyo. Sept. 6, 2001).

Board of Equalization's decision affirming the Department of Revenue's setting of the point of valuation for coal production was consistent with the constitutional requirements of uniformity and equality as the testimony and prior Board decisions showed that the Department had consistently applied the statute to locate Wyoming mine mouths at the point where the minerals actually reached the surface. Wyodak Res. Dev. Corp. v. Wyo. Dep't of Revenue, 2017 WY 6, 387 P.3d 725, 2017 Wyo. LEXIS 5 (Wyo. 2017).

Valuation of intangible personal property. —

Although intangible personal property is exempt from taxation, it may add value to taxable, tangible property, and to that extent, it should be included in any assessment in order to properly reflect the true value of the property; in utilizing the unitary method, however, to the extent that intangible property has value beyond any enhancing effect on tangible property and is separable from those assets, it must be excluded. RT Communs. v. State Bd. of Equalization, 11 P.3d 915, 2000 Wyo. LEXIS 198 (Wyo. 2000), reh'g denied, 2000 Wyo. LEXIS 215 (Wyo. Oct. 26, 2000).

Electric utilities. —

There was no rational basis for treating non-profit electric utilities differently from investor-owned utilities for purposes of ad valorem taxation, and therefore valuation of rural electric cooperative's property constituted an abuse of discretion and was unconstitutional. Basin Elec. Power Coop. v. Department of Revenue, 970 P.2d 841, 1998 Wyo. LEXIS 191 (Wyo. 1998), reh'g denied, 970 P.2d 841, 1999 Wyo. LEXIS 7 (Wyo. 1999).

Tax exempt property. —

A utility's tax exempt property would be valued, for tax assessment purposes, using the same valuation method as that used for its taxable property, in order to assure an ultimate fair market value, as commanded by section 39-11-101(a)(vi) and Wyo. Const., art. 15, § 11. Pacificorp, Inc. v. Dep't of Revenue, 2001 WY 84, 31 P.3d 64, 2001 Wyo. LEXIS 102 (Wyo. 2001).

Irrigation district law was not in violation of this section. Sullivan v. Blakesley, 35 Wyo. 73, 246 P. 918, 1926 Wyo. LEXIS 9 (Wyo. 1926).

Taxation of livestock. —

An act providing for the taxation of livestock brought into the state to graze did not violate the provisions of this section. Kelley v. Rhoads, 7 Wyo. 237, 51 P. 593, 1898 Wyo. LEXIS 2 (Wyo. 1898) (decided prior to 1988 amendment).

Industrial Development Projects Act held constitutional. —

See Uhls v. State, 429 P.2d 74, 1967 Wyo. LEXIS 161 (Wyo. 1967); Powers v. Cheyenne, 435 P.2d 448, 1967 Wyo. LEXIS 191 (Wyo. 1967), reh'g denied, 436 P.2d 961, 1968 Wyo. LEXIS 155 (Wyo. 1968).

City ordinance not authorized. —

City council was not authorized to pass ordinance taxing each lot certain amount for water for irrigation, regardless of value of the property. Town Council of Hudson v. Board of Comm'rs, 37 Wyo. 160, 259 P. 1051, 1927 Wyo. LEXIS 74 (Wyo. 1927) (decided prior to 1988 amendment).

Veterans' exemption. —

See State ex rel. Bd. of Comm'rs v. Snyder, 29 Wyo. 199, 212 P. 771, 1923 Wyo. LEXIS 9 (Wyo. 1923).

Applied in

Tennant v. Sinclair Oil & Gas Co., 355 P.2d 887, 1960 Wyo. LEXIS 73 (Wyo. 1960); J. Ray McDermott & Co., v. Hudson, 370 P.2d 364, 1962 Wyo. LEXIS 77 (Wyo. 1962); Simons v. Laramie County Sch. Dist., 741 P.2d 1116, 1987 Wyo. LEXIS 496 (Wyo. 1987).

Quoted in

Miller v. Board of County Comm'rs, 79 Wyo. 502, 337 P.2d 262, 1959 Wyo. LEXIS 18 (1959); Black v. Teton County Bd. of County Comm'rs, 775 P.2d 484, 1989 Wyo. LEXIS 141 (Wyo. 1989).

Cited in

Rowley v. Chicago & N. R. Co., 293 U.S. 102, 55 S. Ct. 55, 79 L. Ed. 222, 1934 U.S. LEXIS 8 (1934); Unemployment Comp. Comm'n v. Renner, 59 Wyo. 437, 143 P.2d 181, 1943 Wyo. LEXIS 25 (1943); J. Ray McDermott & Co. v. Hudson, 348 P.2d 73, 1960 Wyo. LEXIS 45 (Wyo. 1962); Chicago & N.W. Ry. v. Hillard, 502 P.2d 189, 1972 Wyo. LEXIS 276 (Wyo. 1972); Wyoming Bd. of Equalization v. State ex rel. Basin Elec. Power Coop., 637 P.2d 248, 1981 Wyo. LEXIS 396 (Wyo. 1981); Amoco Prod. Co. v. Board of Comm'rs, 876 P.2d 989, 1994 Wyo. LEXIS 83 (Wyo. 1994); Thunder Basin Coal Co. v. Wyoming State Bd. of Equalization, 896 P.2d 1336, 1995 Wyo. LEXIS 96 (Wyo. 1995); Laramie County Bd. of Equalization v. Wyoming State Bd. of Equalization, 915 P.2d 1184, 1996 Wyo. LEXIS 67 (Wyo. 1996); Amoco Prod. Co. v. Wyoming State Bd. of Equalization, 7 P.3d 900, 2000 Wyo. LEXIS 160 (Wyo. 2000); State v. Campbell County Sch. Dist., 2001 WY 19, 19 P.3d 518, 2001 Wyo. LEXIS 21 (Wyo. 2001); Wyodak Res. Dev. Corp. v. Wyo. Dep't of Revenue, 2002 WY 181, 60 P.3d 129, 2002 Wyo. LEXIS 217 (Wyo. 2002).

Law reviews. —

For article, “Remedies for Defects in General Property Tax Assessments in Wyoming,” see 4 Wyo. L.J. 240.

For article, “Gross Products Tax,” see 4 Wyo. L.J. 250.

For article, “Practitioner's Guide to Valuation and Assessment Appeals of State and Local Assessed Property,” see XXXII Land & Water L. Rev. 173 (1997).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Requirements of full-value of real property taxation assessments, 42 ALR4th 676.

§ 12. Exemptions from taxation.

The property of the United States, the state, counties, cities, towns, school districts and municipal corporations, when used primarily for a governmental purpose, and public libraries, lots with the buildings thereon used exclusively for religious worship, church parsonages, church schools and public cemeteries, shall be exempt from taxation, and such other property as the legislature may by general law provide. (As amended by Laws 1955, House Joint Resolution No. 2, p. 390.)

Cross references. —

As to homestead exemption, see art. 19, § 9, Wyo. Const.

For other provisions concerning exemptions from taxation, see § 39-11-105.

Exemption limited to property used primarily for governmental purpose.—

County properly assessed property taxes on a daycare facility that a town owned and operated because the facility was not exempt from taxation as it was not used primarily for a governmental purpose. Daycare was typically and frequently carried on by private enterprise and case law and regulation established that a municipality engaged in activities that may have been and frequently were carried out by private enterprises were acting in their proprietary capacity. Eisele v. Town of Pine Bluffs, 2020 WY 22, 458 P.3d 46, 2020 Wyo. LEXIS 22 (Wyo. 2020).

Amendment to section legally adopted. —

See Town of Pine Bluffs v. State Bd. of Equalization, 79 Wyo. 262, 333 P.2d 700, 1958 Wyo. LEXIS 45 (Wyo. 1958), limited, State Bd. of Equalization v. City of Lander, 882 P.2d 844, 1994 Wyo. LEXIS 113 (Wyo. 1994).

In determining whether the amendment to this section was not fairly adopted in view of alleged misleading statement the supreme court will assume that the people of the state voted intelligently. Town of Pine Bluffs v. State Bd. of Equalization, 79 Wyo. 262, 333 P.2d 700, 1958 Wyo. LEXIS 45 (Wyo. 1958), limited, State Bd. of Equalization v. City of Lander, 882 P.2d 844, 1994 Wyo. LEXIS 113 (Wyo. 1994).

Uniformity of taxation. —

Declaration of rights requiring uniform taxation must be construed with the revenue article. Harkin v. Board of Comm'rs, 30 Wyo. 455, 222 P. 35, 1924 Wyo. LEXIS 71 (Wyo. 1924).

Plain language of section limits applicability to property taxes. Sublette County Sch. Dist. v. State Bd. of Equalization, 770 P.2d 218, 1989 Wyo. LEXIS 62 (Wyo. 1989).

Exemption statutes are not limited to property similar to that exempted by the constitution. State ex rel. Bd. of Comm'rs v. Snyder, 29 Wyo. 199, 212 P. 771, 1923 Wyo. LEXIS 9 (Wyo. 1923); Harkin v. Board of Comm'rs, 30 Wyo. 455, 222 P. 35, 1924 Wyo. LEXIS 71 (Wyo. 1924).

Construction of exemption provisions. —

The courts will not construe a statute to ascribe to the legislature an intention to evade or circumvent the constitutional restraint upon its powers to exempt municipally owned property from taxation unless the violation clearly appears. City of Cheyenne v. Board of County Comm'rs, 484 P.2d 706, 1971 Wyo. LEXIS 215 (Wyo. 1971).

Where the established policy of the state is to exempt publicly owned property, the view that provisions of the constitution and statutes must be strictly construed does not apply, nor does the view apply which was expressed in Commissioners of Cambria Park v. Board of County Comm'rs, 62 Wyo. 446, 174 P.2d 402, 1946 Wyo. LEXIS 14 (1946), that taxation is the rule and exemption will not be presumed. City of 484 P.2d 706, 1971 Wyo. LEXIS 215.

The amended constitution ought not to be construed as intended to stifle any activity which is for the general welfare of the people and which constitutes purely gratuitous service. Town of Pine Bluffs v. State Bd. of Equalization, 79 Wyo. 262, 333 P.2d 700, 1958 Wyo. LEXIS 45 (Wyo. 1958), limited, State Bd. of Equalization v. City of Lander, 882 P.2d 844, 1994 Wyo. LEXIS 113 (Wyo. 1994).

Time when exemption starts. —

When property has been sold for delinquent taxes and bid in for county, and certificate of purchase has been issued to county, the land is exempt from taxation. Williams v. School Dist., 56 Wyo. 1, 102 P.2d 48, 1940 Wyo. LEXIS 22 (Wyo. 1940).

Burden is on taxing authority to establish taxability. 484 P.2d 706, 1971 Wyo. LEXIS 215.

Municipal property, as such, is not exempt from taxation under the state constitution and statutes. City of Cheyenne v. Sims, 521 P.2d 1347, 1974 Wyo. LEXIS 204 (Wyo. 1974).

But the exemption resolves itself into a question of the use, it being exempt only “when used primarily for a governmental purpose.” City of Cheyenne v. Sims, 521 P.2d 1347, 1974 Wyo. LEXIS 204 (Wyo. 1974).

Which is question of fact. —

The exemption of municipal property is solely dependent upon its use and is therefore solely a question of fact, and not of law or the constitutionality of a statute. City of Cheyenne v. Sims, 521 P.2d 1347, 1974 Wyo. LEXIS 204 (Wyo. 1974).

Exemption limited to property used primarily for governmental purpose. —

This section discards ownership as the sole basis for exemption and limits the exemption of municipal property to that owned and “used primarily for a governmental purpose.” City of Cheyenne v. Board of County Comm'rs, 484 P.2d 706, 1971 Wyo. LEXIS 215 (Wyo. 1971).

The first clause of this section is a limitation upon the powers of the legislature to exempt municipally owned property from taxation; and it can only do so when such property is “used primarily for a governmental purpose.” City of Cheyenne v. Board of County Comm'rs, 484 P.2d 706, 1971 Wyo. LEXIS 215 (Wyo. 1971).

Term “governmental purpose” is not readily amenable to precise definition and such determination is largely dependent upon the circumstances presented in each case. As a general rule, the tests utilized in fixing tort liability on the basis of whether a particular activity is governmental or proprietary may be applied. City of Cheyenne v. Board of County Comm'rs, 484 P.2d 706, 1971 Wyo. LEXIS 215 (Wyo. 1971).

Property not exempt where function proprietary. —

Furnishing electric light and power to the people of a municipality through municipally owned plant is not a governmental function, but is proprietary and hence the property of such plants is not exempt from taxation. Town of Pine Bluffs v. State Bd. of Equalization, 79 Wyo. 262, 333 P.2d 700, 1958 Wyo. LEXIS 45 (Wyo. 1958), limited, State Bd. of Equalization v. City of Lander, 882 P.2d 844, 1994 Wyo. LEXIS 113 (Wyo. 1994).

But property exempt where municipality acts in governmental function. —

Where a service is rendered by a municipality gratuitously and for the public welfare generally, such as lighting streets, directing traffic and lighting offices occupied by city officers, such service constitutes a governmental function and the property of such plants to that extent is exempt from taxation. Town of Pine Bluffs v. State Bd. of Equalization, 79 Wyo. 262, 333 P.2d 700, 1958 Wyo. LEXIS 45 (Wyo. 1958), limited, State Bd. of Equalization v. City of Lander, 882 P.2d 844, 1994 Wyo. LEXIS 113 (Wyo. 1994).

Leasing of municipally owned buildings. —

The mere renting of buildings to a lessee engaged in a profit-making venture is not of itself a use for nongovernmental purposes. It depends upon the circumstances. The test is whether or not those buildings were primarily used and being so used as reasonably necessary or essential facilities to the efficient operation and maintenance of the airport. If so, the improvements were not subject to taxation. City of Cheyenne v. Board of County Comm'rs, 484 P.2d 706, 1971 Wyo. LEXIS 215 (Wyo. 1971).

In considering whether or not as a general proposition buildings owned by a municipality and located upon its airport and used primarily for the housing, care, repair and service of aircraft can be said to constitute a “governmental purpose” the supreme court is impressed with the fact that the legislature apparently regarded such facilities as an essential or necessary adjunct to an airport. The mere fact that the city accomplished such use through a lessee or received rent in return for such use is not controlling. City of Cheyenne v. Board of County Comm'rs, 484 P.2d 706, 1971 Wyo. LEXIS 215 (Wyo. 1971).

A “fixed base operation” is a necessary adjunct to the operation of an airport. That being true, it reasonably follows that city-owned buildings leased for use in such an operation were “used primarily for a governmental purpose” within the reach of the constitutional provision and the exemption statute. Consequently no part of those buildings was subject to county taxation. City of Cheyenne v. Board of County Comm'rs, 484 P.2d 706, 1971 Wyo. LEXIS 215 (Wyo. 1971).

A city-owned building leased to a private corporation in the business of modification, repair, overhaul, conditioning and testing of aircraft, aircraft parts and incidentals for the United States of America and for others was not in use for primarily governmental purposes and was not exempt from taxation by a county. City of Cheyenne v. Board of County Comm'rs, 484 P.2d 706, 1971 Wyo. LEXIS 215 (Wyo. 1971).

A city-owned building leased to an ambulance service, which although subsidized by both the city and county rendered a countywide ambulance service for which it made charges to users of the service, but which made only 3 percent of its service calls in response to airport accidents or contemplated accidents, was not exempt from taxation by the county as municipal property which was part of an airport. City of Cheyenne v. Board of County Comm'rs, 484 P.2d 706, 1971 Wyo. LEXIS 215 (Wyo. 1971).

Property used “primarily” for governmental purpose. —

The city was “primarily” using the property the county wanted to tax for the express “governmental purpose” of a city hall even though the city collected rents or rented space to a state agency. State Bd. of Equalization v. City of Lander, 882 P.2d 844, 1994 Wyo. LEXIS 113 (Wyo. 1994).

Property leased to exempt association not exempt. —

A person whose property would ordinarily be subject to taxation may not be released from bearing his share of the expense of government by simply leasing his property for a substantial rental to an association which, due to the purposes for which it was organized, is exempted from paying taxes when using property for those purposes. When a person derives income from property in such fashion he is using it for his own personal advantage and there is no valid reason why he should not pay the taxes regularly assessed to it. Commissioners of Cambria Park v. Board of County Comm'rs, 62 Wyo. 446, 174 P.2d 402, 1946 Wyo. LEXIS 14 (Wyo. 1946).

Irrigation district. —

An irrigation district not being a municipal corporation, but being a corporation established for purposes chiefly private and with powers conferred mainly for the benefit of its own landowners, does not come within provision for tax exemptions. State ex rel. Goshen Irrigation Dist. v. Hunt, 49 Wyo. 497, 57 P.2d 793, 1936 Wyo. LEXIS 58 (Wyo. 1936).

Special assessments. —

School district property is not exempt from liability for payment of its proportionate share of special assessment for sewer line constructed by municipality in vicinity of school building. 57 Wyo. 121, 113 P.2d 958, 1941 Wyo. LEXIS 24.

Industrial Development Projects Act held constitutional. —

See Reed v. Cheyenne, 429 P.2d 69, 1967 Wyo. LEXIS 160 (Wyo. 1967); Uhls v. State, 429 P.2d 74, 1967 Wyo. LEXIS 161 (Wyo. 1967); Powers v. Cheyenne, 435 P.2d 448, 1967 Wyo. LEXIS 191 (Wyo. 1967), reh'g denied, 436 P.2d 961, 1968 Wyo. LEXIS 155 (Wyo. 1968).

Rule that vendee in possession under contract to purchase is liable for taxes cannot be applied so as to allow taxation of property which is declared exempt by the constitution. Olds v. Little Horse Creek Cattle Co., 22 Wyo. 336, 140 P. 1004, 1914 Wyo. LEXIS 18 (Wyo. 1914).

Direct Cost Ratio. —

Wyoming Department of Revenue's interpretation of its own administrative rule was to be given effect because it was consistent with its statutory interpretation; royalties and production taxes were not to be included as direct costs of producing oil and gas. Excluding royalties and production taxes from the direct cost ratio provided a more reasonable interpretation. RME Petroleum Co. v. Wyo. Dep't of Revenue, 2007 WY 16, 150 P.3d 673, 2007 Wyo. LEXIS 16 (Wyo. 2007).

Applied in

Frank v. City of Cody, 572 P.2d 1106, 1977 Wyo. LEXIS 304 (Wyo. 1977).

Quoted in

Miller v. Board of County Comm'rs, 79 Wyo. 502, 337 P.2d 262, 1959 Wyo. LEXIS 18 (1959); Memorial Hosp. v. Department of Revenue & Taxation, 770 P.2d 223, 1989 Wyo. LEXIS 61 (Wyo. 1989); Deromedi v. Town of Thermopolis, 2002 WY 69, 45 P.3d 1150, 2002 Wyo. LEXIS 74 (Wyo. 2002); Town of Thermopolis v. Deromedi, 2002 WY 70, 45 P.3d 1155, 2002 Wyo. LEXIS 75 (Wyo. 2002); Mt. Vista Ret. Residence v. Fremont Cnty. Assessor, 2015 WY 117, 2015 Wyo. LEXIS 132 (Sept. 2, 2015).

Cited in

Town of Pine Bluffs v. Eisele, 2017 WY 117, 403 P.3d 126, 2017 Wyo. LEXIS 123 (Wyo. 2017).

Law reviews. —

For article, “Practitioner's Guide to Valuation and Assessment Appeals of State and Local Assessed Property,” see XXXII Land & Water L. Rev. 173 (1997).

§ 13. Tax must be authorized by law; law to state object.

No tax shall be levied, except in pursuance of law, and every law imposing a tax shall state distinctly the object of the same, to which only it shall be applied.

This section prohibits taxes not specifically provided by statute. Kelsey v. Taft, 72 Wyo. 210, 263 P.2d 135, 1953 Wyo. LEXIS 41 (Wyo. 1953).

Court cannot impose tax which legislature mentioned only by indirection. —

Under this section, the supreme court is unwarranted in “levying” or “imposing,” by judicial decree, a tax which the legislature mentioned only by indirection. Kelsey v. Taft, 72 Wyo. 210, 263 P.2d 135, 1953 Wyo. LEXIS 41 (Wyo. 1953).

Underground storage tank funding scheme. —

Section 39-6-302(g) (now see § 39-14-703), which imposes a mineral severance tax, satisfies the requirement of this section that a law levying a tax state the object of the tax, because § 39-6-305(k) (now see § 39-14-711) states the disposition of the tax revenue. V-1 Oil Co. v. State, 934 P.2d 740, 1997 Wyo. LEXIS 52 (Wyo. 1997).

Occupation tax. —

A city ordinance, levying occupation taxes, which stated that it was laid for “general revenue purposes,” and “for the purpose of raising revenue for the city during the time mentioned,” sufficiently stated purpose of tax, to comply with this section. City of Sheridan v. Litman, 32 Wyo. 14, 228 P. 628, 1924 Wyo. LEXIS 43 (Wyo. 1924).

Where an occupation tax was authorized by § 15-1-103 (a)(xiii) it must be said that it was enacted in pursuance of law within the meaning of this section. City of Rawlins v. Frontier Ref. Co., 396 P.2d 740, 1964 Wyo. LEXIS 128 (Wyo. 1964).

Bonds. —

The delegation of taxing authority is sufficient under either §§ 18-4-301 to 18-4-303 and 18-4-306 to 18-4-310 relative to bonds generally or §§ 18-4-401 to 18-4-409 relative to viaduct and subway bonds to meet the requirements set forth in this section. Board of County Comm'rs v. White, 79 Wyo. 420, 335 P.2d 433, 1959 Wyo. LEXIS 14 (Wyo. 1959).

Transfer of school funds. —

Where county treasurer transferred funds of plaintiff school district without high school to defendant district with high school at which plaintiff district's pupils attended without permission of plaintiff district's officials, but defendant district was only available district, the latter could, by showing that money transferred to it was in whole or in definite and separable part derived from distribution made by state or was not raised by taxation, have such money applied on its claim for tuition. School Dist. v. Jackson-Wilson High Sch. Dist., 49 Wyo. 115, 52 P.2d 673, 1935 Wyo. LEXIS 9 (Wyo. 1935).

Interest on county funds. —

This article prevents a county treasurer from diverting the principal amount of taxes collected for a school district. Thus, because interest is an accretion or increment of the principal fund earning it and the interest follows the fund, the county treasurer, as soon as the funds are collected, should designate the principal and interest to the school district. Board of County Comm'rs v. Laramie County Sch. Dist. No. One, 884 P.2d 946, 1994 Wyo. LEXIS 144 (Wyo. 1994).

The general rule that the interest is part of the taxes means that the interest on the taxes must be “applied” for the same purpose. Campbell County Sch. Dist. No. 1 v. Board of County Comm'rs, 884 P.2d 960, 1994 Wyo. LEXIS 135 (Wyo. 1994).

Irrigation district law was not violative of this section. Sullivan v. Blakesley, 35 Wyo. 73, 246 P. 918, 1926 Wyo. LEXIS 9 (Wyo. 1926).

Statute upheld. —

The omission from ch. 102, Laws 1895, amending p. 97, § 1, Laws 1877, of the words “for ordinary county expenses” did not signify any intention to change the purpose of the tax. State v. Board of Comm'rs, 8 Wyo. 104, 55 P. 451, 1898 Wyo. LEXIS 26 (Wyo. 1898).

Applied in

Marathon Oil Co. v. Welch, 379 P.2d 832, 1963 Wyo. LEXIS 82 (Wyo. 1963).

Quoted in

Rocky Mountain Oil & Gas Ass'n v. State Bd. of Equalization, Dep't of Revenue & Taxation, 749 P.2d 221, 1987 Wyo. LEXIS 572 (Wyo. 1987).

Cited in

School Dist. v. Board of Comm'rs, 15 Wyo. 73, 86 P. 24, 1906 Wyo. LEXIS 6 (1906); Hansen v. Smith, 395 P.2d 944, 1964 Wyo. LEXIS 124 (Wyo. 1964).

Law reviews. —

For article, “Defeating Tax Levies to Recover Excess Taxes,” see 4 Wyo. L.J. 233.

§ 14. Surrender of taxing power prohibited.

The power of taxation shall never be surrendered or suspended by any grant or contract to which the state or any county or other municipal corporation shall be a party.

Board of equalization must use full value. —

Constitutional provisions deny constitutional or implied legislatively delegable authority to the state board of equalization to set any assessment ratio which would effectively determine the actual tax, except to use full value. Rocky Mountain Oil & Gas Ass'n v. State Bd. of Equalization, Dep't of Revenue & Taxation, 749 P.2d 221, 1987 Wyo. LEXIS 572 (Wyo. 1987), reh'g denied, 749 P.2d 221, 1988 Wyo. LEXIS 3 (Wyo. 1988).

Law reviews. —

For article, “The Constitutionality of Wyoming's Oil and Gas Compulsory Pooling Provision,” see 6 Wyo. L.J. 300.

§ 15. State tax for support of public schools.

For the support of the public schools in the state there may be levied each year a state tax not exceeding twelve mills on the dollar of the assessed valuation of the property in the state. (As added by Laws 1947, Senate Joint Resolution No. 4, p. 259; as amended by Laws 1981, House Joint Resolution No. 3, p. 328.)

Cross references. —

For another provision authorizing tax for support of schools, see art. 7, § 9, Wyo. Const.

As to levy of state tax for schools, see § 21-13-303.

Section added. —

This section was added by an amendment proposed by Laws 1947, Senate Joint Resolution No. 4, p. 259, adopted by vote of the people at the general election held November 2, 1948, and proclaimed in effect December 1, 1948.

Board of equalization must use full value. —

Constitutional provisions deny constitutional or implied legislatively delegable authority to the state board of equalization to set any assessment ratio which would effectively determine the actual tax, except to use full value. Rocky Mountain Oil & Gas Ass'n v. State Bd. of Equalization, Dep't of Revenue & Taxation, 749 P.2d 221, 1987 Wyo. LEXIS 572 (Wyo. 1987), reh'g denied, 749 P.2d 221, 1988 Wyo. LEXIS 3 (Wyo. 1988).

Unified school districts. —

For formation of unified school district joining affluent school district with poorer district, and suggestions for equalization of ad valorem taxation for school purposes, see Sweetwater County Planning Comm. v. Hinkle, 491 P.2d 1234, 1971 Wyo. LEXIS 185 (Wyo. 1971).

Stated in

Washakie County Sch. Dist. v. Herschler, 606 P.2d 310, 1980 Wyo. LEXIS 227 (Wyo. 1980).

Cited in

State v. Campbell County Sch. Dist., 2001 WY 19, 19 P.3d 518, 2001 Wyo. LEXIS 21 (Wyo. 2001).

Law reviews. —

For article, “School Finance Reform in Wyoming,” see XIX Land & Water L. Rev. 135 (1984).

§ 16. Disposition of fees, excises and license taxes on vehicles and gasoline.

No moneys derived from fees, excises, or license taxes levied by the state and exclusive of registration fees and licenses or excise taxes imposed by a county or municipality, relating to registration, operation or use of vehicles on public highways, streets or alleys, or to fuels used for propelling such vehicles, shall be expended for other than cost of administering such laws, statutory refunds and adjustments allowed therein, payment of highway obligations, costs for construction, reconstruction, maintenance and repair of public highways, county roads, bridges, and streets, alleys and bridges in cities and towns, and expense of enforcing state traffic laws. (As added by Laws 1953, House Joint Resolution No. 2, p. 280.)

Cross references. —

As to disposition of motor vehicle registration and licensing fees, see § 31-3-103.

As to disposition of fees under Driver's License Law, see § 31-7-104.

As to imposition and disposition of taxes on gasoline, see §§ 39-17-101 through 39-17-111.

Section added. —

This section was added by an amendment proposed by Laws 1953, House Joint Resolution No. 2, p. 280, adopted by vote of the people at the general election held November 2, 1954, and proclaimed in effect December 7, 1954.

Underground storage tank funding scheme. —

The funding scheme under prior provisions of the taxation and revenue code whereby mineral severance tax revenues previously designated for the state highway fund were used to fund an underground storage tank program and were replaced in the highway fund with proceeds from an additional fuel tax, did not violate the requirement of this section that any vehicle or gasoline tax be committed exclusively to public highway expenses. V-1 Oil Co. v. State, 934 P.2d 740, 1997 Wyo. LEXIS 52 (Wyo. 1997).

An oil company's bare allegation that the state was funding an underground storage tank program by “fraudulently” transferring fuel tax proceeds required by this section to be used for public highway expenses was insufficient to state a claim for fraud. V-1 Oil Co. v. State, 934 P.2d 740, 1997 Wyo. LEXIS 52 (Wyo. 1997).

Cited in

Witzenburger v. State ex rel. Wyo. Community Dev. Auth., 575 P.2d 1100, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 266 (Wyo. 1978).

Law reviews. —

For article, “Mineral Taxation: The Wyoming Problem as Compared with Other Western States,” see III Land & Water L. Rev. 535 (1968).

For comment, “State Level Transportation Management,” see VI Land & Water L. Rev. 701 (1971).

§ 17. County levy for support and maintenance of public schools.

There shall be levied each year in each county of the state a tax of not to exceed six (6) mills on the dollar of the assessed valuation of the property in each county for the support and maintenance of the public schools. This tax shall be collected by the county treasurer and disbursed among the school districts within the county as the legislature shall provide. The legislature may authorize boards of trustees of school districts to levy a special tax on the property of the district. The legislature may also provide for the distribution among one (1) or more school districts of any revenue from the special school district property tax in excess of a state average yield, which shall be calculated each year, per average daily membership. (As added by Laws 1965, Senate Joint Resolution No. 10, p. 520; as amended by Laws 1981, House Joint Resolution No. 3, p. 329; Laws 2006, Senate Joint Resolution No. 1.)

2006 amendment. —

Laws 2006, Senate Joint Resolution No. 1, authorized the submission of a proposed amendment of this section, which was approved by a vote of the people at the general election held November 7, 2006 and certified November 15, 2006.

The 2006 amendment relates to the recapture of excess revenues for the support of public schools.

Editor's notes. —

Laws 2003, Senate Enrolled Joint Resolution No. 2, § 1, authorized the submission of a proposed amendment to the electors of the state of Wyoming at the next general election for approval or rejection to become valid as a part of the constitution if ratified by a majority of the electors.

The proposed amendment would have eliminated the maximum recapture of excess revenues for the support of public schools. The amendment was not ratified by a majority of electors at the November 2, 2004 general election.

Unified school districts. —

For formation of unified school district joining affluent school district with poorer district, and suggestions for equalization of ad valorem taxation for school purposes, see Sweetwater County Planning Comm. v. Hinkle, 491 P.2d 1234, 1971 Wyo. LEXIS 185 (Wyo. 1971).

Transitional school funding recapture limits. —

The $250,000 cap imposed on transitional hold harmless payments applicable to wealthy school districts subject to revenue recapture bore a rational relationship to a legitimate state interest in making the transition to a cost-based school funding system and thus did not violate the equal protection provisions of the Wyoming Constitution. Lincoln County Sch. Dist. No. One v. State, 985 P.2d 964, 1999 Wyo. LEXIS 125 (Wyo. 1999).

Quoted in

State v. Campbell County Sch. Dist., 2001 WY 19, 19 P.3d 518, 2001 Wyo. LEXIS 21 (Wyo. 2001).

Stated in

Washakie County Sch. Dist. v. Herschler, 606 P.2d 310, 1980 Wyo. LEXIS 227 (Wyo. 1980).

Law reviews. —

For article, “School Finance Reform in Wyoming,” see XIX Land & Water L. Rev. 135 (1984).

§ 18. Full tax credit allowed against any liability arising from a tax on income.

No tax shall be imposed upon income without allowing full credit against such tax liability for all sales, use, and ad valorem taxes paid in the taxable year by the same taxpayer to any taxing authority in Wyoming. (As added by Laws 1973, House Joint Resolution No. 12, p. 752.)

Cross references. —

For provision preempting taxation of income to the state, see § 39-12-101.

Section added. —

This section was added by an amendment proposed by Laws 1973, House Joint Resolution No. 12, p. 752, adopted by vote of the people at the general election held November 5, 1974, and proclaimed in effect December 12, 1974.

§ 19. Mineral excise tax; distribution.

The Legislature shall provide by law for an excise tax on the privilege of severing or extracting minerals, of one and one-half percent (1 1/2%) on the value of the gross product extracted. The minerals subject to such excise tax shall be coal, petroleum, natural gas, oil shale, and such other minerals as may be designated by the Legislature. Such tax shall be in addition to any other excise, severance or ad valorem tax. The proceeds from such tax shall be deposited in the Permanent Wyoming Mineral Trust Fund. The fund, including all monies deposited in the fund from whatever source, shall remain inviolate. The monies in the fund shall be invested as prescribed by the Legislature and all income from fund investments shall be deposited by the State Treasurer in the general fund on an annual basis. The Legislature may also specify by law, conditions and terms under which monies in the fund may be loaned to political subdivisions of the state. (As added by Laws 1974, House Joint Resolution No. 2A, p. 111; Amended by Laws 2006, House Joint Resolution No. 4.)

2006 amendment.

Laws 2006, House Joint Resolution No. 4, authorized the submission of a proposed amendment of this section which was approved by a vote of the people at the general election held November 7, 2006, and certified November 15, 2006.

The 2006 amendment relates to clarifying that all monies deposited in the Permanent Wyoming Mineral Trust Fund are inviolate permanent funds of the state.

Section added. —

This section was added by an amendment proposed by Laws 1974, House Joint Resolution No. 2A, p. 111, adopted by vote of the people at the general election held November 5, 1974, and proclaimed in effect December 12, 1974.

Green River/Rock Springs water treatment plant. —

Laws 1995, ch. 201, §§ 1 through 7, authorize the design, construction, and operation of the Green River/Rock Springs water treatment plant, describe the project, restrict the sale of water and sale of the project, and provide for a loan from the Wyoming mineral trust fund under specified options.

Cross references. —

For statutory provisions concerning tax, see chapter 14 of title 39.

Department of revenue and taxation was not required to continue invalid pricing system used in 1985 for determining the severance tax on uranium, where the system afforded no reasonable relationship to market value and was illegal and contrary to the constitutional mandates of equal and uniform taxation. Pathfinder Mines Corp. v. State Bd. of Equalization, 766 P.2d 531, 1988 Wyo. LEXIS 171 (Wyo. 1988).

Exhaustion of administrative remedies. —

Taxpayer was required to exhaust administrative remedies before bringing declaratory judgment action; constitutionally-established and statutorily-directed agency was proper forum for initial review of challenge to tax assessment. Union Pac. Resources Co. v. State, 839 P.2d 356, 1992 Wyo. LEXIS 135 (Wyo. 1992).

Quoted in

Witzenburger v. State ex rel. Wyo. Community Dev. Auth., 575 P.2d 1100, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 266 (Wyo. 1978).

§ 20. Higher education trust funds; investments; earnings.

The legislature may from time to time place monies into endowment funds for higher education scholarships and for improving the quality of higher education, which funds shall remain inviolate. The earnings of the funds shall be used for the purposes specified in this section, but the legislature may from time to time by law regulate the manner in which the earnings are expended. The legislature may also provide for use of the earnings to protect the funds from inflation and to even fluctuations in earnings over time. The funds may be invested in the same manner as other permanent funds of the state. (As added by Laws 2006, House Joint Resolution No. 4, Section 1.)

Section added. —

This section was added by an amendment proposed by Laws 2006, House Joint Resolution No. 4, Section 1, adopted by vote of the people at the general election held November 7, 2006, and certified on November 15, 2006.

Editor's notes. —

Laws 2006, House Joint Resolution No. 4, Section 3 states as follows:

“It is the intention of the legislature that if approved by the voters this amendment will immediately apply to the funds within the education endowment account and the Hathaway student scholarship account previously established by law in Wyoming statutes 21-16-1201(a) and (b), and would subsequently apply to other higher education endowment funds as designated by law.”

Joint resolution. —

Laws 2002, Sp. Sess., Senate Joint Resolution No. 2, §§ 1 to 4, requests Congress to propose and submit to the several states for ratification an amendment to the United States Constitution prohibiting the Supreme Court and inferior federal courts from having the power to instruct or order a state or political subdivision, or an official of such, to levy or increase taxes.

Article 16. Public Indebtedness

  • § 1. Limitation on state debt.
  • § 2. Creation of state debt in excess of taxes for current year.
  • § 3. Limitation on county debt.
  • § 4. Creation of county or municipal debt in excess of taxes for current year.
  • § 5. Limitation on municipal, county or school district debt.
  • § 6. Loan of credit; donations prohibited; works of internal improvement.
  • § 7. Payments of public money.
  • § 8. Endorsements required on bonds and other evidences of indebtedness.
  • § 9. Construction and improvement of public roads and highways.
  • § 10. Construction and improvement of works for conservation and utilization of water.
  • § 11. Construction, maintenance and improvement of public airports, aircraft landing strips and related facilities.
  • § 12. Economic development loan fund.
  • § 13. Industrial and economic development; powers of counties and municipalities.

§ 1. Limitation on state debt.

The State of Wyoming shall not, in any manner, create any indebtedness exceeding one per centum on the assessed value of the taxable property in the state, as shown by the last general assessment for taxation, preceding; except to suppress insurrection or to provide for the public defense.

Cross references. —

As to taxation and revenue generally, see art. 15, § 1 to 19, Wyo. Const.

As to funds of state and political subdivisions, see §§ 9-4-101 to 9-4-904.

As to taxation generally, see title 39.

This section and art. 16, § 2, Wyo. Const., are separate, though related. Witzenburger v. State ex rel. Wyo. Community Dev. Auth., 575 P.2d 1100, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 266 (Wyo. 1978).

Debt limit of this section and art. 16, § 3, Wyo. Const., compared. —

The state's debt limit is one percent under the provisions of this section, while the debt limit for a political subdivision is four percent under the provisions of art. 16, § 3, Wyo. Const.Witzenburger v. State ex rel. Wyo. Community Dev. Auth., 575 P.2d 1100, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 266 (Wyo. 1978).

There is no violation of this section if indebtedness is not state debt, or if liability is limited so as not to be a charge on the taxpayers of the state. State ex rel. Wyoming Farm Loan Bd. v. Herschler, 622 P.2d 1378, 1981 Wyo. LEXIS 285 (Wyo. 1981).

Section not violated. —

Act authorizing trustees of the university to borrow from federal agencies for construction of a building, and to pledge income from the university permanent land fund for repayment, does not pledge the general credit, and does not violate constitutional provision limiting the state's indebtedness. Arnold v. Bond, 47 Wyo. 236, 34 P.2d 28, 1934 Wyo. LEXIS 22 (Wyo. 1934).

School districts are subdivisions of county within the provisions for creating debts only by a vote of the people. West v. School Dist., 37 Wyo. 36, 258 P. 583, 1927 Wyo. LEXIS 63 (Wyo. 1927).

Obligation not “debt” if not potentially payable with tax revenues. —

If there is no present legal potential that an obligation will have to be paid from revenues resulting from the exercise by a governmental entity of its power to tax, the obligation is not a debt within the constitutional provisions relative to the amount of debt and voter approval of the debt. State ex rel. Wyoming Farm Loan Bd. v. Herschler, 622 P.2d 1378, 1981 Wyo. LEXIS 285 (Wyo. 1981).

“Revenue bond” or “special fund” doctrine, constitutionally, does not incur debt. Under this doctrine, if an obligation is payable solely from revenues resulting from the project for which the obligation was incurred and not from taxes, a debt within the constitutional limitations is not incurred. State ex rel. Wyoming Farm Loan Bd. v. Herschler, 622 P.2d 1378, 1981 Wyo. LEXIS 285 (Wyo. 1981).

“The assessed value of the taxable property in the state,” referred to in this section, is there mentioned only as a limit on the amount of total authorized indebtedness the state may incur, if it wishes to become a debtor over and above normal, operating expenses by obtaining voter approval of any debt in excess of taxes for the current year. Witzenburger v. State, 575 P.2d 1100, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 266 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 577 P.2d 1386, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 289 (Wyo. 1978).

Taxes defined. —

Taxes are the enforced proportional contributions from persons and property, levied by the state by virtue of its sovereignty for the support of government and all public needs. Witzenburger v. State, 575 P.2d 1100, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 266 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 577 P.2d 1386, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 289 (Wyo. 1978).

Only way to conform to prohibition of this section and art. 16, § 2, Wyo. Const., is to stay within their clear limits without an election or submit the debt proposition to a vote of the people for approval. To hold otherwise would be to unlock the doors and grant the legislature unbridled authority to create debt without limitation, contrary to what the state's founding fathers, with approval of the people, conceived to be reasonable restraints. Witzenburger v. State, 575 P.2d 1100, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 266 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 577 P.2d 1386, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 289 (Wyo. 1978).

Purpose in endeavoring to catalog transaction involving public entity as lease rather than a sale is often to circumvent statutory or constitutional debt limitations, or it is to avoid statutory or constitutional restrictions on expenditures exceeding annual income. "Laramie Citizens for Good Government" v. Laramie, 617 P.2d 474, 1980 Wyo. LEXIS 307 (Wyo. 1980).

Intent of parties is determinative as to whether or not the transaction is a lease or a sale. "Laramie Citizens for Good Government" v. Laramie, 617 P.2d 474, 1980 Wyo. LEXIS 307 (Wyo. 1980).

When debt is unconstitutional. —

A debt is unconstitutional when, if income from an authorized source is insufficient, the remainder must be paid out of tax money of the state. Witzenburger v. State, 575 P.2d 1100, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 266 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 577 P.2d 1386, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 289 (Wyo. 1978).

Fact that tax collected goes into special account of general fund has no constitutional implications. It still remains a tax subject to constitutional restrictions, which cannot be avoided by accounting procedures. Witzenburger v. State, 575 P.2d 1100, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 266 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 577 P.2d 1386, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 289 (Wyo. 1978).

Revenue bonds paid from future excise tax revenues held unconstitutional. —

Revenue bonds issued by the Wyoming community development authority, for the payment of which excise tax revenue to be derived in future years is committed under the so-called “special” fund theory, come within the debt limit prohibitions of this section and art. 16, § 2, Wyo. Const.Witzenburger v. State ex rel. Wyo. Community Dev. Auth., 575 P.2d 1100, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 266 (Wyo. 1978).

A pledge by a state agency and the legislature to pay off bonds issued for money borrowed by the Wyoming community development authority from revenues to be derived from excise taxes, in whole or in part, to be collected in the future is unconstitutional. Witzenburger v. State, 575 P.2d 1100, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 266 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 577 P.2d 1386, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 289 (Wyo. 1978).

Transportation commission loan unconstitutional. —

Section 24-11-101 is unconstitutionally applied when the loan terms from the Wyoming community development authority require that the debt be paid from future excise taxes to be collected beyond the current year in which the loan is made. Witzenburger v. State, 575 P.2d 1100, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 266 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 577 P.2d 1386, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 289 (Wyo. 1978).

Article 13, § 3, Wyo. Const., does not prohibit municipal corporation from borrowing within applicable limitations of this article. Witzenburger v. State ex rel. Wyo. Community Dev. Auth., 575 P.2d 1100, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 266 (Wyo. 1978).

Voting at bond elections. —

A statute providing that only taxpayers might vote at a bond election was unconstitutional. Simpkin v. Rock Springs, 33 Wyo. 166, 237 P. 245, 1925 Wyo. LEXIS 32 (Wyo. 1925).

Cited in

Witzenburger v. State ex rel. Wyoming Community Dev. Auth., 577 P.2d 1386, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 289 (Wyo. 1978); State v. Campbell County Sch. Dist., 2001 WY 19, 19 P.3d 518, 2001 Wyo. LEXIS 21 (Wyo. 2001).

Law reviews. —

For article, “Administration of the General Property Tax in Wyoming,” see 4 Wyo. L.J. 227.

For article, “Defeating Tax Levies to Recover Excess Taxes,” see 4 Wyo. L.J. 233.

For article, “The Wyoming Constitution: A Centennial Assessment,” see XXVI Land & Water L. Rev. 13 (1991).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Validity, under state constitution and laws, of issuance by state or state agency of revenue bonds to finance or refinance construction projects at private religious-affiliated colleges or universities, 95 ALR3d 1000.

§ 2. Creation of state debt in excess of taxes for current year.

No debt in excess of the taxes for the current year, shall in any manner be created in the State of Wyoming, unless the proposition to create such debt shall have been submitted to a vote of the people and by them approved; except to suppress insurrection or to provide for the public defense.

Basic intent and purpose of this section, limiting incurrence of state debt beyond the current year's taxes, is to prohibit the legislature from binding subsequent legislatures to make appropriations of money in subsequent fiscal years. Witzenburger v. State, 575 P.2d 1100, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 266 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 577 P.2d 1386, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 289 (Wyo. 1978); State ex rel. Wyoming Farm Loan Bd. v. Herschler, 622 P.2d 1378, 1981 Wyo. LEXIS 285 (Wyo. 1981).

This section and art. 16, § 1, Wyo. Const., are separate, though related. Witzenburger v. State, 575 P.2d 1100, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 266 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 577 P.2d 1386, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 289 (Wyo. 1978).

There is no violation of this section if indebtedness is not state debt, or if liability is limited so as not to be a charge on the taxpayers of the state. State ex rel. Wyoming Farm Loan Bd. v. Herschler, 622 P.2d 1378, 1981 Wyo. LEXIS 285 (Wyo. 1981).

Nor where debt liquidated by funds other than tax revenues. —

A debt is not created within the constitutional restrictions by issuance of statutorily authorized bonds which are to be liquidated only by funds other than those derived from taxes. State ex rel. Wyoming Farm Loan Bd. v. Herschler, 622 P.2d 1378, 1981 Wyo. LEXIS 285 (Wyo. 1981).

Section not violated. —

Act authorizing trustees of the university to borrow from federal agencies for construction of a building, and to pledge income from the university permanent land fund for repayment, does not pledge the general credit, and does not violate constitutional provision limiting the state's indebtedness. Arnold v. Bond, 47 Wyo. 236, 34 P.2d 28, 1934 Wyo. LEXIS 22 (Wyo. 1934).

This section does not in any way limit “taxes” to any particular type and the word is construed to mean taxes of every type. Witzenburger v. State, 575 P.2d 1100, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 266 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 577 P.2d 1386, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 289 (Wyo. 1978).

This section in its use of the term “taxes” includes every sort, in whatever form the legislature elects to take them. Witzenburger v. State, 575 P.2d 1100, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 266 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 577 P.2d 1386, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 289 (Wyo. 1978).

And in its prohibitions does not relate only to ad valorem tax. —

See Witzenburger v. State, 575 P.2d 1100, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 266 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 577 P.2d 1386, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 289 (Wyo. 1978).

This section makes no distinction as to old taxes and new taxes. Witzenburger v. State, 575 P.2d 1100, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 266 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 577 P.2d 1386, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 289 (Wyo. 1978).

Taxes defined. —

Taxes are the enforced proportional contributions from persons and property, levied by the state by virtue of its sovereignty for the support of government and all public needs. Witzenburger v. State, 575 P.2d 1100, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 266 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 577 P.2d 1386, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 289 (Wyo. 1978).

Only way to conform to prohibition of this section and art. 16, § 1, Wyo. Const., is to stay within their clear limits without an election or submit the debt proposition to a vote of the people for approval. To hold otherwise would be to unlock the doors and grant the legislature unbridled authority to create debt without limitation, contrary to what the state's founding fathers, with approval of the people, conceived to be reasonable restraints. Witzenburger v. State, 575 P.2d 1100, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 266 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 577 P.2d 1386, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 289 (Wyo. 1978).

Purpose in endeavoring to catalog transaction involving public entity as lease rather than a sale is often to circumvent statutory or constitutional debt limitations, or it is to avoid statutory or constitutional restrictions on expenditures exceeding annual income. "Laramie Citizens for Good Government" v. Laramie, 617 P.2d 474, 1980 Wyo. LEXIS 307 (Wyo. 1980).

Intent of parties is determinative as to whether or not the transaction is a lease or a sale. "Laramie Citizens for Good Government" v. Laramie, 617 P.2d 474, 1980 Wyo. LEXIS 307 (Wyo. 1980).

When debt is unconstitutional. —

A debt is unconstitutional when, if income from an authorized source is insufficient, the remainder must be paid out of tax money of the state. Witzenburger v. State, 575 P.2d 1100, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 266 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 577 P.2d 1386, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 289 (Wyo. 1978).

Fact that tax collected goes into special account of general fund has no constitutional implications. It still remains a tax subject to constitutional restrictions, which cannot be avoided by accounting procedures. Witzenburger v. State, 575 P.2d 1100, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 266 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 577 P.2d 1386, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 289 (Wyo. 1978).

Revenue bonds paid from future excise tax revenues held unconstitutional. —

Revenue bonds issued by the Wyoming community development authority, for the payment of which excise tax revenue to be derived in future years is committed under the so-called “special” fund theory, come within the debt limit prohibitions of this section and art. 16, § 1, Wyo. Const.Witzenburger v. State ex rel. Wyo. Community Dev. Auth., 575 P.2d 1100, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 266 (Wyo. 1978).

A pledge by a state agency and the legislature to pay off bonds issued for money borrowed by the Wyoming community development authority from revenues to be derived from excise taxes, in whole or in part, to be collected in the future is unconstitutional. Witzenburger v. State, 575 P.2d 1100, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 266 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 577 P.2d 1386, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 289 (Wyo. 1978).

Transportation commission loan unconstitutional. —

Section 24-11-101 is unconstitutionally applied when the loan terms from the Wyoming community development authority require that the debt be paid from future excise taxes to be collected beyond the current year in which the loan is made. Witzenburger v. State, 575 P.2d 1100, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 266 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 577 P.2d 1386, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 289 (Wyo. 1978).

Article 13, § 3, Wyo. Const., does not prohibit municipal corporation from borrowing within applicable limitations of this article. Witzenburger v. State ex rel. Wyo. Community Dev. Auth., 575 P.2d 1100, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 266 (Wyo. 1978).

Voting at bond elections. —

A statute providing that only taxpayers may vote at bond elections is unconstitutional. Simpkin v. Rock Springs, 33 Wyo. 166, 237 P. 245, 1925 Wyo. LEXIS 32 (Wyo. 1925).

School districts are subdivisions of county within the provision for creating debts only by a vote of the people. West v. School Dist., 37 Wyo. 36, 258 P. 583, 1927 Wyo. LEXIS 63 (Wyo. 1927).

Irrigation district law was not violative of this section. Sullivan v. Blakesley, 35 Wyo. 73, 246 P. 918, 1926 Wyo. LEXIS 9 (Wyo. 1926).

Cited in

Witzenburger v. State ex rel. Wyoming Community Dev. Auth., 577 P.2d 1386, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 289 (Wyo. 1978).

Law reviews. —

For article, “Administration of the General Property Tax in Wyoming,” see 4 Wyo. L.J. 227.

§ 3. Limitation on county debt.

No county in the State of Wyoming shall in any manner create any indebtedness, exceeding two per centum on the assessed value of taxable property in such county, as shown by the last general assessment, preceding; provided, however, that any county, city, town, village or other subdivision thereof in the State of Wyoming, may bond its public debt existing at the time of the adoption of this constitution, in any sum not exceeding four per centum on the assessed value of the taxable property in such county, city, town, village or other subdivision, as shown by the last general assessment for taxation.

Debt limit of this section and art. 16, § 1, Wyo. Const., compared. —

The state's debt limit is one percent under the provisions of art. 16, § 1, Wyo. Const., while the debt limit for a political subdivision is four percent under the provisions of this section. Witzenburger v. State, 575 P.2d 1100, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 266 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 577 P.2d 1386, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 289 (Wyo. 1978).

Section applies to all county debts. —

The limitation of indebtedness providing that no county shall create any indebtedness exceeding two percent on the assessed value of taxable property, and that no debt in excess of the taxes for the current year shall be created by any county except by vote of the people, applies to all debts of the county, including compulsory obligations imposed by law for salaries or bounties or voluntary obligations entered into for any purpose. Grand I. & N. W. R.R. v. Baker, 6 Wyo. 369, 45 P. 494, 1896 Wyo. LEXIS 21 (Wyo. 1896).

Apportionment of debt where new county created from existing county. —

Where a new county is created from an existing county, the provisions hereof do not apply to the apportionment of the debt of the parent county to the new county. In re Fremont County, 8 Wyo. 1, 54 P. 1073, 1898 Wyo. LEXIS 21 (Wyo. 1898).

School districts are subdivisions of county within the provision for creating debts only by a vote of the people. West v. School Dist., 37 Wyo. 36, 258 P. 583, 1927 Wyo. LEXIS 63 (Wyo. 1927).

Applicability

This section and art. 16, §§ 4 and 5, Wyo. Const., are not involved with the constitutionality of the Wyoming community development authority, since under the terms of the Wyoming Community Development Authority Act, the authority is not and cannot be a political subdivision. Witzenburger v. State, 575 P.2d 1100, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 266 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 577 P.2d 1386, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 289 (Wyo. 1978).

Because any debt created by a housing authority under Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 15-10-108 was not a general obligation and was payable only from sources other than the county's taxing authority, Wyo. Const. art. 16 §§ 3, 4, and 5 did not apply. Gronberg v. Teton County Hous. Auth., 2011 WY 13, 247 P.3d 35, 2011 Wyo. LEXIS 14 (Wyo. 2011).

Purpose in endeavoring to catalog transaction involving public entity as lease rather than a sale is often to circumvent statutory or constitutional debt limitations, or it is to avoid statutory or constitutional restrictions on expenditures exceeding annual income. "Laramie Citizens for Good Government" v. Laramie, 617 P.2d 474, 1980 Wyo. LEXIS 307 (Wyo. 1980).

Intent of parties is determinative as to whether or not the transaction is a lease or a sale. "Laramie Citizens for Good Government" v. Laramie, 617 P.2d 474, 1980 Wyo. LEXIS 307 (Wyo. 1980).

Refunding bonds. —

A county has authority to issue refunding bonds. Board of Comm'rs v. Rollins, 9 Wyo. 281, 62 P. 351, 1900 Wyo. LEXIS 19 (Wyo. 1900).

Where indebtedness has been lawfully created during territorial days and was within four percent on the adoption of the constitution, the county had authority to issue funding bonds not exceeding four percent of the assessed valuation of property. Board of County Comm'rs v. Rollins Inv. Co., 3 Wyo. 470, 27 P. 683, 1891 Wyo. LEXIS 10 (Wyo. 1891).

The refunding of the bonded indebtedness of a school district is not the creation of the debt under this section. Miller v. School Dist., 5 Wyo. 217, 39 P. 879, 1895 Wyo. LEXIS 19 (Wyo. 1895).

Stated in

Board of County Comm'rs v. White, 79 Wyo. 420, 335 P.2d 433, 1959 Wyo. LEXIS 14 (1959).

Cited in

State v. Campbell County Sch. Dist., 2001 WY 19, 19 P.3d 518, 2001 Wyo. LEXIS 21 (Wyo. 2001).

Law reviews. —

For article, “Administration of the General Property Tax in Wyoming,” see 4 Wyo. L.J. 227.

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Validity, under state constitution and laws, of issuance by state or state agency of revenue bonds to finance or refinance construction projects at private religious-affiliated colleges or universities, 95 ALR3d 1000.

§ 4. Creation of county or municipal debt in excess of taxes for current year.

No debt in excess of the taxes for the current year shall, in any manner, be created by any county or subdivision thereof, or any city, town or village, or any subdivision thereof in the State of Wyoming, unless the proposition to create such debt shall have been submitted to a vote of the people thereof and by them approved.

Section applies to all county debts. —

The limitation of indebtedness, providing that no county shall create any indebtedness exceeding two percent on the assessed value of taxable property, and that no debt in excess of the taxes for the current year shall be created by any county except by vote of the people, applies to all debts of the county, including compulsory obligations imposed by law for salaries or bounties or voluntary obligations entered into for any purpose. Grand I. & N. W. R.R. v. Baker, 6 Wyo. 369, 45 P. 494, 1896 Wyo. LEXIS 21 (Wyo. 1896).

Liability of city for official neglect. —

Constitutional provision has been uniformly held not to apply in cases of liability of the city arising out of the neglect of officials to do their duty in connection with special assessments, to purchaser of improvement bonds. Henning v. Casper, 50 Wyo. 1, 57 P.2d 1264, 62 P.2d 304, 1936 Wyo. LEXIS 3 (Wyo. 1936), reh'g denied, 63 Wyo. 352, 182 P.2d 840, 1947 Wyo. LEXIS 20 (Wyo. 1947).

Tax for county revenue is laid distinctively for county as opposed to state purposes and is not applicable to the payment of a deficiency in state levies for which a county may have become responsible. State v. Board of Comm'rs, 8 Wyo. 104, 55 P. 451, 1898 Wyo. LEXIS 26 (Wyo. 1898).

The liability imposed on a county for its uncollected levy of its quota of state taxes, and for interest thereon, and to make a special levy for the deficiency, is not a debt within this section, through the deficiency cannot be paid from the county revenue, and no levy for an anticipated deficiency is permissible. State v. Board of Comm'rs, 8 Wyo. 104, 55 P. 451, 1898 Wyo. LEXIS 26 (Wyo. 1898).

Apportionment of debt. —

The apportionment of a debt between an old county and a new one created out of its territory is merely a division of existing obligations, for which the citizens and taxable property of both counties are liable, so that the provisions of this section have no application. In re Fremont County, 8 Wyo. 1, 54 P. 1073, 1898 Wyo. LEXIS 21 (Wyo. 1898).

The legislature, having plenary power over school districts, may provide for the division of the property and the apportionment of debts in the reorganization of school districts. Lund v. Schrader, 492 P.2d 202, 1971 Wyo. LEXIS 277 (Wyo. 1971).

Applicability. —

Because any debt created by a housing authority under Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 15-10-108 was not a general obligation and was payable only from sources other than the county's taxing authority, Wyo. Const. art. 16 §§ 3, 4, and 5 did not apply. Gronberg v. Teton County Hous. Auth., 2011 WY 13, 247 P.3d 35, 2011 Wyo. LEXIS 14 (Wyo. 2011).

Component districts may be held liable to pay their proportionate share of existing debts. Lund v. Schrader, 492 P.2d 202, 1971 Wyo. LEXIS 277 (Wyo. 1971).

Existing debts cannot automatically and arbitrarily be spread evenly over the entire area included in a unified school district. The fact that such was done in a county unification makes the allocation suspect. Lund v. Schrader, 492 P.2d 202, 1971 Wyo. LEXIS 277 (Wyo. 1971).

There must be a bona fide allocation of debts to any area according to benefits received by that area from additional assets being brought into the unification. Lund v. Schrader, 492 P.2d 202, 1971 Wyo. LEXIS 277 (Wyo. 1971).

Purchase to be paid for out of revenue from property bought. —

The purchase of property by a city or town to be paid for solely out of revenue from the property purchased does not create a debt or liability in violation of this section. Town of Lovell v. Menhall, 386 P.2d 109, 1963 Wyo. LEXIS 117 (Wyo. 1963).

Where a purchase contract itself created a “special fund” for payment of parking meters and specifically provided that the town had no obligation to pay for the meters from any other source, it is not inhibited by this section. Town of Lovell v. Menhall, 386 P.2d 109, 1963 Wyo. LEXIS 117 (Wyo. 1963).

Revenue bonds excluded from debt limitations. —

“Revenue” or “special fund” bonds are not subject to constitutional or statutory debt limitations. "Laramie Citizens for Good Government" v. Laramie, 617 P.2d 474, 1980 Wyo. LEXIS 307 (Wyo. 1980).

Refunding securities. —

The refunding of the bonded indebtedness of a school district is not creation of the debt, within the provisions of this section. Miller v. School Dist., 5 Wyo. 217, 39 P. 879, 1895 Wyo. LEXIS 19 (Wyo. 1895).

The provisions of § 16-5-110, which authorizes the proceeds of refunding public securities to be placed in escrow instead of immediately applying said proceeds to the retirement of the public securities to be refunded, does not constitute the creation of a debt in excess of taxes for the current year without an approving election. Rodin v. State, 417 P.2d 180, 1966 Wyo. LEXIS 155 (Wyo. 1966).

Plaintiff's authorized payment of $79,285.50 refunding bond expenses from refunding bond proceeds, pursuant to § 16-5-109, did not constitute the creation of a debt in excess of taxes for the current year without an approving election, said amount not having been included in plaintiff's 1965-1966 budget. Rodin v. State, 417 P.2d 180, 1966 Wyo. LEXIS 155 (Wyo. 1966).

The concurrent running of interest on both the refunding bonds and on some of the bonds to be refunded during the maximum 15-year escrow term, authorized by §§ 16-5-105 and 16-5-110 does not constitute the creation of a debt in excess of taxes for the current year without an approving election. Rodin v. State, 417 P.2d 180, 1966 Wyo. LEXIS 155 (Wyo. 1966).

Revolving local improvement fund. —

This section is not violated by ch. 155, Laws 1953, authorizing a municipality to set up a revolving local improvement fund from the proceeds of city or state gasoline or state cigarette license taxes, from which the fund city may annually deposit in the local improvement district fund a sum sufficient to meet the difference between the principal amount of assessments due that year and the amount of assessments actually collected that year. Banner v. Laramie, 74 Wyo. 429, 289 P.2d 922, 1955 Wyo. LEXIS 46 (Wyo. 1955).

Purpose in endeavoring to catalog transaction involving public entity as lease rather than a sale is often to circumvent statutory or constitutional debt limitations, or it is to avoid statutory or constitutional restrictions on expenditures exceeding annual income. "Laramie Citizens for Good Government" v. Laramie, 617 P.2d 474, 1980 Wyo. LEXIS 307 (Wyo. 1980).

Intent of parties is determinative as to whether or not the transaction is a lease or a sale. "Laramie Citizens for Good Government" v. Laramie, 617 P.2d 474, 1980 Wyo. LEXIS 307 (Wyo. 1980).

No debt when obligation payable from income of self-sustaining public utilities. —

No debt is created within the constitutional limiting provision when the obligation is payable from the income of self-sustaining public utilities. Frank v. Cody, 572 P.2d 1106, 1977 Wyo. LEXIS 304 (Wyo. 1977).

Such as fund created from service charges. —

There is no debt against the municipality created within the purview of the constitutional limitation when the amounts due are payable solely from a special fund, not fed by taxes where prohibited, created from service charges only collected from users; service charges are not a tax. Frank v. Cody, 572 P.2d 1106, 1977 Wyo. LEXIS 304 (Wyo. 1977).

An agreement to pay a fixed rate for an important service, such as water, electricity, gas or other municipal necessaries, over a period of years, upon an as-needed basis, with periodic payment, creates no debt in the sense of the constitutional requirement. Frank v. Cody, 572 P.2d 1106, 1977 Wyo. LEXIS 304 (Wyo. 1977).

Neither contract between several municipalities, authorizing an agency organized by them under the Wyoming Joint Powers Act, §§ 16-1-102 through 16-1-110, to acquire electrical energy and providing, in turn, for its sale to the municipalities, which contract was to remain in effect for 40 years, nor the issuance by the agency of revenue bonds, secured by a pledge of payments to be received from the municipalities under the contract, created a debt within the constitutional limitation of this section. The contract specifically provided that payments due for electricity sold to each municipality was payable only from revenues derived from the retail sale of electricity to the customers of the municipal distribution system. Frank v. Cody, 572 P.2d 1106, 1977 Wyo. LEXIS 304 (Wyo. 1977).

School districts are subdivisions of county within provision prohibiting creation of debt without vote of people. West v. School Dist., 37 Wyo. 36, 258 P. 583, 1927 Wyo. LEXIS 63 (Wyo. 1927).

Sanitary districts. —

The indebtedness of a sanitary district is limited by this section. In re West Highway Sanitary & Improvement Dist., 77 Wyo. 384, 317 P.2d 495, 1957 Wyo. LEXIS 29 (Wyo. 1957).

A statute which authorized the trustees of a sanitary and improvement district to issue bonds without an election if 40 percent of the electors did not object to issuance of the bonds violated this section. In re West Highway Sanitary & Improvement Dist., 77 Wyo. 384, 317 P.2d 495, 1957 Wyo. LEXIS 29 (Wyo. 1957).

Irrigation district law was not violative of this section. Sullivan v. Blakesley, 35 Wyo. 73, 246 P. 918, 1926 Wyo. LEXIS 9 (Wyo. 1926).

Industrial Development Projects Act held constitutional. —

See Reed v. Cheyenne, 429 P.2d 69, 1967 Wyo. LEXIS 160 (Wyo. 1967); Uhls v. State, 429 P.2d 74, 1967 Wyo. LEXIS 161 (Wyo. 1967); Powers v. Cheyenne, 435 P.2d 448, 1967 Wyo. LEXIS 191 (Wyo. 1967), reh'g denied, 436 P.2d 961, 1968 Wyo. LEXIS 155 (Wyo. 1968).

No application to Wyoming community development authority. —

This section and art. 16, §§ 3 and 5, Wyo. Const., are not involved with the constitutionality of the Wyoming community development authority, since under the terms of the Wyoming Community Development Authority Act, the authority is not and cannot be a political subdivision. Witzenburger v. State, 575 P.2d 1100, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 266 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 577 P.2d 1386, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 289 (Wyo. 1978).

Voting at bond elections. —

A statute providing that only taxpayers may vote at bond elections is unconstitutional. Simpkin v. Rock Springs, 33 Wyo. 166, 237 P. 245, 1925 Wyo. LEXIS 32 (Wyo. 1925).

Statute requiring payment of realty tax as a qualification to vote at a school bond election was invalid. West v. School Dist., 37 Wyo. 36, 258 P. 583, 1927 Wyo. LEXIS 63 (Wyo. 1927).

Law for high school districts on bond issues where property and nonproperty owners may vote was held not to violate constitution regarding elections or elections creating debts. State ex rel. Voiles v. Johnson County High Sch., 43 Wyo. 494, 5 P.2d 255, 1931 Wyo. LEXIS 31 (Wyo. 1931).

Quoted in

Erickson v. School Dist., 67 Wyo. 216, 217 P.2d 887, 1950 Wyo. LEXIS 12 (1950); Elementary Sch. Dist. v. District Boundary Bd., 454 P.2d 237, 1969 Wyo. LEXIS 134 (Wyo. 1969); Sweetwater County Planning Comm. for Organization of School Dists. v. Hinkle, 491 P.2d 1234, 1971 Wyo. LEXIS 185 (Wyo. 1971).

Stated in

Board of County Comm'rs v. White, 79 Wyo. 420, 335 P.2d 433, 1959 Wyo. LEXIS 14 (1959).

Cited in

Cooper v. Town of Pinedale, 1 P.3d 1197, 2000 Wyo. LEXIS 74 (Wyo. 2000).

Law reviews. —

For article, “Administration of the General Property Tax in Wyoming,” see 4 Wyo. L.J. 227.

For comment, “Coping with Expansion: The State as Local Government Financier,” see X Land & Water L. Rev. 577 (1975).

§ 5. Limitation on municipal, county or school district debt.

No city or town shall in any manner create any indebtedness exceeding four per cent (4%) of the assessed value of the taxable property therein, except that an additional indebtedness of four per cent (4%) of the assessed value of the taxable property therein may be created for sewage disposal systems. Indebtedness created for supplying water to cities or towns is excepted from the limitation herein.

No county shall in any manner create any indebtedness exceeding two per cent (2%) of the taxable property therein.
