No school district shall in any manner create any indebtedness exceeding ten per cent (10%) on the assessed value of the taxable property therein for the purpose of acquiring land, erection, enlarging and equipping of school buildings.

All limitations herein shall refer to the last preceding general assessment. (As amended by Laws 1919, Senate Joint Resolution No. 6, p. 273; Laws 1953, House Joint Resolution No. 1, p. 289; Laws 1961, Senate Joint Resolution No. 5, p. 683.)

Prohibition of section. —

This section prohibits the district from creating any debt in excess of the prescribed limit. It does not per se prohibit authorization for a maximum debt which could exceed the prescribed limit. Torres v. Laramie County Sch. Dist., 506 P.2d 817, 1973 Wyo. LEXIS 144 (Wyo.), cert. denied, 414 U.S. 990, 94 S. Ct. 342, 38 L. Ed. 2d 229, 1973 U.S. LEXIS 1185 (U.S. 1973).

“Taxable property” as used herein, does not include real property within a school district sold to county for delinquent taxes for which a certificate of purchase has been issued to the county. Williams v. School Dist., 56 Wyo. 1, 102 P.2d 48, 1940 Wyo. LEXIS 22 (Wyo. 1940).

Applicability. —

Because any debt created by a housing authority under Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 15-10-108 was not a general obligation and was payable only from sources other than the county's taxing authority, Wyo. Const. art. 16 §§ 3, 4, and 5 did not apply. Gronberg v. Teton County Hous. Auth., 2011 WY 13, 247 P.3d 35, 2011 Wyo. LEXIS 14 (Wyo. 2011).

Storm sewers. —

The 1962 amendment to this section does not exclude storm sewers from the additional bonded indebtedness allowance of 4 percent of the city's taxable property. Rodin v. State, 417 P.2d 180, 1966 Wyo. LEXIS 155 (Wyo. 1966).

A storm ditch for flood control comes within the meaning of the term “sewer,” and within the 4 percent limitation of indebtedness. Anselmi v. Rock Springs, 53 Wyo. 223, 80 P.2d 419, 1938 Wyo. LEXIS 14 (Wyo. 1938).

Sanitary districts. —

See In re West Highway Sanitary & Improvement Dist., 77 Wyo. 384, 317 P.2d 495, 1957 Wyo. LEXIS 29 (Wyo. 1957).

Water works indebtedness is excepted from the constitution. Diefenderfer v. State, 13 Wyo. 387, 80 P. 667, 1905 Wyo. LEXIS 16 (Wyo. 1905).

There is no constitutional definition of the term “school district,” as used in this section, and nothing is contained in the constitution which is explanatory in that regard. Goshen County Community College Dist. v. School Dist., 399 P.2d 64, 1965 Wyo. LEXIS 122 (Wyo. 1965).

But the term was used in its ordinary sense in this section, as it would have been understood when first used in the 1920 amendment to this section. Goshen County Community College Dist. v. School Dist., 399 P.2d 64, 1965 Wyo. LEXIS 122 (Wyo. 1965).

And does not include community college. —

A school district, as ordinarily understood when the 1920 amendment was adopted to this section, does not include a community college. Goshen County Community College Dist. v. School Dist., 399 P.2d 64, 1965 Wyo. LEXIS 122 (Wyo. 1965).

Therefore, community college districts are separate and apart from school districts. —

When the legislature authorized the establishment of community colleges and provided for community college districts, it intended such districts to be something separate and apart from a “school district,” as this term is used in this section. Goshen County Community College Dist. v. School Dist., 399 P.2d 64, 1965 Wyo. LEXIS 122 (Wyo. 1965).

School districts not required to reach bonded indebtedness of ninety percent in order to receive state assistance. —

School districts are not required to have reached bonded indebtedness of ninety percent or more of their constitutional debt limitation imposed under art. 16, § 5, Wyo. Const., in order to receive state assistance for those capital construction projects identified in the department of education's study of school construction needs. Snell v. Johnson County Sch. Dist. No. 1, 2004 WY 19, 86 P.3d 248, 2004 Wyo. LEXIS 25 (Wyo. 2004).

Use of bond proceeds. —

Where a portion of voted bond proceeds of a school district was available for furnishings without exceeding limit of the assessed valuation of property in the district, it can be used for purchase of furniture as authorized by statute. Hendricks v. School Dist., 44 Wyo. 204, 10 P.2d 970, 1932 Wyo. LEXIS 19 (Wyo. 1932).

Under constitutional and statutory provisions authorizing school boards to create bonded indebtedness for the erection or enlargement of school buildings, power to use a portion of the proceeds from the bonds to purchase and install equipment necessary for its use is impliedly included, and possibility that trustees might use part of money for unlawful purposes would not invalidate bonds. Jewett v. School Dist., 49 Wyo. 277, 54 P.2d 546, 1936 Wyo. LEXIS 40 (Wyo. 1936).

Election authorizing issue of bonds does not create debt. Torres v. Laramie County Sch. Dist., 506 P.2d 817, 1973 Wyo. LEXIS 144 (Wyo.), cert. denied, 414 U.S. 990, 94 S. Ct. 342, 38 L. Ed. 2d 229, 1973 U.S. LEXIS 1185 (U.S. 1973).

But debt is created when bonds are offered and sold. Torres v. Laramie County Sch. Dist., 506 P.2d 817, 1973 Wyo. LEXIS 144 (Wyo.), cert. denied, 414 U.S. 990, 94 S. Ct. 342, 38 L. Ed. 2d 229, 1973 U.S. LEXIS 1185 (U.S. 1973).

A debt arising from bonds is not incurred until the bonds are issued. Torres v. Laramie County Sch. Dist., 506 P.2d 817, 1973 Wyo. LEXIS 144 (Wyo.), cert. denied, 414 U.S. 990, 94 S. Ct. 342, 38 L. Ed. 2d 229, 1973 U.S. LEXIS 1185 (U.S. 1973).

Financial condition at time of issue is determinative. —

It is the financial condition of the municipality or political subdivision at the time of issue, rather than at the time of authorization, which determines whether the bonds exceed the debt limit. Torres v. Laramie County Sch. Dist., 506 P.2d 817, 1973 Wyo. LEXIS 144 (Wyo.), cert. denied, 414 U.S. 990, 94 S. Ct. 342, 38 L. Ed. 2d 229, 1973 U.S. LEXIS 1185 (U.S. 1973).

The amount of bonds which can be issued depends upon the amount of taxable property at the time the bonds are sold. Torres v. Laramie County Sch. Dist., 506 P.2d 817, 1973 Wyo. LEXIS 144 (Wyo.), cert. denied, 414 U.S. 990, 94 S. Ct. 342, 38 L. Ed. 2d 229, 1973 U.S. LEXIS 1185 (U.S. 1973).

Purpose in endeavoring to catalog transaction involving public entity as lease rather than a sale is often to circumvent statutory or constitutional debt limitations, or it is to avoid statutory or constitutional restrictions on expenditures exceeding annual income. "Laramie Citizens for Good Government" v. Laramie, 617 P.2d 474, 1980 Wyo. LEXIS 307 (Wyo. 1980).

Intent of parties is determinative as to whether or not the transaction is a lease or a sale. "Laramie Citizens for Good Government" v. Laramie, 617 P.2d 474, 1980 Wyo. LEXIS 307 (Wyo. 1980).

Voting at bond elections. —

A statute providing that only taxpayers may vote at bond elections was unconstitutional. Simpkin v. Rock Springs, 33 Wyo. 166, 237 P. 245, 1925 Wyo. LEXIS 32 (Wyo. 1925).

Statement of interest rate. —

Fact that in the proposition submitted to the electors the rate of interest was stated at four percent, and the bonds were later negotiated at three and 1/2 percent, did not affect the validity of the bonds nor the notice of election, as school trustees were justified in effecting a saving for the taxpayers if possible. Jewett v. School Dist., 49 Wyo. 277, 54 P.2d 546, 1936 Wyo. LEXIS 40 (Wyo. 1936).

Statement of bond maturity. —

It is not necessary that the maturity of the bonds be stated in the proposition submitted to the electors. Jewett v. School Dist., 49 Wyo. 277, 54 P.2d 546, 1936 Wyo. LEXIS 40 (Wyo. 1936).

Refunding authorized by General Obligation Public Securities Refunding Law complies with the municipal debt limitation provisions of this section. Rodin v. State, 417 P.2d 180, 1966 Wyo. LEXIS 155 (Wyo. 1966).

Revolving local improvement fund. —

This section is not violated by ch. 155, Laws 1953, authorizing a municipality to set up a revolving local improvement fund from the proceeds of city or state gasoline or state cigarette license taxes, from which fund the city may annually deposit in the local improvement district fund a sum sufficient to meet the difference between the principal amount of assessments due that year and the amount of assessments actually collected that year. Banner v. Laramie, 74 Wyo. 429, 289 P.2d 922, 1955 Wyo. LEXIS 46 (Wyo. 1955).

Industrial Development Projects Act held constitutional. —

See Reed v. Cheyenne, 429 P.2d 69, 1967 Wyo. LEXIS 160 (Wyo. 1967); Uhls v. State, 429 P.2d 74, 1967 Wyo. LEXIS 161 (Wyo. 1967); Powers v. Cheyenne, 435 P.2d 448, 1967 Wyo. LEXIS 191 (Wyo. 1967), reh'g denied, 436 P.2d 961, 1968 Wyo. LEXIS 155 (Wyo. 1968).

No application to Wyoming community development authority. —

This section and art. 16, §§ 3 and 4, Wyo. Const., are not involved with the constitutionality of the Wyoming community development authority, since under the terms of the Wyoming Community Development Authority Act, the authority is not and cannot be a political subdivision. Witzenburger v. State, 575 P.2d 1100, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 266 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 577 P.2d 1386, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 289 (Wyo. 1978).

Quoted in

Washakie County Sch. Dist. v. Herschler, 606 P.2d 310, 1980 Wyo. LEXIS 227 (Wyo. 1980).

Cited in

Casper Community College Dist. v. Natrona County High School Dist., 384 P.2d 319, 1963 Wyo. LEXIS 99 (Wyo. 1963); State v. Campbell County Sch. Dist., 2001 WY 19, 19 P.3d 518, 2001 Wyo. LEXIS 21 (Wyo. 2001); Tavern, LLC v. Town of Alpine, 2017 WY 56, 395 P.3d 167, 2017 Wyo. LEXIS 57 (Wyo. 2017).

Law reviews. —

For article, “Administration of the General Property Tax in Wyoming,” see 4 Wyo. L.J. 227.

For article, “Municipal Assistance to an Improvement District,” see 11 Wyo. L.J. 180 (1957).

For comment, “Coping with Expansion: The State as Local Government Financier,” see X Land & Water L. Rev. 577 (1975).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Validity, under state constitution and laws, of issuance by state or state agency of revenue bonds to finance or refinance construction projects at private religious-affiliated colleges or universities, 95 ALR3d 1000.

§ 6. Loan of credit; donations prohibited; works of internal improvement.

  1. Neither the state nor any county, city, township, town, school district, or any other political subdivision, shall;
    1. Loan or give its credit or make donations to or in aid of any individual, association or corporation, except for necessary support of the poor; or
    2. Subscribe to or become the owner of the capital stock of any association or corporation, except that:
      1. Funds of public employee retirement systems and the permanent funds of the state of Wyoming may be invested in such stock under conditions the legislature prescribes;
      2. The legislature may provide by law for the investment of funds not designated as permanent funds of the state in the capital stock of any association or corporation and may designate which of these funds may be invested. The legislature may prescribe different investment conditions for each fund. Any legislation establishing or increasing the percentage of any fund that may be invested under this subparagraph shall be passed only by a two-thirds (2/3) vote of all the members of each of the two (2) houses voting separately.
  2. The state shall not engage in any work of internal improvement unless  authorized by a two-thirds (2/3) vote of the people.  (As amended  by Laws 1984, House Joint Resolution No. 2, p. 323; Laws 1996, House  Joint Resolution No. 5, § 1; Laws 2015, Senate Joint Resolution No. 2, § 1.)

Cross references. —

For exceptions to the last sentence of this section, see §§ 9 to 11 of this article.

For revolving investment fund, see § 12(a) of this article.

As to investment of permanent funds, see § 9-4-833.

Amendments. —

Laws 2015, Senate Joint Resolution No. 2, § 1, authorized the submission of a proposed amendment of this section, which was adopted by vote of the people at the general election held November 3, 2016, and was proclaimed in effect November 17, 2016.

Laws 1996, House Joint Resolution No. 5, § 1, authorized the submission of a proposed amendment of this section, which was adopted by vote of the people at the general election held November 5, 1996, and was proclaimed in effect November 18, 1996.

Constitution does not define “political subdivision.” Witzenburger v. State, 575 P.2d 1100, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 266 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 577 P.2d 1386, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 289 (Wyo. 1978).

But its concept of such entity is different from that of legislature. —

A political subdivision as visualized by the legislature is entirely different from a political subdivision as envisioned by the authors of the Wyoming constitution. Witzenburger v. State, 575 P.2d 1100, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 266 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 577 P.2d 1386, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 289 (Wyo. 1978).

Political subdivision is unit of local government, not state government. Witzenburger v. State, 575 P.2d 1100, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 266 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 577 P.2d 1386, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 289 (Wyo. 1978).

And must be same kind of entity as county, city, etc. —

A “political subdivision” must be an entity of the same kind or class as a county, city, township, town or school district. Witzenburger v. State, 575 P.2d 1100, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 266 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 577 P.2d 1386, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 289 (Wyo. 1978).

This section indicates that a county, city, township, town and school district are political subdivisions, when it uses the language, “any county, city, township, town, school district, or any other political subdivision.” Witzenburger v. State, 575 P.2d 1100, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 266 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 577 P.2d 1386, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 289 (Wyo. 1978).

Restriction not applicable to agencies of government. —

This restriction is generally regarded as applicable only to private associations or corporations and not to agencies of government. Board of County Comm'rs v. White, 79 Wyo. 420, 335 P.2d 433, 1959 Wyo. LEXIS 14 (Wyo. 1959).

Prohibition against donations by the state cannot be nullified by claim recipient was poor. State ex rel. McPherren v. Carter, 30 Wyo. 22, 215 P. 477, 1923 Wyo. LEXIS 28 (Wyo. 1923).

Tax exemption. —

Lawful exemption from taxation is not “gift or donation by the state.” State ex rel. Bd. of Comm'rs v. Snyder, 29 Wyo. 199, 212 P. 771, 1923 Wyo. LEXIS 9 (Wyo. 1923); Harkin v. Board of Comm'rs, 30 Wyo. 455, 222 P. 35, 1924 Wyo. LEXIS 71 (Wyo. 1924).

Voting at bond elections. —

Statute providing that only taxpayers might vote at a bond election was unconstitutional. Simpkin v. Rock Springs, 33 Wyo. 166, 237 P. 245, 1925 Wyo. LEXIS 32 (Wyo. 1925).

County fair board. —

Public financing of the functions of the county fair board, as authorized by §§ 18-9-101 to 18-9-103 is not prohibited by this section. Board of County Comm'rs v. White, 79 Wyo. 420, 335 P.2d 433, 1959 Wyo. LEXIS 14 (Wyo. 1959).

Chapter 150, Laws 1951, codified as §§ 18-9-101 to 18-9-103, is not void because §§ 18-9-101 and 18-9-102 thereof purport to authorize the loaning of the county's credit for private purposes, in violation of this section. Board of County Comm'rs v. White, 79 Wyo. 420, 335 P.2d 433, 1959 Wyo. LEXIS 14 (Wyo. 1959).

Revolving local improvement fund. —

This section is not violated by ch. 155, Laws 1953, authorizing a municipality to set up a revolving local improvement fund from the proceeds of city or state gasoline or state cigarette license taxes, from which fund the city may annually deposit in the local improvement district fund a sum sufficient to meet the difference between the principal amount of assessments due that year and the amount of assessments actually collected that year. Banner v. Laramie, 74 Wyo. 429, 289 P.2d 922, 1955 Wyo. LEXIS 46 (Wyo. 1955).

Industrial Development Projects Act held constitutional. —

See Reed v. Cheyenne, 429 P.2d 69, 1967 Wyo. LEXIS 160 (Wyo. 1967); Uhls v. State, 429 P.2d 74, 1967 Wyo. LEXIS 161 (Wyo. 1967); Powers v. Cheyenne, 435 P.2d 448, 1967 Wyo. LEXIS 191 (Wyo. 1967), reh'g denied, 436 P.2d 961, 1968 Wyo. LEXIS 155 (Wyo. 1968).

Wyoming Community Development Authority Act does not violate this section on the ground that it constitutes lending of the public credit for a private purpose provided no debt is created in the state beyond the current year's taxes. Any private benefit would then be purely incidental and not within constitutional prohibitions. Witzenburger v. State, 575 P.2d 1100, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 266 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 577 P.2d 1386, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 289 (Wyo. 1978).

The plan of the Wyoming community development authority, under § 9-18-105 (xix), (xx) and (xxi) (now § 9-7-105), to purchase secured and insured loans is not violative of the Wyoming constitution. Witzenburger v. State, 575 P.2d 1100, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 266 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 577 P.2d 1386, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 289 (Wyo. 1978).

Insurance of its property by school district. —

While it may be inadvisable for a school district to insure its property in a mutual company, when subject to assessments in addition to the fixed premium provided for by the policy, if ultimate liability is not greatly disproportionate to the ordinary fire insurance premium, contract does not violate the constitutional provision. Burton v. School Dist., 47 Wyo. 462, 38 P.2d 610, 1934 Wyo. LEXIS 34 (Wyo. 1934).

Veterans' exemptions. —

Statute exempting $2,000 of property of honorably discharged war veterans and their widows and of World War nurses is not in conflict with this section. State ex rel. Bd. of Comm'rs v. Snyder, 29 Wyo. 199, 212 P. 771, 1923 Wyo. LEXIS 9 (Wyo. 1923).

Unemployment benefits do not constitute a gratuity but are a part of compensation or wages. Unemployment Compensation Comm'n v. Renner, 59 Wyo. 437, 143 P.2d 181, 1943 Wyo. LEXIS 25 (Wyo. 1943).

No application where exchange of consideration between parties. —

The constitutional prohibition against a municipality lending its credit to a private corporation has no application when there is an exchange of consideration between the parties. Frank v. Cody, 572 P.2d 1106, 1977 Wyo. LEXIS 304 (Wyo. 1977).

Fair associations. —

An act authorizing a tax by counties for aid of fair associations is void as in violation of this section. Board of County Comm'rs v. Union Pac. R.R., 25 Wyo. 463, 171 P. 668, 1918 Wyo. LEXIS 8 (Wyo. 1918).

Joint ownership of plant by municipalities and private power companies not prohibited. —

The constitutional limitation on municipalities lending money or credit to a private entity does not prohibit a joint ownership by municipal corporations and private power companies of an electric-generating plant. Frank v. Cody, 572 P.2d 1106, 1977 Wyo. LEXIS 304 (Wyo. 1977).

Where participants in an electrical transmission system, including an agency organized by municipalities under the Wyoming Joint Powers Act, §§ 16-1-102 through 16-1-110, and a private corporation, entered an agreement providing, among other things, for making up deficiencies created by a defaulting participant but also that a pro rata share of the portion in system entitlements owned by the defaulter should accrue to the benefit of the other participants, such provision did not conflict with this section, prohibiting municipalities from lending money or credit to a private entity. Frank v. Cody, 572 P.2d 1106, 1977 Wyo. LEXIS 304 (Wyo. 1977).

Bond sale by corporation “on behalf of” city invalid. —

A bond sale by a nonprofit corporation “on behalf of” a city would be invalid as a loan of the city's credit in violation of this section. "Laramie Citizens for Good Government" v. Laramie, 617 P.2d 474, 1980 Wyo. LEXIS 307 (Wyo. 1980).

Quoted in

Miller v. Board of County Comm'rs, 79 Wyo. 502, 337 P.2d 262, 1959 Wyo. LEXIS 18 (1959).

Cited in

State Hwy. Comm'n v. Utah Constr. Co., 278 U.S. 194, 49 S. Ct. 104, 73 L. Ed. 262, 1929 U.S. LEXIS 6 (1929); White v. Board of County Comm'rs, 77 Wyo. 246, 313 P.2d 484, 1957 Wyo. LEXIS 22 (1957).

Law reviews. —

For article, “Municipal Assistance to an Improvement District,” see 11 Wyo. L.J. 180 (1957).

For article, “Governmental Immunity from Damage Actions in Wyoming — Part II,” see VII Land & Water L. Rev. 617 (1972).

§ 7. Payments of public money.

No money shall be paid out of the state treasury except upon appropriation by law and on warrant drawn by the proper officer, and no bills, claims, accounts or demands against the state, or any county or political subdivision, shall be audited, allowed or paid until a full itemized statement in writing, certified to under penalty of perjury, shall be filed with the officer or officers whose duty it may be to audit the same. (As amended by Laws 1969, House Joint Resolution No. 2, p. 491.)

Cross references. —

For provision that money shall be expended only on appropriation, see art. 3, § 35, Wyo. Const.

For provision for itemized statements to be attached to vouchers, see § 9-4-103.

This section is of equal dignity with art. 1, § 33, Wyo. Const., which prohibits the taking or damaging of property without just compensation. In fact, the two provisions are not in conflict. The rights afforded by art. 1, § 33, Wyo. Const., are protected even though the directives of this section are complied with, since this section is no more than a regulation of the procedure by which the rights guaranteed by art. 1, § 33, Wyo. Const., will be exercised. It is not a substantive limitation imposed upon such rights. Wyoming State Highway Dep't v. Napolitano, 578 P.2d 1342, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 291 (Wyo. 1978).

Claim and demand were held to embrace all claims and demands based on a money demand. Houtz v. Board of Comm'rs, 11 Wyo. 152, 70 P. 840, 1902 Wyo. LEXIS 30 (Wyo. 1902).

Sufficiency of petition to require auditor to approve warrants for attorney's compensation from specified fund should be determined in light of all laws affecting right to collect claim against state and not on ground that auditor had previously issued such warrants for 10 months. State ex rel. Watts v. Jack, 58 Wyo. 108, 125 P.2d 165, 1942 Wyo. LEXIS 15 (Wyo. 1942).

Petition held defective. —

In an action against the state highway department on a construction contract, the petition was fatally defective where it did not show that claim was timely filed and filed with proper auditing officer. Utah Constr. Co. v. State Highway Comm'n, 45 Wyo. 403, 19 P.2d 951, 1933 Wyo. LEXIS 15 (Wyo. 1933).

Presentation of claim required. —

The presentation of claim to the proper auditing officer as required by statute is a condition precedent to the right to maintain action thereon. Utah Constr. Co. v. State Highway Comm'n, 45 Wyo. 403, 19 P.2d 951, 1933 Wyo. LEXIS 15 (Wyo. 1933).

Presentation to town of verified claim is necessary before commencement of action thereon against the town. Town Council of Hudson v. Ladd, 37 Wyo. 419, 263 P. 703, 1928 Wyo. LEXIS 15 (Wyo. 1928).

Action on claim arising from highway construction cannot be maintained without complying with law requiring presentation of claims. Utah Constr. Co. v. State Highway Comm'n, 45 Wyo. 403, 19 P.2d 951, 1933 Wyo. LEXIS 15 (Wyo. 1933).

A claim against the state highway commission, as a claim against the state, must be presented to state auditor or as directed by law and such presentation is condition to the right to sue the commission even upon contract. Price v. State Highway Comm'n, 62 Wyo. 385, 167 P.2d 309, 1946 Wyo. LEXIS 9 (Wyo. 1946).

Notice of claim neither signed nor verified. —

A notice of claim filed by the plaintiffs against the defendant city did not satisfy the requirements of this section and, therefore, did not begin the running of the statute of limitations contained in § 1-39-114 where the notice of claim was neither signed nor verified by the plaintiff, who declared in an affidavit that he did not prepare it and that neither he nor any member of his family furnished it to the city. Beaulieu v. Florquist, 2001 WY 33, 20 P.3d 521, 2001 Wyo. LEXIS 43 (Wyo. 2001), overruled in part, Brown v. City of Casper, 2011 WY 35, 248 P.3d 1136, 2011 Wyo. LEXIS 36 (Wyo. 2011).

Claim filed under the Wyoming Governmental Claims Act, Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 1-39-101 et seq., must meet the requirements of art. 16, § 7, Wyo. Const., including the requirement that it be signed by the claimant and certified to under penalty of perjury. Martinez v. City of Cheyenne, 791 P.2d 949, 1990 Wyo. LEXIS 50 (Wyo. 1990), overruled, Beaulieu v. Florquist, 2004 WY 31, 86 P.3d 863, 2004 Wyo. LEXIS 37 (Wyo. 2004).

Where an individual sued the city and a police officer for negligence, the individual's notice of claim, signed by the individual's attorney but not by the individual, did not meet the constitutional requirements for a valid claim under the Wyoming Governmental Claims Act, Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 1-39-101 et seq., because it was not signed by the individual, and it was not certified to under penalty of perjury; thus, dismissal of the individual's complaint was proper despite any imprecision as to whether the district court dismissed the complaint under W.R.C.P. 12(b)(1) or W.R.C.P. 12(c). Yoak v. Ide, 2004 WY 32, 86 P.3d 872, 2004 Wyo. LEXIS 38 (Wyo. 2004), overruled in part, Harmon v. Star Valley Med. Ctr., 2014 WY 90, 331 P.3d 1174, 2014 Wyo. LEXIS 99 (Wyo. 2014).

Where persons injured in collisions with State employees presented putative notices of claim that were neither signed by them nor certified under penalty of perjury, those notices of claim were invalid because they did not meet the requirements of Wyo. Const. art. 16, § 7, and the belated attempts to cure the deficiencies were ineffective because the limitation period of the nonclaim statute had passed, thereby extinguishing the statutory right to sue the State, and the plaintiffs did not show that the deficient notices of claim were, or could be, salvaged by the savings statute, by the doctrine of equitable estoppel, or as a matter of public policy. Bell v. Schell, 2004 WY 153, 101 P.3d 465, 2004 Wyo. LEXIS 197 (Wyo. 2004), overruled in part, Harmon v. Star Valley Med. Ctr., 2014 WY 90, 331 P.3d 1174, 2014 Wyo. LEXIS 99 (Wyo. 2014).

Landowners' monetary claims against a county challenging the conditional use permit application process required under the county's growth management plan should have been dismissed because the landowners failed to comply with the statutory presentment requirements under Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 1-39-113 or Wyo. Const. art. 16, § 7; the actions were not filed within the applicable two-year period, and they were not signed and certified to under penalty of perjury. Laughter v. Bd. of County Comm'rs, 2005 WY 54, 110 P.3d 875, 2005 Wyo. LEXIS 60 (Wyo. 2005).

Order dismissing plaintiffs' negligence action against a town was proper because plaintiffs presented to the town a notice of claim that did not meet the requirements of Wyo. Const., art. 16, § 7, being neither signed nor certified to under penalty of perjury. The court appropriately dismissed the action with prejudice, inasmuch as it was then impossible for plaintiffs to comply with the mandatory filing deadline of Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 1-39-113. Wilson v. Town of Alpine, 2005 WY 57, 111 P.3d 290, 2005 Wyo. LEXIS 66 (Wyo. 2005), overruled in part, Harmon v. Star Valley Med. Ctr., 2014 WY 90, 331 P.3d 1174, 2014 Wyo. LEXIS 99 (Wyo. 2014).

Summary judgment for State and its snow plow operator was affirmed because the claimant failed to meet the requirement of Wyo. Const. Art. 16, § 7 to sign the written claim and certify it under penalty of perjury. He did not sign it at all; rather, it was signed by his attorney. Lavatai v. State, 2005 WY 133, 121 P.3d 121, 2005 Wyo. LEXIS 159 (Wyo. 2005), overruled in part, Harmon v. Star Valley Med. Ctr., 2014 WY 90, 331 P.3d 1174, 2014 Wyo. LEXIS 99 (Wyo. 2014).

Notice of claim neither signed nor verified. —

District court erred in granting summary judgment to the governmental entities and their employees based on lack of jurisdiction because, while a personal representative's negligence claim was neither signed under oath nor certified, the statutory and constitutional claim requirements were substantive, but not jurisdictional, and the entities and their employees waived their defense by failing to properly plead an affirmative defense that the claim was defective. Harmon v. Star Valley Med. Ctr., 2014 WY 90, 331 P.3d 1174, 2014 Wyo. LEXIS 99 (Wyo. 2014).

Claim held sufficient. —

In a contract case, a construction company fully complied with required notice requirements where a claim stated that a city caused delays by changing project specifications and failing to act to keep a project on schedule and where notice also clearly set forth damages that allegedly resulted from the city's conduct; therefore, supreme court and district court had subject matter jurisdiction to proceed with the matter presented. City of Gillette v. Hladky Constr., Inc., 2008 WY 134, 196 P.3d 184, 2008 Wyo. LEXIS 139 (Wyo. 2008).

Filing of claim deemed condition precedent. —

The filing of a claim on a contract with a state department with a state auditing officer is a condition precedent that cannot be waived, and, where a petition does not show that the condition has been performed, a demurrer is properly sustained. The same rule prevails in tort actions. Rissler & McMurry Co. v. Wyoming Highway Dep't, 582 P.2d 583, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 214 (Wyo. 1978).

Dismissal where claim not verified. —

Trial court properly dismissed a medical malpractice claim against a state hospital because the notice of claim submitted to the hospital and attached to the complaint of the patient, while signed by the patient, was not certified to under penalty of perjury as required by the Wyo. Const. art. 16, § 7. Jauregui v. Mem'l Hosp., 2005 WY 59, 111 P.3d 914, 2005 Wyo. LEXIS 68 (Wyo. 2005), reh'g denied, 2005 Wyo. LEXIS 80 (Wyo. June 8, 2005), overruled in part, Harmon v. Star Valley Med. Ctr., 2014 WY 90, 331 P.3d 1174, 2014 Wyo. LEXIS 99 (Wyo. 2014).

Worker's compensation act considered continuing appropriation. —

Because the Wyoming Worker’s Compensation Act is considered a continuing appropriation and the payment of claims under the Act requires no further action under the appropriation provision of the constitution, and because the Act, with the workers’ compensation ambulance provision severed from it, authorizes the payment of the claimants’ air ambulance charges in full, the severed statute is now part of the Act’s continuing appropriation, and the Office of Administrative Hearings did not order a payment without appropriation. Air Methods v. Dep't of Workforce Servs., 2018 WY 128, 432 P.3d 476, 2018 Wyo. LEXIS 132 (Wyo. 2018).

Failure to present claim waived. —

Plaintiff's failure to present claim to town board, where not raised by demurrer or answer, was waived in an action against the town for damages resulting from changing channel of river. Town Council of Hudson v. Ladd, 37 Wyo. 419, 263 P. 703, 1928 Wyo. LEXIS 15 (Wyo. 1928).

Editor's note Martinez v. City of Cheyenne, 791 P.2d 949, 1990 Wyo. LEXIS 50 (Wyo. 1990), overruled, Beaulieu v. Florquist, 2004 WY 31, 86 P.3d 863, 2004 Wyo. LEXIS 37 (Wyo. 2004).

Failure to include allegation that constitutional signature and certification requirements were met. —

District court should not have acquired jurisdiction over property owners' inverse condemnation claim against a city under Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 1-26-516 because owners' complaint failed to include an allegation that the constitutional signature and certification requirements were met as required by Wyo. Const. art. 16, § 7. Gose v. City of Douglas, 2008 WY 126, 193 P.3d 1159, 2008 Wyo. LEXIS 129 (Wyo. 2008), overruled in part, Brown v. City of Casper, 2011 WY 35, 248 P.3d 1136, 2011 Wyo. LEXIS 36 (Wyo. 2011).

Inclusion of “under penalty of perjury.” —

Constitutional requirement that governmental claims be certified to under penalty of perjury under Wyo. Const. art. 16, § 7 was satisfied by the verified affidavit of the parents, and therefore the district court had jurisdiction over the parents' claim against the school district for their son's injuries. Cantrell v. Sweetwater County Sch. Dist. No. 2, 2006 WY 57, 133 P.3d 983, 2006 Wyo. LEXIS 57 (Wyo. 2006).

Presumption regarding issuance of warrant. —

Where a warrant has been issued it will be presumed that the officer did not violate this section in issuing same. Appel v. State, 9 Wyo. 187, 61 P. 1015, 1900 Wyo. LEXIS 13 (Wyo. 1900).

Omission from statute. —

Fact that an appropriation statute does not provide expressly for the issuance of a warrant or for an audit of a claim against the state would not render such statute invalid. State ex rel. Bd. of Comm'rs v. Snyder, 29 Wyo. 199, 212 P. 771, 1923 Wyo. LEXIS 9 (Wyo. 1923).

Omission from statute reimbursing counties for lost revenue of requirement for audit of claim does not invalidate it. State ex rel. Bd. of Comm'rs v. Snyder, 29 Wyo. 199, 212 P. 771, 1923 Wyo. LEXIS 9 (Wyo. 1923); Harkin v. Board of Comm'rs, 30 Wyo. 455, 222 P. 35, 1924 Wyo. LEXIS 71 (Wyo. 1924); State ex rel. Bd. of Comm'rs v. Snyder, 30 Wyo. 468, 222 P. 40, 1924 Wyo. LEXIS 73 (Wyo. 1924).

Later enactment governing expenditure of state funds controls manner of spending legislative appropriations, and approval of attorney's employment in sales tax division under older act could not require auditor to order payment of such attorney's salary unless authorized in appropriation act or by inclusion in budget. State ex rel. Watts v. Jack, 58 Wyo. 108, 125 P.2d 165, 1942 Wyo. LEXIS 15 (Wyo. 1942).

Salaries. —

An act providing for a certain salary for state examiner required no special appropriation to authorize the payment. State ex rel. Henderson v. Burdick, 4 Wyo. 272, 33 P. 125, 1893 Wyo. LEXIS 11 (Wyo. 1893).

Statute fixing salaries of officers and enlisted men of the national guard during encampments was not continuing appropriation. State ex rel. Davis v. Carter, 31 Wyo. 401, 226 P. 690, 1924 Wyo. LEXIS 34 (Wyo. 1924).

Action for tort. —

It is clear from constitutional and statutory provisions that Wyoming has never given its consent that it or the state highway commission might be sued for a tort. Price v. State Highway Comm'n, 62 Wyo. 385, 167 P.2d 309, 1946 Wyo. LEXIS 9 (Wyo. 1946).

Veterans' exemptions. —

Under § 1, ch. 50, Laws 1921, exempting property of veterans from taxation, and providing that the county treasurers should submit to state treasurer a certified statement of exemptions, it was clearly intended that the amount payable to each county should be determined by the state treasurer, and that such certificate was sufficient compliance therewith, in view of the law, providing that the auditor need not audit claims required to be audited by other officers, and auditor should issue his warrant on certificate of the state treasurer. State ex rel. Bd. of Comm'rs v. Snyder, 30 Wyo. 468, 222 P. 40, 1924 Wyo. LEXIS 73 (Wyo. 1924).

Constitution does not define “political subdivision.” Witzenburger v. State, 575 P.2d 1100, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 266 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 577 P.2d 1386, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 289 (Wyo. 1978).

Amendment alleging that constitutional signature and certification requirements were met. —

District court had subject matter jurisdiction to allow amendment of a wrongful death complaint to allege presentation of a notice of claim complying with this section and Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 1-39-113(b), which had been timely presented. The amendment related back to the original filing date in accordance with Wyo. R. Civ. P. 15(c). Hoffman v. Darnell, 2011 WY 65, 252 P.3d 936, 2011 Wyo. LEXIS 67 (Wyo. 2011).

But its concept of such entity is different from that of legislature. —

A political subdivision as visualized by the legislature is entirely different from a political subdivision as envisioned by the authors of the Wyoming constitution. Witzenburger v. State, 575 P.2d 1100, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 266 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 577 P.2d 1386, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 289 (Wyo. 1978).

Political subdivision is unit of local government, not state government. Witzenburger v. State, 575 P.2d 1100, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 266 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 577 P.2d 1386, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 289 (Wyo. 1978).

And must be same kind of entity as county, city, etc. —

A “political subdivision” must be an entity of the same kind or class as a county, city, township, town or school district. Witzenburger v. State, 575 P.2d 1100, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 266 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 577 P.2d 1386, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 289 (Wyo. 1978).

Joint powers board. —

A joint powers board is not a “political subdivision” such that it would be required to comply with the requirements of this section; a joint powers board is a “governmental entity” and therefore the requirements for § 1-39-113 for bringing a claim apply to this board. Weston County Hosp. Joint Powers Bd. v. Westates Constr. Co., 841 P.2d 841, 1992 Wyo. LEXIS 167 (Wyo. 1992).

Industrial Development Projects Act held constitutional. —

See Powers v. Cheyenne, 435 P.2d 448, 1967 Wyo. LEXIS 191 (Wyo. 1967), reh'g denied, 436 P.2d 961, 1968 Wyo. LEXIS 155 (Wyo. 1968).

Applied in

Williams v. Eaton, 310 F. Supp. 1342, 1970 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 12370 (D. Wyo. 1970); Awe v. University of Wyo., 534 P.2d 97, 1975 Wyo. LEXIS 139 (Wyo. 1975).

Cited in

Hudson Oil Co. v. Board of Comm'rs, 49 Wyo. 1, 52 P.2d 683, 1935 Wyo. LEXIS 11 (1935); State v. Underwood, 54 Wyo. 1, 86 P.2d 707, 1939 Wyo. LEXIS 1 (1939).

Law reviews. —

For article, “Governmental Immunity from Damage Actions in Wyoming — Part II,” see VII Land & Water L. Rev. 617 (1972).

For case note, “Filing of Claims Against the State: Is ‘Almost’ Good Enough? Rissler & McMurry Co. v. Wyoming Hwy. Dep't, 582 P.2d 583, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 214 (Wyo. 1978),” see XIV Land & Water L. Rev. 259 (1979).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Amount of appropriation as limitation on damages for breach of contract recoverable by one contracting with government agency, 40 ALR4th 998.

Persons or entities upon whom notice of injury or claim against state or state agencies may or must be served, 45 ALR5th 173.

§ 8. Endorsements required on bonds and other evidences of indebtedness.

No bond or evidence of indebtedness of the state shall be valid unless the same shall have endorsed thereon a certificate signed by the auditor and secretary of state that the bond or evidence of debt is issued pursuant to law and is within the debt limit. No bond or evidence of debt of any county, or bond of any township or other political subdivision, shall be valid unless the same [shall] have endorsed thereon a certificate signed by the county auditor or other officer authorized by law to sign such certificate, stating that said bond or evidence of debt is issued pursuant to law and is within the debt limit.

Constitution does not define “political subdivision.” Witzenburger v. State, 575 P.2d 1100, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 266 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 577 P.2d 1386, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 289 (Wyo. 1978).

But its concept of such entity is different from that of legislature. —

A political subdivision as visualized by the legislature is entirely different from a political subdivision as envisioned by the authors of the Wyoming constitution. Witzenburger v. State, 575 P.2d 1100, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 266 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 577 P.2d 1386, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 289 (Wyo. 1978).

Political subdivision is unit of local government, not state government. Witzenburger v. State, 575 P.2d 1100, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 266 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 577 P.2d 1386, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 289 (Wyo. 1978).

And must be same kind of entity as county, city, etc. —

A “political subdivision” must be an entity of the same kind or class as a county, city, township, town or school district. Witzenburger v. State, 575 P.2d 1100, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 266 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 577 P.2d 1386, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 289 (Wyo. 1978).

Industrial Development Projects Act held constitutional. —

See Reed v. Cheyenne, 429 P.2d 69, 1967 Wyo. LEXIS 160 (Wyo. 1967); Powers v. Cheyenne, 435 P.2d 448, 1967 Wyo. LEXIS 191 (Wyo. 1967), reh'g denied, 436 P.2d 961, 1968 Wyo. LEXIS 155 (Wyo. 1968).

Cited in

Diefenderfer v. State ex rel. First Nat'l Bank, 13 Wyo. 387, 80 P. 667, 1905 Wyo. LEXIS 16 (1905).

§ 9. Construction and improvement of public roads and highways.

The provision of section 6 of article 16 of this constitution prohibiting the state from engaging in any work of internal improvement unless authorized by a two-thirds vote of the people shall not apply to or affect the construction or improvement of public roads and highways; but the legislature shall have power to provide for the construction and improvement of public roads and highways in whole or in part by the state, either directly or by extending aid to counties; and, notwithstanding said inhibition as to works of internal improvement, whenever grants of land or other property shall have been made to the state, especially dedicated by the grant to particular works of internal improvement, the state may carry on such particular works and shall devote thereto the avails of such grants, and may pledge or appropriate the revenues derived from such works in the aid of their completion. (As added by Laws 1915, House Joint Resolution No. 4, p. 266.)

Cross references. —

For provisions relative to highways generally, see title 24.

Suit not within jurisdiction of federal courts. —

A suit by a Utah contractor against the Wyoming state highway commission is not within the jurisdiction of the federal courts on the grounds of diversity of citizenship since the suit is, in effect, against the state which cannot be treated as a citizen. State Highway Com. v. Utah Constr. Co., 278 U.S. 194, 49 S. Ct. 104, 73 L. Ed. 262, 1929 U.S. LEXIS 6 (U.S. 1929).

§ 10. Construction and improvement of works for conservation and utilization of water.

The provisions of section 6 of article 16 of this constitution prohibiting the state from engaging in any work of internal improvements, unless authorized by a two-thirds vote of the people, shall not apply to or affect the construction or improvement of any works designed, constructed or operated for the purposes of conservation or utilization of water, but the legislature shall have the power to provide for the construction or improvement in whole or in part, of any works designed, constructed or operated for the purposes of conservation or utilization of water, either directly or by extending aid to legal subdivisions of the State of Wyoming, duly organized irrigation, drainage, soil conservation, and public irrigation and power districts, and any public corporation legally organized for the purposes of the conservation, distribution or utilization of water or soil; and notwithstanding said inhibition as to works of internal improvement, whenever grants of land or other property shall be made to the state, especially dedicated by the grant to particular works of internal improvement, the state may carry on such particular works of internal improvement and shall devote thereto the avails of such grants, and may likewise pledge or appropriate the revenues derived from such works in aid of their completion. (As added by Laws 1939, Senate Joint Resolution No. 3, p. 254.)

Cross references. —

As to soil conservation, see §§ 11-16-101 to 11-16-134.

As to water distribution and utilization generally, see title 41.

§ 11. Construction, maintenance and improvement of public airports, aircraft landing strips and related facilities.

The provisions of section 6 of article XVI of this constitution prohibiting the state from engaging in any work of internal improvement unless authorized by a two-thirds vote of the people, shall not apply to or affect the construction, maintenance or improvement of public airports, aircraft landing strips and related facilities but the legislature shall have power to provide for the construction, maintenance and improvement of public airports, aircraft landing strips and related facilities, in whole or in part by the state, either directly or by extending aid to its political subdivisions and, notwithstanding said inhibition as to works of internal improvement, whenever grants of land or other property shall have been made to the state, especially dedicated by the grant to particular works of internal improvement, the state may carry on such particular works and shall devote thereto the avails of such grants, and may pledge or appropriate the revenues derived from such works in the aid of their completion and maintenance. (As added by Laws 1947, House Joint Resolution No. 8, p. 257.)

Cross references. —

As to municipal and county airports, see §§ 10-5-101 through 10-5-302.

As to authority of board of commissioners of county to acquire property for airports, see §§ 18-9-101 to 18-9-202.

Constitution does not define “political subdivision.” Witzenburger v. State, 575 P.2d 1100, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 266 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 577 P.2d 1386, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 289 (Wyo. 1978).

But its concept of such entity is different from that of legislature. —

A political subdivision as visualized by the legislature is entirely different from a political subdivision as envisioned by the authors of the Wyoming constitution. Witzenburger v. State, 575 P.2d 1100, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 266 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 577 P.2d 1386, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 289 (Wyo. 1978).

Political subdivision is unit of local government, not state government. Witzenburger v. State, 575 P.2d 1100, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 266 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 577 P.2d 1386, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 289 (Wyo. 1978).

And must be same kind of entity as county, city, etc. —

A “political subdivision” must be an entity of the same kind or class as a county, city, township, town or school district. Witzenburger v. State, 575 P.2d 1100, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 266 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 577 P.2d 1386, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 289 (Wyo. 1978).

Cited in

Geringer v. Bebout, 10 P.3d 514, 2000 Wyo. LEXIS 181 (Wyo. 2000).

§ 12. Economic development loan fund.

  1. Notwithstanding Article 3, Section 36 and Article 16, Sections 1, 2 and 6 of this Constitution, the legislature, by a two-thirds (2/3) vote of all the members of each of the two (2) houses voting separately, may appropriate monies in an amount not exceeding one percent (1%) times the assessed value of the taxable property in the state as shown by the last preceding general assessment for taxation, to provide a revolving investment fund to be used to promote and aid the economic development of the state.
  2. The investment fund created by this section shall be used to provide fully-funded loan guarantees or loans to proposed or existing enterprises which will employ people within the state, provide services within the state, use resources within the state or otherwise add economic value to goods, services or resources within the state.
  3. Monies within the revolving investment fund shall be loaned or used to guarantee loans under such terms and conditions as the legislature may by law direct.
  4. The cumulative total of monies appropriated to provide a revolving investment fund shall never exceed one percent (1%) on the assessed value of the taxable property in the state as shown by the last preceding general assessment for taxation.
  5. Notwithstanding the limitation of subsection (d) of this section, earnings on the revolving investment fund shall be added to the revolving investment fund and shall be invested as provided in this section. (As added by Laws 1986, House Joint Resolution No. 1, p. 292.)

§ 13. Industrial and economic development; powers of counties and municipalities.

Notwithstanding any other provision in this constitution, the legislature may authorize counties or incorporated municipalities, to appropriate from local sources of revenue such funds as may be deemed necessary for an economic or industrial development project or program, public or private, subject to approval by a vote of the majority of the registered voters of the county or municipality voting upon the question. For purposes of this section, “funds from local sources of revenue” means funds raised from general taxes levied by the county or municipality and shall not include any funds received by the county or municipality which are derived from state or federal sources. (As added by Laws 2004, House Enrolled Joint Resolution No. 1.)

Enactments. —

Laws 2004, House Enrolled Joint Resolution No. 1, § 1 authorized the submission of a proposed enactment of a section, which was approved by vote of the people at the general election held November 2, 2004, and certified November 10, 2004.

The section authorizes the legislature to enact laws for local governments to use local sources of revenue for economic or industrial development subject to approval of the voters.

Article 17. State Militia

  • § 1. Of whom militia constituted.
  • § 2. Legislature to provide for enrollment, equipment and discipline.
  • § 3. How officers commissioned.
  • § 4. Flags.
  • § 5. Governor to be commander-in-chief; powers.

§ 1. Of whom militia constituted.

The militia of the state shall consist of all able-bodied qualified residents of the state, and those nonresidents who are accepted into service, between the ages of seventeen (17) and seventy (70) years; except those exempted by the law of the United States or of the state. But all residents having scruples of conscience averse to bearing arms shall be excused therefrom upon conditions as shall be prescribed by law. (As amended by Laws 1999, Senate Joint Resolution No. 3, § 1.)

Cross references. —

As to right to bear arms, see art. 1, § 24, Wyo. Const.

For provision that military shall be subordinate to civil power, see art. 1, § 25, Wyo. Const.

As to exemption of electors from military duty, see art. 6, § 4, Wyo. Const.

For other provisions concerning defense forces and affairs generally, see title 19.

Amendments. —

Laws 1999, Senate Joint Resolutions No. 3, § 1, authorized the submission of a proposed amendment of this section, which was approved by vote of the people at the general election held November 7, 2000, and declared in effect November 15, 2000.

The 1999 amendment rewrote the section to change eligibility requirements so that any qualified resident between the ages of 17 and 70 and any nonresident who meets certain other requirements may serve in the state militia.

Law reviews. —

For article, “The Wyoming Constitution: A Centennial Assessment,” see XXVI Land & Water L. Rev. 13 (1991).

§ 2. Legislature to provide for enrollment, equipment and discipline.

The legislature shall provide by law for the enrollment, equipment and discipline of the militia to conform as nearly as practicable to the regulations for the government of the armies of the United States.

Act fixing salaries of members of national guard during encampments was not a continuing appropriation. State ex rel. Davis v. Carter, 31 Wyo. 401, 226 P. 690, 1924 Wyo. LEXIS 34 (Wyo. 1924).

§ 3. How officers commissioned.

All militia officers shall be commissioned by the governor, the manner of their selection to be provided by law, and may hold their commission for such period of time as the legislature may provide.

§ 4. Flags.

No military organization under the laws of the state shall carry any banner or flag representing any sect or society or the flag of any nationality but that of the United States.

§ 5. Governor to be commander-in-chief; powers.

The governor shall be commander-in-chief of all the military forces of the state, and shall have power to call out the militia to preserve the public peace, to execute the laws of the state, to suppress insurrection or repel invasion.

Cross references. —

For other provisions concerning powers and duties of governor as commander-in-chief of the military forces of the state, see art. 4, § 4, Wyo. Const., and § 19-9-101.

Article 18. Public Lands and Donations

  • § 1. Acceptance of lands from United States; sale of such lands.
  • § 2. Application of proceeds of sale or rental.
  • § 3. Board of land commissioners.
  • § 4. Legislature to provide for disposition of lands.
  • § 5. Special privileges prohibited.
  • § 6. Disposition of unexpended income of perpetual school fund.

§ 1. Acceptance of lands from United States; sale of such lands.

The State of Wyoming hereby agrees to accept the grants of lands heretofore made, or that may hereafter be made by the United States to the state, for educational purposes, for public buildings and institutions and for other objects, and donations of money with the conditions and limitations that may be imposed by the act or acts of congress, making such grants or donations. Such lands shall be disposed of only at public auction to the highest responsible bidder, after having been duly appraised by the land commissioners, at not less than three-fourths the appraised value thereof, and for not less than $10 per acre; provided, that in the case of actual and bona fide settlement and improvement thereon at the time of the adoption of this constitution, such actual settler shall have the preference right to purchase the land whereon he may have settled, not exceeding 160 acres at a sum not less than the appraised value thereof, and in making such appraisement the value of improvements shall not be taken into consideration. If, at any time hereafter, the United States shall grant any arid lands in the state to the state, on the condition that the state reclaim and dispose of them to actual settlers, the legislature shall be authorized to accept such arid lands on such conditions, or other conditions, if the same are practicable and reasonable.

Cross references. —

As to public lands generally, see title 36.

Section does not limit sovereign right of United States. —

This section does not suggest a limitation of sovereign right of the United States to acquire these lands for less than $10 per acre if needed in exercise of governmental functions. United States v. 2902 Acres of Land, 49 F. Supp. 595, 1943 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 2699 (D. Wyo. 1943).

Lands granted to state university. —

Control and disposition of lands granted to the state university lie in board of land commissioners. Ross v. Trustees of Univ., 31 Wyo. 464, 228 P. 642, 1924 Wyo. LEXIS 40 (Wyo. 1924).

Rights-of-way. —

The legislature may grant rights-of-way across university lands. Ross v. Trustees of Univ. of Wyo., 30 Wyo. 433, 222 P. 3, 1924 Wyo. LEXIS 67 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 31 Wyo. 464, 228 P. 642, 1924 Wyo. LEXIS 40 (Wyo. 1924).

Water rights. —

Board of control had jurisdiction to adjudicate water rights. State ex rel. Mitchell Irrigation Dist. v. Parshall, 22 Wyo. 318, 140 P. 830, 1914 Wyo. LEXIS 16 (Wyo. 1914).

Use of land for pipeline. —

Grant of use of land for pipeline purposes only, to which plaintiff subsequently obtained a patent, was not a “disposition of the land.” Richardson v. Midwest Ref. Co., 39 Wyo. 58, 270 P. 154, 1928 Wyo. LEXIS 80 (Wyo. 1928).

Where the state retains an interest in land upon which a purchaser enters under a contract of purchase, such land may not be assessed for taxes as such, though the purchaser's interest may be assessed; a sale of the property for delinquent taxes might indirectly destroy the state's interest and violate the provisions of this section. Olds v. Little Horse Creek Cattle Co., 22 Wyo. 336, 140 P. 1004, 1914 Wyo. LEXIS 18 (Wyo. 1914).

Lease is not a disposal. —

Lease of state lands as authorized by the Wyoming Constitution is not a disposal of those lands and need not be accomplished by public auction. Riedel v. Anderson, 2003 WY 70, 70 P.3d 223, 2003 Wyo. LEXIS 88 (Wyo. 2003).

Exchange of school lands. —

A sale and an exchange are two different concepts with different legal significance attached to each. What Wyoming's framers intended when they required a public auction for a sale of school lands was to prevent school lands from being exploited for private advantage, but there is no need to read the these Constitutional clauses to impose the same restrictions on transfers in which the abuses they were intended to prevent are not likely to occur. Dir. of the Office of State Lands & Invs. v. Merbanco, Inc., 2003 WY 73, 70 P.3d 241, 2003 Wyo. LEXIS 91 (Wyo. 2003), reh'g denied, 2003 Wyo. LEXIS 105 (Wyo. July 10, 2003).

A sale and an exchange are two different concepts with different legal significance attached to each; otherwise, the words would be synonyms for each other with no legal difference. What Wyoming's framers intended when they required a public auction for a sale of school lands was to prevent school lands from being exploited for private advantage, and there was no need to read these constitutional clauses to impose the same restrictions on transfers in which the abuses they were intended to prevent were not likely to occur, and in which the trust may in another and more effective fashion be assured full compensation. Therefore, it could not be concluded that the framers of the Wyoming Constitution intended a public auction must occur before the state can exchange school lands for lands of equal value. Dir. of the Office of State Lands & Invs. v. Merbanco, Inc., 2003 WY 73, 70 P.3d 241, 2003 Wyo. LEXIS 91 (Wyo. 2003), reh'g denied, 2003 Wyo. LEXIS 105 (Wyo. July 10, 2003).

Renewal of lease. —

Right of renewal of a lease on school land was not a vested right as against one claiming a preference right. State ex rel. Huckfeldt v. State Bd. of Sch. Land Comm'rs, 20 Wyo. 162, 122 P. 94, 1912 Wyo. LEXIS 28 (Wyo. 1912).

By the use of the term “renewal” the legislature did not intend to give a preferential right upon the identical terms and conditions of old lease, but old lessee must meet all reasonable terms and conditions laid down from time to time by the board which other persons are willing to meet, making the lease not a continuing one in violation of the enabling act and the constitution but a new one. Wyodak Chem. Co. v. Board of Land Comm'rs, 51 Wyo. 265, 65 P.2d 1103, 1937 Wyo. LEXIS 18 (Wyo. 1937).

Supreme court's duty. —

It is bounden duty of supreme court, insofar as possible, to carry provisions that permanent school funds shall remain forever inviolate and undiminished into force and effect. Alamo Drainage Dist. v. Board of County Comm'rs, 60 Wyo. 177, 148 P.2d 229, 1944 Wyo. LEXIS 7 (Wyo. 1944).

Quoted in

Mayor v. Board of Land Comm'rs, 64 Wyo. 409, 192 P.2d 403, 1948 Wyo. LEXIS 7 (1948); Wyoming v. United States, 310 F.2d 566, 1962 U.S. App. LEXIS 3929 (10th Cir. 1962); Witzenburger v. State ex rel. Wyo. Community Dev. Auth., 575 P.2d 1100, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 266 (Wyo. 1978).

Cited in

Kerrigan v. Miller, 53 Wyo. 441, 84 P.2d 724, 1938 Wyo. LEXIS 24 (1938).

Law reviews. —

For comment, “Wyoming School Trust Lands Trapped Inside Grand Teton National Park — Alternative Solutions for the Commissioner of Public Lands,” see XX Land & Water L. Rev. 207 (1985).

For article, “The Wyoming Constitution: A Centennial Assessment,” see XXVI Land & Water L. Rev. 13 (1991).

§ 2. Application of proceeds of sale or rental.

The proceeds from the sale and rental of all lands and other property donated, granted or received, or that may hereafter be donated, granted or received, from the United States or any other source, shall be inviolably appropriated and applied to the specific purposes specified in the original grant or gifts.

Bequests. —

Where property is bequeathed to the state with an annual income payable to a legatee out of income, the property cannot be considered “not otherwise appropriated” and must be added to the common school fund. Bond v. State, 45 Wyo. 133, 16 P.2d 53, 1932 Wyo. LEXIS 56 (Wyo. 1932).

Higgins Memorial Foundation. —

Chapter 157, Laws 1929, establishing Higgins Memorial Foundation, was unconstitutional insofar as it affected the use and disposition of the property bequeathed and charged the same with an annuity. Bond v. State, 45 Wyo. 133, 16 P.2d 53, 1932 Wyo. LEXIS 56 (Wyo. 1932).

Lands granted to state university. —

Control and disposition of lands granted to the state university lie in board of land commissioners. Ross v. Trustees of Univ., 31 Wyo. 464, 228 P. 642, 1924 Wyo. LEXIS 40 (Wyo. 1924).

Rights-of-way. —

The legislature is not prohibited from authorizing board of land commissioners to grant right-of-way across university lands. Ross v. Trustees of Univ. of Wyo., 30 Wyo. 433, 222 P. 3, 1924 Wyo. LEXIS 67 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 31 Wyo. 464, 228 P. 642, 1924 Wyo. LEXIS 40 (Wyo. 1924).

University permanent land fund was not intended to be confined for use in payment of current expenses but may, if necessary and proper, be used to erect buildings when authorized by legislature. Arnold v. Bond, 47 Wyo. 236, 34 P.2d 28, 1934 Wyo. LEXIS 22 (Wyo. 1934).

Contract with an expert to investigate leases of state lands and ascertain if correct accounting was being made, and if not to assist in recovering amount due state on contingent basis, is not violative of constitution as depleting the school funds, as the moneys so recovered are a new fund brought into existence through the investigation. Bourne v. Cole, 53 Wyo. 31, 77 P.2d 617, 1938 Wyo. LEXIS 1 (Wyo. 1938).

Quoted in

Mayor v. Board of Land Comm'rs, 64 Wyo. 409, 192 P.2d 403, 1948 Wyo. LEXIS 7 (1948).

Riedel v. Anderson, 2003 WY 70, 70 P.3d 223, 2003 Wyo. LEXIS 88 (Wyo. 2003).

Cited in

State v. Underwood, 54 Wyo. 1, 86 P.2d 707, 1939 Wyo. LEXIS 1 (1939).

Law reviews. —

For comment, “Wyoming School Trust Lands Trapped Inside Grand Teton National Park — Alternative Solutions for the Commissioner of Public Lands,” see XX Land & Water L. Rev. 207 (1985).

§ 3. Board of land commissioners.

The governor, secretary of state, state treasurer, state auditor and superintendent of public instruction shall constitute a board of land commissioners, which under direction of the legislature as limited by this constitution, shall have direction, control, leasing and disposal of lands of the state granted, or which may be hereafter granted for the support and benefit of public schools, subject to the further limitations that the sale of all lands shall be at public auction, after such delay (not less than the time fixed by congress) in portions at proper intervals of time, and at such minimum prices (not less than the minimum fixed by congress) as to realize the largest possible proceeds. And said board, subject to the limitations of this constitution and under such regulations as may be provided by law shall have the direction, control, disposition and care of all lands that have been heretofore or may hereafter be granted to the state. (As amended by Laws 1921, Senate Joint Resolution No. 2, p. 293.)

Cross references. —

For other provisions concerning board of land commissioners, see §§ 36-2-101 to 36-2-210.

Discretion of board. —

In leasing state lands, board exercises wide discretion which should be controlling except in case of illegal exercise thereof, or fraud or grave abuse of such discretion. Banzhaf v. Swan Co., 60 Wyo. 201, 148 P.2d 225, 1944 Wyo. LEXIS 8 (Wyo. 1944).

The discretion of the board in both the leasing and the sale of school lands of this state has been given a very broad scope, subject only to the limitation that review by the courts may be had of its action in the event of the board's transgression of provisions of positive law, fraud or having committed a grave abuse of that discretion. Whether the board has exceeded this limitation must be determined from the varying circumstances of individual cases. Mayor v. Board of Land Comm'rs, 64 Wyo. 409, 192 P.2d 403, 1948 Wyo. LEXIS 7 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 64 Wyo. 430, 195 P.2d 752 (Wyo. 1948).

“Under direction of the legislature as limited by this constitution” construed. —

The constitution which creates the board of land commissioners grants broad authority which is to be exercised “under direction of the legislature as limited by this constitution.” Under this provision, the legislature is authorized to establish rules and methods which will govern the board within constitutional limits, but any statutes passed under this authority must if effective to control a controverted point be clear and definite. When there is no such direction the board must exercise its best judgment with which the courts may not interfere except in cases of illegal exercise of discretion, or fraud. Mahoney v. L. L. Sheep Co., 79 Wyo. 293, 333 P.2d 712, 1958 Wyo. LEXIS 46 (Wyo. 1958).

Board has control of all state lands. State ex rel. Walls v. State Bd. of Land Comm'rs, 36 Wyo. 302, 254 P. 491, 1927 Wyo. LEXIS 34 (Wyo. 1927).

Constitution invests the board under such regulations as may be provided by law with the direction, control, disposition and care of all state lands. State ex rel. Marsh v. State Land Comm'rs, 7 Wyo. 478, 53 P. 292, 1898 Wyo. LEXIS 15 (Wyo. 1898); Bucknum v. Johnson, 21 Wyo. 26, 127 P. 904, 1912 Wyo. LEXIS 11 (Wyo. 1912).

Lease of state lands. —

Board of land commissioners is only authority vested with power to lease state lands. Banzhaf v. Swan Co., 60 Wyo. 201, 148 P.2d 225, 1944 Wyo. LEXIS 8 (Wyo. 1944).

Under this section and § 36-2-101, constitutional and statutory authority is granted to the board of land commissioners to lease lands of the state. Reese v. Bruegger Ranches, 463 P.2d 23, 1969 Wyo. LEXIS 172 (Wyo. 1969).

Mineral land leases. —

Board of land commissioners or their employees must ascertain the amounts due state under mineral land leases, and that duty cannot be delegated by contract to others nor can they confer discretionary powers upon such parties, or agree to pay them out of funds in the hands of the board, as the board has no authority to disburse such funds, but must deposit them in the state treasury. MacDougall v. Board of Land Comm'rs, 48 Wyo. 493, 49 P.2d 663, 1935 Wyo. LEXIS 47 (Wyo. 1935).

Lease of school lands. —

Contention that when an applicant for the lease of state school lands, who is in all respects qualified to hold it as a renewal lessee, presents his application for such a lease to the board, that that body must grant the lease and may not under any circumstances decline to issue it to him, could not be sustained. Mayor v. Board of Land Comm'rs, 64 Wyo. 409, 192 P.2d 403, 1948 Wyo. LEXIS 7 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 64 Wyo. 430, 195 P.2d 752 (Wyo. 1948).

The provisions of law in § 36-5-105, relating to preferences in granting leases of state lands, become binding upon the board if and when it decides to lease school lands. Mayor v. Board of Land Comm'rs, 64 Wyo. 409, 192 P.2d 403, 1948 Wyo. LEXIS 7 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 64 Wyo. 430, 195 P.2d 752 (Wyo. 1948).

Exchange of school lands. —

A sale and an exchange are two different concepts with different legal significance attached to each. What Wyoming's framers intended when they required a public auction for a sale of school lands was to prevent school lands from being exploited for private advantage, but there is no need to read the these Constitutional clauses to impose the same restrictions on transfers in which the abuses they were intended to prevent are not likely to occur. Dir. of the Office of State Lands & Invs. v. Merbanco, Inc., 2003 WY 73, 70 P.3d 241, 2003 Wyo. LEXIS 91 (Wyo. 2003), reh'g denied, 2003 Wyo. LEXIS 105 (Wyo. July 10, 2003).

A sale and an exchange are two different concepts with different legal significance attached to each; otherwise, the words would be synonyms for each other with no legal difference. What Wyoming's framers intended when they required a public auction for a sale of school lands was to prevent school lands from being exploited for private advantage, and there was no need to read these constitutional clauses to impose the same restrictions on transfers in which the abuses they were intended to prevent were not likely to occur, and in which the trust may in another and more effective fashion be assured full compensation. Therefore, it could not be concluded that the framers of the Wyoming Constitution intended a public auction must occur before the state can exchange school lands for lands of equal value. Dir. of the Office of State Lands & Invs. v. Merbanco, Inc., 2003 WY 73, 70 P.3d 241, 2003 Wyo. LEXIS 91 (Wyo. 2003), reh'g denied, 2003 Wyo. LEXIS 105 (Wyo. July 10, 2003).

Lands granted to state university. —

Control and disposition of lands granted to the state university lie in board of land commissioners. Ross v. Trustees of Univ., 31 Wyo. 464, 228 P. 642, 1924 Wyo. LEXIS 40 (Wyo. 1924).

Rights-of-way. —

The legislature may grant rights-of-way across university lands. Ross v. Trustees of Univ. of Wyo., 30 Wyo. 433, 222 P. 3, 1924 Wyo. LEXIS 67 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 31 Wyo. 464, 228 P. 642, 1924 Wyo. LEXIS 40 (Wyo. 1924).

University permanent land fund was not intended to be confined for use in payment of current expenses but may, if necessary and proper, be used to erect buildings when authorized by legislature. Arnold v. Bond, 47 Wyo. 236, 34 P.2d 28, 1934 Wyo. LEXIS 22 (Wyo. 1934).

Mandamus. —

Letting of a lease cannot be controlled by mandamus. State ex rel. Marsh v. State Land Comm'rs, 7 Wyo. 478, 53 P. 292, 1898 Wyo. LEXIS 15 (Wyo. 1898).

Judicial review. —

Trial de novo mentioned in § 36-2-206 is limited to a determination on the part of the district court of whether, on the facts proved, there was “an illegal exercise” of board's discretion, fraud, or “grave abuse of such discretion.” Banzhaf v. Swan Co., 60 Wyo. 201, 148 P.2d 225, 1944 Wyo. LEXIS 8 (Wyo. 1944).

Where board in exercising its discretionary power leased state lands to qualified corporation holding expired lease and neither exercised its discretion illegally nor gravely abused it, and no fraud is proved, land board action must be affirmed. Banzhaf v. Swan Co., 60 Wyo. 201, 148 P.2d 225, 1944 Wyo. LEXIS 8 (Wyo. 1944).

Applied in

McGuire v. McGuire, 608 P.2d 1278, 1980 Wyo. LEXIS 251 (Wyo. 1980).

Quoted in

Riedel v. Anderson, 2003 WY 70, 70 P.3d 223, 2003 Wyo. LEXIS 88 (Wyo. 2003).

Stated in

L.L. Sheep Co. v. Potter, 67 Wyo. 348, 224 P.2d 496, 1950 Wyo. LEXIS 17 (1950).

Cited in

Reid v. Filmore, 12 Wyo. 72, 73 P. 849, 1903 Wyo. LEXIS 29 (1903); State v. Underwood, 54 Wyo. 1, 86 P.2d 707, 1939 Wyo. LEXIS 1 (1939); In re Hagood, 356 P.2d 135, 1960 Wyo. LEXIS 87 (Wyo. 1960).

Law reviews. —

For article, “Rights of Way to Mining Claims Across Public Lands,” see 12 Wyo. L.J. 162 (1958).

For comment, “Wyoming School Trust Lands Trapped Inside Grand Teton National Park — Alternative Solutions for the Commissioner of Public Lands,” see XX Land & Water L. Rev. 207 (1985).

For comment, “The Doctrine of Sovereign Immunity in Wyoming: Current Status of the Doctrine and Arguments for Abrogation,” see XX Land & Water L. Rev. 221 (1985).

For comment, “State Participation in Federal Policy Making for the Yellowstone Ecosystem: A Meaningful Solution or Business as Usual?” see XXI Land & Water L. Rev. 397 (1986).

§ 4. Legislature to provide for disposition of lands.

The legislature shall enact the necessary laws for the sale, disposal, leasing or care of all lands that have been or may hereafter be granted to the state, and shall, at the earliest practicable period, provide by law for the location and selection of all lands that have been or may hereafter be granted by congress to the state, and shall pass laws for the suitable keeping, transfer and disbursement of the land grant funds, and shall require of all officers charged with the same or the safekeeping thereof to give ample bonds for all moneys and funds received by them.

Cross references. —

As to leasing state lands generally, see §§ 36-5-101 to 36-5-117.

As to sale of state lands, see §§ 36-9-101 to 36-9-120.

Lands granted to state university. —

Control and disposition of lands granted to the state university lie in board of land commissioners. Ross v. Trustees of Univ., 31 Wyo. 464, 228 P. 642, 1924 Wyo. LEXIS 40 (Wyo. 1924).

Rights-of-way. —

The legislature is not prohibited from authorizing board of land commissioners to grant rights-of-way across university lands. Ross v. Trustees of Univ. of Wyo., 30 Wyo. 433, 222 P. 3, 1924 Wyo. LEXIS 67 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 31 Wyo. 464, 228 P. 642, 1924 Wyo. LEXIS 40 (Wyo. 1924).

University permanent land fund was not intended to be confined for use in payment of current expenses but may, if necessary and proper, be used to erect buildings when authorized by legislature. Arnold v. Bond, 47 Wyo. 236, 34 P.2d 28, 1934 Wyo. LEXIS 22 (Wyo. 1934).

Quoted in

Wyoming v. United States, 310 F.2d 566, 1962 U.S. App. LEXIS 3929 (10th Cir. 1962).

Cited in

State v. Gramm, 7 Wyo. 329, 52 P. 533, 1898 Wyo. LEXIS 8, 40 L.R.A. 690 (1898).

Law reviews. —

For article, “Rights of Way to Mining Claims Across Public Lands,” see 12 Wyo. L.J. 162 (1958).

§ 5. Special privileges prohibited.

Except a preference right to buy as in this constitution otherwise provided, no law shall ever be passed by the legislature granting any privileges to persons who may have settled upon any of the school lands granted to the state subsequent to the survey thereof by the general government, by which the amount to be derived by the sale or other disposition of such lands, shall be diminished directly or indirectly.

One in possession of land under contract to purchase is not liable for taxes on the land. Olds v. Little Horse Creek Cattle Co., 22 Wyo. 336, 140 P. 1004, 1914 Wyo. LEXIS 18 (Wyo. 1914).

§ 6. Disposition of unexpended income of perpetual school fund.

If any portion of the interest or income of the perpetual school fund be not expended during any year, said portion shall be added to and become a part of the said school fund.

University permanent land fund was not intended to be confined for use in payment of current expenses but may, if necessary and proper, be used to erect buildings when authorized by legislature. Arnold v. Bond, 47 Wyo. 236, 34 P.2d 28, 1934 Wyo. LEXIS 22 (Wyo. 1934).

Law reviews. —

For article, “Controlling the Blue Rash: Issues and Trends in State Land Management,” see XXIX Land & Water L. Rev. 1 (1994).

For article, “Fifty Years of Rhetoric on the Range: Reframing the Debate on Public Land Management,” see XXXII Land & Water L. Rev. 339 (1997).

For article, “The Bureau of Land Management: A Half-Century of Challenges and Change,” see XXXII Land & Water L. Rev. 345 (1997).

For article, “The Rise and Fall of Grazing Reform,” see XXXII Land & Water L. Rev. 413 (1997).

Article 19. Miscellaneous Livestock

  • § 1. Legislature to provide for protection of livestock and stock owners.
  • § 2. Day's work.
  • § 3. Who shall not be employed on public works.
  • § 4. Legislature to provide for enforcement of section 3.
  • § 5. Legislature to establish courts of arbitration; duties. [Repealed.]
  • § 6. Importing armed bodies to suppress violence prohibited; exception.
  • § 7. Contract exempting employer from liability for personal injuries prohibited.
  • § 8. Legislature to provide for voluntary submission of differences to arbitrators.
  • § 9. Exemption of homestead.
  • § 10. Intoxicating liquors.
  • § 11. Use of monies in public employee retirement funds restricted.

§ 1. Legislature to provide for protection of livestock and stock owners.

The legislature shall pass all necessary laws to provide for the protection of livestock against the introduction or spread of pleuro-pneumonia, glanders, splenetic or Texas fever, and other infectious or contagious diseases. The legislature shall also establish a system of quarantine, or inspection, and such other regulations as may be necessary for the protection of stock owners, and most conducive to the stock interests within the state.

Cross references. —

For provisions relative to contagious and infectious diseases among livestock, see §§ 11-19-101 to 11-19-407.

Powers of state veterinarian. —

A statute giving certain powers to the state veterinarian in accordance with this section was not in violation of art. 2, § 1, Wyo. Const. and art. 3, § 1, Wyo. Const.Arbuckle v. Pflaeging, 20 Wyo. 351, 123 P. 918, 1912 Wyo. LEXIS 40 (Wyo. 1912).

Dipping of sheep. —

Statute providing for compulsory dipping of all sheep kept or herded within the state, whether diseased or not, done under the supervision of an inspector and regulations of the state board, enacted under this section was a proper exercise of the police power, and not arbitrary in violation of art. 1, §§ 7 and 15, Wyo. Const., nor invalid as reposing judicial powers in an administrative officer contrary to art. 5, § 1, Wyo. Const.State v. Hall, 27 Wyo. 224, 194 P. 476, 1920 Wyo. LEXIS 34 (Wyo. 1920).

Statute requiring annual dipping of sheep was held not to take private property without due process of law or compensation. State v. Hall, 27 Wyo. 224, 194 P. 476, 1920 Wyo. LEXIS 34 (Wyo. 1920).

Law reviews. —

For article, “The Wyoming Constitution: A Centennial Assessment,” see XXVI Land & Water L. Rev. 13 (1991).

For article, “Bison, Brucellosis, and Law in the Greater Yellowstone Ecosystem,” see XXVIII Land & Water L. Rev. 1 (1993).

For case note, “Wildlife — Private Property Damage Law — Once Upon a Time in Wyoming There was Room for Millions of Cattle and Enough Habitat for Every Species of Game to Find a Luxurious Existence. In the Aftermath of Parker, Can We All Still Get Along? Parker Land and Cattle Company v. Wyoming Game and Fish Commission, 845 P.2d 1040, 1993 Wyo. LEXIS 15 (Wyo. 1993),” see XXIX Land & Water L. Rev. 89 (1994). Concerning Labor

§ 2. Day's work.

Eight (8) hours actual work shall constitute a lawful day's work in all mines, and on all state and municipal works.

Cross references. —

For another provision relative to protection of labor, see art. 1, § 22, Wyo. Const.

As to 8 hour day on public works, see § 16-6-110.

As to hours of labor generally, see §§ 27-5-101 to 27-5-110.

Editor's notes. —

This section was numbered 1 in the enrolled constitution.

Street paving is public work. —

Contractor engaged in street paving for municipal corporation is doing public work as contemplated by this section, “public works,” being all fixed works constructed for public use. State v. A. H. Read Co., 33 Wyo. 387, 240 P. 208, 1925 Wyo. LEXIS 47 (Wyo. 1925).

§ 3. Who shall not be employed on public works.

No person not a citizen of the United States or who has not declared his intention to become such, shall be employed upon or in connection with any state, county or municipal works or employment.

Cross references. —

For provision declaring contracts for alien labor void, see § 27-4-113.

Editor's notes. —

This section was numbered 1 in the enrolled constitution.

Quoted in

State ex rel. R.R. Crow & Co. v. Copenhaver, 64 Wyo. 1, 184 P.2d 594, 1947 Wyo. LEXIS 24 (1947).

§ 4. Legislature to provide for enforcement of section 3.

The legislature shall, by appropriate legislation, see that the provisions of the foregoing section are enforced.

Editor's notes. —

This section was numbered 2 in the enrolled constitution. Boards of Arbitration [Repealed]

§ 5. Legislature to establish courts of arbitration; duties. [Repealed.]

Section repealed. —

This section was repealed by a constitutional amendment proposed by Laws 1965, Senate Joint Resolution No. 1, p. 518, adopted by a vote of the people on November 8, 1966, and proclaimed in effect January 17, 1967. Police Powers

§ 6. Importing armed bodies to suppress violence prohibited; exception.
